HEADLINE: Shearson Deal May Embrace The Man Who Built the Firm

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
A remarkable comeback appears to be taking shape on Wall Street.
The man who stitched together a patchwork of investment firms to build what is now one of Wall Street's biggest brokerage houses, only to lose control after selling it to the American Express Company, may return to run his old firm, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.
Sanford I. (Sandy) Weill garnered the respect of Wall Street as his once small firm grew ever larger over two decades. Then he knocked the Street on its ear in 1981 when he sold the firm to American Express in a bid to create what he, and many others, thought would be the financial services company of the future.
But the corporate culture of American Express and the maverick mentality of Mr. Weill did not mesh. In 1985, he resigned, and the next year he took charge of a financial services operation in Baltimore from the Control Data Corporation. For a couple of years, he lived in relative obscurity running the firm, the Commercial Credit Company. 
But in 1988, Mr. Weill returned to his familiar surroundings with a vengeance, buying the Primerica Corporation, a diversified New York financial services company that is the parent of the brokerage house, Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
And yesterday, the circle in the career of Sandy Weill appeared to be nearer than ever to closing. Wall Street executives said Mr. Weill was in negotiations with the American Express Company that could lead to the creation of the largest brokerage firm in the country and put him back as chairman of Shearson.
Shearson has been in financial and internal turmoil over the last year, resulting in the recent resignation of its chairman and chief executive, who was a protege of Mr. Weill. As a measure of its trouble, the firm yesterday told its employees that it planned 2,000 layoffs by April.
The serious negotiations between Mr. Weill's Primerica Corporation and American Express began last week, and have focused on the possible merger of Smith Barney with Shearson to form what would become the largest brokerage on Wall Street.
People directly involved in the negotiations stressed that the talks were at a tentative stage, meaning that they could result in a preliminary agreement as soon as a matter of days, or could fall apart. One person involved in the talks emphasized that no agreement had been reached, while another said last night that they had ended.
''Right now, it's the magical mystery tour,'' a person involved in the talks said. ''We'll see where it takes us.''
 
Assets for Stock
Under the terms of the deal that has been discussed, Mr. Weill would assume the post of chairman of Shearson, while retaining his position as chairman of Primerica. The potential deal, which was described as a swap of assets for stock, would merge the two brokerages, with Primerica receiving a large stake in Shearson. The two companies would then be partners as parents.
The sources said that there were no talks under way yesterday, but that they were expected to resume soon. They added that other possible structures to the deal have been considered, including bringing in another party along with Mr. Weill.
A spokesman for American Express confirmed the talks, but stressed that no deal had been made and that many possible structures for one had been considered, including the type of deal described by the other Wall Street executives as under discussion. He said, however, that none of the proposals involved the sale of Shearson.
Mr. Weill did not return a call for comment, and a spokeswoman for Primerica would not comment.
Howard Clark Jr., the chief executive of Shearson, also confirmed last night that talks had been held and said that the deal that had been discussed involved the purchase of Smith Barney by Shearson. Shearson would have paid for the transaction by issuing new stock in the firm to Primerica, Mr. Clark said.
Mr. Clark said the talks between the various parties had broken off. But other Wall Street executives directly involved in the situation said that while they thought the talks could go either way, they had no reason to believe they had ended.
For Mr. Weill, an emotionally charged executive with a strong leadership manner, such a deal could well be his ultimate achievement. The 56-year-old executive would be able to run a firm with the strength of Shearson and maintain the relationship with American Express. At the same time, he would be able to stay as the top man at Primerica, and therefore shape his own culture.
 
Two Top Executives
The talks began between Mr. Weill and James D. Robinson 3d, the chairman and chief executive of American Express. The two men, who have remained friends since Mr. Weill was president of American Express and Mr. Robinson was his boss, reportedly had spoken about a possible combination in general terms for some time and recently began to consider such an action aggressively.
Since the serious talks began, lawyers and investment bankers have been brought into the negotiations. For example, Joseph Flom, a partner with Skadden, Arps, Slate Meagher & Flom, was said to be playing an active role in the deal, as was J. Tomilson Hill 3d, the head of mergers and acquisitions at Shearson. Neither man returned telephone calls yesterday.
''You've got law firms all over the place now,'' one Wall Street executive said. ''It seems like there are 19,000 people involved.''
Other recent attempts by American Express to support the sagging Shearson by bringing in outside parties have quickly failed. For example, late last year the company held talks with Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of Revlon Inc., in an effort to get him to invest $250 million in the firm. Those talks fell apart shortly after they were revealed.
 
Reaction of Market
The market reacted positively to a possible deal between American Express and Primerica. American Express shares closed yesterday at $29.125, up $1, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Shearson stock rose to $12.625, up 62.5 cents. And Primerica shares also rose, closing at $26.875, up 25 cents.
Indeed, a deal would seem to pose benefits for all the parties involved. Mr. Weill is well known for his interest in running a giant securities firm and has long been rumored as someone who could take charge, again, at Shearson. American Express, which controls more than 60 percent of Shearson, has been seeking a way to decrease its holdings in the firm in order to remove Shearson from its balance sheet.
In addition, Shearson has experienced a succession of embarrassing stumbles since 1988 that have cost it a good deal on the bottom line. The missteps resulted last month in the resignation of Peter A. Cohen, the firm's chairman and chief executive and once Mr. Weill's protege. Mr. Cohen was succeeded as chief executive by Mr. Clark, the former chief financial officer of American Express.
Warren Hellman, an investment banker who was formerly president of Lehman Brothers, has assumed the title of chairman, although he has said it will only be for a short time.
In his memorandum telling employees about the dismissals, Mr. Clark said that the reductions would entail significant one-time charges that would have a negative impact on first-quarter results. He added that the changes should result in $400 million in savings annually.
 
Increase in Investment
Earlier this week, American Express announced it was increasing its investment in the firm in order to shore up Shearson's capital position. The company said it would invest $750 million to purchase common and preferred stock in the firm. People involved in the talks with Mr. Weill said yesterday that those shares are expected to play a role if any deal is reached.
Despite the uncertainty surrounding the negotiations with Mr. Weill, Wall Street executives reacted to the irony of the unfolding events with an anticipation that bordered on giddiness. If completed, the deal would result in bringing together some of the central players in the Wall Street drama of the 1980's. Since taking charge of Primerica in 1988, Mr. Weill has hired a number of people who have been casualties of the upheavals on Wall Street.
These executives include Jeffrey B. Lane, the president of Primerica who until late last year was president of Shearson; Lewis L. Glucksman, the respected Wall Street trader who was chairman and chief executive of Lehman Brothers when it was purchased by Shearson in 1984 and who is now the chief trader at Smith Barney, and many former employees of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. who went to work for Mr. Weill after the now-defunct firm began to deteriorate.
Moreover, the deal would revive a number of old relationships. For example, Mr. Hellman, the current Shearson chairman, worked with Mr. Weill in a failed attempt in 1985 to take over BankAmerica.
The firm that Mr. Weill built into Shearson originated in 1960 as Carter, Berlind & Weill. When Arthur Levitt, who would later become chairman of the American Stock Exchange, joined it and attached his name, the firm was nicknamed by Wall Street ''corned beef with lettuce,'' after the initials of the partners.
By mid-1981, Mr. Weill had engineered a stream of acquisitions of brokerages houses, putting his firm, then known as Shearson Loeb Rhoades, into the position of a player on Wall Street. When American Express purchased it for $915 million, Mr. Weill essentially exchanged control of Shearson for a personal gain of about $30 million from the deal and an opportunity to help shape the much larger financial conglomerate. In 1983, he was named president of American Express.
But the post did not wear well with him. And by 1985, he decided that he preferred running his own show and resigned.

HEADLINE: Justice Officials See Exxon Trial as Risk for U.S.

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
One day after the indictment of the Exxon Corporation on charges stemming from the Alaska oil spill, Federal officials expressed disappointment today about the failure to arrange a plea bargain in the case.
The officials said that because of the collapse of plea bargaining, the Government faces a risky criminal trial based on untested legal principles, and they predicted a difficult court battle to convict Exxon.
The bargaining collapsed following strong opposition by the State of Alaska. State officials objected to any settlement that they felt would prevent them from seeking financial damages from Exxon in separate civil suits, or weaken their chances in such suits.
The unusual statements from the Justice Department officials, some of whom spoke on the promise of anonymity, seemed to be aimed in part at pressing the Alaska officials to reconsider. The Federal officials said the Justice Department remains open to the possibility of negotiating a settlement with the company at Exxon's initiative. 
Today's developments put the Government in the unusual position of pointing up the problems in its own case. This reflected the complex legal and political negotiations that have gone on among state, Federal and oil company officials as a result of the spill, which occurred when the tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground in Prince William Sound last March, leaking nearly 11 millions gallons of crude oil.
Commenting on the difficulties facing the Justice Department, legal authorities said today that to convict the company of two felonies, the Justice Department will have to prove that Exxon officials intentionally violated statutes calling for them to man their ships with fully qualified and competent crew members.
Department officials said they were confident that they had the evidence to support a conviction. But no jury has ever been asked to convict on these grounds, and Exxon, which was also accused of three misdemeanors, has vowed to mount a vigorous defense if the case eventually goes to trial.
 
Hard Case, Novel Issues
''It is going to be a hard-fought case presenting some novel issues,'' said Richard Stewart, assistant attorney general for the department's lands division. Mr. Stewart led the negotiations with the company in recent weeks.
Justice Department officials do not usually discuss the strengths or weaknesses of their cases before trial, but the highly public collapse of the plea bargaining and the charges by environmentalists that the department was shaping a favorable deal with Exxon have led officials to make an exception in the Exxon case.
Complicating the situation is the fact that the outcome of a criminal prosecution, one way or another, is bound to influence civil cases brought by the State of Alaska, the Federal Government and private parties. Parts of the proposed plea bargain involving the future civil suits infuriated Alaskan officials and led to the failure of a deal between the Justice Department and the company.
Justice Department officials said the risk of an acquittal, along with a desire to reach a broad and immediate agreement on environmental restoration without a long trial, was a major motivation in the department's attempt to reach a plea bargain.
Exxon first approached the Justice Department about a settlement last year. The two sides began intensive negotiations two months ago as a Federal grand jury met in Alaska to consider charges against the company.
By February, department lawyers believed they had the basic outline of a proposal, although they did not have Exxon's approval, said Government officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
 
Two-Pronged Approach
The approach involved a two-pronged plea-bargaining arrangement. First, the company would be asked to admit to ''serious charges along the lines of what is charged in the indictment,'' said one Government official.
In addition, Exxon would be required to contribute up to $550 million to a fund for restoring the environment. The company would be asked to pay $150 million into the fund right away and would provide installments of $50 million up to the agreed-upon total as studies showed that further restoration was required.
But if the case goes to trial, nothing is certain. Although it is possible that conviction on all five counts could lead to substantial penalties, there is no certainty that a court will accept the Justice Department's formula for setting fines. This formula calls for penalties equal to twice the economic costs suffered by private parties and government agencies because of the spill, plus twice the value of natural resources damaged by the spill, which killed thousands of birds and animals.
The Justice Department said a conservative estimate for the fines would be more than $600 million, but Exxon has already disputed the legal basis for that calculation.
 
Alaska Had to Agree
By contrast, the penalties involved in the plea bargain might not have been as high, but the settlement would not have been open to dispute.
Many political figures, environmentalists and Wall Street analysts believe that once the outline of the plea bargain became public late last week, the Government, fearful of appearing lenient, toughened the terms.
''That plea bargain was a sweetheart deal that did not go down well with environmentalists and the state,'' said Sarah Chasis, a lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council.
Frank P. Knuttle, a financial analyst with the brokerage firm Prudential Bache, said: ''If the Government started taking the goodies away, Exxon might just have said 'no way.' They had a deal, then Washington started backing away.''
Throughout the negotiations, the company had insisted that Alaska officials agree to the final settlement; otherwise, Alaska could argue in its civil suits that it never endorsed the assessment of environmental damages as set forth in the plea bargain.
Alaska's Attorney General, Doug Baily, said in an interview today that each time he sought changes to the proposed plea bargain, Mr. Stewart would say that the changes needed to be checked with Exxon. In that sense, he said, Exxon always had the last word. Some Alaskans objected to that perception - even though, in a sense, any defendant or prospective defendant has the final say in plea bargaining, since no defendant can be forced to plead guilty.
 
Optimism at the Start
Federal officials said they initially felt optimistic that a settlement could be reached, but as negotiations proceeded over the next two weeks, Alaska officials raised a series of objections. One of their major concerns was the ''forebearance'' component of the plan, in which the Federal Government said it would delay the filing of civil lawsuits for a four-year period after the settlement of the criminal charges.
That arrangement would not have prevented Alaska from filing its own suits, as it has done. But state officials said they needed the Federal Government's help in preparing their civil lawsuits during the four-year period. Federal prosecutors said the provision would not bar them from preparing the suits, but would only keep them from filing such suits. This disagreement eventually proved central to the state's rejection of the proposed settlement.
 
Unwilling to Go Further
During the ensuing two weeks, a series of discussions took place. By the end of last week, state officials indicated they would not support the agreement. Without the state's approval, the company was unwilling to go further.
A spokesman for Gov. Steve Cowper of Alaska said today that state officials had been kept in the dark about the imminence of the indictments even as they met with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh one hour before the announcement that the charges had been filed.
Alaskan officials complained today that they had been subjected to intense pressure from the Justice Department to accept a plea bargain they did not like - pressure that they resented..
''They came down on us with this heavy hand of take it or leave it,'' one state aide said, The stock market reacted negatively today to the indictments, with the price of Exxon's shares falling $1.38. to $47 a share. Analysts said uncertainty over the size of the financial penalties that the company may now face had led to widespread selling.
''There is no way of quantifying the ultimate liability the company faces,'' said William H. Brown 3d of Kidder Peabody.

With them was Garrey Peska, Mr. Cowper's chief of staff. HEADLINE: A SPLINTER PARTY FORMED IN ISRAEL

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Five Likud members of the Israeli Parliament, 13 percent of the party's strength in Parliament, announced the formation of their own opposition party today, putting Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who is already in deep political trouble, in an even more excruciating predicament.
Faced with an imminent and unavoidable decision on whether to go forward with his plan for Palestinian elections or to let the proposal die, Mr. Shamir and his aides say they are, to use a common Israeli adage, ''between a hammer and an anvil.''
If the Prime Minister chooses to stall or kill his elections proposal, the Labor Party says it will bring the Government down, and the United States Government is likely to give up hope and reduce support for the Shamir Government.
But if Mr. Shamir chooses to go ahead with the plan, members of his own party led by Ariel Sharon and the dissidents who made their announcement today, plan to try to vote him out of office. 
 
Calls for Resignation
Already some Likud members are calling on Mr. Shamir to resign, while others - including several close allies of the Prime Minister - are openly upset.
Justice Minister Dan Meridor, one of Mr. Shamir's closest aides, said: ''It's a struggle with the United States, with the Arabs. But it's also a political struggle with Labor, which is trying to change the Government, and to my sorrow also a struggle within the Likud.''
Another senior aide said today: ''The pressures are enormous. I don't think there has been a time like this. The room we have to maneuver, well, there is none. He cannot govern without the support of his party.''
Mr. Shamir, under pressure, is considering moving ahead with his plan for Palestinian elections. And as numerous officials commented, today's troubles give only a hint of the anger and violence that Israel will probably face from within if the Government ever does actually try to make peace with the Palestinians.
 
Decision in 2 Weeks
Speaking to a parliamentary committee on Tuesday, Mr. Shamir promised to decide within the next two weeks whether to accept the American and Labor Party terms for attending a meeting of foreign ministers from Israel, Egypt and the United States next month - the first step toward opening direct talks between Israelis and Palestinians.
A senior aide who spent the morning with Mr. Shamir today said he had not made up his mind. Earlier this week, aides said, he had decided to accept the American terms and ''break the siege by moving ahead with the process,'' as a senior Government official put it at the time.
But once word of that decision became known, the right-wing opposition grew to be so intense that Mr. Shamir is now reconsidering, the aides added. On Tuesday evening his office issued an unusual public statement saying ''everything that has been published indicating that the Prime Minister has given his consent'' to the American plan for starting talks ''is without basis.''
At issue is the composition of the Palestinian delegation that would hold talks with Israel. The United States has indicated that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will not attend the three-way meeting until agreement is reached on this question.
 
On the Delegation
Under the American plan openly endorsed by the Labor Party, the delegation would include at least one Palestinian deported from Israel and at least one resident of Arab East Jerusalem.
Fearing that Mr. Shamir will accept those terms, even some of the Prime Minister's allies within the Likud and his own office are openly questioning him.
Several officials said Mr. Shamir was particularly concerned that Benjamin Begin, the son of the former Prime Minister who is a Likud Parliament member and an important political figure in his right, was upset and might defect from Mr. Shamir's camp. Mr. Begin would not return phone calls today.
In an interview today, Mr. Sharon, head of the large and growing dissident faction within the Likud party, said that the three-way Foreign Ministers' meeting ''is the red line we would not like Mr. Shamir to cross.'' If the Prime Minister does cross the line, Mr. Sharon says he will be able to call another meeting of the Likud Central Committee, at which Mr. Shamir might lose a no-confidence vote by his own party.
 
Party for 'Zionist Idea'
This week, 23 of the Likud's 40 members of Parliament signed a letter demanding that Mr. Shamir explain himself before the Parliament. After word of that became public, three or four of those people came forward to tell the Prime Minister that they were still with him, though they were concerned.
Still, a senior aide said the Prime Minister now counts between 13 and 15 of the Likud's Parliamentary factions as inalterably opposed to Mr. Shamir and his elections plan while another five, at least, are troubled and wavering.
The five who formed their own minority party today are headed by Economics Planning Minister Yitzhak Modai, and the separate but affiliated group is calling itself ''The Party for the Promotion of the Zionist Idea.''
Mr. Modai declined to rule out the idea that this group might abandon Likud altogether and join the Labor Party. Already, the defection of these five from Likud has made Labor Israel's largest political party with 39 seats, compared with 35 for Likud.
Along with the dissent within Likud, Mr. Shamir must fight three smaller far-right parties that control seven seats in the 120-seat Parliament. They openly declared war this week.

HEADLINE: Senators Debate Ways of Using Military Savings

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The Senate abruptly opened debate today on whether to use the anticipated reductions in military spending for tax cuts or to finance domestic programs, including education and anti-drug efforts.
The debate was the first time that lawmakers have taken to the floor to lay out their priorities for how to allocate the ''peace dividend'' expected to result from diminished East-West tensions. It came as an unexpected finale to the Senate's consideration of a bill to create a new voluntary national service program, and it set Democrats against Republicans with competing visions about what to do with money that both sides agree has yet to materialize.
Neither side offered a vision of how American military forces or national security priorities should be changed, although that was not the point at issue. 
But the low-key debate, punctuated by recitations of conflicting budgetary and economic statistics, instead offered a preview of how the battle lines will be drawn in the fights to come over cuts in the capital gains and Social Security taxes and the appropriate spending levels for scores of domestic programs that lawmakers in both parties support. To many lawmakers, Republican and Democrat, liberal and conservative, the peace dividend will plainly serve as a catalyst in the effort to try to transform the domestic agenda.
 
Gramm Starts the Debate
''The halls are filled with those planning new programs and new expenditures,'' said Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who began the debate by offering an amendment expressing the sense of the Senate that any military savings beyond those needed to balance the Federal budget should be returned to ''the long-suffering American taxpayer.'' While it is to early to proclaim a peace dividend, he said, it is not too early to plan for it.
Democrats, who were expecting Mr. Gramm's move, quickly weighed in with their own nonbinding amendment stipulating how savings from the military budget should be used. The amendment called for applying them first to balancing the Federal budget without using the Social Security surplus, referring to the issue raised by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who proposed cutting Social Security taxes.
The Democrats said their other priorities were ''urgent'' national concerns, including anti-drug and anti-crime efforts, education, health care and the environment, and then tax cuts for ''working men and women.''
''Before we start indicating what's to be done with a peace dividend, before we start creating a desire for a tax cut, or creating a desire for anything else,'' said Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who is the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee and who sponsored the Democratic amendment, ''we should first address the issue of is there going to be a peace dividend.''
Mr. Sasser noted that President Bush's proposed budget for the 1991 fiscal year would actually increase military spending and said that if there is any peace dividend to be declared Congress would have to carve it out.
There is no consensus on how large the peace dividend is likely to be or when it is likely to become available. But few doubt that the reduced international tension will allow the United States to spend billions of dollars less on the military in this decade that was believed possible only a few months ago.
But Mr. Sasser saved his real fire for the issue of tax cuts, reiterating Democratic contentions that the reductions in capital gains taxes sought by President Bush would benefit only the wealthiest Americans, while those with lower incomes face rising taxes because of the Social Security payroll tax.
By the time it was all over, the Senate very nearly adopted both amendments. Mr. Gramm, who praised Mr. Sasser for acknowledging the need to balance the budget, declared that he had no trouble voting for the Democratic measure, because it was ''kind of like kissing your sister.''
Mr. Sasser's measure was approved on a vote of 79-19, and Mr. Gramm's then lost narrowly, 50-48.

HEADLINE: Successes of New York's High Schools Aren't Credited Enough

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Two news articles that appeared side by side Feb. 12 - a report on trying times for guidance counselors and a column about low test scores for black children in South Africa and the United States - present two facets of the same problem.
Perhaps the time has come for us in New York City to recognize that there is indeed a typical teen-ager, a youngster who comes from a (usually) single-parent family facing severe economic pressures, where English may not be the home language, where housing and neighborhood are of such poor quality as to be life threatening and where few role models are available for emulation.
Today, the school truly acts ''in loco parentis,'' for the school is called upon to provide a host of life-sustaining services. To say that George Wingate High School, Boys and Girls High School and Prospect Heights High School achieve only 2 percent of their students graduating with a Regents diploma is to miss the point. These schools, and many others like them, receive youngsters who are reading and writing on a fourth-grade level, yet that these schools are successful in moving youngsters to the point where they can pass a Regents competency test in reading and writing is a remarkable achievement. 
Perhaps we should also recognize that the four-year high school career of yesterday is no longer relevant today. At Newtown, we receive students overage for their grade who come to us with horrendous life experiences, from countries undergoing social upheaval, knowing no English. That these students take more than four years to complete their high school education is surely not a criticism of the students or of the school. It is a minor miracle that in the time these students spend with us, they not only learn a new language and adjust to a new culture, but also gain sufficient proficiency to go on to college or into the world of work.
The problems facing these students are indeed overwhelming, and guidance counselors are overwhelmed by these problems. As your article points out, guidance counselors deal with problems ranging from physical and sexual abuse to health and housing. Academic counseling is the least of their responsibilities. Counselor caseloads are such that of necessity they can deal only with the most pressing issues.
At Newtown, we not only feed students, but also provide English classes for their parents. We work closely with Elmhurst Hospital and other community organizations to meet the many needs of our population. In addition, we fulfill the traditional role of a school, providing courses to meet the needs of students at all levels of academic interest and ability.
Schools do not shrink from their responsibilities, but we need the support and the understanding of the greater community. The request by the Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, for increased personnel in all schools was made in recognition that if he is to succeed in his mission, and if the schools are to succeed, we all must recognize the extent of the problems and make a commitment to solve them.
 
BARBARA GREENE
Principal, Newtown High School
Elmhurst, Queens, Feb. 14, 1990

HEADLINE: Change in Europe Demands New U.S. Policy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President Bush proposes decreasing United States troops in Europe to 225,000, while maintaining the initiative in nuclear warfare by development of the Stealth bomber, ''Star Wars,'' mobile intercontinental ballistic missiles and sea-based nuclear missiles (front page, Feb. 1). At the same time, Washington and Bonn insist that a future reunified Germany cannot be neutral and will be militarized, thus presumably taking sides in a unilaterally maintained cold war. 
These contradictions have not passed unnoticed in the European press. Following reunification of Germany and completion of Soviet disengagement from Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia, the Soviet Union will not have any troops deployed outside its own borders in two or three years. There is no longer justification for United States armed forces in Europe or to enhance the military potential of the United States or any country in Europe. United States armed forces in Europe in the post-cold war 1990's are of no benefit to the people of either continent. The North Atlantic Treaty Organization military alliance was an outcome of a particular historical situation. In the wake of its deconstruction, there is no basis for foreign military presence on European soil.
The 25 percent military portion of the United States budget is a major deterrent to solving such problems as America's huge debt payments and decay in its social and economic infrastructure (education, medical care, the banking system, the design and technological level of industry).
A good deal of fresh-thinking glasnost and radical perestroika is required in the West, not simply modification of the policies of the last 40 years.
 
MICHAEL KLEIN
Jordanstown, Northern Ireland
Feb. 2, 1990
 The writer is lecturer in American studies, University of Ulster.

HEADLINE: Nicaragua, Victory U.S. Fair Play

BYLINE: By David K. Shipler; David K. Shipler is a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Nicaraguan election has proved that open, honorable support for a democratic process is one of the most powerful foreign policy tools at Washington's disposal. It is more effective than the sordid practice of using the Central Intelligence Agency to engineer coups and secretly finance political parties. It is more legitimate than military force, and, in this case, it has been more decisive.
In dislodging the Sandinistas, Nicaraguan voters have done peacefully what the U.S.-backed contras could not do violently. The few million U.S. dollars that financed international election observers and made the centrist opposition viable were much better spent than the hundreds of millions that purchased weapons and cost thousands of lives. 
Some will argue that without the contras' military pressure, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra would not have agreed to hold elections at all. It is true that partly because of the confrontation with the U.S., Nicaragua's economy suffered terribly, setting the stage for the widespread public discontent with the Sandinistas reflected in Sunday's balloting.
But few governments become moderate during a war; the contra war strengthened Sandinista hard-liners and probably contributed to their oppressive policies. The way to resolution opened only when Congress suspended the war, in effect, to give the Sandinistas a chance to proceed democratically. International scrutiny, spurred by President Oscar Arias of Costa Rica, provided the context in which voting could be conducted in a relatively free atmosphere.
By that time, considerable groundwork had been laid for about five years with small grants from the National Endowment for Democracy, a nongovernmental institution wholly funded by Congress. La Prensa, the opposition newspaper of the new President-elect, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, was kept afloat with newsprint and other supplies subsidized by the endowment. Money went to build a centrist democratic movement, to bolster an independent trade union, to train oppositionists in organization and campaign techniques and to persuade voters to register.
Thus, Nicaragua's election has vindicated Washington's fledgling program of providing public, above-board funding to help democratic procedures take root in countries with authoritarian regimes.
But there are cautionary notes and subtler morals to this story. One is the virtue of supporting the electoral process rather than a particular party.
Last fall the Bush Administration foolishly proposed making direct contributions to the opposition's campaign. The endowment was poised to convey the funds until some of its supporters on Capitol Hill objected; the endowment's board then voted to rebuff the Administration and hew to the line that had been drawn elsewhere in the past: funds to enhance the fairness of the election, not to promote the success of a candidate.
The line was quite thin in Nicaragua. Congress voted $9 million, most of which went through the endowment, to help the opposition level the playing field against the Sandinistas' power to muster the resources of government. Under the law, the opposition could use U.S. funds to purchase cars, fax machines and other equipment - but not to buy bumper stickers, produce buttons or print campaign posters. The distinction was probably lost on most Nicaraguans, although the opposition obviously overcame the stigma of being Washington's client.
Significantly, the nonpartisan funding proved the most important - for the get-out-the-vote campaign, in which Nicaraguans were reassured repeatedly that their ballots would be secret, and for the monitoring teams, which publicized and curtailed Sandinista harassment of oppositionists.
The money intended to help Mrs. Chamorro's campaign most directly was probably the least effective. Most equipment and payments were delayed by Sandinista bureaucrats until the last three weeks, too late to have much impact. Her victory suggests that such campaign aid was unnecessary.
Now the Administration has pledged economic aid, but Nicaragua also needs help in building democratic institutions - an effective legislature, an independent judiciary and a free press. A strong U.S. commitment to that effort would be a sign of a lesson learned.

HEADLINE: Low U.S. Savings Rate: It's A Myth

BYLINE: By Robert Eisner; Robert Eisner is professor of economics at Northwestern University.

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.

 BODY:
The buzzword now is ''saving.''
President Bush has proposed a program to lift a national saving rate that, we are told, is far too low. Our saving rate suffers by comparison with the Japanese, and with our own past. All this threatens long-term decay, if not disaster.
The fault lies, supposedly, in private profligacy and public budget deficits. The failure to pay enough in taxes, or to curb excessive government handouts, encourages our proclivity to live high on the hog, to think only of the present. 
There are some real issues here, but they are hard to discern among the statistical distortions and self-serving political rhetoric.
It should be neither surprising nor alarming that the U.S. is generally saving less than many other countries, especially those that are growing more rapidly. Rapidly growing nations have to save more, since more capital must be acquired to produce more output.
As higher levels of income are achieved and growth rates taper off, saving rates decline. And saving rates have indeed been declining in the rest of the world. For example, net national saving in Japan, as a percentage of net national product, declined by 7.9 percent from 1976 to 1987.
As they are usually presented, moreover, our deficiencies in saving are badly overstated. The rest of the world follows the sensible United Nations systems of accounts, in which government investment in roads, airports and other infrastructure is classified as public saving. Perversely, we do not. If we did, our net national saving would have risen by $53 billion in 1988, from 2.95 percent of net national product to 4.17 percent - an astonishing 41 percent.
Net saving consists of all activities that increase future production and income. Thus, we add to our children's income not only by saving to leave them a bequest but by investing in their education so that they can be more productive.
But education is not counted in conventional saving. Nor is spending on the environment, infrastructure and research and development, or consumer spending on durable goods like cars and clothes washers. But these all contribute to future income, and thus should be considered saving.
Using an appropriate, broader measure of saving, the real saving rate would rise to about five times the conventional rate that has occasioned nearly universal hand-wringing. But that does not mean that the national saving rate is not a problem. Rather, it points to the true nature of the problem and the absurdity of many of the recommended solutions. We are told, for example, that we must reduce the budget deficit to raise national saving. Yet there is ample evidence budget deficits have contributed to more conventional saving, as the deficits stimulate the economy.
Larger deficits, it is true, bring more consumption. But they also inspire more private investment, as businesses respond to increased sales by increasing their plant. This investment, in turn, increases income, providing more than enough additional private saving to finance the greater deficits.
To the extent that they slow the economy, reductions in the deficit and other devices to reduce public or private spending may well reduce saving - even by its narrow, conventional measure.
But it is in the vast and critical amounts of public saving, not included in the conventional measures, that we are indeed gravely deficient. Our 13-year-olds score last in international tests of math and science skills. A third of an American generation is in the process of growing up illiterate or semi-literate, utterly unequipped to function productively in a technologically advanced society.
We lag in expenditures for basic research. A ''war on drugs'' is given primacy, but the means are sorely lacking. Planes are delayed in landing - and crash - at our overcrowded and understaffed public airports. Billions more are proposed for dubious military defense against a presumed international menace that is crumbling before our eyes.
Here's a simple proposal for Congress: Stop starving the public, national saving that provides the real defense of our future in deference to self-imposed accounting constraints and fiscal myths.
Bring Federal accounting into conformity with the rest of the world by counting public investment as saving. In one stroke we will ''solve'' the phantom saving problem and make a start on our real problem of underinvestment in the future.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Bush and Managua

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
The overwhelming defeat of the Sandinistas in Nicaragua has left the Bush Administration with an obvious first order of response - the immediate disbanding of the ''contra'' army organized and directed by the United States and still in place along the Honduran border.
The next step for Washington is equally obvious and equally important - to find means to help the new Chamorro government not only to take power peacefully but to govern successfully. Money, even the ''big bucks'' specified by Bob Dole, the Republican Senate leader, will not be enough.
The logic of disbanding the contras - and of sending them no more U.S. dollars for anything but repatriation - is apparent. In the first place, the Sandinistas fought the C.I.A.-created rebels for too long to turn over control of Nicaraguan armed forces to the new government, if reason exists to believe the contras will either renew the war or move into Nicaragua as an organized political force. Keeping the rebels in being would create that suspicion. 
The demobilization of the contras, moreover, was the other prong of the Central American peace plan that led directly to the free elections in which the Sandinistas were defeated. By holding those elections and letting the people vote without hindrance, the Sandinistas met their part of the bargain - and that's true even if international pressures left them little choice. Now it's only fair, honorable and good hemispheric politics for the U.S. to honor the other half of the plan - even if the contras resist being sent home, or into exile.
In fact, they were supposed to be disbanded before Sunday's elections, under the terms of the peace plan. The U.S. nevertheless continued to send them ''non-lethal'' aid, allowing their continued existence, on grounds that their threatening presence on the Nicaraguan border was necessary to guarantee that free and fair elections would be held. They were, and no conceivable need for a rebel army remains.
Finally, Dona Chamorro's new government could only be damaged if it appeared to be dependent upon, or to welcome, the support of an army organized by the C.I.A. and operating from foreign bases. The new president will have enough troubles without having to explain such a situation.
Those troubles go far beyond an effective takeover of power in Managua. The Sandinistas lost the election - as it appears from here - because the Nicaraguan people were tired of war and sick of economic deprivation. The war should now be over, which will help but by no means rectify the dismal economic conditions that the new government will face.
The Bush Administration is offering such financial aid as it thinks it can afford, and to lift economic sanctions as the Sandinistas relinquish power. That's the least Washington can do to redeem hardships it did much to create; but Nicaragua's real need will be harder to meet.
Arturo Cruz Jr., a former Sandinista and a former contra, predicted the possibility of Dona Chamorro's victory in a recent speech to the Americas Society in New York. But he also pointed to the hemorrhage of a half-million or more skilled artisans, professionals and managers who had fled Nicaragua during the Sandinista regime. As a result, he said, an influx of ''money capital'' could not rebuild an economy suffering most grievously from the loss of so much ''human capital.''
That loss, he suggested, was a major factor in the decline of Nicaraguan exports from $780 million in 1978 to an expected $200 million this year. Exports are necessary to earn the foreign exchange that could bring an end to the crippling shortages felt throughout the nation's economy.
How to make up for the huge outflux of essential workers, Mr. Cruz said, would be the major problem for Nicaragua, no matter who won the election and no matter how much aid in money the U.S. provided. Many of those workers now are more advantageously employed in Florida and elsewhere than they could be if they returned to even a newly democratic Nicaragua.
Without economic success, Violeta Chamorro will find it hard to achieve political stability - as has another widow of an assassinated leader who was elected President not least in his memory, in the Philippines. To help Dona Chamorro overcome her country's daunting economic problems is thus a necessity for democracy in Nicaragua, and an obligation on the Bush Administration as imperative as the disbanding of the contras.

HEADLINE: No-Fault for Doctors Is Called Feasible

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
A system of no-fault medical malpractice insurance, which would compensate victims of medical injury without a judicial finding of negligence, would not cost significantly more than the existing liability system, according to a state-sponsored study of malpractice in New York hospitals that was released yesterday.
The study projects that a no-fault system in New York State would cost a little more than $1 billion, approximately the same amount currently being spent by New York doctors and hospitals for malpractice insurance premiums.
The study conducted by a team of Harvard University researchers is considered by health-policy experts to be the most thorough survey of malpractice conducted in the nation.
It also concludes that the incidence of negligence in public hospitals is 50 percent higher than in private nonprofit hospitals and three times higher than in for-profit hospitals. 
The researchers speculated that the severity and complexity of cases at public hospitals, where illness is often complicated by drug abuse, AIDS and poverty, increases the likelihood of negligence.
Some preliminary results from the study, including the rates of injury and negligence, were reported by news organizations in late January. But additional results were released yesterday, including the conclusions about the cost of a no-fault malpractice system and the comparative rates of negligence at different hospitals.
 
Effect on Opponents
The findings about cost may diminish a major argument made by opponents of the no-fault malpractice insurance plan proposed recently by the state's Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod. Opponents have contended it would be inordinately expensive to compensate all victims of malpractice for their lost wages and fringe benefits, the value of their household work and their medical costs.
The criticism of Dr. Axelrod's proposal, which was first floated in a speech in January, has also examined whether a compensation system that carries no threat of litigation would provide adequate deterrence to poor medical practice.
''One of the reasons why the no-fault idea in the malpractice field has been a non-starter is this sense that the cost is unmanageable,'' said Paul C. Weiler, a Harvard law professor and one of 12 researchers who conducted the Harvard Medical Practice Study. ''These numbers are startling to us because you can't rule out the no-fault idea on the basis of cost alone.''
The researchers who conducted the four-year study found that 3.7 percent of all hospital patients are injured as a result of their medical care and 1 percent of all patients are treated negligently.
 
Calculating the Cost
The study also concludes that the net compensable losses suffered by patients in New York hospitals in 1984, the year chosen for the analysis, amounted to $894 million when adjusted for inflation to 1989 dollars. In 1988, the latest year for which figures were available, doctors, hospitals and other health-care organizations in New York paid approximately $1 billion in malpractice premiums, according to the study.
Because of the administrative cost of a no-fault system, which was estimated by the researchers to be at least 20 percent of the $894 million in compensable losses, the price of a no-fault plan in New York would also probably exceed $1 billion.
The researchers calculated the cost of a no-fault plan by surveying nearly 800 malpractice victims about their economic losses and applying the results to the state's estimated pool of injured patients.
Many legislators in Albany consider no-fault medical malpractice insurance a radical prescription with little chance of becoming law. It has generated intense opposition from trial lawyers, who are concerned about the loss of both patients' rights and lawyers' fees, and from consumer advocates, who believe the best deterrent to poor medical practice is provided by the threat of legal action augmented by more vigorous state policing of the medical profession.
 
Study Called Biased
Even before the study was released, critics began to attack its methodology, particularly its means of determining negligence and its calculation of the cost of a no-fault system. A critique written for the New York State Bar Association by Maxwell J. Mehlman, a law professor at Case Western Reserve University, said the study is ''heavily biased in favor of no-fault.''
But the no-fault concept has gained some momentum recently. Last week, President Bush directed his Domestic Policy Council to propose solutions to the country's malpractice litigation crisis, and White House aides said a no-fault system is one option that should be explored.
Dr. Axelrod, who has a history of pursuing politically difficult initiatives like universal health care, has not issued a detailed proposal for a no-fault plan, but he believes such a system would extend compensation to more malpractice victims. He also believes a no-fault system would protect doctors from the increasing insurance premiums that are driving many specialists from their fields, especially obstetrics.
Under a no-fault system, all victims of medical malpractice could file claims with an independent panel, much like a workers compensation board. Awards for compensatory damages would be made from a pool of funds created largely by insurance premiums paid by doctors and hospitals, though other sources, like insurance companies and the state, could be called upon to contribute.
The study, which analyzed the cases of 31,429 patients at 51 hospitals, found that eight times more patients suffered an injury because of medical negligence than filed malpractice claims and that 16 times as many suffered negligence than received compensation through litigation.

Dr. Howard Hiatt, left, who headed the Harvard University study group that conducted the survey, and Dr. David Axelrod, the state's Health Commissioner, described the plan in Manhattan yesterday. HEADLINE: The Battle Of Bedtime: Children Won

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
STEPHEN CECCHETTI, an economist who lives in Columbus, Ohio, says his 2-year-old son Daniel stays up every night until 10 or 10:30. Mr. Cecchetti would like Daniel to go to bed earlier, but he doesn't insist. ''We're not disciplined people,'' says Mr. Cecchetti, whose wife, Ruth Charney, is a mathematician.
Bedtime was far different when he was growing up. ''My father had rules,'' said Mr. Cecchetti. ''You could fight, but it wouldn't do any good.''
In many American households, a child's bedtime has become a flexible matter. While parents remember being sent to bed at 7 P.M., their children are going to sleep at 9, 10 or even 11 at night. Almost all the experts agree that bedtimes are later and structure less rigid because of the increasing number of single-parent families and dual-income families. 
''Kids are staying up late because they want to see their parents,'' said Ellen Galinsky, a child development expert who is co-president of the Families and Work Institute in New York.
Some are up late because their hectic lives leave them wound up. Others are watching hours of television. And some parents are unable or unwilling to exert the kind of authority over their children that earlier generations did.
Child development experts say there is nothing necessarily wrong with later bedtimes, if the children make up for it on the other end. ''As long as they're getting enough sleep, it doesn't make too much difference,'' said Richard Ferber, director of the Center for Pediatric Sleep Disorders at the Children's Hospital in Boston and an assistant professor of neurology at the Harvard Medical School.
Indeed, later hours can be a sign that children are participating in a rich family life. Morris Wessel, a pediatrician in New Haven who is a clinical professor of pediatrics at Yale, said some children go to sleep because they are bored. ''If the parents don't stimulate their kids, it's not worth staying awake,'' he said.
But late bedtimes can become a problem when a child starts school and can no longer sleep later in the morning or take naps. Bedtime then must be changed to allow for earlier rising.
Some parents are apparently not making the change. School officials report an increase in the number of children who are cranky and tired.
''We have kids who can tell me what's on David Letterman,'' said Susan Korn, the guidance counselor at Public School 3 in Manhattan's West Village. ''They're so tired, they're really not focused.''
The change in bedtime seems to be occurring in big cities and small towns, among the rich and the poor. ''I have first graders going to bed at 9:30 or 10,'' said Ruth Tetschner, principal of the elementary school in Dallas, Pa., a small town in the northeastern part of the state. ''One first-grade teacher has had children fall asleep in the classroom.''
Teachers, pediatricians and therapists who work with families say children tend to go to bed earlier when they are from families where one parent stays home during the day. When both work, the evening's activities begin and end later.
Nancy Lisagor, editor of a new magazine in Philadelphia called Metro Kids, said her two sons, who are 4 years old and 15 months old, go to bed at 8:30 or 9. ''I think that's terribly late,'' she said. ''I think they should sleep 12 hours, and they don't.''
But she said they aren't ready to sleep earlier. ''They get excited at the end of the day when everybody is all together,'' she said. Ms. Lisagor tries to keep the weekends relatively quiet so the children can get plenty of rest.
Later bedtimes represent a greater integration of the child into the evening life of the family. ''We've always been a society that was split in terms of children and adults,'' said Yvonne Young, a New York social worker who sees children and families.
In Europe, there is more mingling of different ages. When Ilike Pesenti moved to New York from Milan five years ago, she was shocked to see American parents putting their children to bed at 7. ''It's very convenient,'' she said. ''But do they really go to sleep? And when do they get to see their parents?'' Children in Italy often join their parents on evening outings, especially in the summer when they don't have to get up for school. ''If the parents want to have fun, they take the child with them,'' said Mrs. Pesenti, who has two children. ''A Mediterranean mother would not depend on a baby sitter.''
Not all children need the same amount of sleep. Dr. Ferber of the Pediatric Sleep Center said some parents expect a child to sleep for 12 hours and become frustrated when the child who needs only 10 hours refuses to go to sleep or stay asleep.
Like adults, children today generally have busier lives that leave them tired but restless at the end of the day. Many of them attend special programs before and after school because both parents are working. Like their parents, they seem to use the weekend to catch up on sleep.
''For the most part, they are very overscheduled,'' said Carol DeVine, principal of Caedmon School, a private school on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. ''Fatigue creates tensions. They go from school to class. It takes some time to wind down.''
Today's adults are generally more lax in their attitudes toward child rearing, and it shows up in bedtimes, said Michael Ferrarese, a psychologist with a private practice in Eagon, Minn. ''The kids are likely to just fall asleep on the couch,'' he said.
This may be due to the increase in the number of families in which both adults work. Peggy Marble, director of the Christ Church Day School in New York, says parents who work may be less able to tolerate the crying or protests from children that sometimes greet an early bedtime. ''It is a painful way for them to end the day,'' she said.
Generally, school officials say that preschool and elementary school children from families with two working parents tend to go to bed at 9:30 or 10, while children from households in which one parent stays home tend to go to bed at 7:30 or 8.
Gretchen Lengyel, co-director of the Madison Playgroup in New York, said later bedtimes are understandable. ''Young parents who are climbing up the corporate ladder get home at 9 or 10,'' she said. ''They are desperate to see their children. They leave the baby sitter instructions to have the child take a long nap so they can stay up later.''
Ms. Lengyel believes that more than a quarter of the children in her school are not getting enough sleep, which leads to less productive days.
''They can't make choices,'' she said. ''They get frustrated by a puzzle that is within their capability. They can't settle an argument over who is going to wear the fireman's hat.''
Sometimes children go to bed later than their parents, usually because they are transfixed by television. One 11-year-old girl who lives in New York with her father said she rarely goes to bed before 10:30. She stays up late, by herself, watching television in her room. She said she is often so tired in math class that she keeps her hed upright by resting it on her hand.
Even if the child manages to get the needed sleep, later bedtimes may cause trouble for parents. ''It is important for parents to have some time to be with each other,'' said George Lazarus, a pediatrician and associate clinical professor of pediatrics at Columbia University.
Parents who cannot make a bedtime stick may find the school doing their job for them. John Melser, the principal at P.S. 3, said many of the children sent to him as troublemakers go to bed at 10 or later, and they are tired. For those occasions, he has an immediate solution.
''I bring that cot down,'' he said, pointing toward a wall of his office, ''and they drop off very quickly.''

HEADLINE: In the Weill Empire, Some Mixed Results

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Sanford I. (Sandy) Weill built one Wall Street empire with a keen eye for value that helped make up for the fact he did not start with a lot of money.
Now, he has a lot of money, a new empire and is discussing putting together the biggest brokerage house of them all, a combination of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, which he now controls, and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which he built and then lost.
If the two are combined, the result would be a firm that is bigger than Merrill Lynch, long Wall Street's largest retail firm in terms of registered brokers.
Mr. Weill's Wall Street reputation has flourished despite disappointments for those who ''invested with Sandy'' when he returned to the financial community more than three years ago. Investors who bought shares in the company he ran, now called the Primerica Corporation, have seen them underperform the general stock market since then, although the company has produced good earnings. 
Primerica may be best known on Wall Street as the owner of Smith Barney, but the brokerage house plays a relatively small role in the success of the company, which is largely built on making small consumer loans and on selling insurance policies to Main Street America.
The insurance and consumer finance operations provided 75 percent of Primerica's profits last year, a proportion that Samuel Liss, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, forecasts will rise to 77 percent this year. He expected Smith Barney's share of the corporate profits pie to shrink to 10 percent, from 11 percent.
But while Mr. Weill's financial empire may not be centered on Wall Street, there is little doubt that a part of his heart is there. Starting as a partner in a small firm in 1960, he engineered a series of mergers that eventually left him in command of Shearson Loeb Rhodes. In virtually all of those mergers, Mr. Weill bought when brokerage firms were not doing well and when the firms being taken over had troubles. In 1981, he sold Shearson to American Express, where he rose to president before departing in 1985.
Mr. Weill, who is 56 years old, got back into the financial fray in October 1986, when the Control Data Corporation, a computer maker that had diversified into consumer lending, signed him on to run its Commercial Credit subsidiary as it was sold to the public in an intial public offering. The shares were priced at $20.50 each, a bit below what the company had hoped for, but the fact that the sale went as well as it did was widely ascribed to Mr. Weill's standing on Wall Street.
 
Steady Profits
Those shares initially performed well, hitting a peak of $34.625 in 1987, as financial services companies were the stars of Wall Street. But after the stock market crash they fell to a low of $17.
Mr. Weill seems to have done a good job at Commercial Credit, getting out of a variety of businesses, including lending to companies, to concentrate on the lucrative business of making second-mortgage and personal loans to consumers around America. Profits rose sharply in the first year he ran Commercial Credit and have risen steadily since.
Mr. Liss of Salomon puts the pretax profit margins there at 26 percent last year, meaning that for each $4 in revenues, the company manages to earn $1 before taxes. But Wall Street has not been eager to pay much for those profits, in part because of worries that in a recession many loans could default.
In 1988, Mr. Weill made his way back to Wall Street with a deal to take over the old Primerica Corporation. That company was the former American Can Corporation and was being run by Gerald Tsai, a star money manager in the late-1960's bull market whose reputation took a tumble along with stock prices as that decade ended.
 
Can Operations Sold
Making his comeback, Mr. Tsai redirected Primerica into financial services, selling the can operations at prices well below what they would have fetched a few years later, while paying high prices for financial services operations. He capped that buying spree shortly before the crash by paying $750 million for Smith Barney a few months before the crash. Having overpaid, Primerica needed a buyer.
After Commercial Credit took over Primerica in a $1.5 billion deal, mostly for Commercial Credit stock, the surviving firm was renamed Primerica, helping to confuse many an investor. While that deal may prove to have been a good one in the long term, it has done nothing for the stock price so far, in part because the new company pays a small dividend of just 32 cents a share a year. The old Primerica had paid high dividends, and many of those holders have been selling.
Cash had been pouring out of Primerica before the takeover, but that has turned around. While insurance operations remain the most important part of the company, Smith Barney's results have improved to show a record profit last year of $63 million, before writing off $13 million in ''good will'' stemming from its acquisition. In a move typical of Mr. Weill, the brokerage swooped down and acquired a part of Drexel Burnham Lambert's retail network last year at almost no cost.
All told, the new Primerica reported 1989 profits of $289 million, or $2.87 a share. But the shares, even after rising 25 cents, to $26.875, yesterday, are trading at less than 10 times last year's profits, and just eight times estimates of this year's earnings. Those are not impressive figures, and reflect the general disrepute in which financial services companies are now held.
But Mr. Weill, while he may be a man of Wall Street, has never been especially enamored of its collective wisdom. He built his first empire by making cheap takeovers of brokerage firms when others feared to do so. He wisely stayed out when prices were soaring in 1987, only to get back in at much cheaper prices in 1988. Whatever comes of the talks, the fact that he is interested in Shearson now may indicate that in the wake of Drexel's collapse and layoffs around the Street, he thinks Wall Street is undervaluing itself.

HEADLINE: G.N.P. Rate For Late '89 Put at 0.9%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The nation's economy grew at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989, somewhat stronger than the Commerce Department had initially estimated, but still the weakest quarterly performance since 1986, even allowing for last year's long strike at the Boeing Company.
The revised figure for the gross national product was four-tenths of a point higher than the number published last month; most analysts had expected the revision would be slightly downward instead of modestly higher. The numbers also showed a surprisingly strong improvement in the nation's foreign trade situation.
Still, the data did little to alter basic assessments of economic performance, and few analysts saw the slight overall increase as a sign of economic revival. 
 
Weak Points Are Seen
''It still conveys that there is weakness in key sectors,'' said Kathleen Stephansen, an economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.
There is a consensus, however, that the economy has at least stabilized. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today, ''I think the probability of a recession has slipped below 50 percent.''
The report released today also showed that inflation ran at a 3.6 percent rate in the fourth quarter, as measured by the fixed-weight G.N.P. price index, instead of the 3.8 percent estimated last month.
The nation's international trading account was $13.6 billion better than originally estimated, today's report showed, moving from a $4.7 billion deficit to a $8.9 billion surplus. Roughly two-thirds of the change came from lower imports, and the remainder from higher exports.
 
Big Changes in Trade Data
A report on the December trade deficit, released two weeks ago, had shown an exceptionally big drop, and analysts were expecting this sector to lift the G.N.P., but the amount was well above what was anticipated.
Another heartening sign was an upward revision in the final sales category to show an advance of five-tenths of 1 percent instead of the decline of five-tenths of 1 percent that was reported last month. This suggested that consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of economic activity, was advancing at a faster, albeit modest, clip during the final three months of 1989 than previously believed.
The final sales figure removes the effects of changes in business inventories. Goods that pile up on merchants' shelves add just as much to G.N.P. as those that find buyers, so economists look at final sales for clues as to whether production levels will need to be raised or lowered.
Brian M. Jones, an economist at Lloyds Bank North America, called the final sales data 'the most encouraging'' part of the report. It shows the economy is ''certainly not recessionary,'' he said.
 
Two Negative Numbers
Two negatives in today's report were hefty downward revisions in business inventories and business investment, down $6.4 billion and $4.6 billion, respectively. Those declines offset most of the gain from net exports.
The revision in the overall number seemed to catch some economists and others off stride, perhaps because of its unexpected direction, but the size of the revision was well within normal bounds.
During the eight quarters of 1988 and 1989, the average revision between the ''advance'' and ''preliminary'' reports was just over six-tenths of a point, with the largest being a 1.6 percent upward adjustment in the first quarter of 1988.
The ''final'' report on fourth-quarter G.N.P. - a second revision - is to be published a month from now.
At one time the department compiled an early ''flash'' estimate for G.N.P. even before a quarter ended, but the number was often substantially revised and its release was discontinued.
Today's revision did raise G.N.P. growth for all of 1989 to 3 percent, from 2.9 percent. This fell short of the 1988 increase of 4.4 percent and the 1987 increase of 3.7 percent. It exceeded, however, the 2.7 percent growth of 1986. <Slowest Since 1986 The nine-tenths of 1 percent rate of advance for the fourth quarter was the slowest since an eight-tenths of 1 percent increase in the third quarter of 1986. The Boeing strike is estimated to have reduced fourth-quarter output by five-tenths of a point.
Other data in today's report showed that the G.N.P. price deflator was at a 3.2 percent rate instead of the 3.5 percent estimated last month and that the personal savings rate was 5.7 percent instead of 5.8.
Current-dollar G.N.P. - the output of goods and services without adjustment for inflation - rose at a 4.4 percent rate in the fourth quarter rather than the 4.3 percent estimated a month ago.

HEADLINE: Shifts in U.S. Policy Sought To Spur Caribbean Trade

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

 BODY:
By most accounts, the 1984 Reagan Administration plan to increase American trade with 27 nations in the Caribbean and Central America has yet to become what many hailed it at the time: the catalyst needed to generate new industries and more varied agriculture among a largely poor assemblage of one-crop economies.
Even so, Congress is taking up a measure today to extend indefinitely the original 12-year Caribbean Basin Initiative, as the plan is called. And supporters are optimistic that the Senate Finance Committee will change some of the program's policies that they say have kept it from becoming the revolution in trade and industry for the region that some economists and politicians predicted.
The debate over the future of the program takes on added significance as the United States discusses ways to provide economic assistance to the ravaged economies of Panama and Nicaragua, which are eligible to participate.
While there have been strong gains for many products, like flowers and electrical equipment, many countries have been slow to turn out new exports that are being encouraged under the program's liberalized trade rules. At the same time, tariffs and quotas on more traditional exports, like sugar and textiles, have remained in force. Relaxation of these policies is sought. 
''The initiative has had some impact on our economies but it certainly hasn't lived up to what many of us expected,'' said Derick R. Heaven, the Jamaican representative to the United Nations. ''There is a long list of commodities that have duty-free access to the U.S., but most of these are not things we have the capacity to produce in large quantities.''
Mr. Heaven's temperate remarks stand in contrast to those of some politicians and economists six years ago who suggested that the initiative would quickly bring about a historic shift in global investment from the bubbling, upstart economies of the Far East to the muggy and somnolent ports of the Caribbean.
Overnight, the program eliminated import duties on all but a handful of goods shipped to the United States. Soon afterward, increasing amounts of American Government aid and private investment began to flow to many countries in the region.
Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida and a sponsor of a bill to extend the program, said, ''The impact of C.B.I. has been significant but diluted by other events, like the declining quota of sugar entering the U.S. from C.B.I. nations, which occurred around and independent of it.''
 
Three Products Excluded
The mixed appraisals reflect the frustrations of the officials of many Caribbean countries that the initiative's potential to help them has been greatly tempered by the exclusion of three of the region's most important products: sugar, textiles and petroleum products.
Despite wider doors for the bulk of the region's exports, tariffs and quotas on these products and falling commodity prices combined to cause an annual drop of $2.3 billion since 1983 in the total value of United States imports from the Caribbean Basin countries, according to a recent State Department report.
In defense of the program, United States officials say the main cause of the Caribbean countries' deteriorating balance of trade with this country is the $4 billion drop in the value of oil exports from three countries, Trinidad and Tobago, the Bahamas and the Netherlands Antilles.
The officials say that since the Caribbean initiative began, exports of products exempted from duties have grown more than 46 percent, or at an average annual rate of 5.2 percent.
 
The Major Gains
The most significant export gains for the Caribbean region during the last six years have been in apparel, electrical equipment, fruit, flowers, winter vegetables and shellfish - all defined under the program as non-traditional exports. Traditional exports include sugar, coffee, bauxite, bananas, cocoa and rum.
Testifying in February before the Senate Finance Committee's Subcommittee on International Trade, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said the region's nontraditional exports to the United States ''have been increasing so fast that for the first time in 1988 they exceeded the value of traditional exports, compared to representing under one-quarter of our total imports from the region in 1983.''
Mrs. Hills cited the growth of the nontraditional goods, as opposed to the region's mainstays, as ''concrete evidence that the C.B.I. is making progress in helping the economies in the region diversify and achieve self-sustaining growth.''
 
U.S. Companies Active
A number of American companies have reacted enthusiastically to the program, taking advantage of the region's low labor costs and the initiative's tax exemptions to perform offshore labor-intensive tasks, like the assembly or finishing of goods, on this country's doorstep.
One American company that has shifted much of its manufacturing from the Far East to the Caribbean, introducing new industry to the region, is the Conair Corporation, a Princeton, N.J., manufacturer of blow dryers and other small appliances.
''Right now we have 250 people employed in Costa Rica and will probably have about 600 people there in the next year or so,'' said Arthur A. Taylor, director of imports for Conair. ''We are saving a couple of million dollars a year on duties alone'' because of the program, he added.
But many business executives and lobbyists for the region say that without greater access to the American market for the region's traditional export products, like sugar and textiles, sustained economic growth in much of the Caribbean will remain elusive. Textiles is a fairly recent growth industry, Sugar Imports Down Sharply ''There has been more unemployment caused by our sugar policy than jobs created by our basin initiative,'' said Peter B. Johnson, executive director of Caribbean/Central American Action, a Washington-based organization of American and Caribbean businesses.
Sugar imports from Caribbean producers to the United States, which has its own sugar industry, are restricted and have fallen sharply since 1984. Attempts to lower or eliminate tariffs on clothing have stumbled in the face of powerful union lobbying efforts.
In her testimony to the Senate, Mrs. Hill opposed one proposal that would guarantee a minimum volume of sugar sales by Caribbean Basin countries to the United States. She said such a provision would violate United States commitments to end support for suagr production under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The House of Representatives recently approved a floor for sugar imports when it passed a bill to indefinitely extend the life of the initiative. But at the same time, the House rejected the elimination of duties for textiles and footwear.
 
Hopeful on Textile Plan
Senate supporters of new Caribbean Basin legislation and lobbyists representing Caribbean governments and companies doing business in the region say they are optimistic that the Senate Finance Committee will approve lower barriers on garments made of fabrics cut and formed in this country when it takes up the matter next week.
Senator Graham said he hoped that with Administration support Congress would soon approve more generous textile provisions. But citing Mrs. Hill's opposition to easing sugar restrictions, he said passage of a new measure for that commodity was less likely.
Even with gaps remaining in some trade categories considered vital by eligible countries, Mr. Johnson of Caribbean/Central American Action said, ''The initiative has clearly helped them reduce the devastating impact of falling sugar, oil, coffee and other commodity prices, over which they have absolutely no control.''
