HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
The Bass Profits In Savings Bailout

BYLINE: By Nathaniel C. Nash

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A FAVORITE pastime of banking experts in late 1988 was to try to figure out which were the sweetest of the deals the Government had struck to sell insolvent savings and loan institutions to investors.
Such analyses focused on tax breaks that gave the new owners the right to offset taxes with huge operating losses from the sick institutions and guaranteed yields on certain assets that assured profits for as many as 10 years to come.
One of the most celebrated deals was the purchase in December 1988 by the Robert M. Bass Group of the American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton, Calif., the country's largest ailing savings institution. In return for a $400 million investment, Mr. Bass, the Fort Worth billionaire, received control of an institution with $30 billion in assets and more than 170 branches in California. 
A little more than a year later, Mr. Bass's institution, renamed the American Savings Bank, has stunned analysts with news that it earned $214.2 million in its first year - making it one of the most profitable savings and loans in the country.
But regulators and analysts who have looked closely at the deal say Mr. Bass did not profit from a Government handout. While he did receive a healthy dose of tax breaks and guaranteed profits, a larger portion of American Savings' 1989 earnings came from fortuitous changes in the industry and the fact that Mr. Bass purchased an essentially healthy institution whose bad assets had been cleaned out.
''The transaction left the Bass group wth a relatively clean thrift institution, which they subsequently managed in an intelligent way,'' said R. Dan Brumbaugh, senior fellow at the Center for Economic Policy Research at Stanford University and a former deputy chief economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. ''And that is exactly the kind of transaction that the Government should attempt to negotiate, the point being that an acquirer should be left with a solid institution with which to go forward.''
What is more, these people say, the institution's profits will be cut because a ruling by the Office of Thrift Supervision in January rescinded some lenient regulatory provisions. In Mr. Bass's case, the change will force him to invest an additional $240 million of the company's profits into the institution to increase its capital.
What helped American Savings most in 1989 was probably the major rally in the bond market, which pushed interest rates down, and a program by the Government to force sick savings institutions to stop paying excessively high rates on deposits.
As market rates fell, American Savings found that the value of its loans rose sharply, and it began a program of selling large volumes of fixed-interest mortgages and corporate bonds at a big profit, replacing them with adjustable-rate mortgages.
At the same time, it was able to reduce drastically the rate it paid on its deposits, in comparison with other big California institutions, by almost a percentage point.
Mario Antoci, the chairman of American Savings, said last month that the institution made $50 million on the sale of loans and earned another $50 million by lowering its cost of deposits. About $40 million in profits was attributable to closing some branches, laying off personnel and other cost cutting, he added. The institution benefited greatly from two arrangements it had made with the Government.
One involves an $8 billion, 10-year note from the Government that American Savings carries as an asset. This note essentially replaced bad loans in the old American Savings that were not passed on to Mr. Bass. Some competitors see this as a guaranteed profit stream for the next decade, since the Government agreed to pay an interest rate that was initially 2.25 percentage points above the average cost of deposits for California savings institutions.
Although that premium drops to 1.75 points by January 1992, analysts note that there is little administrative expense to servicing that giant loan, unlike an $8 billion portfolio of mortgages, and estimate that the profits could total more than $40 million a year, or almost $500 million through the end of the century.
Bass officials disagree, saying their profit margins are much thinner and that profits from the 10-year note will depend on how efficiently they run the institution.
The second area that assures profits is the $2.2 billion in losses from the old American Savings. That can offset taxes on future earnings. While that may seem high, the final payoff will be far less, since American Savings will have to pay 75 percent of its tax savings to the Government. Thus, officials calculate the institution's net savings at less than $200 million.
Regulators and analysts said that in the end the real value that Mr. Bass bought was American Savings itself, with $15 billion in consumer deposits that do not flee in hard times. They give Mr. Antoci high marks for the dramatic one-year turnaround and note that the institution is now a conservative traditional savings and loan, which makes a profit on the difference between what its pays for deposits and charges for mortgage loans.
Indeed, American Savings' one real bust of 1989 was a foray into high-risk bonds: the purchase by American Savings of $493 million in ''junk bonds'' just before the market began to crumble.
''And would you believe that the portfolio was a very conservative one?'' one Bass official said. ''It was just the worst time in the history of the world.''

HEADLINE: Home Resale Rate Off 2.2%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes declined 2.2 percent in January, as rising mortgage interest rates and the usual winter lull combined to reduce sales to their slowest pace since last summer, a real estate trade group said today.
The National Association of Realtors said resales of single-family homes totaled a seasonally adjusted 3.48 million units in January, compared with 3.56 million one month earlier. It was the slowest pace since the rate of 3.44 million last August.
Surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation show that the interest rate on fixed-rate, 30-year mortgages rose from 9.83 percent to 10.05 percent during January.
The association's survey found the median price of an existing home to be $96,200, up 4 percent from December and 7.1 percent from January 1989. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less.
The only increase in resales occurred in the South, where 1.4 million units were sold on an annual rate, up seven-tenths of a percent from December.
The West had the biggest decline, down 11.5 percent, to 540,000 units. The Northeast posted a 3.4 percent drop, to 560,000 units. The Midwest had a decline of 2 percent, to 960,000 units.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Sees Slow Growth

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said today that he expects that economic growth in the first three months of the year will be ''slow but positive.''
 
His remarks helped bolster
Wall Street stocks, which had already been buoyed by a Government report showing the economy grew by a stronger pace in the last quarter of 1989 than had been estimated. 
 
Testifying before the House
Budget Committee, Mr. Greenspan was asked whether he thought the first three months of this year would show similar results to the fourth quarter.
''I expect the growth rate to be slow but positive,'' he said.
Mr. Greenspan said that weakness in durable goods manufacturing had made the economy resemble a tire with a slow leak. On Tuesday, the Government reported that durable goods orders plummeted by a record 10.5 percent in January.
''That leak has ended,'' he said. ''The system is no longer eroding. It has stabilized and has not exhibited any weakening.''
Mr. Greenspan told the panel that although the danger of a recession had been increasing most of last summer and into the fall, ''the period of highest vulnerability probably came in the fall.''
He added that whenever growth was slow, the economy was vulnerable to a recession, but chances of one occurring soon had dropped.

HEADLINE: Prices Paid To Farmers Decline 0.6%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Prices farmers received for raw products declined six-tenths of 1 percent from January to February, but the overall commodity index still averaged 2.7 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.
Lower prices for milk, eggs, lettuce and wheat were mostly responsible for the decline from January, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report. The report said higher prices for cattle, chickens and tomatoes partly offset the decline for the other commodities.
''Tomato prices for February were at the highest level of record,'' the report said. ''During the past two months prices have been about twice the previous record established in March of 1985.''
The price climb reflected short supplies caused by the December freeze in Florida, the report said.
On the other hand, the report said the drop in milk prices paid to farmers - which had been at record levels - was the largest month-to-month decline ever recorded. The egg price drop was the third largest ever.
The report did not include new figures on farm expenses. Those are computed every three months. In January, however, quarterly figures showed that prices paid by farmers were up 1.1 percent from October, the previous reading, and averaged 2.9 percent more than a year earlier.
Department economists say the net cash income of farmers in 1990 may be in the range of $52 billion to $57 billion, compared with about $53 billion in 1989. Net cash income is the money that farmers have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses.

HEADLINE: Stocks Advance a Third Day; Dow Up 10.13

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks rose for the third session in a row yesterday on moderately higher volume, and the Dow Jones Industrial average, which was up more than 28 points in the early afternoon, finished 10.13 points higher at 2,627.25.
So far this week, the Dow has risen more than 63 points.
Advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declines, 917 to 565, as volume rose to 164.4 million shares, from 152.6 million on Tuesday.
It appeared that once again the movement of the stock market in Tokyo had little impact on the course of equities in the United States. The 225-stock Nikkei index climbed 694.04 points, or 2.05 percent, relatively a much larger increase than the Dow, which gained only four-tenths of 1 percent. Indeed, some analysts characterized this week's upward move by equities as primarily technical in nature. 
''The stock market is exhibiting a markedly more durable tone in the midst of what appears to be a massive shift in both trading psychology and industry leadership,'' said Eugene E. Peroni Jr., chief technical analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia.
''The Dow's technical features are improving from the standpoint of both breadth and volume, and stocks are showing a more tolerant attitude toward the unsettled Japanese market and conjecture about the course of interest rates.''
Traders said prices were buoyed early in the day by futures-related trading and a comment by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that he expects slow but positive growth in the nation's first-quarter gross national product.
 
Durable Goods Weakness Ends
Traders noted that in his remarks, Mr. Greenspan also said that weakness in durable goods manufacturing had ended. On Tuesday, the Government reported a 10.5 percent drop in durable goods orders for January, the biggest decline on record.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index moved up 1.63 points, to 331.89, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index added 0.91, to 183.07.
The Dow transportation average continued strong, rising 12.80 points, to 1,129.09, on the collective strength in airline issues. UAL rose 2 1/2, to 131; AMR 7/8, to 60 3/8; Delta Air Lines 1 1/4, to 69 5/8, and USAir 2, to 32.
Among individual issues, American Express added a point, to 29 1/8. The company said it had held preliminary talks with the Primerica Corporation and its Smith Barney, Harris Upham unit about achieving economies of scale with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which is 61 percent owned by American Express.
Shearson gained 5/8, to 12 5/8. The company announced that as part of a cost-cutting plan designed to save about $400 million a year, it would cut its employment rolls by about 2,000 people during the first quarter.
Boeing jumped 2 1/4, to 63 7/8. Howard Rubel, aerospace analyst with C.J. Lawrence, citing a positive outlook for earnings, reiterated his ''buy'' recommendation on the company because of the prospects of sharply accelerated earnings.
Digital Equipment soared 6 points, to 78, in late trading as rumors circulated that Japanese companies were accumulating Digital stock in order to make a bid for the company.
Union Carbide rose 1/2, to 24 1/4, on continued but unsubstantiated rumors of a possible takeover of the company or a sale of some of its units.
Active glamour stocks included Exxonei, off 1 3/8, to 47; Philip Morris, down 5/8, to 37; Pfizer, off 1/8, to 59; General Electric, up 1/4, to 61 3/4, and A.T.&T., up 1/8, to 39 3/4.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 1.50 points, to 352.90, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index jumped 3.22 points, to 425.83.
In over-the-counter trading, Intel rose 3/4, to 40 1/4. Thomas Kurlak, Merrill Lynch analyst, reiterated a ''buy'' recommendation on the company on expectations of continued demand for its proprietary 32-bit microprocessors used in high-end personal computers.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Broad Gains Against Mark and Pound

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Making one of its first broad upward moves of the year, the dollar yesterday rose against the mark, the pound and the Swiss franc.
But dollar selling for Japanese yen by the Federal Reserve helped stem any gains against the flagging yen, whose weakness played a major role in the steep declines in the Japanese stock market last week and on Monday. Both the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan have been selling dollars since Friday in an effort to support the yen. 
Traders said the dollar's rise was not initiated by any economic news or significant change in the economic outlook in the United States or Europe. Rather, they said the move appeared to be an adjustment, or correction, to the too sharp drop of the dollar against the mark and other European currencies in response to the proposed unification of Germany and the opening of Eastern Euorpe.
These events drew money to the mark and other European currencies so investments could be made in hopes of profiting from the economic developments. The dollar has fallen sharply from the 1.84 level last November, when the Berlin wall was dismantled, to 1.65 marks to the dollar this year.
''This is a correction of the downward trend that was exaggerated,'' said Robert A. White, vice president at First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles. Will Trend Continue? But he also warned that he was not sure if the trend would continue. ''The market has had a habit of not following through this year on trends,'' he said.
In late trading in New York, the dollar was at 1.7045 marks, up from 1.6887 on Tuesday and 1.6681 a week ago. The dollar also gained against the pound. At the close yesterday, a pound was worth $1.6765, down from $1.6890 Tuesday and $1.7145 a week ago. Against the Swiss franc, the dollar was at 1.5000, up from 1.4850 Tuesday and 1.4800 a week ago.
Against the yen, the dollar ended at 148.92, up from 148.73, but below the 149 level at which it has been trading.
Alan C. Leveten, managing director at Balfour Maclaine in New York, said the fall of the pound against the dollar was partly a correction of the pound's sharp rise this year that has made it once of the best-performing currencies of the year. The sharper-than-expected widening of the British current account deficit also hurt the pound.
Francoise Soares-Kemp, vice president at Credit Suisse in New York, said the rise in the dollar appeared to be ''a precautionary move'' because of the uncertainity surrounding the developments in Germany and Eastern Euorpe. She said this uncertainity should continue until at least the elections in East Germany on March 18. But she said that after that, if the unification began to go smoothly, the mark would strengthen again and the dollar would weaken.
Mrs. Kemp also said the mark was hurt by a report that the Deutsche Genossenschaftsbank A.G. was involved in dispute with a group of French banks over a bond deal that could involve as much as 600 million marks, about $352 million.

HEADLINE: WORLD DRUG CROP UP SHARPLY IN 1989 DESPITE U.S. EFFORT

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The State Department reported today that global production of opium poppies, coca, marijuana and hashish soared in the last year. This occurred despite President Bush's highly publicized effort to curtail drug supply and demand.
Worldwide drug abuse has also increased, as higher yields have pushed drug traffickers to aggressively seek out new markets, the report said.
The State Department's report has become an annual admission of the inability of the United States to single-handedly fight the war on drugs, which it has portrayed as a crisis of global proportions beyond the ability of the United States to control.
 
Some Successes Claimed
The document cited some encouraging developments, including record drug seizures; the capture, extradition and imprisonment of leading traffickers; the seizing of assets; new international treaties of cooperation, and new laws against money laundering. But it acknowledged that these limited successes were far overshadowed by the failures. 
''Worldwide narcotics production reached new levels, corruption undermined enforcement efforts, and a number of governments still failed to exhibit a serious commitment to reducing drug production and trafficking,'' the report said. It singled out as particularly troublesome corruption among officials in Bolivia, Thailand, Laos and the Bahamas. A similar problem was reported among Syrian officials operating in the Bekaa, Lebanon's major narcotics cultivation, refining and trafficking region, which is under Syrian control.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, said: ''Corruption remains a major problem wherever narcotics are produced or trafficked. And there are governments which simply seem unwilling to stand up to the trafficking organizations and take the tough actions necessary to rid their countries of the scourge of drugs.''
 
Administration Defended
This year's report did not repeat last year's candid admission that the United States had subordinated the ''drug control agenda'' to concerns that punishing drug-producing countries with weak economies and political institutions might further destabilize them. It also stopped short of reiterating the 1986 directive by President Reagan that elevated drug trafficking to a national security issue.
Rather, it praised the Bush Administration's drug control strategy that aims to ''disrupt and dismantle the multinational criminal organizations that support the production, processing, transportation and distribution of drugs to the United States and to other nations.''
In testimony on the report to a House Foreign Affairs task force on drugs today, Melvin Levitsky, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters, defended the Administration strategy against lawmakers' attacks and explained that it had only been in effect a ''very short time.'' He attributed the rise in drug production in part to the unwillingness of governments to ''go after the poor elements of the population growing opium or coca.''
''The figures are not what we'd like to see,'' said John P. Walters, chief of staff to William J. Bennett, director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. ''We're disappointed but I'm not surprised. It reflects the fact that we are doing a better job at demand than supply. That is why we have proposed expanded programs in Latin America to begin to better stem the flow of drugs.''
Mr. Walters emphasized that that past figures have not been as accurate in ''presenting the level of the problem'' and that global drug production ''is not something that radically increased over the last year.''
But in light of the increased production figures, Representative Larry Smith, a Florida Democrat, criticized the Bush Administration for not being tough enough against governments that have failed to cooperate. ''We are slipping backward badly,'' he said.
In one major shift in strategy, the Administration no longer considers aerial eradication of drug crops, especially coca, as the key to curbing production, as it has been in for a number of years. Last year's report, for example, called aerial spraying the only way to significantly curb cocaine production.
But coca-producing countries have routinely opposed plans for eradication efforts largely because they would cause vast economic dislocation, political unrest by stripping peasants of their livelihood and severe environmental problems in the tropical forests. For example, Bolivia, second only to Peru in coca production, in 1989 eradicated only about 6,175 acres of coca, half of its own legal target and less than one percent of its total production.
''These countries are not our country,'' Mr. Levitsky said, acknowledging the limited influence of the United States in persuading countries to eradicte their drug crops.
The report estimated that from 1988 to 1989, the production of opium increased by a staggering 47 percent. Coca production increased 12 percent among the four coca-producing countries: Peru, Colombia, Bolivia and Ecuador, while hashish rose 16 percent. Estimates of marijuana production were up 210 percent, most of it in Mexico, although much of that increase reflects an improved methodology based on new United States satellite surveillance, rather than an outright increase in production, the report said.
 
Heroin Threat Cited
A major concern, according to the report and senior Administration officials, is the increase in opium production, which it said threatens the United States ''with a potential heroin epidemic.''
David L. Westrate, assistant administrator for operations at the Drug Enforcement Administration, told the Congressional task force that heroin might eventually become a bigger worry that cocaine, which in its smokable form - crack - has caused such serious addiction problems in the United States in recent years, particularly in its inner cities. Heroin problem may worsen dramatically in the next 10 years, he said, because it is grown in so many regions of the world, in countries that use diverse traffic routes. By contrast, 80 percent of the world's supply of cocaine comes from the processing and distribution networks of one country, Colombia.
The drug production increase is even more dramatic when compared over five years. Since 1985, opium production has increased 187 percent, coca 43 percent and marijuana 502 percent. Burma, for example, which last year suspended all narcotics control programs, doubled its opium production last year.
In Afghanistan, opium production has increased significantly over the last decade, much of it in areas controlled by United States-backed Afghan guerrillas. It is feared, the report said, ''that once hostilities end, refugees will turn to poppy cultivation during the period of economic disruption as they seek to rebuild a livelihood interrupted by 10 years of war.''
Another significant finding of this year's report is that Mexico produces 10 times more marijuana than the United States has previously estimated, making it by far the world's leading marijuana grower.
 
Ties With Mexico Strained
The report emphasizes that the increase does not suggest a sudden surge in production but that previous estimates based largely on data provided by the Mexican Government were far too low. Nevertheless, the assertion already seems to have further strained relations between the two nations.
In an address to the United Nations General Assembly last week, for example, Mexico's Attorney General, Enrique Alvarez del Castillo, strongly ruled out any United States-Mexican military cooperation in the war on drugs. The revised estimate in the case of Mexican marijuana also highlights just how imprecise the estimates of production can be.
The report cited ''widespread corruption'' in Bolivia's judiciary, police and some military units as a ''major impediment'' to the country's drug eradication and interdiction campaign. But it fell far short of a recent classified internal State Department memorandum stating that Bolivia's performance almost always indicates lack of commitment to anti-drug efforts.
Accompanying the annual report is a statement in which the the President declares whether a foreign country is eligible for American aid. Under a law passed in 1986, the President must certify by March 1 that countries where major drug trafficking occurs are ''fully cooperating'' in anti-drug efforts as a condition for receiving aid.
Despite the negative tone of the State Department's report, the penalties that the United States imposed were few and mild.
 
No Ally Penalized
In fact, no ally of the United States has been penalized in the last four years for lack of cooperation, and there has been growing sentiment in Congress that the law is flawed because it is applied selectively. In practice, penalties are imposed only against those countries where United States Government believes it has little to lose politically or economically.
That pattern was repeated today. Mr. Bush announced mostly symbolic penalties against four nations with which the United States has no relations or has severely strained relations: Afghanistan, Iran, Syria and Myanmar, former Burma.
In a statement of explanation, Mr. Bush said he was formally lifting the decertificaion imposed last year against Panama, because the new Government of Guillermo Endara ''immediately demonstrated a willingness to fully cooperate with the United States,'' and against Laos, because American-Laotian counternarcotics cooperation had improved.
Lebanon, an important drug producer and transit point, was cited as needing to do more to cooperate with the United States. But it was certified as ''fully cooperating'' because it is Syria that actually controls the Bekaa region.

HEADLINE: SENATORS ACHIEVE ACCORD WITH BUSH ON CLEAN AIR BILL

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
After weeks of negotiations in closed sessions, Senate leaders today diluted some provisions of their proposed clean air legislation to meet President Bush's demand for a less costly solution to the nation's pollution problems.
Announcing the result of negotiations with the White House, the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, said the bill was ''sound comprehensive legislation'' that would reduce acid rain, urban smog and toxic chemicals released in the air by industry.
The White House said the senators, in settling for less stringent standards and a slower cleanup schedule, had satisfied in part Mr. Bush's demand for anti-pollution measures that do not pose risks to the economy.
 
Action in Senate Scheduled
The agreement cleared the way for a Senate action on the bill, which is to start next week. The original bill had been approved by the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee last fall. A separate clean air bill is before a House committee. 
The President's chief domestic policy adviser, Roger Porter, said that while the Administration would support the package announced today with the Senate, it may seek further changes in the House.
The senators gave ground on several points. They agreed to stretch out the first stage of new regulations on automobile emissions to 1995 from 1993 and to allow a second stage, with even stricter limits on carbon monoxide and other pollutants, only under certain conditions.
On acid rain, the Senate leaders agreed to allow power plants in Western and Midwestern states to continue burning low-sulfur coal for a longer period. When burned, low-sulfur coal produces sulfur dioxide, the major component of acid rain.
 
Economic Impact Cushioned
Senators from the affected regions wanted this provision to cushion the economic impact of reducing pollution from coal-fired power plants.
The senators also softened a plan to reduce the risk from toxic substances released into the air by industrial plants. This step will lower the costs to industries for reducing airborne toxic chemicals.
Both sides hailed the agreement as a fair compromise that would lead to significant improvements in the nation's air quality and in the protection of public health. But environmental groups and several senators said they had serious objections to many of the provisions and would fight for amendments on the Senate floor.
Gene Karpinski, director of the United States Public Interest Research Group, an environmental and consumer advocacy organization, said, ''The clean air bill went into the back rooms and it looks like a dirty air bill is coming out.''
William Fay, administrator of the Clean Air Working Group, the chief industry lobby working on the legislation, called the compromise ''a move in the right direction.'' But he added that industry still had ''some problems'' with the legislation, particularly with the proposed rules for airborne chemicals.
The compromise removes the threat of a White House-sponsored filibuster in the Senate. In particular, senators from the Midwest and West objected to provisions for reducing the pollution from coal-fired power plants that cause acid rain, contending they would put a heavy burden on industrial and residential customers and hurt the coal industry.
Senator Mitchell repeatedly stated today that he could not have prevented or ended a filibuster without a negotiated agreement. The agreement strikes a middle position between the ambitious cleanup requirements of the Senate bill drafted last fall and the less expensive approach of the legislation proposed by Mr. Bush last summer.
 
Under $21 Billion Yearly
When negotiations started in late January, President Bush said he would not accept legislation that exceeded the costs of his own proposal. Mr. Bush estimated the cost of the Senate bill at $41 billion a year and the annual costs of the Bush proposal at $19 billion a year.
Mr. Porter, the assistant to the President for domestic and economic affairs, who headed the Administration negotiating team, said the package announced today would cost the nation ''under $21 billion'' a year.
''The President is extraordinarily pleased with this agreement,'' Mr. Porter said, adding that the concessions made by the Senate resulted in a bill that would provide important environmental benefits ''in an economically efficient way.'' But in saying the White House might push for additional amendments in the House, Mr. Porter seemed to be reserving the right to further reduce the cost.
 
Serious Problems Remain
The legislation still faces a long and difficult path to enactment.
A number of senators, environmental groups and industry spokesman said today that they had serious problems with provisions of the compromise. Amendments are likely to be introduced and debated at length on the Senate floor. And there are many differences between the today's compromise and the clean air legislation that is before the House committee.
The proposed amendments to the Clean Air Act of 1970 are intended in part to provide new tools for reaching the unachieved goals of the original law. Despite deadlines that were originally described as mandatory, many areas of the country were unable to comply with requirements for reducing urban smog and toxic air pollution, even with repeated extension of deadlines by Congress. The initial deadline for controlling smog in urban areas, for example, was 1975.
Senate negotiators gave ground on several critical points. They agreed to stretch out the first stage of a crackdown on pollution from auto tailpipes, originally scheduled to take effect in 1993, over a three year period ending in 1995. The negotiators also agreed to impose a second round of more stringent restrictions on auto exhausts, scheduled to go into effect in 2003, on a mandatory basis, only if 11 of 27 cities now seriously polluted are still out of compliance with the maximum pollution levels by the end of 2001.
The Administration, which originally strongly opposed a second round of auto emission controls as being too expensive, has now accepted the additional controls on a conditional basis.
 
Los Angeles an Exception
The compromise bill envisions that all cities will come into compliance with the law's anti-smog requirements within 5, 10 or 15 years, depending on the current severity of the problem. An exception is made for Los Angeles, the city with the nation's most polluted air, which would be given 20 years.
Both the Senate and the Administration had proposed that chemical producers be required to install the ''maximum available control technology'' to reduce the volume of toxic gases sent into air. The controls would be installed over the next 2 to 10 years, depending on the chemicals involved.
The Senate also called for mandatory additional controls if, after the original equipment had been installed, people living near the plant were still exposed to a cancer risk of more than 1 in 10,000 over a 70-year lifetime of exposure to the pollutants. The Administration wanted additional controls only if deemed necessary by the Environmental Protection Agency on a case-by-case basis.
The agreement retained the second round of controls based on estimates of risks to human health. But it changed the method by which the risks were calculated in a way that would reduce the number of people protected.
The Senate and Administration were in basic agreement on the goal for acid rain control from the beginning. Both wanted a 10-million-ton reduction in sulfur dioxide emissions from power plants in the Midwest by 2000, with the first reduction coming at a preliminary deadline of 1995. They also called for a ceiling on future pollution from power plants at levels not exceeding emissions in 1980.
Sulfur dioxide, along with nitrogen oxides, are the precursor chemicals of acid rain, which has been found to damage aquatic life and buildings in the Northeast and Canada. Currently more than 20 million tons a of sulfur go into the nation's air each year, 17 million of which come from power plants.
But many senators in the Midwest argued that the cost of reducing sulfur dioxide would place a heavy costs on utilities, which would then be passed on to industrial and residential customers. Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia and other Senators from states that produce coal with a high percentage of sulfur, said they feared that coal miners' jobs would be lost as utilities switched to low-sulfur fuel to meet the new requirements.
Bowing to these concerns, the Senate leaders and the Administration extended the initial deadline to 1997 from 1995 for plants that choose to reduce sulfur dioxide by using scrubbers on high-sulfur fuel rather than switching to low-sulfur coal.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
C.I.A. Says a Gorbachev Removal Is the Sole Threat to Soviet Change

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The Director of Central Intelligence said today that changes in the Soviet Union's political and economic structure had progressed so far that only the removal of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and a forced return to Stalinist-style government could reverse them.
In testimony to the House Armed Services Committee, the director, William H. Webster, acknowledged publicly for the first time that reactionary opponents of Mr. Gorbachev's policies could seek to remove him from office, possibly by force, if the Soviet Union's economy and internal order continue to deteriorate.
Although Mr. Gorbachev's allies have increased their political standing in recent months and he now appears secure in office, the Soviet leader's long-term prospects for remaining in power are uncertain, Mr. Webster said. 
Even if a coup against Mr. Gorbachev were to succeed, he said, the Soviet Union would be so consumed by its internal economic and political difficulties that it would probably pose no increased threat to the United States or Europe. 'Win-Win Situation' for U.S. ''Soviet citizens are increasingly impatient with low living standards, shortages, rising crime, ethnic unrest and other problems,'' Mr. Webster said. ''Labor unrest could intensify this year, raising serious new challenges to central authority and further constraining the economy. Under such circumstances, it is possible that reactionary forces opposed to President Gorbachev's reforms could move to oust him.''
The chairman of the Armed Services Committee, Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, called Mr. Webster's statement ''ground breaking,'' adding that Mr. Webster was almost saying the United States is in ''a win-win situation'' with regard to the Soviets.
Mr. Webster's remarks represent the intelligence agency's view of the Soviet situation and Mr. Gorbachev and, in general, reflect the assessment that the C.I.A. is providing to the White House.
Within the intelligence bureaucracy, however, some experts question whether Mr. Gorbachev is still leading the crusade for internal change, as Mr. Webster's statement suggests, or instead has already moved toward the right to pacify his conservative critics.
 
Little Room for Middle Course
In his most direct public statements on the Soviet changes to date, Mr. Webster said the Soviet political process had become so polarized between advocates of revisions and reactionary opponents that ''it has become clear that a middle course is no longer viable.''
Mr. Webster indicated that he expected the rapid pace of Soviet internal change to continue as long as Mr. Gorbachev remains in power. He also made these points:
* ''A good chance'' now exists that the Baltic states - Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia - will reach agreement with Moscow on a peaceful transition to independence ''during the next few years.''
* Local elections in the 15 Soviet republics this spring ''will probably strengthen the reform process and give additional authority to legislative institutions at the expense of the party.''
* It is highly unlikely that the Soviet Union could reassert its authority over the formerly Communist states in Eastern Europe, in part because such an effort would require military expenditures that the crippled Soviet economy could no longer tolerate.
In the Soviet Union, he said, ''the internal political process there is tending toward a polarization between those demanding retrenchment and others who seek more radical reforms.''

HEADLINE: Asian Population in U.S. Grew by 70% in the 80's

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
A sustained wave of Asian immigration in the past decade fueled a 70 percent increase in the Asian population of the United States from 1980 to 1988, said a report made public today by the Census Bureau.
The bureau reported that the Asian population grew nearly seven times as fast as the general population and three times as fast as the black population. Asian Americans numbered about 6.5 million on July 1, 1988, up from 3.8 million eight years earlier, the report said.
The increase changed the political and social landscape of California, where more than one-third of those from Asia and the Pacific islands settled. The rise is largely due to the influx from the Philippines, China, South Korea and India, said officials of the bureau and of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. 
Asians and Pacific Islanders are in a heterogeneous category, the officials said. Many are native Americans who trace their descent to China, Korea, Vietnam, Cambodia, Japan, the Philippines and Micronesia. Some trace their origins to the Indian subcontinent.
 
Combining of Statistics
The figures in the census report are extrapolated from data derived from the 1980 census, during which those who participated with the census-takers classified themselves a white, black, Asian or American Indian and, if necessary, Hispanic.
These figures were then combined with the Federal Government's annual birth and death statistics and with immigration and emigration data from the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Census demographers assigned racial categories to the immigrants of the 80's based on the way earlier immigrants from the same countries identified themselves in the census. For instance, if 95 percent of the Cambodians called themselves Asians, 95 percent of subsequent Cambodian immigrants would be considered Asian. Soviet immigrants, for the purpose of the report, were considered white.
The Census Bureau, for the purposes of this study, considered all Soviet emigres white. Under Soviet emigration law, the only ethnic groups allowed to leave the country in the 1980's were Jews, Armenians and ethnic Germans, all of whom would have been considered white by the Census Bureau.
Although some individuals will be included in a given category incorrectly, the overall estimates using this inference are statistically sound, experts said. At least 80 percent of the Asian immigrants of the past eight years were from China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, the Philippines, Japan, South Korea, Micronesia and the subcontinent.
 
'It's an Unusual Migration'
The 1980's Asians, for the most part, have far higher professional and educational qualifications than most earlier groups, one expert says.
''It's an unusual migration - I don't think there's been anything like it in our history,'' said Ronald Takaki, the author of ''Strangers from a Different Shore,'' a book about Asian immigration published last year by Little, Brown & Company.
''People in earlier migrations were squeezed out of economies in transition from agriculture to industry,'' Mr. Takaki said. ''What's happenning today is that, while you do find accelerated modernization in Korea, India and the Philippines, it is not fast enough to accommodate a large new class of professional workers.''
Mr. Takaki, who is also a professor of Asian-American studies at the University of California at Berkeley, said these immigrants tend to choose the United States, in part, because its policies favor skilled applicants.
 
Factor of Reuniting Families
But Michael Hoefer, chief of demographic statistics for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said most immigrants in the 1980's were admitted under ''family reunification'' priorities. Preference was given to applicants with relatives in the United States.
Annual Asian immigration figures ranged from 268,000 to 281,000 in the latter part of the 1980's, and the Philippines, with an average of 50,000 immigrants annually from 1985 through 1989, was the leading source of Asian and Pacific Island immigrants. The combined annual figures for China, Taiwan and Hong Kong in the same period averaged more than 40,000 from 1985 to 1989.
Mr. Hoefer said he expected the rates of Asian immigration to remain high. Since 1975, from 40 percent to 45 percent of all immigrants have come from Asian countries, including Iran and the Middle East.
The Census Bureau report, by a demographer, Frederick W. Hollmann, is the first to offer statistics on Asians and Pacific Islanders out of a general ''other'' category including American Indians, Aleuts and Eskimos.
The report says that in addition to 6.5 million Asian Americans, there are 30.5 million blacks and 20 million people of Hispanic descent in the total United States population of 247.6 million.
The increase in the black population, about 1.8 percent a year in the 1980's, was ''fueled by a higher fertility rate than that of the general population,'' the report said. There was, however, some immigration from Haiti, Jamaica and African countries like Nigeria in that period, according to Mr. Hollmann.
Immigration and natural growth were equally responsible for the increase in the Hispanic population, which grew at an average annual rate of about 3.4 percent annually from 1980 to 1988, according to the census report.
By comparison, the white population of the country has been growing at a rate of about 0.7 percent annually, a significantly lower rate than any of the minorities.
Mr. Hollmann said he was not sure how long the numbers of Asians and Pacific Islanders could continue to grow at the current rate, in part because it will take larger and larger numbers of new immigrants or a higher fertility rate simply to maintain the rate.
 
Concentration in California
More of this country's Asian and Pacific Islander population is centered in California. The Los Angeles suburb of Monterey Park has become a Chinese enclave, Filipinos are one of the largest minorities in Daly City, outside San Francisco. As of 1985, David Ward, a bureau demographer, estimated that more than a fourth of San Francisco's population was either Asian, Pacific Island or American Indian descent.
In Manhattan and Queens, New York City, in 1985, about 7 percent of the population was of Asian, Pacific Islander or American Indian descent; in Brooklyn and the Bronx the percentage was from 2 percent to 3.5 percent.

HEADLINE: Chronology of Seabrook: Plans, Protests, Building

 BODY:

1966: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire tentatively decides to build a nuclear power plant, among the first in New England, in Newington, N.H. The Atomic Energy Commission says the site is too near Pease Air Force Base.
January 1972: The company decides to build twin reactors at Seabrook, at a cost of $973 million. The first unit is scheduled for completion in November 1979, the second in November 1981. 
January 1974: Massachusetts begins legal action to block construction, arguing that emergency evacuation would be impossible. But the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, successor to the Atomic Energy Commission, rules that emergency planning need not be considered until the builders seek an operating license, after the plant has been built.
July 1976: Construction begins. Sixteen utilities and utility groups agree to pay for half the project in return for half the electricity generated.
May 1977: In the largest of many illegal protests at Seabrook, 2,000 demonstrators cut through barbed wire and camp on Public Service property for two days. Fourteen hundred are arrested.
PUB-DATE: March 30, 1984:
July 1986: Construction of Unit 1 is completed.
Sept. 20, 1986: After the Chernobyl accident in the Soviet Union, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts announces that his state will not submit an emergency evacuation plan.
October 1986: Technicians complete loading 100 tons of uranium fuel, but cannot begin low-power testing because no license has been issued.
Nov. 26, 1986: Maine and Vermont utilities, under orders from state regulators, sell their shares of Seabrook.
PUB-DATE: May 22, 1987:
Jan. 26, 1988: The New Hampshire Supreme Court, rejecting Public Service's request for a 15 percent emergency rate increase, upholds the 1978 law barring rate increases for work in progress.
Jan. 28, 1988: Public Service files for bankruptcy, becoming the first investor-owned electric utility to do so since the Depression. Its Seabrook investment has reached $2.1 billion. The filing leads some creditors to plan takeover bids.
PUB-DATE: June 28, 1988:
Nov. 18, 1988: President Ronald Reagan issues an executive order allowing the Federal Government to draft emergency plans for nuclear plants if local officials refuse.
Dec. 30, 1988: An N.R.C. panel endorses an emergency evacuation plan written by the utilities that own Seabrook.
PUB-DATE: May 19, 1989:
PUB-DATE: June 13, 1989:
PUB-DATE: June 23, 1989:
Nov. 9, 1989: An administrative panel of the commission approves a plan by the utility for the evacuation of the six Massachusetts towns within 10 miles of Seabrook.
Nov. 18, 1989: Northeast Utilities, of Berlin, Conn., prevails in the bidding for Public Service, offering $2.3 billion.
Nov. 20, 1989: The five members of the N.R.C. vote that they, rather than administrative law judges, will make all the remaining license questions, setting the stage for approval.
Dec. 15, 1989: The New Hampshire Legislature, in its first special session since 1966, approves the takeover of Public Service.

HEADLINE: Ben Hill Griffin Jr., 79, Is Dead; Leader in Florida Citrus Industry

BYLINE: By ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ

 BODY:
Ben Hill Griffin Jr., a major figure in the Florida citrus industry, died yesterday at his home in Avon Park, Fla., after a long illness. He was 79 years old.
Mr. Griffin was chairman and president of Ben Hill Griffin, Inc., one of the largest citrus producers in Florida, with 10,000 acres of citrus groves and 85,000 acres of ranch and timberland in central Florida, where Avon Park is situated. 
He was also chief executive and a major stockholder of Alico, Inc., a publicly held company that controls more than 175,000 acres of citrus groves, grazing land, oil and mineral deposits and timber. From 1958 to 1981 he was also a major producer of orange juice concentrate, including Orange Nip, his regional brand.
He became a millionaire in 1962 when his groves escaped a freeze that destroyed more than a million orange trees and caused the price of concentrate to jump to 65 cents a pound from 25 cents.
Over the years Mr. Griffin's interests also included a fruit-packing house, a canned-juice operation, a bank, a car dealership, a fertilizer plant, a country club and a 15,000-acre ranch with about 25,000 cattle. Forbes magazine listed him among its 400 richest Americans, citing him in 1989 as 261st, with estimated assets of $390 million.
''It doesn't affect my ego a damn bit,'' he said in a 1982 interview when asked about being on the Forbes list. ''There are people who would give $10,000 to get on that list. I wouldn't give 2 cents. I wouldn't give 1 cent.''
 
Started With 10 Acres
Mr. Griffin began his business empire in 1933, after studying agriculture at the University of Florida. His father gave him 10 acres of orange groves as a wedding present. Through hard work, business acumen and the seizing of opportunities, he became one of the five largest growers in Florida.
One opportunity came in 1958 when the Justice Department, acting in an antitrust case, ordered Minute Maid to divest itself of some holdings in the orange juice industry. Mr. Griffin agreed to buy a juice processing plant for $1 million, if Minute Maid financed the deal and added a packinghouse.
He was a major benefactor of the University of Florida, endowing a chair of agricultural economic marketing and establishing a citrus research and education center. The university named the stadium at its athletic field in his honor.
He was also a member of the major citrus industry organizations.
A conservative Democrat, Mr. Griffin served in the Florida Legislature for 12 years, 8 in the House and 4 in the Senate. In 1974 he ran unsuccessfully for Governor.
He is survived by his wife, Eleanor; a son, Ben Hill Griffin 3d of Frostproof, Fla.; four daughters, Harriett Harris of Bartow, Fla., Sarah Jane Alexander and Lucy Anne Collier, both of Frostproof, and Francie Milligan of Marseilles, France; a stepdaughter, Julie Chapman of Avon Park; a sister, Naomi Drane of Sebring, Fla.; 16 grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: photo: Ben Hill Griffin Jr. (NYT)

HEADLINE: Killing Cocaine at the Source

 BODY:
What, fight drugs at the source? The very idea has prompted ridicule among many Americans who believe it simply can't work. But suddenly there's mounting reason to believe that the idea is right and the ridicule is uninformed.
Colombia's ongoing campaign against drug traffickers warrants increasing respect. And now Bolivia adds heartening evidence for the effectiveness of tough law enforcement combined with economic incentives. 
To be sure, the State Department's latest annual report on narcotics trafficking concludes, depressingly, that drug production and sales are up around the world; it mentions, among other things, past problems of corruption in Bolivia. But new data document a startling fact: The Bolivian market for coca leaves has collapsed. That means getting the Andean countries out of the drug business is a plausible goal.
In the 1980's, Bolivian dirt farmers and tin miners flocked by the thousands to the Chapare region, where they found it easy to grow coca. At harvest time, agents of drug cartels would buy the leaves and haul them away. A hundred pounds that cost about $30 to grow sold for up to $200. By last year, so many people were growing coca that the price sank to about $60. But that still provided a fine living for people used to a few hundred dollars' income a year.
The Bolivian Government, with U.S. backing, began offering the growers $2,000 per hectare to tear out coca and plant something else. But with the price of raw leaf holding up, the program sputtered. Growers eradicated only 200 hectares a month for most of last year.
Then last summer the Colombians began their offensive against drug trafficking, and in late fall, a new Administration in Bolivia stepped up its own campaign of disruption. With the cocaine market in chaos, the middlemen stopped buying raw leaves and the price plunged to $12 per 100 pounds.
Suddenly the substitution program looked more attractive. In December growers cashed in about 600 hectares, in January about 700, and the figure for February should exceed 800.
That's a significant start, but to make the gain permanent will take a larger investment. At $2,000 per hectare, it would cost $80 million to eradicate Bolivia's 40,000 hectares of coca. And success with substitute crops will inevitably require investments in roads and development aid.
While the Bush Administration acknowledges the need, Bolivia will receive only about $20 million this year. More money won't begin to flow before fall. But coca market economics won't wait. Thus Senator Joseph Biden plans to introduce legislation calling for $125 million in emergency economic aid for the Andean countries this fiscal year.
That's a sound idea. When Andean coca farmers, like U.S. drug addicts, demonstrate a strong motivation to reform, it's in every American's interest to help.

HEADLINE: LAW;
Non-Lawyers to Be Partners In Firms in Nation's Capital

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The District of Columbia Court of Appeals adopted a rule today that will allow non-lawyers to become partners in Washington law firms, the first time that will be permitted anywhere in the nation.
The rule, which will take effect in January, comes after years of debate on the subject in many states and before such forums as the American Bar Association. It was drawn as narrowly as possible in response to the concerns of some lawyers about its potential effect, supporters of the rule say. 
The rule will require that non-lawyer partners be involved only in helping a lawyer deliver legal services. For example, an economist could help work on antitrust cases.
A firm's lawyers will be responsible for seeing that non-lawyers adhere to legal ethics rules.
 
No Outside Partners Allowed
Under the rule, investors who do not work in a law firm will not be allowed to become part-owners, a concern that has figured largely in the debates, said Robert E. Jordan 3d, a partner in the Washington firm of Steptoe & Johnson. Mr. Jordan, a former president of the District of Columbia Bar Association, was instrumental in promoting the change.
The new rule was formulated by the local bar association but required approval by the District of Columbia Court of Appeals, which serves as a kind of state supreme court for the District. In most jurisdictions, the highest court is the final arbiter of legal codes of professional responsibility.
A far broader proposal was rejected by the American Bar Association in 1983 when opponents voiced fears that law firms would become like variety stores, diluting their legal specialization.
In the last decade, many law firms have expanded beyond legal practice to offer services like lobbying and economic and investment counseling. Because they could not offer partnerships to lobbyists or economists, many law firms have spun off subsidiaries.
 
Firms With Subsidiaries
Arnold & Porter, for example, Washington's largest law firm, with 340 lawyers, now has three subsidiaries. These includes APCO Associates, which offers lobbying, public relations and market research services.
James Jones, Arnold & Porter's managing partner, said the subsidiaries were started partly in response to the inability to have non-lawyers as partners of the firm. But because the new rule is so tightly drawn, he said, it will have little effect on the way his firm does business, and Arnold & Porter will still need to have subsidiaries.
''If you have a non-lawyer professional who is really top-rate, that person is not going to be willing to accept the restriction that he devote himself only to legal services,'' Mr. Jones said.
Mr. Jones said the law might be used to allow firms to attract senior administrators and managers.

HEADLINE: WEEKENDER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:

Friday
 
FELINE PULCHRITUDE
Some 30,000 cat lovers and more than 1,000 of the objects of their affection are expected to crowd into Madison Square Garden this weekend for America's largest annual cat show. The sixth International Cat Show will feature representatives of about 42 breeds competing for ribbons, trophies and other accolades at this 15-ring feline beauty pageant. New breeds include the Wyoming (or Selkirk) Rex, the California Spangled Cat, the Snowshoe and the Nibelung. Veterinarians, animal behaviorists and other cat experts, including the author Cleveland Amory, will speak about nutrition, grooming, health and ''pet-assisted therapy.'' A ''cat supermarket'' will comprise scores of vendors selling and giving away cat food, clothing and other items. The show will culminate in several cat-of-the-year awards ceremonies on Sunday afternoon. Large projections of the competing cats can be seen on six-foot viewing screens next to the stage. Hours today are 3 to 9 P.M.; tomorrow and Sunday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is $8 today, $12 tomorrow, $14 on Sunday, and $22 for a combination Saturday-Sunday ticket; for children and the elderly, admission is $4 today and $5 tomorrow or Sunday. The box office is on Seventh Avenue near 32d Street. Information: 563-8300. 
 
Saturday
 
BELATED BIRTHDAY PARTY
The Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts, a three-theater complex at Brooklyn College, is belatedly celebrating its 35th anniversary this weekend and next with several performances. The center - which offers about 300 performances a year in its theaters, the 2,500-seat Whitman Hall, the 500-seat Gershwin Theater and the 165-seat Sam Levenson Recital Hall - was actually dedicated in 1954. The birthday party will include an all-Gershwin concert on Saturday at 8 P.M., featuring the pianist Peter Nero and the Orchestra of the Center for the Performing Arts playing ''An American in Paris,'' ''Rhapsody in Blue,'' selections from ''Porgy and Bess'' and other works. Tickets are $20, $25 and $35. Other events in the coming week include the actor F. Murray Abraham performing scenes from ''Hamlet,'' ''Cyrano de Bergerac'' and other plays, Thursday at 8 P.M. (tickets are $25); a concert of music, dance and theater by students of the Preparatory Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, on March 10 at 3 P.M. (tickets are $10), and a performance of three dance works that had their premieres at the center, featuring the Brooklyn Dance Theater, Dance/ June Lewis and the Brooklyn College Conservatory Orchestra conducted by Tania Leon, on March 11 at 2 P.M. (tickets are $10). The center is at Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, near the Flatbush Avenue station of the IRT No. 2 subway. Reservations: (718) 434-2222.
 
CHINA'S ENVIRONMENT
Environmental issues are crucial to understanding traditional Chinese culture and the problems now facing a country with nearly one-fourth of the world's population. The complex web of ecology, economics and culture in China will be the subject of a symposium, performances and film presented by the China Institute in America on Saturday at Florence Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street. The daylong program, called ''The Chinese Earth,'' will begin at 9 A.M., and will include lectures on such disparate subjects as the mystique of the earth in Chinese thought; the connection between land and water use in Imperial China and class relationships, and China's responses to pollution. There will also be a concert of Chinese folk music by the Chinese Music Ensemble of New York at 2 P.M. The evening program, at 8, includes a commissioned dance called ''Ways, Shrines, Mysteries'' by Muna Tseng, with music by Mieczyslaw Litwinski and sets by Tobi Kahn, a painter and sculptor, and a screening of ''Yellow Earth,'' a 1984 feature film about a poor Chinese family struggling to survive in a drought-plagued environment. Admission is $40 ($20 for students) for the daytime portion, and $10 for the evening dance and film program. Reservations: 744-8181.
 
INDEPENDENT CINEMA
The Brooklyn Arts Council will show about 50 of the best new independently produced films and videos from throughout North America, Europe and Japan during the 23d annual BACA Film and Video Festival, which will be held at seven different locations during the next five weeks. A dozen or so animated works, comedies, dramas and documentaries will be shown during eight free marathon programs, at Jefferson Market Library (425 Avenue of the Americas, at Eighth Street, in Greenwich Village), Saturday and March 10 from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Millennium Film Workshop (66 East Fourth Street in Manhattan), March 15 from 8 to 11 P.M.; Brooklyn College (Plaza Building, at Bedford Avenue near Campus Road in the Flatbush section), March 26 from 11 A.M. to 1:30 P.M.; Anthology Film Archives (32-34 Second Avenue, at Second Street, in Manhattan), March 26 from 7 to 10 P.M.; the Metropolitan Museum of Art, March 31 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M.; the Brooklyn Central Library (at Grand Army Plaza), April 1 from 1 to 4 P.M., and at BACA Downtown (111 Willoughby Street, in Downtown Brooklyn), April 8 from noon to 5 P.M. Information: (718) 783-3077 or (718) 783-4469.
 
SITE-SPECIFIC DANCE
The choreographer Susan Marshall will bring her company to the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center, on West Street south of Vesey Street in Battery Park City, on Saturday, Sunday and Monday at 8 P.M. for the premiere of her work ''Articles of Faith.'' Ms. Marshall has described the 40-minute site-specific work as exploring the tension between individual freedom and society. The piece, commissioned by the Financial Center's Arts and Events Program, is also said to incorporate the 16 tall palm trees inside the glass-enclosed Winter Garden. Admission is free. Information: 945-0505.
 
Sunday
 
ISRAEL FILM FESTIVAL
The Palestinian uprising in occupied territories and the Palestinian exile community in West Berlin are the backdrops for a politically charged friendship between an Israeli Jew and a Palestinian Arab in Judd Ne'eman's film ''Streets of Yesterday.'' This thriller will have its New York premiere on Sunday at 7:30 P.M., and will open the annual Lens on Israel Film Festival at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue. Neil Livingstone, an expert on terrorism and author of ''Inside the P.L.O.,'' will speak after the movie. The festival's four subsequent programs - all at 7:30 P.M., and all moderated by Eric Goldman, a distributor who specializes in Jewish films and videos -include ''Peeping Toms'' on March 11, ''The Big Dig (or the Blaumilch Canal)'' on March 18 and ''Fictitious Marriage'' and ''That's Not Me'' on April 1; the May 13 program is to be announced. Single tickets are $8, and subscriptions are $35. Information: 996-1100.
 
ON THEIR TOES, ON SCREEN
Sixteen films and videos about dance and dancers - from Dame Margot Fonteyn and Isadora Duncan to Armenian folk dancers and contemporary experimental works -will be presented on Sunday from noon to 5 P.M. at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street. Highlights of this ''Dance on Camera 1990 Festival'' include a biography of Dame Margot at 1 P.M., of Bronislava Nijinska at 3:35 P.M. and of Duncan at 4 P.M. There will also be films marking the 50th anniversary of Britain's Royal Ballet at noon, documentaries on ballroom dancing at 2:50 P.M. and two Armenian-American dance companies at 2:58 P.M. and works about such choreographers as Margaret Jenkins (12:48 P.M.), Merce Cunningham (1:28 P.M.), and Bella Lewitzky (2:30 P.M.). Screenings will be in the first-floor Kaufmann and Linder Theaters. The festival is free with museum admission, which is $4 ($2 for children). Information: 769-5305.

HEADLINE: Rap's Trip To a New And Surreal Territory

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS

 BODY:
Tonight at the Ritz, the Next New Thing in Pop Music, subchapter hip-hop, will make its appearance. Three rap groups - Third Bass, a duo of white New Yorkers who have the highest-ranking rap album on the black charts; the Jungle Brothers, whose newest record, ''Done by the Forces of Nature,'' is one of the best new rap albums, and a Tribe Called Quest, whose single ''I Left My Wallet in El Segundo'' is a surreal underground favorite - will try to make a claim for themselves on the stage.
But instead of the standard-issue self-aggrandizement of many rap acts, the three bands plan to bring something new and less single-minded to their audience.
With the huge success of the group De La Soul last year allowing for eccentricity and individuality in rap, hip-hop's vanguard has moved into richer, more detailed territory, using humor, surrealism, politics, more intricate and literate wordplay, and even more arcane and nonsensical sampling to construct records. 
Hip-hop has become a repository for nearly all recorded information. The form is capable of absorbing almost anything: a hip-hop album will use a message left on a rapper's answering machine, dialogue from B movies, classical-guitar strumming, excerpts from spoken-word albums, bass lines from a Parliament-Funkadelic album and music borrowed from just about every other source. It is the reproduction of the world, but on vinyl and under the ordering of a coherent mind. And in the similarities between groups, there is the mark of a movement.
 
'We Like to Sample'
''I see a lot of similarities between us and De La Soul and the Jungle Brothers,'' said Pete Nice of Third Bass. ''When De La Soul's record came out, our record was done and they had used a lot of the samples that we had used. It surprised me. But it makes sense, because we like to sample from things that are really out there.
''The rhymes and the word structures and patterns are more complicated now as well; we're all trying to be more ambiguous, so that a listener has to dig in more to get more out of it.''
Q-tip of a Tribe Called Quest said he agreed. ''Yeah, it's new,'' he said. ''We're known as trying to interject a new flavor alternative to the music. We don't just want to hit the hard-core crowd; we want to hit Middle America as well. Digital Underground, Third Bass, De La Soul, the Jungle Brothers: they're part of the genre. It's changing because everybody needs something different to break the monotony.
''Rap is a good medium; a million and one kids with a million and one ideas want an expression that they can use.''
The Jungle Brothers and a Tribe Called Quest are part of a loose coalition of rap performers with similar ideas about culture and politics. That association, called Native Tongues, includes Queen Latifah, Monie Love, De La Soul and Karen Wheeler.
''The whole thing just clicked about two years ago when we were touring with Latifah,'' said Mike G from the Jungle Brothers. ''We realized that we had a lot in common, shared the same thoughts about being ourselves and expressing it in our way and doing our own thing. We're all family.
''Other groups want to be like Big Daddy Kane or Heavy D, but deep down we all realize that what it is about yourselves that makes you an individual is important. And we're different because we weren't raised to be loud, and we're not for material values. We're for mental power instead.''
 
Race and Rap
Black nationalism and Afro-centric thinking has seemingly left out the white rap duo Third Bass. But the band, which is headlining the show at the Ritz, is respected by most rap performers, and it has produced music that is idiomatically accurate. More important, Third Bass's record is selling big in the black community. The duo's success and the integrity of its music point out that race in America is an endlessly complicated issue.
''Obviously, despite the similarities between us and the other groups, there are lots of differences,'' said Pete Nice of Third Bass. ''The Jungle Brothers have a more militant and Afro-centric approach, while De La Soul is just bugged out. We're white and harder than De La Soul, which I think is a reaction. We have different things to say. We've grown up differently.
''They grew up in different place, and while we've been heavily influenced by black culture - it's in our song 'Product of the Environment' -all these things have an effect.''
Among other things, the duo is actively political and anti-racist, putting it in the mainstream of the new movement. Though it is almost a novelty record, the band's newest hit, ''The Gas Face,'' is political. ''This kid Doom was saying 'gas face' all the time when he was talking about being dissed,'' Pete Nice said. ''He kept on saying it, and everybody we were hanging around with started saying it. So I decided we should do a record about it. My verse talks about record companies exploiting us, and we talk about how evil racial stereotypes can be when things like black cats are signs for bad things and the word 'black' is defined as dirty in Webster's.
''And we haven't had it easy, and neither has our black deejay, Richie Rich. When the three of us go into a store, security follows him around, and not us. Not too many white people have come straight out and said in pop music that whites are, in essence as the majority, pretty racist. It's not being said on a record. So it's important that we are saying what we are saying.''
 
A Showier Setting
That the concert is being held at the Ritz, hardly a bastion of black youth culture, is also an indication that things may be changing for rap. For the last several years, rap bills have been virtually banned from stages in urban centers all across the country. Fear of violence has made producers wary of booking rap acts. As usual, the economic consequences are felt esthetically.
Rap shows are notoriously threadbare, with little concern given to visual or performance values. Rap acts, used to playing in small clubs with little time or money, have suffered. But Third Bass puts on a good show, and a Tribe Called Quest says it intends to try.
''We're going to come out with black capes that I made, which will freak the audience out,'' Q-tip of the Tribe said. ''Then music drops. I can't tell you what will happen after that, except that we'll be wearing Afro-centric garments. We definitely have a big show, and it won't be violent. The type of people who will come aren't about violence: they're into listening and having a good time. People will be there with notes and pencils, taking down what we have to say.
''People are still throwing rocks at us: people like Peter Townshend and Wynton Marsalis. I can't figure it out. Townshend wrote 'My Generation' because people downed rock-and-roll, and now he's doing it to us. It doesn't matter, because they're going out like suckers.''
Show time at the Ritz (254 West 54th Street near Broadway) is at 9 P.M.; tickets are $17.50. Information: 956-3731.

HEADLINE: Bush Seeks Japan Shift On Imports

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
When leaders of the two biggest economic powers meet during the weekend in Palm Springs, Calif., the United States will offer a closer global economic partnership but insist that Japan slash import barriers, Administration officials said today.
Japanese officials in Washington and Tokyo said they did not expect Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu to make any commitments.
The officials also said they feared that American demands for rapid action on trade issues could undermine the chances of Japanese concessions down the road and that high expectations for the talks could backfire. [Page D6.] Lowered Expectations ''I find it difficult to think that something specific will come out of this meeting,'' a senior Japanese official said. 
Although Mr. Kaifu's plans were said to be subject to last-minute change, Japanese officials here said today that they did not expect a Cabinet-level trade officer to accompany him - an indication that the Japanese expect the meeting to deal with broader global issues rather than the nitty-gritty of trade.
President Bush is taking the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, and Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher with him to Palm Springs.
One Administration official said Mr. Bush's short-term goal was to send a clear signal to the bureacucracies of both nations to settle trade issues quickly.
 
Bush Takes Initiative
Usually, Japanese prime ministers request meetings with American Presidents. This time it was President Bush who took the initiative, proposing the meeting with Prime Minister Kaifu less than two weeks after the Japanese leader's party retained power in parliamentary elections.
The White House is being forced to pursue the Japanese issues vigorously because, unlike the situation in other trade conflicts of the last decade, the President faces a series of deadlines imposed by Congress. The Administration must decide in the next few months whether to impose sanctions on Japan, and the 1988 Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act allows it less discretion in such decisions than it had in the past.
By inviting Mr. Kaifu on such short notice, the President has given a signal that he intends to be forceful on the trade issue, if only to deflect some heat from Congress.
In the past, meetings of Japanese and American leaders have not yielded breakthroughs. In light of the opening position taken by Tokyo, the weekend meeting may be little more productive. The White House has tried to lower expectations by insisting that the meeting, the second between Mr. Kaifu and Mr. Bush, is not intended for decision making, but for general talk about the relationship between the two nations.
 
The President's Goal
While Mr. Bush and Mr. Kaifu will hardly discuss technical differences over wood-product tariffs or Japanese reluctance to buy American satellites, Mr. Bush is seeking a political commitment that would shift Japan from an export superpower to a leading importer.
''It's like arms control negotiations with the Soviet Union,'' a senior American official said. ''There's the need to get the political level engaged before progress can be made at the technical level.''
What Mr. Bush is seeking, as one White House official put it, is ''broad, conceptual, forward-looking'' talks about where the Japanese-American relationship is headed.
 
Full Opening Sought
But an expanding relationship, in the Administration view, requires a full opening of the Japanese market.
The weekend meeting comes as public opinion polls show that most Americans consider Japan a greater threat to security than the Soviet Union. On Capitol Hill, tensions were heightened by last year's debate over letting Japan have military aircraft technology that it might use to develop a commercial aviation industry.
And in Japan, attitudes about the United States are hardening. If the United States imposes trade sanctions, some people have suggested, Japan should retaliate by cutting back on its purchases of Treasury securities, which finance the Federal debt.
In Washington's view, the trade frictions arise from the failure of American exports to Japan to reach the levels they would in an unfettered market.
The problem with Japan is compounded by the existence of both a protected Japanese market and the popularity of Japanese products in the United States. Last year imports from Japan rose by 13 percent, compared with 7.3 percent from all countries. From Germany, imports actually fell by 5.8 percent.
 
A Number of Fields
But if the trade problems can be dealt with, American officials see a bright future of strengthened cooperation in a number of fields, including the military, technology, international peacekeeping, overseas development assistance, environmental protection, the war against drugs and aid to fledgling Eastern European democracies.
''The time has come for Japan to translate its domestic and regional successes more fully into a broader international role with increased responsibility,'' Secretary of State Baker said in one recent speech.
The call for deeper cooperation is bipartisan. Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, envisons what he calls an ''Amerippon'' arrangement that would involve coordination of foreign policy and international economic decision making, more industrial collaboration and eventually even a common consumer market across the Pacific, without restrictions.
''If Japan and the U.S. can't agree now, I don't know when they will,'' added Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee's trade subcommittee.
