HEADLINE: New England Bank Signs Lending Pact

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Bank of New England Corporation, which lost more than $1.1 billion last year, said yesterday that it had signed agreements with Federal banking regulators that describe in unusual detail how it will improve its lending procedures and seek to recover its financial health.
The agreements, called cease and desist orders, were proposed by officials of the Federal Reserve and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, a part of the Treausry Department that regulates national chartered banks. Although several dozen of the agreements are arranged each year, the Bank of New England's problems were severe enough that the agreements were much more detailed than normal.
Most of the bank's losses stemmed from real estate loans that soured as property values in New England flattened last year after years of growth. 
Ellen Stockdale, a spokeswoman for the Office of the Comptroller, said the 35-page agreement ''does not give us the authority to take business decisions away'' from the Bank of New England. ''The fact that it is more detailed than some others just reflects the suggestions we have to help them,'' she said.
H. Ridgely Bullock, acting chairman of the banking company, described the agreements as a ''partnership with Federal regulators'' that will strengthen the bank, mostly from bad real estate loans, Over the last two months the company has sold its credit card and leasing businesses, and has plans to sell other assets, including $1.3 billion of home equity loans, $900 million of loans to communications companies, $900 million of asset-backed loans to borrowers outside New England and $3 billion of commercial loans.
Mr. Bullock said discussions were under way to sell the Bank of New England Corporation's subsidiary banks in Maine and Rhode Island, ''which do not fit our strategic plan.'' But there are currently no discussions for the sale of the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, the second-largest bank in the company and the No. 2 bank in that state.
Some of the requirements in the agreement, such as improved procedures to limit lending risks by evaluating borrowers and using improved real estate appraisals, are part of approved practices described in the Comptroller's handbook for national bank examiners. Others, like a review of every officer in the bank with the rank of senior vice president or higher, are a consequence of special management problems Federal regulators found at the bank.
To rebuild shareholder capital, the money that serves as a cushion for future losses, the agreement with regulators bars the payment of dividends on common or preferred stock until the Fed approves. The company promised to increase its capital and reduce its assets by the end of May so that capital equals 3 percent of assets, rising to 5 percent of assets by the end of 1991. At mid-February, the company had more than $600 million of equity, or roughly 2.5 percent of its $26 billion of assets.
Other parts of the agreement with the Comptroller's office require the company to keep close track of its large deposits and compile a list of all assets it might sell.
Because the company had canceled its January common stock dividend and is operating with inadequate capital, analysts were not surprised by the company's statement that it does not expect to pay dividends ''for some time.'' Bank of New England stock fell 37.5 cents yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $4.50 a share.
''They have a fighting chance of survival, but they cannot afford further deterioration in the New England economy,'' said Dan Kauth, an analyst at the First Albany Corporation, a securities firm. To satisfy regulators' capital standards, Mr. Kauth said that ''some of the subsidiary banks will have to be sold.''
In addition to the Bank of New England, based in Boston, which recently absorbed other subsidiary banks in the region, the company has a subsidiary bank in western Massachusetts, as well as those in Maine, Rhode Island and Connecticut.
Warren L. Dennis, a partner at the law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn of Washington, noted that detailed agreements like the one regulators forced the Bank of New England to sign, ''can be a way for regulators to impose more control over a bank, without going so far as to put the bank in receivership or conservatorship.''

LENGTH: 1224 words

HEADLINE: A 'Baby Bell' Outgrows Its Siblings

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
The Pacific Telesis Group, which was considered one of the weakest of the seven regional Bell companies after the Bell system breakup six years ago, is emerging as perhaps the strongest.
The company, parent of Pacific Bell in California and Nevada Bell, is benefiting from a robust California economy and an aggressive diversification strategy that has paid off in several overseas contracts in recent months, including a huge one to build West Germany's first private cellular telephone system.
Pacific Telesis, which had revenues of $9.59 billion last year, has also been helped by regulatory changes in California over the last few years, particularly the state's recent adoption of a new regulation that removes the cap on profits the company can make, encouraging it to cut costs.
Pacific Telesis has wasted little time in exploiting the new regulation: In January the company announced that it would eliminate 11,000 jobs, or 16 percent of its work force, in the next five years to reduce overhead. 
At the time of divestiture in 1984, Pacific Telesis was the financial runt of the ''Baby Bell'' litter. It was assigned a higher amount of Ma Bell's debt relative to its equity than the other regional companies, its network contained old equipment that was costly to operate and California had one of the strictest regulatory structures in the nation. But the debt was substantially paid down, the equipment improved and California eased it regulations.
Pacific Telesis's success is apparent in a number of important industry measurements. From 1985 through 1989, the company's net income increased 7.8 percent, compared with an average of 5 percent for all seven regional companies. The company now has the highest growth in new telephone lines among the Baby Bells, and earns more from each of those lines than any of the other regional Bells.
In addition, the number of phone lines in Pacific Telesis's service area increased by 4.3 percent last year, to 13.4 million, compared with an average increase of 3 percent for all the Baby Bells. And the company earned an estimated $185 per line in service last year, compared with an average of $165 for the seven regional companies. Its operating margin on a per-line basis was 26.3 percent last year, second only to the St. Louis-based Southwestern Bell Corporation, which had a per-line margin of 27.3 percent.
Pacific Telesis's stock has performed especially well since the Bell System breakup. Shares of Pacific Telesis have risen 213 percent since 1984, compared with an average of 167 percent for the other Baby Bells. [Pacific Telesis shares closed at $44.625 on the New York Stock Exchange Thursday, up 50 cents.] ''Pacific Telesis is the best combination of everything you would want - liberal regulation, a high-growth region, top-notch management, and successful non-telephone businesses,'' said Frank J. Governali, a telecommunications analyst with the First Boston Corporation. ''No other Baby Bell has all these things going for it.''
 
Clouds in the Short Term
For the short term, however, Pacific Telesis's outlook is not as bright. The company's earnings are expected to be significantly reduced by the higher capital spending necessary for ventures overseas and by a $391 million refund that the company must provide customers as part of the new California profit-incentive regulation. In addition, some analysts are concerned that a recession or further cuts in military spending - a major contributor to California's economy - could slow growth.
Sam Ginn, Pacific Telesis's chairman and chief executive, has said that 1990 will not be ''a strong year of growth for earnings-per-share'' because of rate reductions mandated in the new regulatory framework, higher labor costs and increased capital investments.
''We are no longer talking about where we want to go in terms of regulation and international expansion -we are already there,'' Mr. Ginn said in a recent interview. ''It's just a matter of continuing to grow these businesses.''
Among those businesses is mobile cellular telephones, where Pacific Telesis has been among the most successful of the Baby Bells. It quickly acquired cellular franchises in high-growth markets like Los Angeles, San Francisco and San Diego, and became the first regional telephone company to report a profit from its cellular operations.
Pactel Cellular, which is the nation's fourth-largest cellular company, had 381,000 subscribers at the end of last year, a 45 percent increase over 1988. Revenues for the cellular division rose 46.8 percent last year, to $453.2 million, and net income more than doubled, to $55.4 million, accounting for 4.4 percent of the company's total profits.
Pacific Telesis has also invested heavily in wireless communications, cable television and information services throughout Europe. It holds 26 percent of a consortium that won a $6 billion contract in December to build the first private cellular-telephone network in West Germany, beating out five other regional Bell companies. It has acquired interests in four cable-television companies in Britain, and is part owner of a fiber-optic cable link between the United States and Japan.
Since their formation at the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984, the regional companies have been seeking to become more than just providers of local telephone service and to escape the decades-old regulatory structure that limits their profits. The Baby Bells are already earning close to their allowed return on equity from local telephone operations, so profits from nonregulated businesses have become crucial to growth.
Last year, Pacific Telesis - telesis means intelligently planned progress - became the envy of the other Baby Bells when it persuaded the California Public Utilities Commission to allow Pacific Bell, its local phone subsidiary, higher profits if it cut costs.
Under the new regulation, the rates of Pacific Bell are no longer calculated by adding a profit margin to the company's costs. Instead, the commission sets price caps on the services. The new regulation is intended to give the phone company the incentive to keep costs low and to introduce new products and services.
But the new incentive regulation has raised concerns among consumer advocacy groups, who argue that staff reductions at Pacific Telesis and less regulatory oversight will ultimately diminish the quality of telephone service in California.
''How can Pactel maintain a high quality of service when it is laying off large numbers of employees just to take advantage of the incentive regulation?'' said Audrie Krause, executive director of Toward Utility Rate Normalization in San Francisco.
The consumer group plans to appeal the commission's decision in California Supreme Court.
In response, Pacific Telesis said it was streamlining its work force, taking advantage of new technology that increases the quality of the phone network and requires fewer workers.
California is the first state to adopt the new framework for price caps, following the Federal Communications Commission's decision last March to allow A.T.& T. to price its services within a floor and a ceiling. Regulators in other states have adopted or are considering local telephone deregulation, and California has become a test case.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Opposes Rescue Of Failing Securities Firms

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, the first Government regulator called before Congress to discuss the bankruptcy of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, said today that the authorities would almost certainly refuse to rescue even the largest securities firms from the brink of collapse.
The notion that some financial institutions might be too big to fail ''is not good policy,'' Mr. Greenspan told a House judiciary subcommittee. ''It's not good for discipline'' - nor is it fair, he said, adding that regulators are seeking an alternative approach to what has almost become a policy of giving large banks special consideration for protection. 
Mr. Greenspan, who was among various Government officials who monitored the bankruptcy of Drexel, said that contingency plans were in place to aid in the overriding goal of keeping financial markets functioning. But he said that even if the Fed was so inclined, it would be precluded by its legislative charter from providing cash from its discount window to securities houses.
 
Pleased With Markets
In general, Mr. Greenspan said he was pleased with the way markets absorbed the shock of the Drexel Burnham failure but he offered three tentative suggestions to help head off similar future episodes.
The most radical, which he acknowledged would require major change, would be to shorten the period between the time most securities transactions are made and the time of financial settlement, normally five business days. Mr. Greenspan said that Drexel's Government-securities business, which provides for payment at time of delivery, was smoothly unwound during the crisis and that some consideration might be given to ''extending this type of settlement and bookkeeping procedure to other markets.''
Mr. Greenspan also suggested requiring additional capital for institutions with assets like high-yield, high-risk ''junk bonds'' that might be illiquid or subject to big price swings.
A third area for study, he suggested, would be the ''possible need for an overview'' of holding companies, including entities not now regulated, because Drexel showed that impairment of one kind of activity is not automatically isolated by present structures.

Before testifying, he chatted briefly with Congressman Jack Brooks, the chairman of the House Economic and Commercial Law subcommittee. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Settles Dispute At 2d Mexican Plant

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 1

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that it had reached a new labor agreement with the union representing 2,100 hourly workers at its plant in Hermosillo, Mexico.
The agreement removes a significant hurdle in the company's introduction of new Ford Escort and Mercury Tracer models, which will be assembled in Hermosillo beginning in April.
Ford needs the fuel-efficient Escort and Tracer models to increase its overall corporate average fuel economy and to meet higher Federal standards for 1990 models. The Escort and Tracer, which were developed with the Mazda Motor Corporation of Japan, are also assembled at Ford's Wayne, Mich., assembly plant. 
The labor agreement in Hermosillo resulted in a 27 percent increase in wages and benefits. ''While that appears very large by U.S. standards, it is actually considerably lower than wage and benefit increases in recent years in Mexico,'' said Al Chambers, a spokesman for Ford. Rapid inflation in the 1980's has strained the Mexican economy and sharply cut the buying power of wage earners.
The Hermosillo agreement also means that Ford has settled labor problems at two of its three Mexican plants. Three weeks ago, 800 hourly workers at an engine plant in Chihuahua ratified a new contract, according to a Ford spokesman, ending a walkout that began in the last week in January.
Separately, the company has dismissed about 2,400 workers at its assembly plant in Cuautitlan, near Mexico City, which assembles six Ford car and truck models for the Mexican market. About two-thirds of the 3,700-member work force occupied the Cuautitlan plant in January after an intra-union dispute led to a shooting in which seven workers were injured and one killed.
Mr. Chambers said the company had hired back about 1,200 of those who received dismissal notices, and plans to replace another 1,200 who occupied the plant. The Cuautitllan plant is currently producing about half as many cars and trucks as it did before the labor unrest, Mr. Chambers said.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Up Last Month; Wal-Mart Posts 33% Gain

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Some of the nation's largest retailers yesterday reported good February sales growth, but analysts say that 1990 is expected to be another tough year for the industry.
One standout for the month was Wal-Mart Stores Inc. The discount chain, based in Bentonville, Ark., said its February sales surged by nearly 33 percent, to $1.95 billion, from $1.47 billion a year earlier.
In contrast, Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's biggest retailer, continued to struggle. The Chicago-based company, which began a new merchandising strategy a year ago to try to reverse losses in market share, had virtually flat sales last month, at $2.127 billion in the four weeks that ended on Feb. 24, compared with $2.126 billion a year earlier. 
 
Weather a Factor
Walter F. Loeb, a retail consultant in New York, said unusually warm weather in the first half of the month helped the retail business.
Fewer general merchandise chains, discounters and department stores issued their results than usual on the first Thursday of the month because of differences in sales-reporting calendars.
Jeffrey Feiner, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, said, ''We remain somewhat cautious,'' given continuing high consumer debt levels and sluggish trends in the financial and real estate markets.
The retailers could have a tough time this year coping with the effects of the so-called rolling recessions, which are rippling through parts of the manufacturing sector, like the automobile industry.
Monroe Greenstein of Bear, Stearns & Company, said retailers would probably have a mediocre year in 1990, similar to 1989. February marks the start of the fiscal year for many retailers.
 
February a Slow Month
The analysts were reluctant to attach too much significance to the results because February is typically a slow time for retailers. January and February are transition months, as winter merchandise is cleared to make room for new spring lines.
Despite the general softness in the economy, Wal-Mart has consistently been a star performer among retailers as it expands across the country. Besides its overall gain of nearly 33 percent in last month, the sales at Wal-Mart stores open a year or longer posted a 17 percent increase.
The sales at Sears stores open a year or longer edged up by only 1.5 percent.
Retailers and analysts prefer to focus on sales comparisons for stores operating at least a year, called same-store or comparable-store results. New stores typically enjoy a period of unusually brisk business that is not sustained over time.
 
Ranked No. 3
Wal-Mart, the nation's third-largest retailer, could overtake Sears and the K Mart Corporation in sales volume in the United States, many in the industry believe.
K Mart, which is based in Troy, Mich., recently stepped up efforts to respond to the challenge. To improve sales and profit, the second-largest retailer will accelerate its store-opening and renovation program, reducing its after-tax earnings by $422 million to carry out the plan.
K Mart's report on last month's sales will be released on March 8, along with the Limited Inc.'s and those of several other large retailers.
Many of the retailers who in recent years have reported their monthly results on the first Thursday of each month will be reporting later in March. An effort is being made within the industry to reach a compromise on a single monthly reporting date.
Several top retailers do not report their sales monthly at all, including: the Campeau Corporation's Federated Stores Inc. unit, R. H. Macy & Company and Batus Inc., which owns Marshall Field & Company and Saks Fifth Avenue.
Following are retailers who reported their February domestic sales yesterday:

Wal-Mart Stores Inc.: Month of February: $1.95 billion, up nearly 33 percent from $1.47 billion.
J. C. Penney Company: Four weeks ended Feb. 24: $880 million, up 8.1 percent from $814 million.
Melville Corporation: Four weeks ended Feb. 24: $503.2 million, up 11.7 percent from $450.6 million. First two months: $929 8 million, up 10.4 percent from $841.8 million.

HEADLINE: Personal Income and Spending Up

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
Personal income rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in January despite a new tax bite from Social Security, the Government said today.
The report also showed consumer spending climbed six-tenths of 1 percent, a pace that analysts attributed to caution in the face of mounting inflation.
The Commerce Department said personal income ran at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.60 trillion in January, after gaining five-tenths of 1 percent in December. 
Several factors affected the January income increase, including cost-of-living increases in Social Security and other Federal benefits, and a 3.6 percent pay increase for Federal workers.
Those increases were offset by a rise in taxes withheld for Social Security, as well as a reduction in farm subsidy payments.
Excluding these special factors, personal income increased five-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Increase in Consumer Prices
Analysts cited the 1.1 percent increase in consumer prices in January for the slowdown in consumer spending, from a 1 percent gain in December to six-tenths of 1 percent in January, or an annual rate of $3.60 trillion.
''Consumers behaved fairly cautiously in January, probably because they had to pay so much for energy and food that they didn't have that much to spend on other items,'' said Michael K. Evans, head of Evans Economics Inc.
The Labor Department said food and energy costs, driven up by the effects of the fourth-coldest December on record, accounted for 60 percent of the jump in the January Consumer Price Index.
''Once food and energy prices settle down, consumer spending will pick up,'' Mr. Evans said.
Personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, totaled $19.9 billion - down from $36.7 billion in December.
But purchases of durable goods -big-ticket items expected to last more than three years - rose $24.3 billion. Analysts said this spending was spurred in part by automobile sales incentives.
Nondurable purchases were up $2.5 billion, while spending on services fell $6.8 billion.
Consumer spending is considered a barometer of economic health because it represents about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
The key component of the income category, wages and salaries, edged up $16.2 billion in January after gaining $16.8 billion in December.
Americans' incomes after taxes rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, the department said, up from December's four-tenths of 1 percent gain. That category does not count Social Security withholding as a tax; the department, instead, treats it as a ''contribution,'' just as it does other retirement program costs.
The personal savings rate, as measured against disposable income, advanced 5.9 percent, compared with a 5.5 percent rate a month earlier.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing Decline Slows a Bit

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Despite increases in the level of new orders and exports, the manufacturing sector of the nation's economy remained in decline in February for the 10th consecutive month, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday. But the decline was at a slower rate than in previous months.
The association said its index of economic activity rose to 48.3 percent, from 45.2 percent in January. The group says a reading below 50 indicates that the manufacturing sector of the economy is in decline, and a reading above 50 indicates an expansion. A reading below 44 is said to indicate a decline in real gross national product. 
The February level was the highest since June 1989, when the index stood at 48.8 percent. The survey indicated that suppliers' deliveries were faster and that inventories levels declined sharply. Prices declined for the ninth consecutive month and at the greatest rate since December 1982.
 
No Recession Is Seen
''This confirms our expectations that the economy is not in the process of going into a recession,'' said Wayne C. Stevens, chief economist with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. ''The economy is in a slow growth mode. The numbers reinforce our feeling that manufacturing in the United States is weak, but not recessionary.''
Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's business survey committee and director of materials management at Pitney Bowes Inc., said that despite the increases registered in production and new orders since ''the continued improvement in supplier deliveries and significant decline in prices suggests a lack of underlying strength in the economy.''
The purchasing managers' report is considered an important economic indicator because it is compiled from information supplied by purchasing executives from a range of more than 300 industrial companies in 20 industries.
The index for new orders rose above the 50 percent level for the first time since June of last year, to 51.8 percent, from 45.8 percent in January. The report said that the increase reflected a rebound from the severe reductions in auto production in January and problems related to cold weather during December.
The level of new orders continued to grow in February, but at a slower pace than the previous month. The survey's new order index fell to 53 percent, down from 55.5 percent in January. Also, the level of imports continued to increase in February, remaining at the same index level as January's 50.5 percent. That figure was the highest in five months.
For the first time since the middle of last year, production increased in February as the production index rose to 51.5 percent, up from 45.4 percent in January. The February level was the highest since June of last year. The association attributed the increase to lower production activity in January, particularly from the automobile industry.
The supplier deliveries index fell to 43.3 percent in February, down from January's 47.2 percent, a reflection that production increased and that there were fewer shortages than in January, when the availablity of some items was hampered by severe cold weather.
Nine items were reported to be in short supply in February, including bearings; castings; electric motors; acrylic acid, which is used in making plastics; caustic soda and soda ash, used heavily in making paper, soap and refining petroleum; hydrogen peroxide and sodium chlorate, which have been the replacement used by paper makers who are avoiding the dioxins in chlorine. Also in short supply were titanium dioxide and polyethylene resins.
Prices declined in February for the ninth consecutive month as the price index fell to 42.2 percent, from 49.7 percent in January. Higher prices were reported for a number of items, including Freon, coal, corn products and methanol. Lower prices were reported for aluminum, steel, copper, nickel, rubber, gasoline, eggs, zinc and corrugated shipping containers.
Employment continued to decline for the 12th consecutive month, but at the lowest rate since the middle of last year. The employment index rose to 46.7 percent in February, from 44.1 percent in January.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Fewer Companies Lifting Dividends

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE economy may not be in a recession, but more and more companies are acting as though they think it may enter one. They are doing that by forgoing dividend increases that might have been made in other years.
Last month, the number of companies raising dividends fell by more than 25 percent from the previous February, the Standard & Poor's Corporation reported yesterday. The report said 149 companies increased their payouts in the month, compared with 200 a year earlier. Not since 1971 have there been fewer February increases. 
''It surprised me,'' said Arnold Kaufman, the editor of S.&P.'s Outlook newsletter, which compiles the figures. ''I did not think it would be off that much. I was looking for a relatively small decline in the number of increases this year, with a pickup in the later part of the year.''
There are seasonal patterns to dividend increases, as company boards hold regularly scheduled meetings to decide whether to change dividends. February has traditionally been one of the most popular months for increases, in large part because most companies have figured out their annual profits for the previous year by then. In the last three years, more companies increased their payouts in February than in any other month.
The weakness in dividend increases began to appear last summer, before most analysts saw the downturn in corporate profits. In eight of the last nine months, the number of companies raising their payouts was lower than in the comparable month in the preceding year.
The decline in dividend increases has not been matched by a sharp rise in the number of companies lowering their dividends, something most corporate boards hate to do. But there has been a large increase in the number of companies eliminating their payouts entirely. For the last several months, that figure has been running almost as high as in 1986, when the economy slowed and almost went into a recession.
Mr. Kaufman said the sharp falloff in dividend increases might be a signal that companies were worried that their business would get worse. ''Although they are perhaps not transmitting that message to analysts, they are assuming that earnings will not be good, and they are therefore holding back on dividends,'' he said.
 
New Bets on Tokyo and London
One of the oldest policies on Wall Street, seldom stated but normally followed, is ''Sell them what they want to buy.'' Responding to demand this year, the investment banks that create products have offered Americans ways to bet that European stocks will rise and that Japanese issues will fall.
There is still no new product to allow buyers to be bullish on Japan, but Salomon Inc. said yesterday that it would offer one to enable investors to be bearish on British stocks.
The new products, among the few bright spots for underwriters in 1990, have fallen into two groups. For those bullish on Europe, as well as many other countries, there have been country funds, closed-end mutual funds that buy stocks in the specified market. They have often traded at levels far above the values of the stocks they own, to the amazement of many. That particular craze seems to be waning. This week's new German fund, the Future Germany Fund, slipped $1.125 a share yesterday, to $18.125. That is still above the original offering price of $18 but not by nearly as much as expected.
The new Japanese products have consisted of four series of put warrants, sold in January and February. Details vary, but put warrants enable investors to bet that the Japanese stock market will be lower in three years than it is when the securities are issued. They have been popular and, with the recent slump in Japan, good performers.
The new Salomon issue, to be sold next week, offers similar put warrants on The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading British stocks. It is expected that to buy a put, betting that the British market will be lower in three years, will require buyers to put up a premium of 8.8 percent to 9.3 percent of the underlying value. In other words, to break even, the buyer would have to see the market drop by that much over the period.
Unlike the Japanese products, Salomon's British plan will also offer call warrants, which will be much more expensive, carrying a premium of 25 percent or so and providing a way to bet on a British bull market. Salomon is initially registering an equal number of puts and calls but is willing to sell more of one than the other.
Why has Wall Street not yet offered call warrants on Japan, providing a way to bet on that market rising? Part of the reason, investment bankers say, is that Americans seem uninterested. But another reason is that the bankers who issue the warrants hedge their bets in the home market, and that in Japan, unlike Britain, such hedges are difficult. ''The Japanese market is a classic case of the Japanese institutions not believing the market can fall and everybody else not believing it can stay up,'' a banker said.

HEADLINE: Supercomputer Accord With Japan Advances

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 1

 BODY:
On the eve of a meeting between President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, Japanese and American negotiators said today that they had agreed to scrap a failed 1987 accord on supercomputers and ''work out new language'' to improve American access to the Japanese market.
The announcement was the first sign of progress in any of the major trade disputes that have divided the United States and Japan for the last year.
One American negotiator said tonight, ''The Japanese have been willing to address all of our proposals,'' and Japanese officials were equally optimistic.
 
A Host of Other Issues
While negotiators said they were confident that a final settlement was near, they also said the supercomputer issue was probably the easiest of a host of nettlesome conflicts to solve. And the new language on that must still be worked out on a mutually satisfactory basis. 
While progress was reported on this front, an impasse continues in a parallel set of talks between the two nations being conducted here, known formally as the Structural Impediments Initiative, in which the two nations remain at odds how to make fundamental changes in their economies and business practices to improve their relationship.
In the trade dispute over supercomputers, makers of the American machines have complained that stringent Japanese rules force them out of Government bidding when their models, which often exceed the performance specifications set by the Government, cost more than a less powerful Japanese computer.
''Even if your machine is twice as good as a competitor's, you lose if your price is a dollar higher,'' one American negotiator said tonight.
 
Setting Other Criteria
As part of the talks, the negotiators are establishing criteria other than price that the Japanese Government could use in buying supercomputers.
Access to the Government supercomputer market here has long been a point of friction, because the technology touches so many areas in which the United States and Japan compete: microelectronics, software, advanced computer designs and a number of problems in physics and biotechnology that require a supercomputer's huge number-crunching ability.
But the progress on the computer front does not signal a breakthrough in the meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Kaifu. Rather than discuss specific trade disputes, the President will offer Japan a closer global economic partnership but insist that Japan slash import barriers, Administration officials said today.
While American-made supercomputers - particularly those manufactured by Cray Research Inc. of Minneapolis - have been extremely popular in private industry here, the Japanese Government and universities have bought only a few, and those purchases were made under tremendous pressure from the United States.
The United States contends that Japan is protecting its own supercomputer industry, and last year it invoked the ''Super 301'' section of the nation's trade act, threatening retaliation unless Japan ends by this spring what Washington views as the exclusion of Americans from its supercomputer market.
 
Two Disputed Areas
Despite the progress on computers, negotiators said they had made no headway on satellites and wood products, two other areas named under the Super 301 provisions. Mr. Bush is expected to raise those issues, at least in a general way, during the meeting with Mr. Kaifu, which starts Friday night in Palm Springs, Calif.
A senior Japanese Foreign Ministry official warned today against ''raised expectations'' that any pending trade issues would be solved during the weekend talks. ''This is not a negotiating session,'' he said.
And Japanese officials in Washington and Tokyo said they were fearful that any American demands for rapid action on trade issues could undermine the chances of Japanese concessions down the road.
While Japan is discussing all three areas named under the Super 301 clause, it has refused to recognize the deadline set under the trade legislation. Japan contends that Super 301 violates the rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the international body that oversees world trade.
In August 1987, after heated negotiations, the United States and Japan signed an accord intended to make Tokyo's process for seeking bids on supercomputers more ''transparent'' or understandable to outsiders. But American supercomputer makers have complained that it did not improve access to the Japanese market.
During a visit to Tokyo not long ago, John Rollwagen, the chief executive of Cray, said that the accord ''worked'' only in that it now allows Japan's supercomputer rivals ''to see all the contracts that we are excluded from.''
 
Obstacles Remain
In recent months Japanese negotiators have begun to acknowledge publicly that many obstacles that Americans have long complained of are still present.
For example, Japanese manufacturers often offer - or feel compelled to offer - ''academic discounts'' of up to 80 percent to get their computers installed on university campuses. American companies have said they could not match such huge discounts.
The Ministry of International Trade and Industry has talked publicly of new rules that will forbid ''academic discounts'' that exceed 50 percent, about what the International Business Machines Corporation offers to some universities in the United States.
Complicating the issue is the fact that the United States has yet to buy a Japanese-made supercomputer, asserting that Japan's models do not offer the variety of software that Cray does. Japan, however, has used that fact to argue that the United States also has trade barriers in supercomputing. The Pentagon has often expressed reluctance about depending on foreign-made supercomputers, saying a healthy domestic industry is needed for national security.

HEADLINE: Japanese Fear Problems From a Hasty Meeting

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 1

 BODY:
As Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu prepares to meet President Bush this weekend, Japanese officials say they are suddenly fearful that American demands for rapid action on trade issues could undermine the chances of Japanese concessions down the road.
''No Japanese politician wants to rush off as if he is a mere vassal and President Bush is the lord,'' a Japanese official said. ''If Bush tries to force some sort of commitment on Mr. Kaifu at this moment, it will simply make the job of following up more difficult.''
Associates of Mr. Kaifu, who led his party to a re-election victory less than two weeks ago, said the Prime Minister was still struggling to gain supremacy over rivals in his own party and needed more time before he could forge a consensus to meet American economic demands. 
 
Fear of High Expectations
An atmosphere of concern has permeated Japanese planning for the Bush meeting, especially since Japanese officials greatly prefer structured sessions planned in advance.
Several officials here said they were taken aback and puzzled by Mr. Bush's abrupt decision last Friday to invite Mr. Kaifu to Palm Springs, Calif., this weekend.
Officials also say they fear that high expectations could backfire on both Japan and the United States.
''I find it difficult to think that something specific will come out of this meeting, especially when it was proposed several days ago,'' a senior Japanese official said, adding that Mr. Kaifu would prefer not to negotiate any specific trade matters himself.
Echoing this view, an American official in Washington said Mr. Bush and Mr. Kaifu simply wanted ''to step back from the immediate kinds of problems and set a direction for the 1990's.''
 
Growing Anxiety
The worries of the Prime Minister's aides reflect growing anxiety in the Japanese Government over what the Foreign Minister, Taro Nakayama, recently described as a deterioration of relations with the United States.
Recently, American negotiators have focused not only on specific trade areas, like supercomputers and telecommunications, but also on broad demands that Japan change some fundamental business and government practices. The talks over these fundamental issues are at an impasse, and Mr. Kaifu's Government is unlikely to make major concessions, Japanese officials say.
For instance, they say, Mr. Kaifu will find it impossible to break up the big Japanese business combines or to revise the Japanese law that permits small stores to block big retail stores from coming into their areas. These steps are being pushed by Washington as possible ways to open Japanese markets to more imports.
Mr. Kaifu plans to leave Friday evening for Palm Springs, where he is expected to talk with Mr. Bush on Saturday and Sunday in informal settings, perhaps even on a golf course. He returns to Japan on Sunday.
 
A Question of Emphasis
Mr. Kaifu and his aides are trying to dispel speculation about substantive discussions. American officials are playing down trade matters and emphasizing the growing importance of Japan in supporting American political, economic and security interests in Asia and elsewhere.
Japan has supported such American initiatives as the restructuring of Mexico's debt and aid to the Philippines. It has also backed the Bush Administration on global environmental issues and other matters.
Lately, the Bush Administration has begun to talk of ways that Japan could increase assistance to Hungary, Poland, Panama and Nicaragua, now that a more friendly government is in the offing there.
Mr. Kaifu took office in August but has spent most of his time since then working to keep the ruling Liberal Democratic Party in power. Since the elections on Feb. 18 that gave the party control of the lower house of Parliament, Mr. Kaifu has devoted most of his attention to forming his Cabinet.
 
Comparison to a Bird
''When the invitation came, Kaifu had to accept,'' a business executive with close ties to the Government said of the Palm Springs meeting. ''But the Kaifu Government is like a fledgling bird. If you put too much weight on it, the bird Kaifu will not be able to fly.''
Mr. Kaifu is generally seen to be in a weak position because of widespread fears in Japan about the economy, prompted by the recent drop in stock prices and fears that higher interest rates could slow growth.
Mr. Kaifu has said his Government's most urgent challenge is to reach a consensus on what steps to take to improve ties with the United States. At the same time, he has warned against expectations of quick action.
''There is no magic word that will erase the $49 billion trade surplus,'' Mr. Kaifu said at a news conference on Wednesday. He said Japan had done a great deal already and would do more in the future.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Decline

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury issues dipped yesterday in light trading, as dealers sold securities in the wake of a series of economic reports that were somewhat stronger than anticipated.
Specifically, traders were disappointed that a survey of the nation's purchasing managers showed that manufacturing activity improved slightly in February from the previous month. In addition, data on construction spending and personal income growth during January were above expectations.
Such positive economic news tends to be viewed negatively in the bond market, since it reduces the chance that the Federal Reserve will ease monetary policy, setting the stage for lower interest rates. 
Despite the market's negative reaction, analysts said the data did little to support the notion that the pace of economic activity was quickening.
''Almost all the numbers depict an economy that is recovering from a temporary decline rather than one that is beginning to take off,'' said Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist for Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago. ''But the market chose to react negatively to numbers that were mixed, at best.''
 
End of Small Rally
Bond prices had fallen on Wednesday, as well. The price drop over the last two sessions has wiped out what had been a small rally in the secondary market for Treasury securities. But most market participants said they expected market interest rates to move in a narrow range from current levels, rather than continue to move higher.
''I would expect that we will do better soon,'' one Government-bond trader said. ''These numbers were a little stronger than anticipated, but they are not strong enough to make the Fed tighten policy. In this sort of market, with no supply coming until the end of the month, you have to buy on dips. I think that will happen soon.''
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 98 29/32, down 3/4 point, or $7.50 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.60 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 1/2, down 14/32, to yield 8.57 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 100, down 6/32, to yield 8.50 percent.
''I think yields on the long bond will slosh around for a while, with 8.50 percent being the center of a very tight trading range,'' said Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''The economy has not shown any evidence of slowing down nor of speeding up.''
 
Higher Short-Term Rates
Short-term Treasury-bill rates moved higher for the second straight session. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.79 percent, up 4 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bills rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 7.74 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by 8 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.63 percent.
Yesterday, the Treasury sold $10 billion of 52-day cash management bills. The bills, which mature on April 26, were sold at an average discount rate of 7.95 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. acted as lead manager on a $137.9 million offering for the Dow Chemical Company's employee stock ownership plan.
The 9.42 percent amortizing stock ownership plan notes, which have a final maturitiy of Dec. 31, 2004, were priced at par, or 100, 87 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/2 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A by the Standard & Poor's.
 
Some Secondaries Slump
Participants in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities said that prices of most actively traded issues slumped in sympathy with the declines in Treasury prices.
Prices of most intermediate-term corporate bonds fell by 3/8 point, while long-term issues fell by about 1/2 point.
Meanwhile, municipal-bond traders said most prices fell by about 1/2 point.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week that ended Feb. 19. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of 52-day cash-management bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Advance, Helped by Economic News

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Lifted by reports showing strength in the United states economy and by economic uncertainty in Japan, the dollar continued to climb against most foreign currencies yesterday.
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that the nation's economy declined in February for the 10th consecutive month, but at the lowest rate since June. The Commerce Department said that personal income rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in January; that consumer spending increased six-tenths of a percent, and that construction spending rose 1.8 percent. The construction figure was the biggest increase in more than a year. 
 
'Economy Is Doing All Right'
Craig Sloane, a currency futures analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said the reports ''seemed to paint the picture that the economy is doing all right.''
Traders said the Federal Reserve sold dollars in an attempt to halt the rise of the dollar against the yen, but the intervention appeared to have limited impact. The yen was also weakened by the slump in the Tokyo stock market, said Chris Mendell, a vice president at Security Pacific Bank in Los Angeles.
Mr Sloane said that although the dollar flirted with the 150-yen level, it never reached it.
The West German mark continued to be hurt by concern that a plan for exchanging East German marks for the West German currency would cause inflation, Ms. Mendell said.
 
Dollar Higher in Tokyo
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 149.78 yen, from 148.52 yen Wednesday. Later, in London, the dollar traded lower at 149.67 yen. But in New York, the dollar rose to 149.85 yen, from 148.92 late Wednesday.
The dollar has not closed that high against the yen in New York since June 15, when it reached 151.30.
The dollar also rose against the British pound. In London, one British pound cost $1.6655 late yesterday, cheaper for buyers than $1.6895 on Wednesday. In New York, the pound closed at $1.6640, down from $1.6752.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday rates, included: 1.7194 West German marks, up from 1.7074; 1.5095 Swiss francs, up from 1.5010; 5.8070 French francs, up from 5.7695; 1,267.25 Italian lire, up from 1,260.75, and 1.1910 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1927.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery rose 10 cents, to $406.20 a troy ounce.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Large Supplies of Gasoline Prompt Heavy Selling in Oil

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Reports of large supplies of gasoline prompted heavy selling of petroleum futures yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
On other commodity markets, coffee futures surged to their highest levels in seven and a half months. Precious metals also advanced, and grain and soybean futures finished mixed. 
On the Mercantile Exchange, futures of West Texas Intermediate, the American benchmark crude, settled 28 cents to 37 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in April at $21.17 a barrel. Wholesale home heating oil was 1.13 cents to 1.93 cents lower, with April at 54.63 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline was 0.80 cent to 2.43 cents lower, with April at 55.81 cents a gallon. The April gasoline contract traded as low as 54.70 cents a gallon.
Jim Ritterbusch, an energy analyst for Paine Webber Inc., said gasoline supplies were so high ''that on the East Coast they're having some difficulty finding available storage for all this stuff.''
He said gasoline demand was off by about 5 percent from a year ago, possibly reflecting a weakness in the economy.
The price slide ran contrary to the seasonal pattern of rising prices for petroleum products at this time of year as some refiners shut down to retool for greater gasoline production after concentrating on heating oil for the winter months.
Peter Beutel, the head of the energy trading group at Elders Futures Inc., said that while the so-called turnaround season was already under way, the markets were not responding as they usually do. ''It just seems at this point,'' he said, ''that there is too great a supply and not enough demand.''
On the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, coffee futures rose sharply for the second straight day, reaffirming a strong upward trend linked to tight short-term supplies. Some support stemmed from reports that Mexican roasters might need to import up to 400,000 of the 132-pound bags of coffee to meet a domestic shortfall caused by a freeze during the Christmas season.
Coffee futures settled 1.02 cents to 3.94 cents higher, with the March contract at 96.75 cents a pound, the highest settlement of a near-month coffee future since July 5.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold and silver futures rose modestly. The rally in silver, the second in as many days, erased the rest of the losses posted Wednesday. Gold futures settled unchanged to 10 cents higher, with April at $409 an ounce, and silver was 2.5 cents to 3.1 cents higher, with March at $5.154 an ounce.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat futures fell sharply, reflecting slack export demand and improved growing conditions for the winter wheat crop. Corn futures finished lower, while soybeans ended mostly higher.

HEADLINE: 'Roger & Me': Narrow, Simplistic, Wrong

BYLINE: By David Bensman; David Bensman is chairman of the labor education department at Rutgers University.

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

 BODY:
Many people were outraged that Michael Moore's documentary, ''Roger & Me,'' was shut out in the Academy Award nominations. I can't understand why. The film mocks American culture brilliantly, but forfeits any claim to distinction by manipulating its audience to believe that General Motors abandoned Flint, Mich., in the pursuit of profits.
In reality, General Motors poured billions of dollars into its domestic plants, including Flint's, in the 80's. In fact, it embarked on the largest industrial modernization drive in the history of the world. The company bought thousands of robot welders, computer-controlled machine tools, sophisticated computer systems and automated paint shops. 
Because of this modernization effort, 50,000 G.M. employees still work in Flint, in the new Buick City complex. Some of the highest-quality cars made by Big Three auto makers are manufactured there.
Mr. Moore conveniently ignores G.M.'s efforts so he can convey his sense that American society has turned its back on the working class. In ''Roger & Me'' he tells the viewer that G.M. closed down 11 plants, including several in Flint, and opened 11 plants in Mexico to take advantage of cheaper labor. Profits earned by making cars were spent to acquire Hughes Aircraft, which makes weapons at government-guaranteed profits.
He then shows how these decisions wrought devastation on Flint. The historic Fisher Body N1 plant is filmed being torn down, and there are shots of ruined houses infested by rats, of whole blocks standing empty and forlorn.
The film crew's efforts to meet Roger Smith, G.M.'s chairman, and invite him to see all this for himself are met with indifference, and impatience. The audience comes away feeling the company deserves every bit of red ink on its balance book.
The story of Flint's ruination is much more complicated than Mr. Moore's explanation of G.M.'s arrogance and indifference to the working class.
There is bungling: As Mary Ann Keller's book ''Rude Awakening'' documented, much of G.M.'s massive investment was wasted because the company's attempts to find quick, technological fixes simply threw money at problems.
There is bureaucratic paralysis: Though G.M. started planning its Lumina model at the same time Ford started planning its similar Taurus, the car that brought Ford back from the brink, wars within General Motors stalled the Lumina's introduction for four years.
There is corporate authoritarianism that undermines efforts to achieve labor-management partnership often necessary in achieving efficiency. And public policy played a role: High consumer interest rates and the elimination of tax advantages on consumer debt and sales tax certainly do not encourage consumers to buy cars.
Had Mr. Moore considered these factors, his analysis of the auto industry would have been more politically useful. If the audience knew that G.M. did not simply abandon Flint, but rather reinvested fruitlessly everywhere, they might have been inspired to think how America can preserve its working-class jobs: Should labor cooperate with management? If not, is trade protectionism a solution to preserving American jobs? Can government help corporations become globally competitive when corporate management is incompetent?
Mr. Moore, however, appears unwilling to provide such inspiration. Instead he wants us to laugh with him at those who believe that companies like G.M. are good for America. He plays on our moral and cultural superiority to the rich corporation that destroyed the beloved working-class community of the past.
The truth is that these working people have not let themselves be destroyed. They've organized food banks, church service societies and unemployed movements. They've run for political office, lobbied their legislators - often with success - to gain trade restrictions, trade adjustment assistance and improvements in unemployment coverage.
They've gone back to school, learned new skills, started new careers. Precisely because they've demonstrated such resilience, there can be hope that the nation will begin to address its problems.
Mr. Moore depicts Flint's working people as industrious. But he concludes that they are politically ineffective. They cry at their fate, they curse, they complain - in other words, they are pathetic. They are victims.
Only Michael Moore and his film crew seem to have any spunk, any persistence, any desire to understand what's happening and to call G.M. to account. At least the title is perfect: ''Roger & Me.''

HEADLINE: Nicaragua Victor Plans to Return Some Land Seized by Sandinistas <f1081>

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 2

 BODY:
The government of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro will move promptly to return or make compensation for most land confiscated by the Sandinista Government, and will sell many state enterprises, aides to Mrs. Chamorro say.
The new leadership, which is to take office on April 25, will seek the recovery of buildings, farms, vehicles and other property now in the hands of members of the Sandinista National Liberation Front. It also plans broad incentives to encourage professionals and other Nicaraguans who have left the country to return, the aides said. [A team of advisers to the new leadership is to arrive Monday in Washington seeking at least $550 million in assistance from international lending institutions and the United States to help revive Nicaragua's war-shattered economy. Page 2.] Mrs. Chamorro's chief economic adviser, Francisco Mayorga Balladares, emphasized that the new government would not displace any farmers or workers who have received property under Sandinista land-reform programs. And he asserted that her government's policies would be guided by economic prudence, not political revenge. 
''We are going to respect the rights of the people who are already settled,'' Mr. Mayorga said today in an interview. ''But we are going to take a lot of wealth that has been misused, mismanaged, pilfered by the Sandinista Government, and distribute it to the society in a very democratic way.''
Before Mrs. Chamorro's victory over President Daniel Ortega Saavedra in national elections last Sunday, many senior opposition leaders spoke of their platform only in broad terms.
But backed by an electoral victory margin of more than 14 percentage points, the opposition has given its program new definition. And it has drawn the lines for what is expected to be a political battle over the practical legacy of the decade-long Sandinista revolution.
The most critical points to be negotiated with Sandinista officials, opposition leaders say, are the dismantling of the contra army and the ending of Sandinista control over Nicaragua's large military and security forces. Those issues, which are being discussed by negotiating teams established on Tuesday, are expected to define what opposition leaders say is a critical test of Sandinista good faith.
''It is their obligation to hand over power,'' said Virgilio Godoy Reyes, Mrs. Chamorro's Vice Presidential running mate, ''and to hand it over completely, not in pieces or installments.''
But broader conflicts have begun to emerge over the opposition's intention to dismantle the large government sector created by Sandinista policy, and to use the proceeds to reverse or make compensation for the extensive confiscation of property by the Sandinista leadership in its early years of power.
 
How Property Was Redistributed
Since the Sandinista revolution succeeded in 1979, opposition economists say, the Government has taken control of approximately 40 percent of the country's arable farmland.
Of that, they estimate, a little less than half belonged to the family or associates of the ousted dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle; the rest was seized for political, military and economic reasons by Government decree.
Mr. Mayorga said the new government does not intend to return the land that belonged to Mr. Somoza and his associates because it considers those confiscations justified. But he said all other seized property would be subject to recovery by its original owners under provisions being worked out by the new leaders.
In the case of unoccupied farmland, he said, the former owners will be able to apply for new titles. For land that has already been given to small farmers under Sandinista agrarian-reform programs, original owners will be compensated with transferable coupons redeemable at special auctions of Government land, he said.
Roughly 20 percent of all confiscated land has been distributed in the form of private parcels or state-organized cooperatives, and would fall into the same category, Mr. Mayorga said.
He did not identify the state enterprises the new government is planning to sell. But they are expected to include businesses ranging from the state monopoly on grain distribution to confiscated sugar mills, textile factories and seafood processors.
 
Hopes of Enough for Everyone
Mr. Mayorga expressed confidence that, given the large amount of property left in state hands from the Somoza family's holdings, there will be enough idle land to redeem all outstanding claims by Nicaraguans. If there is not enough, he said, the government will issue long-term bonds to compensate the original owners.
''We'll make sure everybody gets a piece of the rock,'' said Mr. Mayorga, a Yale-educated economist.
The return of such property is bitterly opposed by Sandinista leaders, who view the redistribution of agricultural land as one of the most important achievements of their 10-year rule.
Opposition officials also said they planned to encourage the return of the Nicaraguan professionals who fled the country in large numbers during Sandinista rule. Mrs. Chamorro's advisers hope to pass new legislation providing broad tax incentives and even direct aid to Nicaraguans living in exile so that they can return.
Those plans will depend in part on foreign assistance, which has yet to be confirmed. But Alfredo Cesar Aguirre, a top opposition adviser, said Mrs. Chamorro has already received offers of help from dozens of countries. There have been unofficial talks with the Soviet Union, whose Ambassador in Managua, Valery D. Nikolayenko, visited the President-elect today.

HEADLINE: Panel Says Broad Health Care Would Cost $86 Billion a Year

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
A sharply divided bipartisan commission today recommended an $86.2-billion-a-year program to provide health insurance and long-term nursing care to every American who needs them. But the panel could not recommend specific ways to raise the money.
Some members of the panel, the Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care, said the program stood little chance of being enacted without a way to finance it.
''We are not dealing with the world's easiest problem,'' said Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia, who is chairman of the 15-member Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care, created by Congress in 1988 to recommend legislation on health issues. ''We can't offer easy answers, but we can offer a challenge to this country.'' 
The Bush Administration had asked Republicans on the commission to hold out against any recommendations for tax increases. That, along with a general nervousness among Republicans about significant new health care initiatives, accounted for the narrow 8-to-7 vote by which the panel approved the ambitious plan unveiled today.
Representative Fortney H. Stark, a California Democrat who joined the Republicans in voting against the plan, took note of its bleak legislative outlook. Mr. Stark, chairman of the health subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee, said the split vote indicated ''that it's hopeless to get a comprehensive plan passed in the U.S., with politics being what it is.''
''Without a way to pay for it, it is a non-starter,'' Mr. Stark added. ''It is legislatively dead.'' In forming the panel, Congress had directed it to recommend ''the sources of those funds.''
Although the legislative prospects were described as ''nil'' by one member, the program does provide an accounting of how much major improvements in health care would cost the nation.
The commission put the total Federal share of the programs covering health insurance and nursing homes at $66.2 billion a year. Of this, $42.8 billion would pay for expanded nursing home care for elderly people with low and moderate incomes and for others with severe disabilities.
The remaining $23.4 billion in Federal money would provide health insurance for those who do not already have it. The total cost of the health insurance program would be $43.4 billion, with the remaining $20 billion paid through private employers. The employers would pay 80 percent of that cost and the employees 20 percent.
 
Broad Agreement on Nursing Care
The health insurance section of the plan was adopted by 8 to 7, with some members saying they opposed any additional charges for private employers. On the nursing care proposal, the vote was 11 to 4 in favor.
Under the plan, nursing home coverage would be greatly expanded. The ''severely disabled'' of all ages would receive three months of free care. And the Government would pay the nursing home costs of individuals with assets of $30,000 or less or couples with assets of $60,000 or less.
Under current law, only the elderly receive nursing home coverage, and only for the first 100 days after hospitalization for each spell of illness. To get more Government coverage, they must then divest their assets. They can qualify for Medicaid, the Federal-state program of health care for the poor, if their assets are an average of $2,000 or less.
The plan approved by the panel, named the Pepper Commission after its first chairman, the late Representative Claude Pepper of Florida, does not require such divestiture.
''This gets us out of povertizing people because they're disabled,'' said Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, a commission member who voted for the nursing care program but joined the three other Republican members in opposing the health insurance program.
 
'No Consensus,' Sullivan Says
The panel was appointed in 1988 by President Ronald Reagan, the Senate and the House. It has eight Democrats, four Republicans and three members who were not appointed on the basis of party membership, including a past president of the American Medical Association.
Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, called the report ''a sincere and commendable effort.''
''However, it is important to note the wide divergence of views within the commission itself,'' Dr. Sullivan continued. ''This divergence reflects the simple fact that there is no consensus in this country today on how to achieve the kind of health care system we want, or how the cost of improvements in our system should be borne.''
Senator Rockefeller was more optimistic. He said there was growing recognition that ''the American health care system is in total crisis.''
''We're plunging ahead in this country toward a health care catastrophe,'' he added.
The commission proposal differs in many respects from the short-lived Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act, repealed last year, which covered the costs of hospitals and doctors for the elderly, but not long-term nursing care, which many older Americans sought and indeed thought the act had provided.
The proposal also calls for ''reforms'' in the health insurance industry. It would require insurers to base their premiums on the health experience of a community, and prohibit insurers from refusing to sell policies to people with health problems.
''We would pre-empt state health insurance laws,'' Mr. Rockefeller said.
The commission report received mixed notices. The American Medical Association hailed it. ''The American people were the real winners,'' said Dr. James E. Davis, the former A.M.A. president who was a member of the panel.
Ron Pollack, president of Families United for Senior Action, an advocacy group for the elderly, said that the report ''calls to mind President John F. Kennedy's proposal of Medicare 30 years ago.''
 
'A Mixed Bag'
But the United States Chamber of Commerce called the recommendations ''a mixed bag,'' and said, ''We are disappointed by the emphasis on mandated benefits as a solution to the access problem.''
Similarly, the Health Insurance Association of America called the report ''a blueprint for economic disaster.'' The organization warned that the requirement that employers provide health insurance for their employees ''could result in increased unemployment and an additional burden on the publicly funded programs.''
Besides Senators Rockefeller and Durenberger, Mr. Stark and Dr. Davis, these are the members of the commission: James Balog, chairman of the Lambert Brussels Capital Corporation.
 
Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of
Montana. John Cogan, a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution. Representative Bill Gradison, Republican of Ohio.
 
Senator John Heinz, Republican of
Pennsylvania. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachussets. Representative Mary Rose Oakar, Democrat of Ohio. Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas. Representative Louis Stokes, Democrat of Ohio. Representative Tom Tauke, Republican of Iowa. Representative Henry Waxman, Democrat of California.

HEADLINE: Nicaraguans Plan To Unlock U.S. Funds

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
A team of economic advisers to the Nicaraguan President-elect, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, is to arrive here on Monday seeking at least $550 million in aid from the United States and international lending institutions to revive a war-shattered economy.
Jose Antonio Alvarado, a Nicaraguan-born investment banker from Miami who is serving on Mrs. Chamorro's delegation, said in a telephone interview that she would seek $500 million in loans and grants over 18 months to create jobs, reinvigorate Nicaraguan agriculture and develop the country's industrial base.
The four-member delegation will also seek $50 million or more for a special government fund to encourage small business.
Mr. Alvarado said his group's itinerary included meetings with the International Monetary Fund, the Inter-American Development Bank and the World Bank. Describing the Nicaraguan request as ''very modest,'' he emphasized the importance of an economic revival to ''the consolidation of a democratic government.'' 
''We, the United States and the international banking institutions have to move forward as a team,'' he said.
 
Persuading the Policy Makers
The most important mission of the Nicaraguan delegation will be to describe the incoming government's needs to a group of officials from the State, Treasury and Commerce Departments and other United States agencies. The interagency panel is headed by Bernard W. Aronson, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs.
''We are prepared to give significant economic aid to Nicaragua,'' Mr. Aronson said. ''Mrs. Chamorro says her two priorities are economic recovery and national reconciliation, and we want to support her on both as effectively and generously as we can.''
Mr. Aronson said it was too early to specify how much aid the United States would be willing to give the new Nicaraguan leaders, who are to take office on April 25.
His group met for the first time on Thursday. A participant who asked not to be identified said the panel had not readied a plan beyond agreeing that the American trade embargo against Nicaragua should be lifted.
''There was nobody at the table who gave a serious analysis of specifics on the economy,'' the official said. ''People first have to look at how we can undo what we have done.''
 
Washington's Budget Limits
Several experts are concerned that Washington will not be able to meet all of Nicaragua's needs. The United States already faces commitments to aid Panama and several countries in Eastern Europe at a time of large American budget deficits.
''For 10 years we had money for the contras and every single effort to destroy Nicaragua, but now there is no money left to rebuild it,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, the chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee that deals with foreign aid.
Several members of Congress and of the Bush Administration ''talk of helping Nicaragua, but I have the checkbook here and it is already overdrawn,'' he said in an interview.
A senior official at an international lending institution, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said: ''Nicaragua needs large bridge loans, but there will be delays. Bankers and investors will say, 'Before I invest, I want to see how these new guys work out.' ''
 
Legacy of War and Disasters
The new government headed by Mrs. Chamorro will face a difficult challenge. As the President-elect seeks the smoothest possible transition from Sandinista rule, particularly the handing over of control by the security forces, she will also be dealing with the legacy of civil war, natural disasters, the United States trade embargo and poor economic management.
Inflation in Nicaragua was 1,700 percent last year. Unemployment stands at 25 percent, and an estimated 45 percent of Nicaraguans are underemployed. The Government in Managua is effectively bankrupt, and many in the private business sector and the skilled labor force have fled the country.
As April approaches, Nicaraguan farmers need immediate financing to buy seeds and fertilizer.
Commercial bankers and aid specialists at the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank say they cannot lend money to Nicaragua as long as it remains in arrears on its $8 billion foreign debt. Additional loans are unlikely to be granted, they say, unless the United States persuades Japan and Western European Governments to join in providing $500 million in interim loans to bolster Managua's foreign exchange reserves.
Washington must also allow American shipping companies to return to Nicaraguan ports to pick up coffee, cotton and sugar, something they have not done since President Ronald Reagan imposed the trade embargo in 1985.
