HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Decisions On Taxes? Forget Numbers

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
When it comes to tax policy, how you count often depends on where you stand.
Take, for example, the disagreement between the staffs of the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation and the Treasury Department over President Bush's proposed capital gains tax cut.
The committee staff says the proposal would cost the Government about $11 billion in lost revenue over the next five years. The experts at the Treasury believe the proposal would lead to an increase in revenue. Who's right? Who knows? 
The amount of money generated by the tax depends on two factors: the tax rate and, because no tax is paid until a profit is realized, how many people decide to sell stocks, bonds and other property.
The tax rate on capital gains is now the same as the tax rate on other income, generally 28 percent or 33 percent. Mr. Bush would lower the rate to around 20 percent in most cases. That would lead more people to sell. The question is, Would enough people sell to increase total tax revenue despite the lower rate?
The problem is that decisions to sell are based on more than the tax rate. They depend, for instance, on how well the stock market will do, what will happen to real estate prices and what kind of new opportunities will become available to entice investors. Experts make different judgments on those matters. And so the fact is that the question of whether to lower the capital gains tax is political and not simply budgetary.
Democrats argue that the tax break would be unjust because it would mostly benefit the wealthy directly. Republicans say it would help the economy so much that everyone would benefit at least indirectly.
No one doubts that the staff experts are honorable. But those in Congress are answerable to Democrats; those in the Treasury, to Republicans.
A similar disagreement has arisen over the fairness of recent changes in the tax system. The question is central to the issue of how the country changed in the Reagan years.
Last month, the staff of the House Ways and Means Committee, controlled by Democrats, published a study examining whether, the tax system became more progressive or regressive over the last decade. A tax is said to be progressive if the ratio of taxes to income rises as incomes rise. It is regressive if the ratio falls as incomes rise.
The pivotal table in the study shows that counting all taxes - income taxes, Social Security and Medicare taxes and excise taxes - the effective tax rate for the poorest 20 percent of the population rose by 16.1 percent from 1980 to 1990. The effective rate, the proportion of taxes to total income, for the wealthiest 20 percent fell by 5.5 percent in that period. Moreover, the table indicates, the rate for the wealthiest 10 percent fell by 7.3 percent and for the wealthiest 5 percent, it fell by 9.5 percent.
After the study received a bit of publicity, the Administration came out swinging. The staffs of the Office of Management and Budget and the Council of Economic Advisers published their own analysis, attacking not the Ways and Means Committee's facts, which are unassailable, but the study's ''serious conceptual problems and methodological flaws.''
The Administration's economists argued, for example, that the Congressional staff had skewed the results by choosing 1980 and 1990 as its ''end points.'' In 1980, the economists said, ''inflation-induced bracket creep'' had led to unusually high tax rates. Moreover, 1987 is the last year for which the Internal Revenue Service has full data. Thus the Congressional report relied on projections to arrive at its figures for later years.
From 1977 to 1980 and from 1985 to 1990, the Administration observed, producing a table of its own, the tax system became more progressive. A better 10-year period to measure, these economists said, would be 1977 to 1987.
But that would skew the results also. In 1987, the lower rates enacted in the Tax Reform Act of 1986 were not fully in place. Income taxes were clearly more progressive in 1987 than they have been since.
That the data are inconclusive underscores an important point. Changes in the tax system may indeed be in the offing this year. Capital gains taxes may be cut. The top income tax rate may be raised. The Social Security tax may be lowered. But the impetus will be politics, not the numbers.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
A Writer in Castro's Stifling Shadow

BYLINE: By Herbert Mitgang

 BODY:

Self-Portrait of the Other
By Heberto Padilla
Translated by Alexander Coleman. 247 pages. Farrar Straus & Giroux. $19.95.
Fidel Castro looms like a wraith over the remarkably calm but highly revealing pages of Heberto Padilla's memoir, ''Self-Portrait of the Other.'' The author, one of Cuba's leading poets (''Legacies: Selected Poems'') and novelists (''Heroes Are Grazing in My Garden''), knew Fidel Castro at the beginning of the revolution, became one of his followers and was given a cultural post in the Foreign Commerce Ministry. Then, as the revolution turned into an oligarchy, the poet allowed his disenchantment to show openly. 
Although we know it has happened in dictatorial countries on the left and right, it is still hard for an American reader to imagine that an author could be thrown into jail because his poetry was out of favor or that a book review he wrote could so displease the powers in the official Writers' Union that he would be placed under house arrest. Only after growing protests by people like Bernard Malamud, then president of the American branch of PEN, Robert Silvers of The New York Review of Books and Senator Edward M. Kennedy and an international outcry by dozens of distinguished authors was Mr. Padilla permitted by the Maximum Leader of Cuba to leave for the United States in 1980.
Mr. Padilla comes through as an honest observer who seems able to distance himself from his oppressors and from the beatings he received that led to a forced confession of wrongdoing. He even forms a dispassionate judgment about Fidel Castro, who, like the right-wing rulers in Latin America, never sheds his uniform. The surprising portrait of Mr. Castro that emerges is not of an ogre but of a tragic figure unable to hear himself talking, deaf to the opinions of his own countrymen and stuck in a time warp of failed Marxist theory.
In a final face-to-face meeting with the Maximum Leader, Mr. Padilla is told that he is free to leave Cuba -and to return some time in the future. ''Stay as long as you want,'' Mr. Castro tells him, ''and when you want to come back, give me a call. If you are a true revolutionary, you will want to return.'' Then Mr. Castro lectures his old friend in these antediluvian words in defense of a police state:
''What is most obvious in your conduct over the past years is your blind hatred for State Security. Would you mind telling me what government on this earth is able to do without it? It is inevitable in a revolution. People who criticize a revolution may be mistaken, they may be sincere, but they are dangerous nonetheless. To create a new society, we have to demand national unity. Marx and Lenin are the prototypes of a revolutionary and they were both implacable with their enemies.'' To which, the author comments, ''For Fidel, an enemy was anyone who displayed the merest disagreement with his ideas.''
Of equal interest in ''Self-Portrait of the Other,'' which was translated from the Spanish by Alexander Coleman, are the author's encounters with literary personages he met in the 1960's while a correspondent for Prensa Latina, the Cuban press agency, in Moscow, Paris and London before returning to Cuba to serve the revolution.
Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Russian poet, told Mr. Padilla that he knew what disappointed him about the Soviet Union: ''The lack of freedom, the power of the Secret Police, the untouchable bureaucracies known as the Nomenklatura, the hegemony of the party, the stagnation of literature, the constant pressure of the censor, the cynicism of most of the writers.''
Albert Camus, the French novelist, made him ponder the effect of the sun on writers: ''Also, my impression was that the fact that he was born in Algeria and extolled life, sun, and the sea had irritated those born in the rain and gloom of Paris. Evidently, Camus attracted people with the same intensity as he drew their hatred.''
Mr. Padilla also quotes Jean-Paul Sartre, the French philosopher, on writing and weather: ''Yes, I would have preferred for the characters in 'Nausee' to have had an encounter with the meridional atmosphere of North Africa. But apparently you Cubans react antagonistically toward the milieu into which you were born. You have a prenatal nostalgia for snow.''
''Self-Portrait of the Other'' ends sentimentally as the author gets airborne and leaves his country for self-imposed exile: ''I looked out the window at the great brilliant expanse -that vivid frieze of greenness and luminosity that is Cuba.''
It is too bad that the memoir lacks an epilogue about Cuba today in light of the changes taking place in Moscow, Mr. Castro's source of economic and military aid. An index would also have helped to make ''Self-Portrait of the Other,'' with its many little-known names, more valuable as a reference work. But these omissions do not detract from Mr. Padilla's own story, which he relates with controlled emotional power.

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Now for Election Groupies

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Compared with difficulties ahead, winning Nicaragua's election was the least of Violeta Chamorro's problems. But the elections had to be the first step toward creating (not rebuilding - there never was a substantial foundation) a peaceful, democratic society with a functioning economy.
It is tempting to note superficial similarities of the Nicaraguan lady in white and Corazon Aquino, who wears yellow. Both were catapulted into politics after their crusading husbands were murdered, both have strong support from the Catholic Church, both face a ravaged society. The experience of the Philippines' President holds some warnings for Mrs. Chamorro, too: watch out for corruption and abuse of connections by a large, entrenched family. 
But there are important differences. Fragile and feminine as she is, Mrs. Chamorro has a will of steel, a complete lucidity of purpose and a talent for reconciliation. She held her family together although two of her children are ardent Sandinistas and two are pro-contra. Her troubles in turning the Sandinista-run army and police into non-political forces will be considerably greater than Mrs. Aquino has had, and the economy is run down much worse. Making democracy stick won't be easy.
Still, the successful conduct of free and fair elections in the context of a regional plan brings a starting advantage. Apart from the Nicaraguans themselves, credit goes to Costa Rica's outgoing President, Oscar Arias, who persistently pushed the peace plan despite repeated setbacks, and to Secretary of State James Baker and House Speaker Thomas Foley, who forged the bipartisan compromise establishing U.S. support for a political settlement.
They saw that elections offered the only chance for solution. The vote could have gone the other way. But the thing was to make sure people had the chance to speak for themselves and not through their self-appointed revolutionary or counterrevolutionary armed ''vanguards.''
This is a new development in international affairs. The idea of free elections is as old as democracy, of course. But the idea that foreigners have a right and responsibility to monitor introduces accountability to the world as well as to the electorate.
The monitors' verdict invokes only the force of international opinion, yet a growing force. Acceptance of human rights as a subject for diplomacy only took hold in the last decade or so, and it brought important changes in Europe. Attitudes about the sovereign impunity of states in their domestic deeds have evolved.
Elections are next. Mr. Baker wants to add guarantees for regular, free elections to the Helsinki accords. When they were signed in 1975, many wrote off the human rights commitments as a delusion. Ask Eastern Europeans if they were worth the paper they were written on.
Surprisingly, the Soviets also say elections should be included in a new Helsinki document. It would apply to Europe, themselves and America, and so much the better. International supervision of the campaigning, voting and counting process should not be seen patronizingly as a way for legitimate governments to put nannyish pressure on bad ones, leaving the nannies to look after themselves.
On occasion, the U.S. could have used some certified onlooking. A recent New Yorker series by Robert Caro on Lyndon B. Johnson's Texas elections provided stunning documentation of plain theft, especially in his first election to the Senate. Questions about propriety of the Chicago vote count that assured John F. Kennedy's becoming President might not have arisien if international election watching were the rule.
It's no shame to invite outside observers into the family precincts. The more countries that accept monitoring as standard, the harder it will be for cheaters to refuse, and the more obvious their reason.
There's a certain tasty irony in Nicaragua's being the country to prove the value and effectiveness of a horde of foreign ballot overseers. Nicaragua was one of the countries that played host to thousands of revolutionary groupies who ran from Havana to Lisbon to Madrid and on in the 1970's and 80's. If they weren't all the same people, they were look-alikes in their leather sandals and their defiant rejection of grooming.
The Nicaraguans called them ''sandalistas,'' and Mrs. Chamorro's newly elected Vice President, Virgilio Godoy, has invited them to go home. Replacing them with a new set of well-shod itinerant groupies keeping the vote honest would do a world of good, in a world loudly signaling that's the way it wants to go.

LENGTH: 701 words

HEADLINE: Bush's 'Whitewash Effect' on Warming

BYLINE: By James H. Scheuer; James H. Scheuer, Democrat of New York, is chairman of the House Subcommittee on the Environment.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In his recent speech to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, President Bush, who promised in his campaign to use the ''White House effect'' to counter the ''greenhouse effect,'' delivered the ''whitewash effect'' instead.
Coming in the wake of the Hague conference, in which the U.S. was virtually alone in opposing proposals to cut emissions of gases that cause global warming, the speech was another example of his abdication of global leadership on the environment.
His top advisers reportedly were unanimous in urging him to take action to reduce emissions. They included William Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency; James Watkins, Secretary of Energy; Secretary of State James Baker, and the science adviser, Dr. D. Allan Bromley. 
Such unanimity is astonishing: for years, the Energy Department fought to protect the U.S. fossil fuel industry from E.P.A. forays. But this hard-won unanimity was overturned by the White House chief of staff, John Sununu, whose supposed qualification is a mechanical engineering degree.
Attacking ''faceless bureaucrats'' for trying to ''create a policy in this country that cuts off our use of coal, oil and natural gas,'' Mr. Sununu defended his veto on the grounds of two beliefs: that scientific evidence was insufficient to warrant action and that antipollution measures would sap U.S. economic growth. The first proposition is dubious; the second, preposterous.
Days later, when eight prestigious environmental organizations sent Mr. Bush a letter criticizing his aide's action, Jay Hair, president of the National Wildlife Federation, said with exasperation, ''The American people did not elect John Sununu.''
No one denies that pollution has dramatically changed the world's atmosphere. What is in question, and fiendishly difficult to prove, are the effects of the changes.
Most scientists agree that increasing levels of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases will inevitably lead to global warming. But no one is certain how fast and how much temperatures will rise, and what the effects will be in any geographical area.
Scientific uncertainty does not mean we have to wait for more research to take action. We do not need to know everything in order to do anything. The relevant policy question is not whether the scientists are right but whether policy makers can afford to be wrong. Suppose we take reasonable, cost-effective steps to slow down global warming, and learn later the scientists were wrong and we didn't have to do anything after all.
Admittedly, we will have spent billions of dollars to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases. But, wisely spent, that investment will have brought us billions of dollars of benefits: reduced pollution, improved health, more energy-efficient cars, U.S. industry that is more internationally competitive and the creation of new global markets for American-made environmental technologies and services.
But suppose we gamble that global warming won't happen, and are wrong. When we have unambiguous evidence that warming is happening, it will be too late to slow it down.
Scenarios of sudden change - temperatures climbing three to five degrees in a decade - pose the greatest risks. Predicted plagues will come to pass: forests will die, crops will wither, oceans will rise, disease will increase. And we will be defenseless before them. Money in the bank, unspent to reach environmental goals, will then be cold comfort.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Sununu would have us believe we can protect ourselves from global warming only at the expense of economic growth. But Japan's impressive economic growth has hardly been stymied by its huge investment in some of the world's toughest air pollution controls and its development of an economic sector twice as energy-efficient as ours.
On the contrary, Japanese companies see environmental protection as a major market opportunity, and are aggressively developing and selling environmental technologies.
The ''jobs vs. environment'' argument is a myth handed down by an earlier generation of industrialists and long discredited. It deserves a decent burial, even by Mr. Sununu, who surely knows better - or should.

HEADLINE: After 12 Years, Koch Says Rohatyn Misuses Watchdog Power

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In a stinging personal rebuke that unleashed the pent-up frustrations of 12 years in office, former Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York City has accused Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker and chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, of misusing his power as head of the fiscal watchdog agency.
Responding to recent published criticism of his fiscal stewardship by Mr. Rohatyn, Mr. Koch broke his past posture of wary respect for Mr. Rohatyn's powers and accused him of parlaying his reputation into millions of dollars in investment-banking fees.
Mr. Koch said Mr. Rohatyn had used ''his considerable political and presentational skills'' to acquire ''sole and inappropriate discretion'' in disposing of billions of dollars in city tax revenues. He called him ''the Robert Moses of municipal finance,'' a reference to the powerful but unelected ''master builder'' who dominated planning in the city for decades. 
The former Mayor made his comments in a letter that he sent to the weekly magazine 7 Days, which recently published an article in which Mr. Rohatyn said that Mr. Koch had ''squandered a lot of opportunity'' by increasing New York City's work force and granting labor settlements that were too generous and that contributed to the city's current fiscal problems. Mr. Rohatyn's office said last night that Mr. Rohatyn had left for Europe and could not be reached for comment. The office said it could not provide a telephone number for him in Europe.
The article quoted Mr. Rohatyn as saying, ''I could argue that if Ed Koch had been more austere in his labor contracts and the size of the city's payroll and the number of people on the public payroll - in squirreling away in some of the good times to deal with what was coming - that we wouldn't be in the shape we're in today.''
Mr. Rohatyn has made similar comments in the past and Mr. Koch has chafed at them, as he has at statements by Mr. Rohatyn and others that he interpreted as suggesting he had not played a major role in helping the city out of the fiscal crisis of the mid- and late 70's. But Mr. Rohatyn's comments were often couched in the dry language of fiscal reports and Mr. Koch has never before criticized Mr. Rohatyn so harshly in public.
''You have to understand that that kind of letter I wanted to write a dozen times,'' Mr. Koch said last night, after making a copy of it available to The New York Times. ''But every time I thought of writing it and discussed it with our people, they said, 'Listen, the law allows him to tie up city monies, and we are dependent on his largesse.' ''
''But I don't have that constraint any more, and I can tell him exactly what I think is truthful.''
''I would not have sent this letter except for the unprovoked, gratuitous, false attack launched by him,'' Mr. Koch added.
The Municipal Assistance Corporation was created by state legislation in the wake of the fiscal crisis. Its purpose was to issue bonds so the city could borrow indirectly in the public credit markets from which it was barred because of its precarious situation. The bonds are backed by the city's sales tax revenues, which the assistance corporation diverts to pay the interest and principal.
 
Koch's Accusation
Appointed in the mid-70's by Gov. Hugh L. Carey, Mr. Rohatyn has dictated how the city could spend any surplus revenues after the bondholders are paid.
But Mr. Koch said Mr. Rohatyn had created artificial surpluses by assuming that diverted revenues waiting to be paid out would earn unrealistically low interest. When more interest is earned, Mr. Koch said, Mr. Rohatyn declares a surplus and keeps control over the money, rather than returning it to the city's general fund. He said Mr. Rohatyn had created similar surpluses by periodic refinancings of the corporation's bonds.
''In other words,'' Mr. Koch's letter said, ''Felix through M.A.C. accumulates funds that otherwise would be available to support the city's operating expenses and insists that these funds, which he should never have accumulated, be used for specific one-time uses that he thinks have the highest priority.''
''Who elected this guy to make those kinds of decisions?'' the letter asked. ''Certainly not the people of the City of New York!''
 
Challenge on Work Force
In recent years, Mr. Rohatyn has proposed using surpluses mostly for mass transit and schools, insisting on the creation of a new School Construction Authority before he would make some money available. Mr. Koch said the money could well be used for other purposes.
In the 7 Days article, Mr. Rohatyn is quoted as saying: ''What Ed wanted to do was for us simply to give him the money for the expense budget, and we just didn't want to do it.''
Mr. Koch said most of the staffing increases that Mr. Rohatyn had faulted were for mandated programs like special education, child abuse, jails and homeless shelters. He challenged Mr. Rohatyn to specify how many thousands of workers should be cut.
The former Mayor also said he took quick action in the wake of the 1987 stock market plunge to limit the city's spending and ''continued that retrenchment until the day I left office.''
Mr. Koch also faulted Mr. Rohatyn, a member of Mayor David N. Dinkins's council of economic advisers, for not attacking the city's plan to help close its budget gap for the current fiscal year by using $150 million in one-time revenues from the sale of long-term bonds by the Battery Park City Authority to meet current expenses - a move some fiscal monitors have criticized.
 
'Talk Is Always Cheap'
''Yet rather than be the watchdog at the gate,'' Mr. Koch said, ''he is acting like a pampered poodle lying quiet as a lap dog.''
Mr. Koch's letter also accused Mr. Rohatyn, a senior partner in the investment banking concern Lazard Freres & Company, of profiting from his repuation for fiscal probity.
''Talk is always cheap,'' he added. ''Felix has parlayed that talk into millions of dollars in fees received from other cities and individuals based on his fame as M.A.C. chairman.'' Mr. Koch noted that Mr. Rohatyn takes no pay as chairman of the commission.
''Some sacrifice,'' he wrote. ''He is also exempt under the law for all conflicts of interests.''

HEADLINE: 3 Cities in Connecticut Begin Laying Off Workers

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 2

 BODY:
Facing declining revenues and a rising demand for more social services, three of Connecticut's largest cities - Bridgeport, New Haven and Stamford - have begun laying off employees and paring municipal programs to balance their budgets.
So far the layoffs have been small: 89 employees in New Haven, 15 in Bridgeport, 13 in Stamford. But layoffs are often viewed as a last resort for fixing city finances.
Officials in the three cities blamed their fiscal troubles on factors ranging from the Northeast's economic slowdown, particularly the depressed real-estate market, to the financing of social services, a burden that has been shifted to cities by Federal and state governments. 
''It's the trickle-down effect of 10 years of Reaganomics,'' said Stamford's Commissioner of Finance, Paul A. Pacter.
 
It Could Get Worse
They also criticized neighboring suburbs for not helping solve regional problems, like homelessness, that manifest themselves most often in urban areas.
The officials warned that the budget troubles in the three cities - as well as in some cities in New Jersey and New York - could worsen during the year, forcing more layoffs, service cuts and tax increases.
In New Haven, the newly elected Mayor, John Daniels, has already reduced a shortfall in the city's $235 million budget from $11.7 million to $3.5 million by laying off 89 workers and eliminating another 26 jobs through attrition. None of the cuts came from the police or fire departments. The city has about 4,000 employees, including school personnel.
New Haven was recently placed on Standard and Poor's CreditWatch list, suggesting that its bond rating might soon be lowered. Besides the layoffs, New Haven has closed an ice rink, restricted overtime, and cut back on publications.
Officials have also started negotiations with Yale University about possibly taxing some of its properties in the city, like athletic facilities.
 
Blames Previous Mayor
''They understand the plight of the city,'' said Allen Howe, an assistant press secretary to Mayor Daniels.
The Acting Controller, Peter Halsey, blamed the shortfall in part on slow collection of back taxes and a soft real estate market, which has made it difficult to sell some municipal properties.
But the largest cause, he said, was the unrealistic budget of the previous administration headed by Mayor Biagio DiLieto.
''It was unrealistically optimistic,'' Mr. Halsey said. ''The revenue projections were way too high, and expense projections were too low.''
Bridgeport, the state's largest city, with about 135,000 residents, is expected to have a small surplus this fiscal year. But Mary Moran, the city's newly elected Mayor, said this week that the city may have to lay off more workers next year to trim a projected $28 million deficit.
 
Long History of Trouble
Already, 15 employees in the parks and public works departments have been dismissed. ''There are going to be more,'' said Richard V. Robinson, the city's financial director.
Bridgeport, which has about 4,000 employees and an operating budget of about $285 million, has a long history of financial troubles. Three years ago, it obtained state-backed bonds to cover a $60 million deficit. In return, the state appointed a special panel to oversee the city's finances.
Mr. Robinson added that the city's unions' contracts may have to be renegotiated to bring down next year's projected shortfall.
The city is one of the state's poorest and has one of its highest property tax rates. ''Raising taxes is an option that the Mayor has said she will look at last,'' Mr. Robinson said. #5 Percent Cuts Requested By contrast, Stamford, with a population of 110,000, became one of the wealthier cities in Connecticut in the 1980's as it became the business center of Fairfield County. It has had budget surpluses every year for the last seven years, but not for the current year. No estimate of the projected deficit has been announced.
This week, however, Mayor Thom Serrani laid off 13 public works employees and ordered all city departments, including the police, to cut their budgets by 5 percent. The city has an operating budget of about $250 million and a 3,200-employee payroll.
Mr. Pacter blamed the deficit in part on the loss of at least $500,000 in conveyance taxes and building permit fees because of the slow real-estate market. He also said the market is so depressed that the city has been unable to find a buyer for $3 million of the $5 million in property it hoped to sell this year to help pay for the $45 million office building it bought from G.T.E. in 1986 for a new city hall.
''The real estate market is in the doldrums,'' he said.
 
Not Just Connecticut
Cities in New Jersey and New York are facing similar fiscal pressures. None of the major cities, though, have resorted to laying off workers so far.
''It's a problem that's starting to come to a head in certain communities, but it hasn't reached a critical point'' said Christopher J. Carew, analyst with the New Jersey League of Municipalities in Trenton.
In Yonkers, the fourth-largest city in New York with a population of about 190,000, revenue from three sources -real-estate transfer taxes, income-tax surcharges and sales taxes - is declining. The city is considering labor cutbacks.
City Manager Neil J. DeLuca estimated that the city's 1,943-person work force will be reduced by about 40 positions through attrition.
He said revenue from the city's property tax has remained constant, but declines in the real-estate transfer tax and city income tax are hurting the city's $372 million budget.
 
Slowdowns All Over
''We derive over $30 million from the two sources, but a soft real-estate market and a generally declining economy is hurting both,'' he said.
He added that sales-tax revenues have also slowed. ''We get about $30 million from the sales tax, and we are projecting a 2 to 3 percent growth rate,'' he said. ''If that number doesn't come up, we'll have to start laying people off.''
In White Plains, a city of 45,000 that swells by 200,000 commuters every weekday, Mayor Alfred Del Vecchio said the city was feeling the effects of a decline in revenues because of a stagnant housing market and a slow market in office space.
''There's a slowdown in new construction - by popular demand,'' he said, explaining that the city had reached a saturation point.
''We have 1,000 residential units for sale, which is a lot. Office space also is not renting, and new construction is coming on line. In fact, our new construction has practically come to a halt.''
He said municipalities also continue to suffer from mandates imposed by the state and Federal governments. ''The Federal E.P.A. says we'll have cleaner air and water, and the state passes the new regulations on to us, sometimes adding their own higher standards,'' he said. ''So we have to hire our own consultants and absorb other costs to fulfill these requirements.''
Mr. Del Vecchio also said that the state recently passed a telecommunications bill barring the city from taxing equipment inside a building. ''We have a lot of telephone company equipment in this city, so it will mean a $20 million loss to us over the next four years,'' he said.

HEADLINE: 2 Investor Groups Go To Waterford's Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 2

 BODY:
Investor groups led by Morgan Stanley & Company and Anthony J. F. O'Reilly have come to the rescue of Waterford Wedgwood P.L.C., the troubled maker of crystal and china.
Under the investment plan anounced today in Dublin, the two groups will together hold a 29.9 percent stake in the company, which is staggering under a burden of $233.7 million in debt.
Both Morgan Stanley and Mr. O'Reilly, who is chairman of the Pittsburgh-based H. J. Heinz Company and a leading industrialist in his native Ireland, said they were eager to invest in a company with luxury brands. ''There are 250 quintessential brands in the world,'' Mr. O'Reilly said in a telephone interview from Dublin, ''With Waterford and Wedgford, we have two of those.'' 
Morgan Stanley Leveraged Equity Fund II L.P. and Fitzwilton P.L.C., the group led by Mr. O'Reilly, will each pay about $61.5 million for their stake. They also plan to raise about $35.8 million through a share offering to Waterford shareholders. A substantial portion of the $158.9 million will be used to reduce Waterford's debt to about $80 million.
''I look forward to spending more of my time on operations and less on servicing an untenable level of debt,'' Patrick P. Bryne, Waterford Wedgwood's chief executive, said today in a telephone interview.
The heavy debt - a result of the $360 million-plus purchase of the British Wedgwood by the Irish Waterford in 1986 - proved to be too much as the company was hit by a host of problems.
When they merged, Waterford and Wedgwood had hoped to modernize their production and increase their worldwide marketing power. But the company found itself spending more time digging out of problems than exploiting opportunities.
Last April the Waterford crystal unit was found to be suffering from serious accounting and operation problems and had overstated 1988 earnings by some $21 million. That produced deep losses for the unit, largely offsetting the record operating earnings of Wedgwood.
Patrick Hayes, who was then chairman and chief executive, resigned, as did the finance director. The head of the crystal unit retired.
The company was dealt another blow when the crucial American and British markets softened last year. With Waterford's losses remaining high and Wedgwood's profits sinking, the company had a pretax loss of $32 million in 1989 on sales of $542.5 million.
The United States accounts for 40 percent of total sales and 70 percent of crystal sales. Britain accounts for about a third of total sales and 32 percent of china sales.
 
Labor Troubles
The company's problems have been compounded by an exodus of Wedgwood management and labor difficulties. After agreeing to a three-year wage freeze last summer, the 2,100 workers at Waterford crystal, who are among the highest paid in Ireland, rebelled when asked to make further concessions to increase productivity and lower costs.
Although the reduction in debt will certainly help, ''there are formidable problems to overcome,'' said John Hogan, head of research at Riada & Company, a Dublin brokerage.
Indeed, the labor impasse remains to be broken. The American and British economies are barely growing. Several department store chains in the United States are in bankruptcy proceedings or on the auction block. Dr. Hogan believes the company will be lucky to break even on a pretax basis in 1990.
Nonetheless, the leaders of Morgan Stanley and Fitzwilton say they are confident Waterford Wedgwood will become highly profitable. A Record of Winners Both Morgan Stanley and Fitzwilton have a strong record of picking winners. Morgan Stanley's first leveraged fund invested $30 million and returned $700 million.
The current Morgan Stanley fund, which is two years old, has invested about $900 million in 12 companies, including big American corporations like Colt Industries, the diversified manufacturer, and Fort Howard, the paper-products maker. The fund has a target rate of return of 40 percent pretax a year. ''To date, all of the investments, except one, are on track,'' said Robert H. Niehaus, a managing director of Morgan Stanley.
Mr. Niehaus is optimistic that Waterford will not be the second disappointment.
''Almost all the problems and losses are on the crystal side, and we are confident that the new management team will get that business to a reasonable cost position,'' he said. ''We see significant growth potential in the china business in the United States and Japan and we see additional growth opportunites in both the United States and Britain for the crystal business.''
Mr. O'Reilly will be applying his marketing skills to helping Waterford Wedgwood exploit those opportunities. He will be one of the four non-executive directors of Waterford Wedgwood from Fitzwilton and Morgan Stanley.
 
To Help Map Strategy
While he does not intend to play a day-to-day role, Mr. O'Reilly made it clear that he intended to help Wedgwood with its marketing strategy ''particularly in the North American market, with which I have considerable familiarity,'' he said.
He also intends to push management to do what he did successfully at Heinz: cut costs and increase volume to raise profit margins substantially, and then plow much of that cash into ''extra marketing.''
Another way to increase profits, he said, is to expand in Japan, where Wedgwood china is already doing well and where Waterford crystal has recently been introduced. Other makers of luxury goods - including Cartier, Dunhill and LVMH - have made ''very, very substantial profits'' by selling to the Japanese, he noted.
Mr. O'Reilly, 53 years old, is one of Ireland's leading press entrepreneurs. He also has interests in hotels and oil prospecting and owns a 500-acre estate in County Kildare, with a 28-room, 18th-century mansion.
He owns 10 percent of Fitzwilton, as does Metromedia, which is headed by John Kluge, and the Power Corporation, the Canadian company headed by Paul Demarais.
 
Diversified Investments
Fitzwilton's investments include Ford and General Motors dealerships in Britain, an Irish exporter of commercial freezers, a manufacturer of reflective materials and a big distributor of food and non-food cash-and-carry goods. Its companies have sales of about $600 million, and analysts estimate it earned $20 million in 1989. After the $61.5 million it plans to spend on Waterford Wedgwood, its investment will total about $190 million.
The price of 37.5 Irish pence, or 58 cents, a share that the two groups are paying for their stake in Waterford compares with the stock's peak of 150 pence in 1987. Fitzwilton initially began talks with Waterford two and a half years ago, but dropped out when the stock reached 140 pence.
On the London Stock Exchange, the stock closed today at 47 pence, up 2 pence.

Mr. O'Reilly, also breeds race horses at Castlemartin, the estate he rebuilt near Dublin. (The New York Times/Jonathan Player)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Germany And Japan Sell Dollars

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
In an unusual double-barreled assault, the central banks of West Germany and Japan intervened in foreign exchange markets yesterday to defend their currencies against a weeklong rally in the dollar.
The Bank of Japan, even with aid from the Federal Reserve's sale of dollars in New York, was not successful. The dollar rose to 150.25 yen, its highest level in more than two and a half years. The dollar was up from 149.85 yen Thursday and from 147.07 a week ago. 
The Bundesbank of West Germany, with help from the central banks of France and Spain, was able to slow the dollar's rise but it will not be clear for some time if the bank will be able to cap it. The dollar ended at 1.7177 marks, down from its day's high of 1.7230 and a little below Thursday's 1.7197. It had fallen to 1.7080 after the Bundesbank intervened yesterday but then rallied back. For the week, the dollar is up almost three pfennigs.
 
Varied Reasons for Rise
The dollar's strength against the Japanese currency is a result of troubles in the Japanese economy that have weakened investors' desire to hold yen. Against the mark, the rally is, in part, a response to uncertainty about the economic effect of the unification of the two Germanys.
For the Japanese, the dollar-selling is a determined effort to stem the yen's decline. The Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve have been selling dollars together for a week in support of the yen, which now is well above the 140 level thought to be the top of the range agreed to by the United States and its economic allies in the Group of Seven industrial nations.
Market experts say the weak yen is a major cause of the sharp stock market decline in Japan.
Of the two tools used by governments to support their currencies -intervention and higher interest rates to attract investors - only intervention is available to Japan right now because of a stalemate over interest rate policy.
In a very public dispute, the Bank of Japan is backing higher interest rates to support the yen and fight inflation, but the Finance Ministry is worried that higher rates would further depress the stock market. As a result, no action has been taken and the official discount rate in Japan, which is used to signal the direction for interest rates, remains at 4.25 percent.
The declining yen is also likely to hurt the effort by Japan to reduce its trade surplus with the United States, an issue that is expected to be addressed as President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu meet this weekend in Palm Springs, Calif.
 
Prediction on Rates
Ian Spence, the chief foreign exchange trader at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, said he thought it would now take a steep rise in Japan's discount rate to help the yen.
For the Bundesbank, traders said, the dollar-selling was more of a gentle reminder to the market that the central bank does not want the mark to weaken much because a stronger currency helps German officials control inflation.
While inflation is now low in West Germany, the plan for unification of the two Germanys has led to fears of sharply higher inflation. So the dollar-selling was also a way the Bundesbank could signal its determination to resist future inflationary pressures.
The action also suggests that the Bundesbank would prefer to keep the dollar at or just below 1.70 marks, which is believed to be the bottom of the range agreed to by the United States and its economic allies.
John Lipsky, director of international bond trading at Salomon Brothers in London, said the move by the Bundesbank was a ''signal to show the market that the central bank was still around.''
 
A Credibility Problem Is Seen
He said the central bank was facing a credibility problem because it had to convince the markets that it could curb the inflation that is expected when unification causes a burst of spending by the West German Government and East German consumers.
Yet, with inflation now so low in Germany, it is hard to justify any major policy shift, like raising interest rates, that would display the Bundesbank's commitment. Inflation for the 12 months ended in February was 2.6 percent, the same as the January number and down from a 3 percent annual rate for November and December.
This was the first dollar-selling by the Bundesbank since Jan. 4, when a surprise intervention sent the dollar down sharply. This round was less of a surprise because the dollar had risen this week to 1.72 marks, around the level at which the Bundesebank intervened in January.
A German official familiar with Bundesbank policy said the dollar-selling yesterday did not represent any new policy.

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Unchanged

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
The Government's barometer of economic vitality was flat in January and might have fallen but for a jump in building permits ascribed to mild weather, the Commerce Department said today.
The index of leading indicators was unchanged for the month after rising a revised six-tenths of a percent in December, the department said.
January's performance was weaker than expected by economists, who had generally forecast that the index would rise by three-tenths of a percent. The report comes at a time when other economic data show little growth. 
 
Markets Post Gains
Bond prices rose on the prospect of lower inflation in a weaker economy, which helped support the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day up 24.77 points, to 2,660.36.
The department originally said the index, intended to signal the direction of the economy in six to nine months, had risen eight-tenths of a percent in December but revised that to six-tenths.
Seven of the 11 components were negative for the index in January: manufacturers' orders for consumer goods, money supply, orders for plant and equipment, stock prices, commodity prices, an index of consumer expectations and weekly jobless claims.
Three components were positive: building permits, faster vendor deliveries and manufacturers' unfilled orders.
Building permits and housing starts, which had been suppressed by bitterly cold weather in December, rose strongly during the exceptionally mild weather in January.
One indicator, the average workweek, was unchanged in January.
 
How Economists See It
Economists said the report suggests further slow growth in the economy. They said it would not sway the Federal Reserve to change its neutral credit policy.
''I don't think the leading indicators tell us much about the economy,'' said Robert Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank. ''They only reinforce the notion that there are pluses and minuses and we're growing at a pretty slow rate.''
For the near future, economists see the economy plodding along, without sharp upturns or downturns. Inflation, more than growth, will be raising questions in the second quarter, they said.
''For now, it's a continuation of a non-recessionary, non-booming economy,'' said Kevin Flanagan, money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
 
G.N.P. Shows Weakness
The Commerce Department said Wednesday that the nation's gross national product, the total output of goods and services, expanded at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of nine-tenths of a percent in the final three months of 1989. That was up from an initial estimate of five-tenths of a percent but was still the weakest quarterly performance since 1986.
With January unchanged, the leading indicators index was at 145.3 of its 1982 base of 100.
The index of coincident indicators, which shows current economic trends, declined seven-tenths of a percent in January after rising two-tenths of a percent in December.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Off 7.1% In January

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
Sales of new single-family homes fell 7.1 percent in January to the lowest level in 10 months, the Commerce Department said today.
The seasonally adjusted January drop, which followed an 8.4 percent decline in December, surprised and distressed industry economists.
They had thought that mild weather and the prospect of higher mortgage rates would prove an incentive for buyers during the month. 
 
Good Weather, Poor Sales
''We were looking for a pretty solid number, largely because of the wonderful weather swing,'' said Dave Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders.
Many areas of the country had their warmest January on record, and builders had responded enthusiastically. New-home construction soared 29.6 percent, and 26.7 percent more building permits were issued in January than in December.
But buyers stayed home. The January sales rate, at 589,000 units, was the lowest since March 1989, when the annualized rate was 556,000 units.
''What this means is that builders were stimulated by good weather, but buyers weren't,'' Mr. Seiders said, and that means the level of building activity will be curtailed quickly.
Mr. Seiders said of the outlook for 1990, ''This kind of a start worries us.'' 2 Regions Down and 2 Are Up The biggest regional drop occurred in the South, where sales fell 18.9 percent in January from December levels. Sales dropped 5.9 percent in the West.
But in the Northeast, sales were up 13.5 percent, while the Midwest had a rise of 1.1 percent.
The average price of a new home in January fell to $152,600 from $157,200 in December, the department said, as builders sought to draw in buyers. Many builders also offered free or low-cost options like fireplaces and decks as a sales incentive, Mr. Seiders said.
The median sales price, however, rose to $127,000 from $125,200, meaning half of all sales were above that figure and half were below.
Dick Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, said long-term mortgage rates by mid-January had hit 10 percent for a 30-year loan and were rising.
Normally, rising interest rates encourage sales as buyers seek to lock in mortgages before they climb further, Mr. Peach said.
 
Lack of Demand Cited
''Now that we're very late in the economic recovery, it seems that pent-up demand has largely been satisfied,'' he added, so the potential for sales is weaker.
He said the inventory of unsold homes had risen to a 7.3-month supply by the end of January, up from 7 months in December.
''I don't think we're out of the woods yet as far as the backed-up inventories that builders have to sell,'' Mr. Peach commented. ''That's not a good sign for housing starts.''

HEADLINE: Dow up 24.77; Week's Gain is 96.17

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks closed a week of five consecutive gains yesterday, as bond yields declined and individuals and small institutional investors appeared to move strongly into telephone issues.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.77, to 2,660.36, closing out the week with a cumulative rise of 96.17.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose slightly, but was still relatively modest at 164.3 million shares, up from 157.9 million on Thursday. Advances outnumbered declines, 982 to 484. 
 
Best Week Since Plunge
The 3.8 percent rise in the Dow for the week was the best gain since the average rose 4.7 percent, to 2,689.14, in the week ended Oct. 20. That was the week after the Dow fell 190.58 points on Friday, Oct. 13.
The last time the industrial average rose in five consecutive trading sessions was the week ended Nov. 28, when it jumped 69.97 points, to 2,702.01.
Laszlo Birinyi, the president of Birinyi Associates, a Wall Street research firm, said the week's gain was ''no big deal - it's happened 381 times since 1915,'' which was the year that Dow calculations began in their current form.
''The most positive thing today,'' he added, ''is that except for one 'buy program' in the morning, we've had very little program trading. That means you have real buyers in there.''
He said he had spotted numerous orders of fewer than 10,000 shares for the telephone stocks - a sign that individuals and small institutions were buying them.
''It's a positive sign,'' he said, ''and suggests they think interest rates have peaked, or are near the peak.''
American Telephone and Telegraph and the seven regional telephone companies all advanced. Nynex was up 1 3/4, to 81 3/4; Southwestern Bell gained 1 1/4, to 57 1/4; BellSouth was up 1/2, to 53 1/4; U S West rose 5/8, to 69 3/4; Bell Atlantic gained 3/8, to 91 1/4; Pacific Telesis was up 5/8, to 45 1/4, and Ameritech rose 1 1/4, to 59 1/4. A.T.& T. tacked on 1/2, to 40 3/8, with 1.2 million shares changing hands.
Philip Morris, the second-most-active issue, rose 7/8, to 36 7/8, on volume of 2.6 million shares.
Ford Motor rose 1 1/4, to 47 1/8, on 1.36 million shares. General Motors advanced 1, to 46, on nearly 2.5 million shares. Chrysler tacked on 3/4, to 17 1/4. Traders said that analysts were becoming a little more optimistic on American car sales and are now looking for volume to improve.
 
Transportation Issues Gain
The Dow transportation index rose 12.09 points yesterday, to 1,145.98, a 6 percent jump for the week. UAL gained 1 3/4, to 134 1/4, and Conrail rose 1 1/8, to 48 1/8.
Among issues showing strong gains were Circus Circus, the casino operator, which rose 3 1/8, to 50, on a recommendation by Steven Eisenberg, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company.
Motorola, which is expected to introduce a new computer on Monday, rose 2 3/8, to 63.
Other averages recorded small gains. The Dow utilities rose 0.50, to 219.63; the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rose 2.80, to 335.54, and the New York Stock Exchange composite rose 1.45, to 184.97.
The American Stock Exchangex market value index rose 2.08, to 356.12, while the Nasdaq composite tacked on 3.81 points, to 431.02.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Coffee Prices Rise Sharply; Copper Hits a 4-Month High

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Arabica coffee futures rose sharply yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, and copper futures reached their highest level in nearly four months at the New York Commodity Exchange.
A flurry of late buying lifted coffee for March delivery by 2.25 cents a pound to close at the day's high of 99 cents. The rise was set off by reports that Mexico may buy 500,000 of the 132-pound bags this year. Mexico, a large producer, said on Thursday that it might have to import coffee to make up for short domestic supplies. That amplified existing concerns of tight supplies for immediate needs.
Traders said Mexican processors had already made small purchases.
 
Copper Rises on Supply Concerns
Copper prices rose, meanwhile, in reaction to concerns that supplies are shrinking.
The lack of deliveries against the March contract has signaled traders that supplies are tight. Owners of the deliverable copper may be withholding it, hoping for higher prices.
Helping fuel copper's rally was widespread talk that supplies in London Metal Exchange warehouses may have shrunk by 10,000 metric tons this last week.
Copper contracts for March soared 4.6 cents a pound, to $119.80.
Civil unrest in the Ivory Coast, the world's leading cocoa producer, also set off a wave of nervous buying in cocoa at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, with the spot March contract rising $50, to $1,123 a ton. Cocoa traders and analysts said they doubted that the price rise would continue.
A slump in cocoa exports has hurt the Ivory Coast's economy, leading to riots and calls for the resignation of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny.

HEADLINE: Soviet Trade Pact Expected

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, March 2

 BODY:
United States officials said today that they expect to conclude a new trade accord with the Soviet Union in time for a superpower summit meeting in June, a move that would end a 16-year dispute linking trade with Soviet emigration policy.
''It is highly likely we will be able to come to a trade agreement in time for the summit,'' the deputy trade representative, Julius Katz, said after two days of talks between United States and Soviet teams in London. ''I don't see any obstacles to that.''
A broad trade pact is a prerequisite for the United States to grant the Soviet Union most-favored-nation status, which would greatly reduce the tariffs on Soviet goods exported to the United States and clear the way for lending to Moscow by the American Government.
The status has been withheld by Washington under the 1974 Jackson-Vanik amendment, which denies it to countries that restrict emigration. A law to liberalize emigration is expected to be passed soon by the Soviet Parliament.
President Bush has made the trade pact and most-favored-nation status a centerpiece of his economic show of support for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reform program. The moves are likely to be portrayed as significant achievements of the June summit meeting.
United States officials said today that they expected a trade pact to be reached by April or May, which would give Congress time to ratify it.
Soviet negotiators were unavailable for comment today, but the delegation leader, Yuri Chumakov, deputy minister for foreign economic relations, said earlier that he was optimistic about an accord, although it would take months to reach.

HEADLINE: Revenue Problems Endanger Budgets In Half the States

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
More than half of the states are battling serious budget problems as they approach the final months of the fiscal year, and eight Eastern states are striving to avoid deficits that could disrupt statewide and local programs.
In the past month there has been a steady drumbeat of fiscal bad news: revenue falling short, programs cut back, workers laid off, economies weakening. The situation has startled the states' officials and prompted partisan squabbling over faulty forecasts and excessive spending. All the fiscal years start July 1 except New York's, which starts April 1.
Congress is also being widely blamed for forcing the states to pay for costly new Medicaid services, and Democratic governors say President Bush's stand against taxes makes it difficult to raise local taxes. 
 
What Bush Said or Didn't
Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut, a Democrat, has personal experience of the unpopularity of raising taxes. ''The tax increase last year for Connecticut is causing me serious political problems, and I certainly won't recommend any this year,'' he said in an interview. ''President Bush has said'No new taxes' so often that people now honestly believe they can get all kind of services without paying for them.''
But Gov. John R. McKernan Jr. of Maine, a Republican who raised taxes last year, retorted in an interview: ''That's whining! President Bush didn't say the Governors shouldn't raise taxes. The President said if taxes have to be raised, raise them at the level closest to the people affected so you can get a debate about whether they are really necessary.''
But experts in public finance say the revenue shortages are primarily a result of a slowing of the national economy that was far worse than had been expected and of state budget forecasters' inability to warn of sudden declines.
 
Bad, but 'Perfectly Ordinary'
''It is the most widespread set of budgetary imbalances that we have seen since the depths of the 1982 recession,'' said Herman B. Leonard, who teaches public finance at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, ''but it is a perfectly ordinary and anticipated outcome of a cooling national economy.''
There is no crisis, Dr. Leonard and other experts say, but there could be greater hardship if states fail to maintain adequate cash reserves to cope with economic slumps.
Interestingly, the Northeastern states are in the most trouble because they enjoyed so much prosperity in recent years, said Dr. Harold A. Hovey, president of State Policy Research, an Alexandria, Va., publisher of periodicals on states' economies. ''Northeastern states estimated better economic growth than the national average, and they are getting economic performance that isn't as good as the national average,'' he said.
 
Where the Deficits Will Be
Potential deficits are ahead this year for Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island, Vermont, Virginia and West Virgina, according to the National Conference of Legislatures. Those states' revenue shortage is so severe that they are not expected to meet their obligations without raising taxes, floating deficit bonds or making substantial reductions in spending.
New Jersey, for example, expects to eliminate a projected $550 million deficit on its $12.1 billion budget this year through measures like imposing a freeze on state hiring, deferring maintenance on state buildings and returning 500 automobiles in state use to car dealers.
Nineteen other states scattered over every region except the Far West are collecting taxes well below anticipated levels, according to the conference of state legislatures. After conducting a survey, the conference reported Feb. 8 that most states can offer no firm estimates of how slack their revenue has become.
Slack tax revenue usually forces states to draw on cash reserves, postpone some expenditures, or both. Unlike the Federal Government, all states but Vermont have enacted mandatory budget-balancing.
 
Surpluses in the West
California, Hawaii, Idaho, Nevada, Oregon and other Western states are still growing, their employment has held steady and they are running surpluses. Budget directors report that Southwestern states, hard hit by sagging oil prices, and Midwestern states, which saw a drop in farm prices in the early 1980's, have stabilized themselves fiscally as a result of improving economic conditions and austerity budgets for several years.
Dr. Hovey said only Nevada and Washington were enjoying a boom, based on substantial growth in personal income, population and employment.
The budget problem in the State of Washington, for example, is figuring the best way to spend an unexpected $724.7 million, Gov. Booth Gardner, a Democrat, said in an interview. ''It's allowing us to fund services that are so badly in need, especially those that help children,'' he said.
Nevadans measure economic conditions by counting big hotels. ''When the Mirage Hotel Casino opened last Thanksgiving in Las Vegas, it was the largest hotel in the world,'' said Lieut. Gov. Robert J. Miller, who has also been Acting Governor since January 1989, after Gov. Richard Bryan was elected to the Senate. ''The Mirage is already the second-largest hotel in Las Vegas. By summer it will be the third largest in Las Vegas, and in two years it could be the fifth largest.''
 
And a Boost for Las Vegas
He said 5,000 people a month move into the Las Vegas area, which helps explain why Nevada is the fastest-growing state in proportion to its population. Nevada expects to have a $30 million surplus in its $3.9 billion two-year budget.
But healthy states can sicken quickly, as the series of deficits in once-booming states demonstrates. ''While there are no overt signs of fiscal stress in the states as a whole, the condition of the Northeastern states is cause for concern,'' says a report on the states' 1990 budgets by the National Association of State Budget Officers. ''The decline in their revenue streams came very quickly and could portend equally rapid downturns in other states.''
Budget forecasts this year have generally fallen in the accepted realm of accuracy, said Ronald K. Snell, program director of the National Conference of Legislatures. He said achieving that level of accuracy requires states to maintain cash reserves equal to 5 percent of their budgets. But one in five states, including many with large deficits this year, have little or nothing in reserve. On average, Mr. Snell said, states have only about half the reserves they should.
 
Impossible, Some Governors Say
But some governors say it is impossible to maintain large reserves for contingencies. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York defends his plan to borrow $615 million in deficit notes to cover part of this year's $1 billion shortage.
''It would be ludicrous to save $615 million just in case the econcomy suddenly and unexpectedly plummets,'' Governor Cuomo said. ''It would be ludicrous to have that money doing nothing when we don't have enough beds for AIDS patients, when we don't have enough treatment beds for people on drugs, when we don't have enough prison cells for violent felons and when we don't have enough money to rebuild our bridges.
''Especially when the alternative is so reasonable - we can take out a short-term loan for $615 million and pay it back in the next budget.''
The rug was pulled out from under the Northeast in the last three months of 1989, when the states' economies declined much more rapidly than their budget directors had forecast. In Massachusetts and New Hampshire, forecasts have been off by 10 percent.
 
The Crisis in Massachusetts
''Over the last 18 months, tax revenues have fallen precipitously and we still don't know where the bottom is,'' said S. Stephen Rosenfeld, chief secretary to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, which is in the worst fiscal condition of any state. The deficit was $1.1 billion last year. Cuts in spending reduced it to $500 million on a $12.8 billion budget.
Mr. Rosenfeld said that discussions on resolving the deficit have deadlocked, with legislators resisting the Governor's proposals for new taxes. As a result, he said, Massachusetts will probably have to dump the problem on counties and municipalities. They are the last to receive state funds each year.
''Massachusetts is literally paralyzed,'' said State Senator David H. Locke, a Republican. Mr. Rosenfeld did not argue.
The picture is bleak elsewhere, partly because of the drop in revenue from sales taxes, income taxes and corporate taxes.
New York's anticipated $1 billion revenue shortage for the fiscal year 1990, now the largest in the nation, is threatening the state's credit rating. Vermont, which faces a $90 million deficit on a $1.2 billion budget, has closed some of its civil courts until June 30. Maine is trying a new lottery to raise $7 million, offering a tax amnesty to raise $15 million and reducing aid to higher education and local governments.
Connecticut is reportedly exhausting its cash reserves and cutting 2,300 jobs. New Hampshire has already frozen spending and increased many fees charged by the state government to eliminate a $60 million deficit on a $642 million budget. West Virginia proposes to sell its state liquor business to raise $20 million. Arizona is cutting back nearly all state services and proposing to raise $170 million in taxes.
 
When It Really Will Hurt
Belt-tightening in some states will be painful. West Virginia, for example, plans to close a state-run nursing home with about 150 patients that provides about 60 jobs for residents of Hillsboro, a town of 300 people in Pocahontas County, the poorest in the state.
Gov. Gaston Caperton, a Democrat, said eliminating the nursing home was one of some ''very tough'' measures this year to make up for a $40 million shortage in revenue on a $1.7 billion state budget.
Nationally, economic troubles were evident in the fiscal year 1988 and the economy soured in 1989, said Sara L. Johnson, managing economist at DRI/ McGraw Hill, an economic forecasting company. ''The entire Northeast region has made the transition from economic boom to stagation,'' Ms. Johnson said. ''In fact, New England is in recession and mid-Atlantic economies are stalled, in our estimation.''
She said that no single industry nor any group of industries was responsible for the slump, but that the dominant industries in each state were obviously leading the decline.
Governors and budget directors say they cannot control spending because of a recent surge in state and federally mandated programs and court-ordered prison expansions.
 
Mandated Programs' Squeeze
In South Carolina, budget officials said 98 percent of the $7.3 billion budget this year was being spent on mandated programs, leaving little flexibility for adjusting to economic conditions or increasing costs of services.
''Practically everything we spend is mandated by statute,'' said Mike L. Shealy, a spokesman for South Carolina's state budget division. South Carolina, which has $360 million in reserves, had projected a shortage this year, but the boom in construction after Hurricane Hugo improved business tax receipts.
Two weeks ago Standard & Poor's indicated that New York's and Connecticut's excellent ratings were imperiled by rising deficits. New York's revenue forecasts have been ''overly optimistic'' in the past two years and Connecticut is trying to solve its problems by depleting cash reserves and using other resources that will not recur, said Hyman C. Grossman, managing director of Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: FOREST SERVICE ABUSING ROLE, DISSIDENTS SAY

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 3

 BODY:
Saying the Forest Service has abused millions of acres entrusted to it, supervisors and professionals in the service are rebelling against Federal policies that promote logging, mining and road-building in 191 million acres of public forests.
The dispute could also determine how the country manages nearly half its clean water supply, its biggest and oldest trees, its largest wilderness areas, its most bountiful wildlife habitats and resources, which provide the most jobs in many Western communities.
In the rush to sell Federal timber, the agency created by Theodore Roosevelt to manage the vanishing wilderness has lost sight of its original goal, say the supervisors of many national forests and hundreds of lower employees who have joined a dissident group in the service.
 
The Leading Road-Builder
They say the Forest Service has become the No. 1 road-builder, hacking more than 340,000 miles of logging roads in the woods in the last half-century, and that it is now spending more money on cutting down trees than for any other purpose.
''We're managing our resources horribly,'' said Jeff DeBonis, a Eugene, Ore., forester who organized the Association of Forest Service Employees for Environmental Ethics in an attempt, he says, to change the service's direction. His group claims it has 1,500 service members out of a total of 38,000 employees. 
The protests are not unheeded. At the very top of the Forest Service, officials who were saying a decade ago that boards are more valuable than old trees have been replaced, Current appointees, the dissidents say, who believe century-old stands of trees have a value beyond lumber's value.
F. Dale Robertson, chief of the service since 1987, said in an interview that the internal debate was good for the service. Reflecting a change in its direction and a shift in the public's view of forests toward more concern for the environment, the service's proposed budget for the fiscal year 1991 is ''better-rounded than we've ever had before,'' he said.
President Bush has proposed that $175 million be spent on a tree-planting program to be supervised by the service. But critics say that merely planting new trees while another arm of the service is knocking down centuries-old trees will leave America's woodlands impoverished.
 
Change in Society
''There's a change going on in society, and the Forest Service can't just ignore that,'' Mr. Robertson said. ''We intend to be more environmentally responsible.''
Many top agency officials from around the country applaud the philosophical changes, but they say more should be done to change programs and spending priorities to reflect the good stewardship values of the service.
Its budget is established by the President and Congress, but the process of deciding how to spend the money begins with the philosophy and requests of the 156 forest supervisors.
For example, Tom Kovalicky, supervisor of the 2.2 million-acre Nez Perce National Forest in Idaho, makes a request each year on how much money to spend on his forest. He has complained that his efforts to restore salmon and steelhead runs receive minimal financing, while the timber-cutting program, which he says harms those streams, receives the lion's share of the $14 million Nez Perce budget.
 
'Troubling Times'
''These are troubling times for many of us,'' Mr. Kovalicky and supervisors of national forests in Montana, Idaho and the Dakotas wrote three months ago in an open lettter to Mr. Robertson. ''Many people, internally as well as externally, believe the current emphasis of national forest programs does not reflect the land-stewardship values embodied in our forest plan.''
Citing continuing logging programs in pristine areas and ''sagging'' public support for the service, the supervisors from the northern Rocky Mountain region who signed the letter wrote, ''We have become a dysfunctional Forest Service family.''
Similar letters to Mr. Robertson came from supervisors of national forests throughout the West. He said this ''straight talk'' could help fashion for the agency a new conservationist role, which he said many have been seeking for a long time.
Even with its enormous acreage, $3 billion annual budget and legion of rangers and biologists, the service has long operated in virtual anonymity. But now, driven by a revolt from within and criticism from outside, the agency is going through a major, and very public, transformation.
''There are a lot of good, dedicated people in the Forest Service, but there is also a lot of dead wood left over from 25 years of rape-pillage-and-plunder mentality,'' said Don Kern, a hydrologist with the Flathead National Forest in Montana. ''Unfortunately, many of those people are in key management positions.''
 
Critics in Logging Industry
Some leaders in the logging industry say the revolt in the Forest Service is fueled by environmental zealots.
''They're rabble-rousers,'' said Troy Reinhart, a former service employee who is executive director of Douglas Timber Operators. The group represents Oregon companies that depend on public land for their wood supply.
Mr. Robertson said he would prefer that the dissidents promote change by quietly working within the agency, but he said he is ''officially neutral'' about the group.
Mr. DeBonis, founder of the group, resigned last week as a Federal timber sales planner after 12 years with the service because, he said, he wanted to stop supporting the timber policy and devote more time to the organization.
Mr. DeBonis, who now publishes a quarterly newsletter, Inner Voices, started his campaign early last year, when he wrote a blistering letter to Mr. Robertson.
 
A Letter of Protest
''Our basic problem right now is that we are much too biased towards the resource-extraction industries, particularly the timber industry,'' Mr. DeBonis wrote to the chief. ''We support their narrowly focused, shortsighted agenda.''
He also sent a computer memorandum to other employees reporting on a conference that singled out the Forest Service as being mainly responsible for severe logging of old-growth forests in the Pacific Northwest.
After being reprimandeded for using the service's computer, Mr. DeBonis began organizing the dissident group on his own time, he said, by sending fliers to other Forest Service offices.
His criticism that the Forest Service has become too much of an industry ally has been repeated by supervisors of some national forests, pointing to the increased logging on public lands.
For most of the last five years, the share of the service's budget for wildlife and stewardship has been in steady decline, while more than a third has gone to the timber program.
 
Rise in Logging on Public Land
Before World War II, very little logging was done on national forest land. But as the last of the big trees disappeared from private land, attention turned to the reserves, set aside 100 years ago, as a source of the industry's wood supply. In the last three years, a record number of trees have been cut from the national forests, more than 12 billion board feet a year, or triple the number of a generation ago.
In the Pacific Northwest, where almost half of all the logging on national forests is done, the Forest Service has cut the oldest and biggest trees first and replacedthem with new trees.
In the early 1980's, John B. Crowell was the Assistant Secretary of Agriculture in charge of the national forests. Mr. Crowell said one of his main goals was to speed logging of the 3 million to 4 million acres of original forest left in the West. That policy is now under review, Mr. Robertson said.
Since the mid-1980's, the last of the old growth has been cut at a pace of about 70,000 acres a year. Most national forests in the Northwest are now laced with roads and clearcuts. In the Gifford Pinchot National Forest in Washington (named for the service's founder) less than a tenth of the 1.1 million acres of the original forest remains as it was in Mr. Pinchot's time.
''We are trading our forests in on European-style plantations that are really nothing more than economic tree farms,'' Chris Maser wrote in his book, ''Forest Primeval,'' published last year by Sierra Club Books. Mr. Maser is a former research scientist with the Interior Department.
 
A Legacy in the Balance
In the view of Mr. Maser and some top scientists in the Forest Service, the Government is wiping out the biological archives of the old forest, a legacy of several generations of plant life that may be needed as a hedge against disease, global warming and fires.
''Our forest lands should be more than just agricultural lands with a slow-maturing crop,'' said Dr. Jerry Franklin, an ecologist with the Forest Service who is considered the Government's foremost expert on old-growth forests. He advocates keeping much of the remaining ancient forest of the West intact as a storehouse of information for future foresters.
After years as an outside voice, Dr. Franklin's warnings are finding a home in the upper echelons of the Forest Service.
''For the first time as an agency we are recognizing the importance of old growth on a national level,'' said Mr. Robertson, who noted that this new policy was influenced by the work of Dr. Franklin. ''Old-growth forests are an important ecosystem that we are just beginning to understand.''
