HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;
Soviet Union Opposition Hits Democracy Circuit for Votes

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 3

 BODY:
At 2 A.M. today, Ilya I. Zaslavsky, political kingpin, was on the phone with his pollster. A last-minute survey of the Oktobr district of Moscow showed the tide running against the Communist establishment and in favor of Mr. Zaslavsky's slate in Sunday's local elections.
''He's smelling victory already,'' smiled the pollster, Aleksei G. Levinson, who urged his client to take aim at a few working-class high-rise apartment buildings for a final wall-poster assault.
Mr. Zaslavsky, a 30-year-old member of the Soviet Parliament, is at the center of a new and increasingly sophisticated network of pro-democracy insurgents from within and outside the Communist Party who believe that they have a real chance on Sunday to wrest control of Moscow and other cities from the party regulars.
More than a million seats are at stake in the electoral sweepstakes that American diplomats have dubbed Slavic Super Sunday, elections to local councils and republic parliaments in Russia, the Ukraine and Byelorussia. 
Hampered by voter confusion, the Communist Party's domination of the electoral laws, and their own inexperience, groups advocating greater democracy are doubtful of winning control of the Slavic heartland as a whole.
But with the help of campaign techniques borrowed from the West, they have mounted their most formidable challenges in Moscow, Leningrad and other big cities. True Democracy? If they succeed, they have audacious plans to turn these urban governments into strongholds of real democracy and free enterprise, and to step up pressure on President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for bolder changes.
''In the districts and cities where we take power, we will register new parties,'' Mr. Zaslavsky explained over tea late the other night, following a day of barnstorming. ''We'll publish newspapers, create free radio stations, support democrats in other districts. We'll begin recall campaigns against conservative deputies to the national Parliament.
'''What we have now is a permanent revolution, and not the kind Lenin or Trotsky had in mind.''
Yuri A. Prokofiev, the Moscow Communist Party chief, conceded in an interview this week that the insurgents stand a fair chance of winning a majority in the 498-member Moscow City Council, and naming one of their own -possibly a radical economist, Gavriil K. Popov, or a political scientist, Sergei B. Stankevich - as the city's chief executive.
''Well, I see no harm in it, and if it happens we will cooperate with them,'' Mr. Prokofiev said, although he regards most of the opposition as political dilettantes who do not really want to take responsibility for the city's cratered streets and empty stores.
The Communists have not yet delivered on their promise to legalize rival parties, but in each of the republics preparing for Sunday's balloting, the opposition has stitched together a campaign coalition to take on the Communist monopoly.
In the Russian Republic, the eclectic umbrella group Democratic Russia includes the anti-Stalinist group Memorial, the Moscow Voters Association, the Association of Social Democrats, and a patchwork of local Popular Fronts and Communist clubs impatient with the mainstream party.
At least half of their candidates are Communist Party members, most of them disgruntled with the party leadership.
 
No Admirers of Gorbachev
The candidates differ on specific planks, but they share a commitment to unfettered, multiparty democracy and more Western-style market economics, and a general sense that Mr. Gorbachev has frittered away his credibility in making compromises.
''Personally, I'm against perestroika and glasnost,'' Mr. Zaslavsky said wryly, dismissing the Gorbachev emphases on economic and politics restructuring and on openness. ''I'm for democracy and freedom of speech.''
Political independents who won seats in the Soviet Parliament last year are now spreading their coattails.
Boris N. Yeltsin, one of the leaders of the opposition faction in the Soviet Parliament, is now campaigning for the Russian Republic's legislature and is trying to take enough like-minded candidates with him to be chosen the President of the republic. Soviet law allows a politician to hold elected positions at any two levels.
Others like Mr. Zaslavsky are focusing on local councils, hoping to create little islands of power.
Mr. Zaslavsky is a deceptively frail-looking man, crippled by a childhood illness and elected to the Soviet Parliament last year as the nominee of the Society for Invalids.
In the Oktobr district of Moscow, a region of about 200,000 voters, one of them Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Mr. Zaslavsky has built an impressive non-Communist political machine.
He has endorsed a slate of about 150 candidates to represent that district on its regional council, the Moscow City Council and the Russian republic's parliament. He has also worked in close league with the Democratic Russia group to help candidates in other districts.
Mr. Zaslavsky has organized seminars for candidates, consulted psychologists on preparing election materials, and enlisted writers with connections to printing presses. He has tapped a nonpartisan civic fund to get around campaign spending limits.
 
Voter Meetings
He often speaks to three voter meetings a day on behalf of his slate, taking questions from the audience for two hours at each stop while the candidate basks in his reflected popularity.
''It's a kind of papal blessing,'' said Mr. Levinson, whose polls give Mr. Zaslavsky a local approval rating that Mr. Gorbachev would envy.
Mr. Zaslavsky's team has used political polling more extensively than any independent political group in the past.
He first commissioned an extensive poll in late December by Mr. Levinson, a sociologist. It provided a detailed picture of voter attitudes that was valuable for orienting candidates.
In precincts where several progressive candidates had been nominated, small opinion surveys were used to identify those with little chance and to persuade them to withdraw.
By all accounts, the toughest battle for independent candidates has been getting the attention of voters dazed by the new profusion of politics.
Most voters on Sunday will be confronted with at least four ballots containing the names of 30 or more candidates in all. The six-week election sprint has allowed little time for individual candidates to distinguish themselves.
''Where there is a clear choice between a party-apparatus candidate and a progressive candidate, it is nine to one the democrat wins,'' Mr. Levinson said. ''So the party strategy has been to hide who is who.''
 
Propaganda Aplenty
Although the election law banned advertising and required that all material be printed by supposedly neutral election commissions, it is clear from the papered walls of any Moscow housing complex that both the party and its challengers have circumvented that rule with abandon.
Supporters of the democracy slate have stuffed mailboxes with lists of candidates - the Soviet equivalent of palm cards - and finagled enough paper to print thousands of wall posters boasting of their independence from the Communist machine.
''We're having a lot of difficulties making copies of the list because practically all typesetting shops are controlled,'' said Vladimir O. Bokser, a campaign coordinator for the Moscow Voters Association. ''You make an agreement with one place where there's a xerox machine, it turns out today there's no paper, tomorrow there's no copying powder, the day after tomorrow the machine breaks down, and on the fourth day, the party secretary comes and stops the whole process.
''The only thing that will work now are these lists. If we manage to spread them, I have no doubts about the outcome of the elections.''

HEADLINE: Wine Equation Puts Some Noses Out of Joint

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Calculate the winter rain and the harvest rain (in millimeters). Add summer heat in the vineyard (in degrees centigrade). Subtract 12.145. And what do you have? A very, very passionate argument over wine.
Prof. Orley Ashenfelter, a Princeton economist, has devised a mathematical formula for predicting the quality of red wine vintages in France. And the guardians of tradition are fuming. 
Robert M. Parker Jr., generally regarded as the most influential wine critic in America, calls Professor Ashenfelter's research ''ludicrous and absurd.''
William Sokolin, a New York wine merchant, said the Bordeaux wine industry's view of the work ranges ''somewhere between violent and hysterical.'' Those reactions are not surprising. No formula could capture the variations in estate-bottled wines from the same vintage. But if widely accepted, Professor Ashenfelter's approach to judging the quality of the red wines of Bordeaux and Burgundy long before they are drinkable could turn the clubby, exclusive world of wine rating on its ear.
 
Alas for the Human Element
And even if it does not, enthusiasts who care more about drinking wine than talking about it could use what seem to be startlingly accurate forecasts to gain an edge at the expense of wine brokers and dealers.
For the moment, though, Professor Ashenfelter is too distracted to ponder the cosmic implications of removing the human element and the romance from vintage rating. That is because his just-completed calculations suggest that the 1989 Bordeaux wines will be the greatest of the century.
Most wines are bottled soon after they are made and are ready to drink shortly thereafter. The small fraction of French red wines destined to be sipped and savored spend 18 to 24 months in oak casks and are then set aside for aging in bottles.
Tastes from the barrel heavily influence the prices of wine futures, sold the year after the harvest. Samples from the newly bottled wines help determine the wholesale price - rarely less than $10 a bottle - at which the wines are first shipped around the world.
Only years later can vintages be ranked by taste with any precision. And as most experts acknowledge, there is many a slip between barrel, bottle and lip.
In 1967 Andre Simon, the prominent wine writer, predicted that the 1965 Bordeaux would be as good as the promising 1961 vintage. Today, few of the weak, acidic 1965's are available. One that is, Chateau Lafite-Rothschild, sells at auction for just one-fifteenth the price of the truly great 1961 wines from the same vineyards.
Mr. Ashenfelter, a 47-year-old specialist in labor economics who is the managing editor of The American Economic Review, is convinced he has found a better way.
It is widely agreed that weather influences wine quality. What few understand, he argues, is that a mere handful of facts about the local weather tell almost all there is to know about a vintage. And using the same techniques employed to forecast, say, the effect of a change in wage rates on employment in the auto industry, he has gone a long way toward proving his audacious theory.
 
It's Laptop vs. Nose
Weather-based vintage prediction is not a new idea. What is new is the notion that laptop computers can outperform the most sophisticated noses and palates.
The critical concept, Professor Ashenfelter acknowledges, came from Bruno Prats, owner of Chateau Cos d'Estournel in the St.-Estephe region of Bordeaux. Mr. Prats charted both the average temperature during the growing season and rainfall during the harvest months to make systematic comparisons between vintages.
Professor Ashenfelter added data for winter rainfall and then rigorously measured their statistical relationships to the most objective measure of quality he could devise: an index of auction prices for about 80 wines after they have matured in the bottle.
According to this ''multivariate regression analysis,'' heavy rains in the winter followed by a hot summer improve wine quality, while rainfall before the harvest damages it. The statistical fit from 1952 through 1980 is remarkably snug for the red wines of Burgundy as well as Bordeaux.
 
Year-to-Year Variations
Michael Broadbent, director of wines at Christie's auction house in London and a leading authority on Bordeaux, points out that the system cannot predict quality differences between estate-bottled wines of the same vintage. And it may yield systematic errors by lumping together wines primarily based on the cabernet sauvignon grape with the minority based on the softer-tasting merlot grape, which matures earlier.
But as Steve Ross, a wine enthusiast who is a professor of finance at the Yale School of Management, points out, the simple statistical model does explain basic year-to-year variations without major slips. ''If you did not tell them a machine did it,'' Mr. Ross said, ''I think it would pass muster with the wise heads in the business.''
Interest in the system has mostly been confined to the small group of wine buffs who are comfortable with econometric techniques. Circulation of Mr. Ashenfelter's semiannual newsletter, ''Liquid Assets'' ($30 for a yearly subscription), numbers about 600 - a tiny fraction of the readership of The Wine Advocate ($30, with a circulation of more than 27,000), which Mr. Parker publishes from his home in Maryland. But that could change if two of the Princeton economist's predictions prove accurate.
For most young Bordeaux vintages, the Ashenfelter forecasts are within hailing distance of the tasters' conventional wisdom. For the 1986 vintage, however, they are poles apart.
 
'Sometimes Exceptional'
Mr. Parker rates the 1986's as ''very good and sometimes exceptional.'' Peter A. Sichel, author of the influential Bordeaux Vintage and Market Report, said the 1986's have ''elegance and classic Bordeaux structure.'' New York stores, brimming with the vintage, are pricing the wines in the same range as the much-praised 1985's.
But according to the Ashenfelter system, below-average growing season temperatures and above-average harvest rainfall doom the 1986 Bordeaux to mediocrity. When the dust settles, he predicts, it will be judged the worst vintage of the 1980's, and no better than the unmemorable 1974's or 1969's.
Perhaps the most dramatic Ashenfelter prediction, the one likely to vault the ratings system into prominence or doom it to obscurity, is for the 1989 vintage.
These wines are barely three months in the cask and have yet to be tasted by critics. By Professor Ashenfelter's calculations, the hottest growing season in memory, combined with a very dry harvest, all but guarantee that the 1989 Bordeaux will be stunningly good. Adjusted for age, he predicts, these wines will eventually sell for a substantial premium over the great 1961 vintage.
For the moment, though, the wine industry's assessment of the champion of vintage rating by the numbers is hardly flattering. To paraphrase James Thurber, they are most definitely not amused by his presumption.

HEADLINE: Message for Nicaragua's Victors: Things Must Get Better, and Fast

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 3

 BODY:
With the store shelves largely bare and one-third of the work force without a job, Nicaraguans are serving notice that they expect the newly elected government to bring about rapid improvement or face political consequences.
Ten years of economic decline under the Sandinista Front, compounded by eight years of civil war and five years of an American economic boycott, have reduced living standards here to the same level as in 1940. Perhaps as much as the desire for peace, dissatisfaction with the state of the economy resulted in the stunning victory of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and her 14-party opposition coalition in the presidential election last Sunday.
''We have been drowning,'' said Xiomara Silva, a housewife and mother of five children who voted for Mrs. Chamorro, as she shopped in the sprawling Oriental Market in Managua on Thursday. ''Everything is so expensive and salaries have fallen through the floor. If you eat today, you don't eat tomorrow. But now maybe we will be able to work and know the sight of meat and medicine again.'' 
 
'Everything Will Be Better'
Advisers of the President-elect have contributed to such expectations, all but expropriating the Sandinista election campaign slogan, ''Everything will be better.'' They have promised that ''the first fruits'' of her victory will begin to appear within 100 days of her inauguration, scheduled for April 25, and will face a backlash should they fail to deliver to the satisfaction of voters.
''I don't want Dona Violeta so much as I want a change,'' said Guillermina Medina, a street vendor. ''I want an end to the military draft, jobs, food, less inflation, and if she can give me that, fine. If not, then I will go with someone else.''
Paul S. Reichler, a Washington lawyer who has long been an adviser to the Sandinistas, argues that Daniel Ortega Saavedra's defeat stemmed largely from a punishing ''one-two punch'': 35,000 percent inflation in 1988, followed by a wrenching and unpopular economic austerity program in 1989. Like voters elsewhere, Nicaraguans were thinking more of their pocketbooks than of foreign policy issues when they cast their ballots, diplomats and political analysts here said, Indeed, with many Nicaraguans convinced that Mrs. Chamorro's victory means the war is now effectively over, the economy promises to be the main battlefield on which Nicaraguan politics will be fought in the next six years. The Sandinista Front and Mrs. Chamorro's National Opposition Union, known as UNO, offer sharply different visions of how Nicaraguan society should be organized, and each believes its future success will be guaranteed by the failure of the other's program.
''The Sandinistas know the disastrous state of the economy is how they lost, and they want UNO to lose too,'' said Gilberto Cuadra, president of the Superior Council for Private Enterprise, the country's most influential business group, and an architect of the incoming government's economic program. ''They will do everything so there will not be confidence. It's going to be a mine field.''
Already the Sandinistas have painted Mrs. Chamorro, who has little knowledge of economic matters herself and relies heavily on a small group of academics and businessmen around her, as an elitist who intends to govern for the benefit of the few. They have attempted to stake out a position for themselves as guardians of the people's welfare.
The Sandinistas also appear to be encouraging workers to make large wage demands of the newly elected government, both to keep pace with inflation that totaled 1,700 percent last year and as a political weapon. ''We workers will demand salary readjustments, and if they do not respond, we will paralyze production,'' Berenicia Sanders, a Sandinista union leader, told Barricada, the official Sandinista newspaper.
 
New Currency Planned
On these and other questions, UNO's immediate economic strategy seems to focus on circumventing the Sandinistas and their program rather than defying them. The nationalized banks are to be supplemented by new private ''finance houses,'' the state monopoly on foreign trade weakened by granting licenses to qualified private companies, and state enterprises that cannot be unloaded made more efficient by introducing profit-sharing measures and allowing worker and opposition party representation in management councils.
The incoming government also hopes to make a fresh start by introducing a new currency, which will be freely convertible and will circulate at a value of one to the dollar. Existing cordobas, which now trade at 72,000 to the dollar, will continue to serve as legal tender, at least for a few months.
But in a country whose livelihood has depended on agricultural products like coffee, cotton, beef, rice and beans, it is not surprising that the strongest blows struck have been over the issue of ownership of land. In a statement on Thursday, the UNO coalition dismissed as ''lies and coarse distortions'' Sandinista accusations that Mrs. Chamorro intends to dismantle peasant cooperatives and strip farm families of holdings given them for cultivation after the fall of the Samoza dictatorship in July 1979.
The ability of the incoming government to win over peasant producers will depend to a large extent on its ability to finance the next planting cycle, which begins in May and continues through July. The Sandinistas were unable to do so last year and that failure led to a burst of inflation and strained food supplies just before the campaign got under way.
 
Foreign Aid Essential
With the country virtually bankrupt, a large and quick infusion of foreign aid is essential to the new government's recovery plan. ''We are going to be waiting for the international community to act in an especially generous manner, recognizing this is a prostrate economy, destroyed by 10 years of conflict and the bad management of the Sandinista Front,'' said Francisco Mayorga, the President-elect's chief economic adviser.
''They need external funds, and fast,'' the representative of an international agency here agreed. ''If not, the new government will not be able to do anything, things will collapse, and Washington will lose all credibility.''
On Monday, Mr. Mayorga will travel to Washington to meet with Bush Administration officials and representatives of international bodies like the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the Inter-American Development Bank. His immediate goal is to obtain at least $300 million from the United States, a large part of which will be destined for a ''social emergency fund'' to supply credit to small enterprises and to create jobs.
In the longer term, however, Nicaragua will need much more to restore its economy to health. The preliminary economic plan Mr. Mayorga will present to potential aid donors calls for an additional $1.5 billion to $1.8 billion in ''external resources'' over three years, after which he expects the economy to be on its feet once again.
 
'Defense Into Production'
Mrs. Chamorro's advisers hope that money will enable them to solve what looms as one of their thorniest political problems: what to do with nearly 100,000 men in arms, divided between the Sandinista Army and security apparatus and the contra rebel force in Honduras. The new government hopes, in the words of its economic plan, to ''transform defense into production'' by giving demobilized soldiers land and offering them job training programs and loans while organizing active duty units into to construction and reforestation brigades.
''I came down from fighting in the mountains to find my family dying of hunger and my brother in prison,'' said Ricky Mayorga, a 20-year-old demobilized Sandinista Army soldier who was wounded three times and who is now a day laborer. ''The Sandinistas betrayed us, destroyed the economy and persecuted the merchants. Dona Violeta has got to make things better for us, because I do not ever want to have to take up arms again.''
 

 
CARDINAL TO INVITE POPE
 VATICAN CITY, March 3 (AP) -The Roman Catholic primate of Nicaragua said in an interview broadcast today that he would invite Pope John Paul II to visit his country as soon as the political situation settled down.
Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, the Archbishop of Managua, also told Vatican Radio that Nicaragua's bishops wanted the Sandinistas to turn over all power to the new government. He was referring to the issue of relinquishing power over the security forces.
The Pope made a 10-hour visit to Nicaragua in 1983, during which Sandinista supporters disrupting his Mass by shouting political slogans.

HEADLINE: NICARAGUA EXPERT TURNS THE TABLES

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 3

 BODY:
When Francisco Mayorga Balladares boarded a plane for the United States on Friday to represent Nicaragua's government-elect in vital economic talks, he was well prepared. For make the trip.
''The Sandinistas will feel they're winning all the way to the end, and the polls will never tell the truth,'' the soft-spoken economist said weeks ago, predicting the opposition's victory over the Sandinistas in national elections on Feb. 25. ''When they discover they have lost, it will be too late.'' 
The election result stunned Sandinista leaders and embarrassed many international pollsters. But Mr. Mayorga, the chief economic adviser to President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, never wavered in his analysis. The same quiet calculation and self-confidence will now be brought to the Herculean labor of salvaging Nicaragua's economy.
Amid the turmoil and bloodshed of his country's decade-long political conflict, Mr. Mayorga has been a bystander, sidelined by his intellectual disagreement with Sandinista policy and his moral aversion to the violent alternative posed by the American-backed contra rebels.
 
A Consistent Counterpoint
But from his post as a professor at the Central American Institute for Business Administration, the 39-year-old economist has offered a consistent counterpoint to official descriptions of Nicaragua's economic crisis. His analyses of the country's problems have been a crucial resource for the opposition over years of political isolation.
''In this kind of environment, his work has been essential,'' said a diplomat who has lived in Managua throughout the years of economic decline. ''We depend on it, the opposition depends on it - the Government probably depends on it, too.''
Born in Leon, a city 45 miles northwest of Managua, Mr. Mayorga attended college in Nicaragua before leaving for graduate school at Yale University, where he studied economics and began his doctoral dissertation. He returned to Nicaragua to work in the central bank, but was forced to leave the country in 1977 after a conflict with the dictator Anastasio Somoza Debayle.
Mr. Mayorga offered his services to the Sandinista National Liberation Front, then fighting Mr. Somoza. He became associated with the hard-line faction led by Tomas Borge Martinez, and served as his representative in discussions on shaping a post-revolutionary economy.
 
Falling Out With Sandinistas
But as an advocate of free-market policies, he quickly fell out with the Sandinista leaders after they reached power in July 1979. ''It took about 30 days,'' he said, describing his disillusionment. ''I think we were being used, because they had never changed their commitment to Marxism-Leninism.''
In what he described as a ''strategic retreat,'' Mr. Mayorga stayed on as a director of the Central American Bank for Economic Integration. In 1984 he went to Yale to finish his doctorate.
When he returned two years later, he says, he committed himself to ''creating a space in terms of criticizing economic policy and the system.'' His wife and two children remained behind in Miami, and he took up residence in a spartan apartment here.
In subsequent years, most economic information was kept secret by the Government. After two Nicaraguan economists were imprisoned for possession of basic statistical data, Mr. Mayorga began relying on projections from old statistics, along with information on prices and exchange rates gathered at markets and from black marketeers.
His information sufficed, Mr. Mayorga said, for shaping a detailed recovery plan. It is with this plan, and broad input from businessmen and political leaders, that he now hopes to overcome the structural ills of a shattered economy.
 
Months of Anticipation
After a regional agreement last year set Nicaragua's electoral process in motion, Mr. Mayorga said, he knew he would have the chance to put his plan into action.
Several weeks before the election last Sunday, Mr. Mayorga represented the opposition coalition in a campaign debate that was watched throughout the country.
Attacking Mr. Mayorga's plans as unrealistic, the Sandinista representative, Edmundo Jarquin Calderon, argued that the Government had done everything in its power to reverse the economic slide. He said the opposition was irresponsible in suggesting that it could accomplish anything more.
Where, he asked, did Mr. Mayorga expect to find the magic wand that would allow him to change things overnight?
''Every Nicaraguan has a magic wand,'' Mr. Mayorga replied without hesitation. ''It is called a vote.''

He said those steps would include ''economic assistance for the reconstruction of the region as the peace process in Central America progresses.'' He gave no details.

HEADLINE: The Talk of Belgrade;
White City More Gray And Sullen

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The White City, as this ancient urban center has been named for most of its existence, looks a bit grayer to visitors returning after a few years, a result, residents say, of neglect and a decade of economic crisis.
There is also a measure of grimness and suspicion in the Beogradjani, as they call themselves. ''There are no jokes anymore,'' said Zlatko Sinobad, a retired Ambassador who used to tell the latest ones.
Mr. Sinobad, who spent his last working years as head of the Yugoslav Radio Corporation, said: ''Nowadays, acquaintances you meet on the street and talk to are not likely to tell you what they really think. But since I am retired, I am free to speak my mind. So I say what I think about someone and they throw up their arms, smile and say, 'That is what I think, too.' '' 
The ''someone'' many people fear and many like in this double capital - the seat of the Yugoslav federal Government as well as of the republic of Serbia - is Slobodan Milosevic, the president of Serbia. In the last two years Mr. Milosevic has made his wrath known about suspected opponents by having them dismissed.
 
Enterprising Purges
 This week, the newspaper Borba disclosed that three victims of Mr. Milosevic were now engaged in private enterprise. Zivorad Kovacevic, who was Ambassador to the United States until last summer, has opened an international trading company here. Dragisa Pavlovic, former head of the Belgrade Communist Party organization, heads a car rental agency. Spiro Galovic, another longtime party official, has joined a law firm representing foreign companies.
Occasionally, the ebullience of the people of Belgrade bursts through the pessimism, which is fed by economic uncertainty and what appears to be a series of intractable stalemates in the politics of Yugoslavia.
It is displayed in their love of fountains. There are five fountains within a four-block area of the city center and there is now a popular demand to restore a sixth, which once stood in the middle of Terazije, the most frequented street of Belgrade. It was torn down in 1947 under the Government of Marshal Josip Broz Tito to make way for a military parade. Now a search is on for pieces of the fountain. One piece was found here and the large centerpiece was traced to the villa of the late Gen. Ivan Krajacic, a Croatian Communist.
 
Parliament's Fence
 A similar hunt is on for the handsome wrought-iron fence that once surrounded the federal Parliament and was taken down years ago by the Communist authorities to convey the idea that the legislature was open to the people it purported to represent.
The search for the fence began after irate Serbian demonstrators stormed the Parliament building last year. One section was found in a Belgrade junkyard and another in a city in Macedonia, the southern republic.
There is a streak of practicality in the people here. Printing of new currency to cope with runaway inflation last year caused the abolition of dinar coins, including the 5-dinar coin used for parking meters. The meters stand unused and municipal employees circulate along the streets to collect the parking fees. Citizens toss the unusable coins into the fountains.
 
Sense of Zaniness
 A sense of zaniness also seems to pervade Belgrade. There was a young man in tennis shoes standing on the edge of the old marble fountain in front of the Moskva Hotel on Tuesday afternoon, shouting in Romanian that there had been a nuclear explosion in Romania four years ago. A small crowd gathered until a young man yelled, ''Speak Serbian, so that the whole world will understand you.''
Sometimes the zaniness comes out at the most unexpected moments. Last December, after years of reconstruction, the National Theater reopened with a gala opera to which the high and mighty were invited. In the middle of the performance, the heavy front curtain came crashing down, not easily to be raised, causing some of the singers to protest that the show could not go on. It did.
This city of 1.5 million prides itself on its clean thoroughfares. Around midnight, municipal crews swarm out to wash down the streets and the broad downtown sidewalks with high-pressure hoses attached to fire plugs and, in the outlying districts, from tank trucks.
Although public transporation by bus and street car is swift and frequent, this remains a city of walkers whose numbers peak about 7 P.M., during the traditional Mediterranean hour of strollers known here as korso.
Mud, rain puddles, the huge cobblestones of the older streets - not even wet cement stops Belgrade walkers on their rounds. There is a patch of recently cemented sidewalk on the north side of Knez Mihajlova Boulevard that bears the deep imprints of at least 30 shoes, ranging in size from those of a child to about size 13.

HEADLINE: Japan Promises to Ease Trade Tensions

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 3

 BODY:
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan and President Bush ended two days of talks today, and Mr. Kaifu said he had pledged to take serious action to ease trade tensions between the two countries. As part of that effort, Mr. Kaifu said he would try to improve the quality of life in Japan.
That approach would mean that Japan's economic growth would be based more on domestic demand for better health care, housing and other services, as well as for consumer goods, and less on exports. That would lower Japan's trade surplus with the United States and other nations. 
At a joint news conference late this afternoon, Mr. Bush said he was pleased with the talks. He said he hoped Japan and the United States could broaden the areas in which they cooperate internationally.
 
Seeking Freer Competition
But such a partnership, he said, would depend on Japan's opening its markets to allow American companies to compete more freely. That would presumably increase American exports and cut the nation's trade deficit.
''Make no mistake about it, I want to see the deficit come down,'' Mr. Bush said, noting that the United States trade deficit with Japan last year was $49 billion.
The President also said he was ''very aware of the mood and concern in this country about the continuing impediments to further growth of our trade relationship.''
Answering journalists' questions after Mr. Kaifu left, the President said, ''The Japanese side knows how important it is to move forward.''
At a briefing later in the day, Mitoji Yabunaka, a senior official at the Foreign Ministry, said Mr. Kaifu was returning ''with a sense of urgency.'' Asked how this would translate into action, he said, ''We have to wait and see what the developments will be in Tokyo. You will see them.'' No Details Disclosed Mr. Kaifu and his team did not disclose the details of any specific programs to make such changes. Mr. Bush also provided few details about what changes might be made.
In previous meetings, other Japanese officials have promised to try to make similar fundamental changes in their society. Those promises have been largely unfulfilled.
At one point during the talks, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told Mr. Kaifu, ''A political decision from the very top is necessary'' to achieve breakthroughs in the trade talks, Mr. Yabunaka said. Mr. Kaifu did not respond to that comment. the Japanese official said.
Mr. Kaifu said at the news conference, ''I am determined to firmly tackle structural reforms of Japan as one of the top priorities of my new Cabinet, with a view to improving the quality of Japanese life, with further stress on the consumer-oriented economy.''
 
Leaves for Tokyo
Mr. Kaifu's approach will enable him to tell the Japanese that he is not bowing to American pressure but acting instead for the greater good of his nation's 120 million people. He left for Tokyo immediately after the news conference. On Monday he will answer questions in Parliament about his visit.
Mr. Bush, in turn, will be able to tell legislators who have asked him to put pressure on the Japanese that Mr. Kaifu has acknowledged the broad-based trade problems caused by the structure of Japanese society.
''We feel very good about the commitment we received today,'' the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, told reporters at a briefing after Mr. Kaifu left.
That optimism may enable the President to buy some time against legislatively imposed deadlines under the 1988 Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act that could require the President to retaliate against Japan with sanctions.
Asked if he might be able to avoid sanctions, Mr. Bush responded: ''I hope so, but I don't know.'' He added, ''I will do from the executive branch side what I can.''
Before the meeting, at a country club in Rancho Mirage, near Palm Springs, both sides made clear that the two leaders sought a broad understanding rather than a negotiation of specific issues.
 
High Savings Rate in Japan
The United States has complained that Japan is moving too slowly in changing its high savings and investment rates, which reduce the money available for purchasing goods and services from other countries. The United States has also complained that Japan's business practices are exclusionary, that consumer prices are too high and that distribution of consumer goods is inefficient.
Such complaints about what the United States calls structural impediments to trade have been the subject of talks between the two nations since July. Last week, after the structural talks reached an impasse in Tokyo, Mr. Bush invited Mr. Kaifu to Palm Springs.
In agreeing to the talks, Japan added its complaints about American society to the agenda. Those complaints include criticism that the savings rate is too low; that corporations focus on short-term profits rather than long-term competitiveness; that too little is spent on research, and that development and workers are not adequately trained.
At the news conference today, Mr. Bush struck a conciliatory tone on those issues.
''Let's face it, these talks are a two-way street.'' the President said. ''We Americans must increase our savings, reduce our budget deficit, provide more incentive for our investors, strengthen our educational system, focus on producing goods of the highest quality.'' He also mentioned that Mr. Kaifu supported President Bush's call for a lower tax rate on capital gains.
Thus, the President was able to find support from Mr. Kaifu for a number of proposals that fit neatly into his political agenda.
In a briefing for Japanese journalists on Friday night, Mr. Kaifu said he had addressed some American complaints about Japanese society. A translation of a transcript of that briefing was provided by a Japanese official.
 
Address to Parliament Cited
Mr. Kaifu said land in Japan must be used more efficiently, for example, and he called Mr. Bush's attention to remarks he made in Parliament just before flying to the United States.
In a major policy address, Mr. Kaifu told Parliament, ''Soaring land prices undermine the sense of social fairness and rob people of their dream of home ownership.''
He also told Mr. Bush that he would work to lower Japanese consumer prices by strengthening antitrust enforcement, streamlining distribution and promoting imports.
Japanese and American negotiators have been holding separate talks on specific trade disputes. Last week, both sides said they were pleased with their progress on changing the rules by which the Japanese Government buys supercomputers. No progress was reported on the American complaints that the Japanese markets for wood products and satellites were closed to American companies.
This was the second meeting between Mr. Kaifu, 59 years old, and Mr. Bush, who is 65. Mr. Kaifu came to Washington in September, shortly after being named Prime Minister. This weekend's meeting came two weeks after Mr. Kaifu led his Liberal Democratic Party to an election victory.
To underscore the gravity of the trade dispute, Mr. Bush brought with him four members of his Cabinet -Mr. Baker; Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, and the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills.
Mr. Kaifu brought Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, who met Mr. Baker.

HEADLINE: Hotel Workers in Hawaii Strike

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HONOLULU, March 3

 BODY:
About 7,500 hotel workers went on strike today after contract negotiations collapsed, threatening to disrupt the state's $6-billion-a-year tourism industry.
The strike, by Local 5 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union, affected 11 hotels that account for one of every five hotel rooms in Hawaii and two of every five in Waikiki, the state's main tourist destination.
The hotels remained open using management employees. The affected hotels in Waikiki, on the island of Oahu, were Hilton Hawaiian Village, 2,523 rooms; Sheraton Waikiki, 1,900 rooms; Hyatt Regency Waikiki, 1,230 rooms; Princess Kalulani, 1,150 rooms; Ilikai Hotel, 800 rooms; Sheraton Moana Surfrider, 793 rooms; Royal Hawaiian Hotel, 526 rooms; and the Kahala Hilton, 369 rooms. 
Those affected on the other islands were the Kona Hilton on Hawaii Island, 445 rooms; Sheraton Kauai, 456 rooms; and Sheraton Maui, 495 rooms.
 
Disagreement on Proposals
Union and management leaders could not agree even on what the hotels' last contract offer contained.
Bill Crawford, the executive director of the Council of Hawaii Hotels, said the union rejected a four-year deal that called for annual wage increases of 5 percent plus increases in benefits that made the total increase of 7 percent a year.
Rod Rodriguez, a spokesman for the union, said the union calculated the management proposal to be around 4 percent, which he said was lower than the 5 percent package offered Friday.
''Management seems to be going backwards,'' he said. ''The offer is meager and measly and shows they could really care less about the hotel workers.''
Mr. Crawford called the union's calculations ''voodoo economics.'' He urged hotel workers to return to work. ''The union is making a grave mistake,'' he said. ''Nobody likes a strike, but the hotels had to stand firm against totally unrealistic union demands that ultimately could hurt the employees themselves.''
Guests were mixed in their views on whether the strike was disrupting hotel service.
''It's unfortunate, considering what I'm paying for a room,'' said Jennie Peters of Huntington Hills, Mich. ''We're not thinking of leaving, though.''
Gary Flintoff, a member of Painters Local 64 in Tacoma, Wash., said: ''I'm a union man, and I don't feel comfortable staying here. We've thought about going to another hotel.''

HEADLINE: Annenberg Gift a Point of Light, Bush Says

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., March 3

 BODY:
President Bush, describinghimself as a longtime supporter of the United Negro College Fund, used his best-known term for private charity in praising the gift of $50 million by Walter H. Annenberg to the consortium of private black colleges.
''Our Administration has stepped up support for historically black colleges and universities, the endowment concept there,'' the President said, predicting that Mr. Annenberg's generosity would be a challenge ''that will bring on well-deserved support from others.'' 
''It's most generous, and one of the most brilliant thousand points of light I can think of,'' he said.
Mr. Annenberg, the 82-year-old former United States Ambassador to Britain and builder of a sprawling publishing empire, said today he hoped the donation would raise the educational aspirations of young black people.
In remarks to The Los Angeles Times, which, along with The New York Times, reported the plan in today's editions, Mr. Annenberg said, ''Unless young blacks are brought into the mainstream of economic life, they will continue to be on the curbstone. The key to this problem is education.'' ''Black colleges have got to be supported,'' Mr. Annenberg continued. ''The entire country has to get behind this. Foundations, corporations and private citizens. We can't just leave this for the Government to do.''
Mr. Annenberg was expected to announce the gift Sunday at his estate here, where President and Mrs. Bush are weekend guests. Mr. Bush is the honorary chairman of a three-year capital drive by the consortium.
The gift by Mr. Annenberg is the largest in the consortium's history and one of the largest made to higher education in this country.
The United Negro College Fund raised $45.8 million last year for distribution to its member institutions.

LENGTH: 2976 words

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
Why Curators Are Turning to the Art of the Deal

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRENSON

 BODY:
''It's impossible to be all things to all people,'' said Eric S. McCready, speaking of his 15 years as a museum director, first at the Elvehjem Museum of Art of the University of Wisconsin, then at the Archer M. Huntington Art Gallery of the University of Texas at Austin. ''The demands generally by boards are so complex that very few people are capable or willing to meet them - to be a scholar, a fund raiser, a diplomat, an entertainer, an after-dinner speaker, a budget officer and a personnel officer - and all of that for the glory, for being able to say that you run a museum. It is no longer worth the headache.''
''It's like being let out of jail,'' he said, describing his present job as director of the Charles Cowles Gallery in the SoHo section of Manhattan. 
Like Diane Upright (formerly of Harvard and the Fort Worth Art Museum, now with the Jan Krugier Gallery on 57th Street), Linda Cathcart (formerly of the Contemporary Arts Museum in Houston and now of the Linda Cathcart Gallery, in Santa Monica, Calif.), Thomas Schulte (formerly of the Museum of Modern Art, now at the John Weber Gallery in SoHo) and Sean Kelly (formerly of the Glynn Vivian Art Gallery, a museum in Wales, now at the Louver Gallery in SoHo), Mr. McCready is one of many museum curators who have become art dealers since 1985, and who feel liberated by the change.
They reflect a sea change in the art world - in the definition of art galleries, in the perception of art dealers, and in the relationship between galleries and museums. The boundaries between galleries and museums have been increasingly blurred, and this has worked almost entirely to the benefit of galleries and to the detriment of museums.
The 80's was not the first decade in which curators became dealers. In 1960, for example, John Weber resigned as associate curator of 20th-century art at the Dayton Art Institute and began working for the Martha Jackson Gallery in New York because he felt that as a dealer he could take more risks and have more of an effect on art. In 1971 he opened his own gallery.
In 1967 Stuart Feld resigned as head of the department of American paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and began working for New York's Hirschl & Adler Gallery, which he now owns. ''At that point,'' Mr. Feld said, ''there were extremely few galleries paying attention to research in general, and having researched as thoroughly as possible many works of art while at the Met, basically I continued to do the same thing here.''
It was only in the 80's, however, that the curatorial trickle into galleries became a stream. What matters is less the numbers - there are probably two or three dozen who have now made the switch - than the sense of release so many of them feel, the ease with which they have been able to move from one world to the other and the scholarly discipline they bring with them to galleries. Both those who may have gone as far as they could in museums and those who left promising curatorial careers speak of museums with the same level of frustration. They are glad to be done with them.
''In the museum world you can never do enough, you can never please everyone,'' said Linda Cathcart, one of the more outspoken and controversial curatorial voices before she was fired as director of the Houston museum in 1987. ''I have absolute freedom now. I don't have to conform to some image of an institution. I don't have to worry about the public. I don't think about whether something can have an education component or not. I could not have cared less how many members were in the museum. Every day I feel incredibly happy and lucky, and I never felt this before. It fits.''
''There is the scholarly side of me that is being satisfied,'' said Jeffrey Hoffeld, who has been associated with Krugier since 1988. He was a curator at the Metropolitan Museum and director of the Neuberger Museum in Purchase, N.Y., before joining the Pace Gallery in 1978. ''The whole of me is being satisfied. And when I sit down at the end of every month to pay my bills, unlike in the museum world, I don't feel despair.''
 
Dealers Have Money, Curators Don't
 In the boom years of the 80's - when museums combed social registers for possible contributors and dealers were overheard to say about a show, ''It's like printing money'' - money, and its effect on quality and power, became a powerful issue. Major dealers have money; major curators, unless they inherit it, don't.
Dealers in a top New York gallery can start with a salary of around $60,000 to $75,000 a year and move fairly rapidly to $150,000 and $200,000. Gallery owners working with highly productive blue-chip artists or with a modern master's estate, can make more than $1 million.
According to the Association of Art Museum Directors, the average salary for curatorial assistants in the Mid-Atlantic region, which includes New York and Washington, is $20,000, for associate curators $32,000, and for chief curators $47,000; the average salary for museum directors is $84,500, with the top being $167,500. During the last two years, around 40 directorships of the 150 American art museums belonging to the association have been filled. Fourteen are now open.
''One of the big problems in American museums is that curators are just not paid a decent salary,'' said Thomas Schulte, who studied art history in Dusseldorf and West Berlin. In West Germany, he said, someone in a position equivalent to a senior curator at the Modern ''would be paid the same salary as senior professors at the university, with the same status and benefits. At the Modern, you start with $19,000 to $22,000 and gradually move up to $30,000 after a while. Even if you become a senior curator, money is a real problem.''
For many former curators and even for many curators who remain committed to their profession, museums have become places in which it is hard to breathe. ''Museums are cannibalizing,'' said Michael Botwinick, who was the director of the Brooklyn Museum and then of the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington before working with Old Master paintings at the Knoedler Gallery in New York. He now handles business investments in the art field for the Pritzker family of financiers in Chicago.
''Because museums survive by living off the flesh of their key staff members, they cannibalize themselves. An extraordinary number of museums are struggling economically, and their staffs are told to hang on. They give and they give and they give and they give and they give, and some people have to run out of gas.''
 
A Dealer Who Abandoned the Market
 Through the observations of former curators, and those of the handful of curators who used to be dealers, it is possible to underline the distinctions between museums and galleries and to appreciate the role that only museums can fill.
''Everything I love about working in a museum is not possible working in the market,'' said Marion True, the curator of antiquities at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., who previously sold ancient and Old Master art in New York. ''You cannot spend too much time on any one object; the objective is to sell it or place it in the right institution. You cannot spend months doing background research for publications. There is a transience, an impermanence. You cannot see the collection grow or study and reflect over it over a long period of time.''
But Ms. True is generous in acknowledging how a new breed of dealer, such as Michael Ward, of the Michael Ward Gallery on Manhattan's Upper East Side, has affected her field. ''Because a number of very well educated people have chosen to become dealers,'' she says, ''there is now a class of dealer in antiquities that can do the kind of scholarly exhibition museums can do, and I say, bravo!''
 
A Golden Age For Dealers
 While this is a troubled moment for curators, it may be the golden age of art dealers. In New York alone there are several hundred of them, and for every gallery that fails two or three seem to spring up to replace it. Some SoHo spaces, like those of the Salvatore Ala, Bess Cutler, Louver and Vrej Baghoomian Galleries, are as large as small museums. And a number of the best galleries periodically mount loan exhibitions of near museum quality.
''We borrow from museums and private collectors who not long ago would not have lent to galleries,'' said Diane Upright of Krugier. ''They lend because of the quality of the exhibition and the quality of the catalogue. Like other galleries, we commission major scholars; we treat catalogues as major publications.''
What is new is that galleries are now actually organizing or presenting museum shows. In 1986 the Pace Gallery organized an exhibition of Picasso's sketchbooks that traveled to American and European museums. In 1988 a Forrest Bess exhibition organized by New York's Hirschl & Adler Modern Gallery traveled to museums in Chicago and Cologne.
An exhibition of Lucian Freud drawings organized by the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford stopped off last year in New York at the Brooke Alexander Gallery. ''Dancers on a Plane: Cage. Cunningham. Johns,'' organized by the Anthony d'Offay Gallery in London, is at the Tate Gallery's branch in Liverpool through March 25.
In short, at a time when stretch limos are bumper to bumper outside hot galleries and the competition among top dealers has never been more heated - ''Each time you want something, you are in a cockfight,'' Mr. Hoffeld said - dealers have never seemed more independent and free. There seem to be no limits to what they can do. Even with the many stories of dealers not paying their artists or maneuvering behind the scenes to cut other dealers out of the action, respect for the best of them has never been greater.
No longer are curators who become dealers automatically looked down upon by scholars and curators. ''Something I like about America is that a lot of galleries and especially certain dealers are respected very, very well by museums, and working together is a very different thing than in Europe,'' Mr. Schulte said. ''If in America you are an art dealer there is not as much of a stigma as there is in West Germany. There you have this very old traditional image. Art historians and art professors have the same social value as doctors, but dealers are dealers, and they are merchants in a certain way, and in a way you cannot trust them. Here it is very different.''
 
They Went to School Together
 Said the dealer Michael Ward, who received a doctorate in medieval art from New York University's Institute of Fine Arts, ''There is another generation of curators, and they know we have all been together in graduate school, and many of us were as good students as they were, and they could be in our shoes and we could in theirs.''
So it is not surprising that art galleries are now capable of inspiring a sense of possibility and power in dealers that museums have traditionally inspired in curators.
''Dealers are working with artists on a continuing basis to shape the culture in which we live,'' said Sean Kelly of the Louver Gallery, who left Wales to become the director of art for the Bath International Festival. ''In the public sector, you cannot do it the same way. For instance, I would do a show on Jannis Kounellis, or Rebecca Horn, or Anne and Patrick Poirier, and because I was working in the public sector, it was a one-shot deal, and I would lose contact with the artists. Now I can have an ongoing relationship with the artists. As I grow, that growth is contiguous with their growth as artists.''
 
The Trouble With Museums
 While galleries now seem filled with promise, museums have never seemed less sure of what they are and what they need to do. There are fewer distinct curatorial voices than ever. Many museums seem to be spending more and more time thinking about every aspect of their operation - including bookstores, garages and restaurants - except the curator's condition.
Compared to galleries, which thrive on the speed and glamour of today's art world, museums are dinosaurs. ''A museum's every decision has to go through boards,'' Mr. Weber said. While a dealer can put together an exhibition in months, or even weeks, curators need years. Museums are run by boards of trustees who may be chosen more often for their social standing and financial resources than for their knowledge of art.
Many curators feel a sense of dissatisfaction and betrayal that is overwhelming. ''The reason most of us went into art history,'' Mr. McCready said, ''is because we love art, and in the museums that fades further and further away as you have to deal with administrative stuff. In museums you are often tied up in meetings all day and you do not even see art.''
What has happened to create a situation in which galleries seem so liberated and museums so shackled? The Overlapping of Church and State Part of the story is the relationship between art and money, which for dealers is natural. ''In many dealers,'' Mr. Hoffeld said, ''it is hard to separate the salivating quality related to love of the object and the question of what will I do with this, who will I sell it to and how much money will I make.''
The best dealers know not only how to make money but also how to recognize, promote and nurture artists. The relationship between scholarship and commerce can build public confidence in dealers and their work and, up to a point, is not a conflict.
In museums, the relationship between art and money can be thorny. The success of a museum depends upon its ability to keep art and money separate.
But as museums are more and more involved with acquiring the kind of money that will pay for art and keep themselves going, this separation becomes harder and harder to maintain. While museums court collectors -some of whom are very eager to have artists they collect shown - and woo corporate V.I.P.s for their boards, curators are expected to insure that in their evaluation of art and in the public's perception of art within their museum, money will play no role.
Yet almost everything curators do has financial implications. Every exhibition increases the value of the art in it. In addition, curators are expected to advise collectors in the hope that they will buy art and one day give it to the museums. The Metropolitan in New York and the National Gallery of Art in Washington now regularly mount exhibitions of private collections, like those of the Manoogian Collection and the Jacques and Natasha Gelman Collection (which remains at the Met until April 1).
The conflicts curators live with are not easy. ''I used to think being a curator was like being a village priest,'' said Mark Rosenthal, formerly a curator at the Philadelphia Museum of Art and now a curator at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. ''That's fine, except that you are constantly surrounded by lavish displays of money.''
For Ms. True of the Getty, curators are still thought of as a ''luxury profession.'' ''Museums tend to think curators are offered a chance to work with beautiful objects and travel and have this aura, and for that reason they don't have to be offered a great salary,'' she said. ''A lot of curators go on and take it and enjoy the luxury life in superficial ways, jetting around, having great fun at parties around a big auction, but there is suffering on the other end; there is a real contrast with the life they live. Ultimately there is a temptation to leave the scholarly side and think, 'I'm going to go where the money is.' ''
 
However Scholarly, Galleries Are for Selling
 However much the lines between them are blurred, galleries will never replace museums. They can never be driven by the same commitment to disinterested scholarship and public responsibility. However informative gallery catalogues may be, they are intended to sell art. A gallery cannot have the kind of independence that is imperative for a museum.
Patterson Sims worked as a dealer in the O.K. Harris Gallery from 1969 to 1976. He was a curator at the Whitney Museum of American Art from 1976 to 1987. He is now associate director and chief curator at the Seattle Art Museum. He does not want to be a dealer again.
''I don't want to be in that atmosphere again where every work of art has an insurance value and a very hot value,'' Mr. Sims said. ''I like Joel Shapiro, and if this Shapiro is 1969 and it is bronze, then it is $79,000. I just don't want the price tag to always be central to my relationship to works of art. I'd like my relationships with art to be undiluted by whether someone is going to buy it.''
Mr. Rosenthal said: ''It's not as if a museum is a pure world any longer. If a museum wants to acquire art, it has to get money and convince people to give things. The beauty is when the museum acquires it, it loses the qualities it might exude as to what it is worth. You walk through the Museum of Modern Art and you don't wonder what the 'Demoiselles d'Avignon' would get at auction. You are thinking about it as art and art history.''
Just as important, a dealer's relationship with art is usually ephemeral. ''In a museum you have a long-term relationship with objects; in a gallery it is very short term,'' Mr. Sims said. ''They come and go. They flee before you. In a museum you know that you can see these objects over decades. You have the opportunity for a cultural continuity that is simply not offered in galleries.''
For Mr. Kelly, working in a gallery means that dealer and artist can grow together. For Mr. Sims, the emphasis is different: working in a museum means that ''the work and you grow together.''
A curator can be both uncompromising in placing art in the context of its time and imaginative in considering what enables art to endure or collapse outside its time, and no gallery can do that.
