PUB-DATE: March 4, 1990

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1, Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2797 words

HEADLINE: In Hollywood, Black Is In

BYLINE: By JAMES GREENBERG: James Greenberg is the senior editor of American Film magazine.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
When Melvin Van Peebles first came to Hollywood 34 years ago to break into movies, he was offered work as an elevator operator. Last month he was honored at the Sundance United States Film Festival as a pioneering black film maker. When Wendell Harris Jr. first came to Hollywood with hopes of working as an actor in 1976, he couldn't get past ''the secretary to the secretary'' to see an agent. Earlier this year, his first feature, ''Chameleon Street,'' won the grand jury prize at the Sundance Festival.
Would the same thing happen in 1990 to a black film maker who came knocking on Hollywood's door? Not likely, for a number of reasons, most of them economic. Black film makers are being welcomed into the film industry as never before. Just about every studio in town has a project in development with a black director . . . or wants to.
Hollywood has long recognized the potency of the black film-going audience, and legend has it that it was that audience that rescued the industry from a bleak period in the early 70's with the success of a series of black exploitation pictures. The crucial difference now is that industry marketing mavens long resistant to the idea are beginning to recognize that a white audience will spend money to see black movies. 
It's not a realization that happened overnight, and the unprecedented success of Eddie Murphy and more recently the trend-setting popularity of Arsenio Hall have certainly been factors. But more directly responsible was Spike Lee's left field hit ''She's Gotta Have It'' in 1986, which opened the eyes of the industry to the potential of black films. Following ''She's Gotta Have It,'' Robert Townsend humorously exposed the stereotyping of blacks in the film industry in his satire ''Hollywood Shuffle.'' Keenen Ivory Wayans, who co-wrote ''Hollywood Shuffle'' and made his own contribution with ''I'm Gonna Git You Sucka,'' a parody of B action movies, can't deny or exaggerate the changes or how they came about. '' 'She's Gotta Have It' and 'Hollywood Shuffle' were made under extreme terms,'' says Mr. Wayans. ''They were films that were never meant to get made. Movies are not supposed to be made on credit cards and Government grants and loans from your grandmother'' says the soft-spoken Mr. Wayans, sitting in his production company office beside a poster for ''Cooley High,'' a favorite film from his youth.
But they did, and a movement of diverse film makers with varied goals was under way as barriers started falling. Each new film established a precedent and broadened the range of acceptable styles and subject matter. Mr. Lee upped the ante with his insistence on making serious and provocative entertainment; and with the success last summer of ''Do the Right Thing,'' he challenged the status quo of what a black film could say and get away with. ''Hollywood doesn't care what kind of films they are,'' says Mr. Lee, ''as long as they make money.''
 
Enter the Hudlin Brothers
 Reginald and Warrington Hudlin grew up in East St. Louis, Ill., a place they call ''the blackest city in America.'' Since graduating from Yale in 1974, Warrington has been paying his dues as an independent film maker. Last year, Reggie was approached by New Line Cinema. He sent them two scripts, and they decided to produce ''House Party,'' based on a 20-minute short Reginald had made as his senior thesis at Harvard. Screened before a white audience for the first time at Sundance, ''House Party,'' an all-American story of teen-age turmoil told through the black idiom of rap music and hip-hop culture, won the film makers' trophy as well as an award for cinematography.
The enthusiastic reception for ''House Party'' in Sundance demonstrated that a film can have crossover appeal without sacrificing its cultural authenticity. After the festival, the Hudlins went to Los Angeles, where, for two weeks, they were the target of intense courting by the Hollywood establishment, which smelled a hit. ''House Party'' opens nationally on Friday.
''This is the best time in history to be a black film maker'' says Reginald Hudlin, relishing the possibility. ''Spike has created a whole new recognition of the commercial viability of an audience that wasn't being served before. The studio said, 'Hmm, black film makers. That's a good idea.' ''
Thomas Pollock, chairman of M.C.A.'s motion picture group, the company that produced ''Do the Right Thing,'' says he doesn't think that way. ''It was a business decision. We believed in Spike as a film maker. It wasn't about black. We believed in the subject matter directed by him. I don't want to take credit for breaking ground for black film makers. It may be true, but all that really proves is Spike is a great film maker.''
 
Executives Say They're Color-Blind
 Indeed, most of the executives interviewed for this story insisted that Hollywood was color-blind. But since it is so overwhelmingly a white community, the films Hollywood turns out are inevitably products of a white imagination. The black population makes up 13 percent of the moviegoing public, but 30 percent are frequent moviegoers (as opposed to 24 percent of the white population). Still, only a handful of the more than 400 films produced by Hollywood last year were made by black film makers or dealt with black themes.
Barry Reardon, president of distribution for Warner Brothers, admits that it is slightly more difficult to market a film with a black theme, but he is quick to note that with the success of such films as ''The Color Purple,'' ''There are no minuses [in making black films]. Any time a genre becomes popular and makes money, it becomes accepted in the marketplace.''
Furthermore, in a high visibility arena like the entertainment industry, producing black films has an intangible public relations value and makes the studios look as if they are doing the right thing. ''Having a successful black film gives a studio a great social profile,'' says Mr Wayans. ''It makes the executives smell like roses.''
Nonetheless, it took four years, with the help of his mother, for Wendell Harris Jr., a Juilliard graduate, to raise the money from independent investors to make ''Chameleon Street,'' the true story of a black man (played by Mr. Harris) who assumes a variety of professional disguises. Now he is ''reeling'' from the offers pouring in. Aside from several of the major studios and independent companies interested in distributing his film, he has been approached by no fewer than 10 companies about other scripts he might have on the shelf. Representatives from the most powerful agencies in town, including Creative Artists and William Morris, have contacted him about signing with the company. Warner Brothers is even interested in purchasing the remake rights to ''Chameleon Street'' as a vehicle for Arsenio Hall.
''I wasn't born yesterday, and I'm not totally unprepared for the response,'' says Mr. Harris in a modulated actor's voice, measuring his excitement. ''But I thought it would come after the film was released, not before.''
 
How Deep Is the Interest?
 Because Hollywood is moved by historical precedent, no one particularly wants to be first. Everyone wants to be second. Consequently there is a competitive spirit driving the industry's new-found interest in black film makers. Stephen D. Barnes, an attorney for Bloom, Dekom and Hergott, one of Hollywood's leading entertainment law firms, acknowledges the openings but wonders how deep the motives are. ''There has not been a consistent effort on the part of any major film company to develop black film makers,'' argues Mr. Barnes. ''When someone gets hot, like a Spike Lee or a Keenen Wayans or a Reggie Hudlin, every studio will talk to them, every studio will do a deal with them. Whether they will commit to make the movie is another matter. And that takes a tremendous amount of heat. I don't get the sense that there is a consistent interest, aside from a Spike Lee movie or a Reggie Hudlin movie, something that has commercial value.
''I do see a tremendous number of talented people who are about to get their opportunities, and when they do, the quality of the films and commercial success will convince the studios that this is a gold mine they've tapped into.''
The studios may not yet be ready to put $20 million in the hands of a black film maker, but there are numerous small-scale projects in the works. Charles Lane, who wrote, directed, starred in and raised the money for the silent comedy ''Sidewalk Stories,'' has landed two deals since the release of his picture. At Touchstone, he will direct the English comic Lenny Henry in ''True Identity,'' and for Island Pictures he will direct his own script for ''Skins,'' an interracial romantic comedy.
The television director (''Raisin in the Sun'') and actor Bill Duke will break into feature film making with ''Rage in Harlem,'' an action picture starring Forest Whitaker, followed by a biography of Otis Redding for A & M Pictures, a project that has kicked around for years and, given the current climate of Hollywood, may finally be made. The director Euzhan Palcy (''A Dry White Season'') is in the early stages of developing another music-related feature, a biography of the blues belter Bessie Smith.
Another director, Rolando Hudson, moves from music videos to movies with ''Go Beverly,'' a black coming-of-age love story at Island Pictures written by his wife, Pam Gibson, and Nelson George. Mr. George, a long-time black-music writer for Billboard, is also writing a screenplay about the Apollo Theater for Steven Spielberg's Amblin Entertainment.
Not every black project is being instantly gobbled up. After his project made the rounds of the studios and went into turnaround at Warner Brothers, Robert Townsend landed at 20th Century Fox with ''The Five Heartbeats,'' a script he co-wrote with Mr. Wayans.
 
Some Blacks Want Independence
 Many black film makers, like the MacArthur grant recipient Charles Burnett, have worked independently for years on personal projects and are skeptical about Hollywood's sudden interest and the artistic price of working within the system. Mr. Burnett, whose latest picture, ''To Sleep With Anger,'' won a special jury prize at Sundance, says, ''I need the money [to make movies], but I don't need it that bad.''
Perhaps the most exciting new project - one that challenges the expanding boundaries for black entertainment - is not a motion picture at all but a television show, ''In Living Color.'' Scheduled to make its debut on the Fox network in late spring, this show is an audacious black-themed ''Saturday Night Live,'' created by and featuring Mr. Wayans and a cast of mostly black comic actors. The humor is blunt and topical and aimed directly at the color line with such bits as a gay black parody of Siskel and Ebert and a child's-eye view of the white world. ''White people don't have a problem with black entertainment; it's only when they're told by marketing that it's not for them that they don't get into it,'' says Mr. Wayans.
What ''In Living Color'' and other films by black film makers offer an audience is a fresh way of seeing the world, says the show's producer, Tamara Rawitt. ''Hollywood is finally awakening to the idea that you can tell a familiar story from a new perspective and attract a large audience. In 'Living Color' we take an existing genre and tickle it with a scalpel,'' says Ms. Rawitt. ''It's for a hip and progressive audience with the same street energy Arsenio Hall has.''
Whether Hollywood knows it or not, ''When you talk about language, style, music or dance, the people who carry culture in America from Day One have been black,'' theorizes Warrington Hudlin. Somehow movies have been left behind. ''Motion pictures are the last frontier, and we're here to tame the West,'' says Reginald Hudlin, burning with the energy of his first success. ''Hollywood is now convinced that there is something special about a black perspective, but the financial value of that has been undervalued. Eddie Murphy is still regarded as an exception to the rule,'' says Mr. Hudlin incredulously.
Mr. Wayans believes that what holds down the potential of black films more than anything is marketing. His frustration is obvious when he rehashes miscues in the selling of ''I'm Gonna Git You Sucka.'' ''They say, 'No one will go see this.' Why? Because they wouldn't? It's a racist attitude. You can't sell a film as a black picture. You sell it as a comedy or whatever it is. You never see a film publicized as 'the whitest movie you've ever seen - all white people,' '' he says, launching into a mock pitch.
The solution? ''A film will have to come along and hit a home run, a grand slam, and make $60 million or $70 million and blow preconceptions out of the water,'' he says. ''Then Hollywood will take a whole other approach.''
And maybe then black film makers will get a chance to work on bigger-budget projects. What makes black films appealing now to both the major studios and the independents is that they can be made for a price, with little risk. ''Do the Right Thing'' was a good deal at $6 million; at $12 million, Universal wouldn't have made it. But for $2 million, you can't do an epic or anything really meaningful, says Mr. Wayans. ''Being in this position is a lot of responsibility, because people are looking for you to do everything at once. But to be a diverse film maker you need to command the budgets to make the kinds of films you want to make, and that will only happen when you make your mark in the mainstream and become part of everyone's audience.''
 
Spike Lee Speaks Out
 Sidney Ganis, president of Paramount Motion Pictures, the company that bankrolls Eddie Murphy, insists that the only criterion that he uses in selecting a director is: Who is the best person for the job? Since that is open to a world of interpretation, it's an attitude that doesn't necessarily make Spike Lee happy. One of the projects currently in development by Mr. Murphy's company and Paramount is the film version of August Wilson's play ''Fences,'' a dramatic tour de force about black family life in the 1950's. Mr. Wilson reportedly submitted to Paramount a list of suggested black directors that included Mr. Lee, Gordon Parks, Bill Duke and Lloyd Richards. Also under consideration by Paramount is Barry Levinson, a white director of such films as ''Rain Man'' and ''Tin Men.'' Mr. Lee says he is ''gravely disturbed'' at that possibility and labels it ''wrong with a capital 'W.' '' Mr. Wilson was not available for comment.
Spike Lee is a hard man to please, and, though he admits things are better than ever before, he is appalled by the dearth of black executives in the industry. On a recent visit to Creative Artists Agency, he says, he was disturbed to see only one black agent and a black receptionist. ''Mike Ovitz [the chairman of C.A.A.] is one of the most powerful men in Hollywood. If he were committed to aggressively going out and hiring black people and setting up a training program, there'd be more black agents,'' says Mr. Lee, working up a head of steam. ''If they were interested in change, it would have happened a long time ago. And it's not just C.A.A.; it's all over. It changes when people with clout demand it, and when I have more clout, I plan to talk to Universal about it.''
In his short time dealing with the studios, Mr. Harris has observed ''a weird dance . . . always elliptical and oblique. The studios are huge monsters with frail, tremulous souls. No one individual can make a decision. It's like a 12-headed beast.''
What's needed, according to Mr. Wayans, is greater self-reliance and financial independence from Hollywood. ''The destiny of black arts rests on black people and black corporate America. Every year it's another conference and more talk, but there's no evidence of anything happening right now. As long as Hollywood controls the mainstream, we need a sponsor within the industry. We have no voice without black executives in the business, and right now there is no black executive who can green-light a project.''
The Hudlin brothers don't intend to sit back passively and be the recipients of change. ''We want to effect change,'' says Warrington Hudlin. ''Film is a business founded on alliances and worthwhile investments. Hollywood is just one source to secure capital. We're not going to depend on people's good will; we will depend on people's good business sense.''
It is impossible for black film makers like the Hudlins, Mr. Lee and Mr. Wayans not to be aware of their precarious position in Hollywood. ''Black film makers may be hot today, but tomorrow it will be Hispanic films. What happens then?'' asks Mr. Lee.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Weighing the West German Markets

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
There is another country, aside from Japan, where the bond market has fallen sharply and sent interest rates to startingly high levels. But in that country - West Germany - the impact has not been nearly as devastating.
The Japanese stock market is down 12.48 percent for the year, with sharp one-day falls of 1,569.10 and 1,161.19 in the Nikkei 225 index in the last two weeks. In West Germany, the stock market is 7.13 percent below the high for the year it reached on Feb. 6. But it is still up 1.56 percent in 1990, while all the other major markets, including the United States, Britain and France, are down. 
Morgan Stanley & Company is arguing that the German decline is an opportunity for investors. And they do not see a major downside risk now, even with other markets still skittish over the sharp fall in Tokyo.
But Alistair Ross Goobey of James Capel Inc. in London said the German market still poses risks. He thinks that high interest rates could push the market down another 14 percent, to about 1,550 on the DAX index of 30 leading shares. The DAX closed on Friday at 1,818.23.
Barton M. Biggs, director of worldwide strategy at Morgan Stanley, finds Germany a haven in an otherwise dismal investing landscape that has led him to sit on the sidelines in every other market. Mr. Ross Goobey, on the other hand, thinks that markets outside of Japan and Germany may now be nearing their bottoms, enough so that he is ready to polish his ''buying boots,'' but not yet put them on. One of the key differences of view here involves the impact of interest rates. In both Japan and West Germany, rates have been rising this year and edged up further at the end of last week. The yield on the 10-year bond in Japan is 7.16 percent. In West Germany, it is 8.99 percent, just below its recent peak.
In assessing the impact of interest rates analysts calculate a ratio of returns from bonds compard with stocks. The higher the ratio, the more attractive the bond market is and the more likely that money will be drawn out of the stock market. A high ratio can thus be a signal of trouble for the stock market.
At the end of this week, the ratio in Japan was rising again at 3.58, not far from its recent high of 3.81, according to Mr. Ross Goobey. In West Germany, the ratio was 4.966, below its recent high of 5.268 but also rising again.
Mr. Ross Goobey is worried by the numbers for West Germany. ''This is the same sort of danger sign we saw in Japan before the stock market fall,'' he said.
But Madhav Dhar, global equity stratigist at Morgan Stanley, is less concerned, arguing that the impact of high rates is being offset by the long-term promise of much higher earnings as the two Germanys are reunited and Eastern Europe is developed.
''The psychological risk premium for Germany is going down,'' Mr. Dhar said. ''People are revising up their earnings estimates.''
Another reason West German stocks are holding up better despite the higher interest rates is that they are, at this time, a much better value than Japanese stocks. Japanese stocks, according to Mr. Dhar, are on average selling at prices 17 times the companies' cash flow while West German stocks are priced at 5 times cash flow. In addition, the Japanese economy, although it is still growing and fundamentally sound, is facing more problems, including rising oil prices and a weakening yen. Both the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve sold dollars last week in an effort to support the yen. But the currency still fell, reaching 150.25 to the dollar on Friday.
Mr. Ross Goobey worries that people ''are buying the dream'' of the German market and pushing their earnings estimates too high. It seems, he said, that ''people believe if investors are throwing money at the market, it can't go down.'' He is not pessimistic about Germany's future, and sees economic benefits from reunification. But he thinks the optimism has gone too far.
''It's a question of degree,'' Mr. Ross Goobey said. ''The Japanese have recognized their problems and have corrected for them. The German stock market has not recognized this. We really have not corrected for the excessive optimism.''

LENGTH: 1585 words

HEADLINE: GERMANY AND INTEREST RATES

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
The meshing of West and East Germany - one a sleek, postwar capitalist engine and the other a shattered, inefficient state-run rowboat with high unemployment - is expected to be a formidable task. While the two halves may some day become a seamless and vibrant economy, the transition is expected to be rough, and unsettling for interest rates around the globe. There are divergent schools of thought on the subject. One group of economists believes that there is a finite amount of capital in the world. As West Germany seeks to finance the redevelopment of East Germany, so the argument goes, borrowers there will bid up interest rates to attract capital, forcing borrowers in the United States and Japan to raise their rates in a global competition for funds.
But other economists say the matter is not that simple. German reunification, they say, may not affect interest rates elsewhere. And even if it does, the shifts will be subtle and indirect. Besides, some say, the German markets are so much smaller than those in the United States or Japan that their impact, while important, is inherently limited. 
 
Rate Rise, Isolated
 Neal Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, believes that higher German interest rates are inevitable. The most immediate upward pressure will come as East German citizens demand better housing and clothing, even before production in that country rises. This ''demand shock,'' as it is called by economists, represents an inflationary push on interest rates.
Once production in East Germany improves, there will be a second upward force on interest rates as the capital stock of the nation becomes more productive and businesses begin to borrow more money.
Then too, the so-called ''risk premium'' that German borrowers must offer to investors as compensation for investing in such an uncertain economic climate will also cause rates to climb.
Mr. Soss likens the events in Germany to the reunification of the United States following the Civil War - the problems of unifying the currency and organizing a decimated and largely unemployed labor force in the South.
''The restoration of the States was filled with discord and messiness,'' he said. ''And it will be the same in putting West and East Germany together. There will be a lot of new habits that have to be developed with regard to labor and money. That raises the sense of risk and that is the final influence on rising German interest rates.''
Despite this, Mr. Soss believes, there is ''no reason'' that interest rates should go up in the United States or Japan. He says that rates are influenced more by domestic than international issues. In his view, rates in Japan have been going up only because the unification of the Germanys threatens the belief that Japan is about to become the pre-eminent economic power. The 1990's, which have often been billed as the decade of the Pacific Rim, could instead be a time when economic power shifts to a more dynamic Europe, as the Germanys reunify and Eastern Europe re-emerges as an economic force.
To back up his theory that international rates do not march in lock step, Mr. Soss points to last summer, when the United States enjoyed lower interest rates than many of its trading partners. He felt that this came from the notion of the United States as a ''safe haven'' for capital following the death of the Ayatollah in Iran, the supression of the uprising at Tiananmen Square in China and the political scandals in Japan.
''Domestic economies tend to be the more important influence on interest rates,'' Mr. Soss said. He explains the current rise in rates in this country as a ''return to more normal circumstances'' after last summer's startling political developments. Right now, however, he predicts that rates here may fall slightly if the economy continues to weaken.
 
Rate Rise, International
 The opposite view is taken by C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a research institute in Washington. Mr. Bergsten believes that events in East and West Germany will ''drag up interest rates around the world.'' He, too, sees higher German rates as inevitable. They will first come from the inflationary pressures of reunification as the purchasing power of East Germany is mobilzed. Once this happens, he anticipates that the West German central bank, fearful of inflation, will try to tighten monetary policy, which would push up rates.
But unlike Mr. Soss, he says the United States is particularly vulnerable to such events because it is so dependent on foreign capital to finance its large trade and budget deficits. ''We're depending on foreign capital inflows of about $10 billion a year to finance our trade balance,'' he said. ''That means we have to pay whatever price is necessary to attract that capital. If interest rates abroad are up, they have to be here.''
In Mr. Bergsten's view, ''The chickens have come home to roost. Our dependence on foreign capital has made us hostage to economic events abroad.''
Conversely, Japan is less vulnerable because it is an exporter of capital, he said. But he noted that a rapid German reunification would probably push up inflation and interest rates in Japan by several percentage points, while a slower pace would dampen inflation fears and keep rates more stable.
 
The Rate Floor
 Nicholas Sargan, an economist at Salomon Brothers Inc., makes a distinction between different components of interest rates: inflation, real returns and the uncertainty premium. He believes that inflation in a given country directly affects rates within its own borders, but has little impact on global rates. To support this, he points to the decline in United States interest rates last summer as inflation dropped and the economy slowed here. This contrasts with Japan and West Germany, where rising inflation fears pushed up rates.
But he believes that real interest rates - the component that is set by the productive capacity of an economy - equalize across the globe and set an international floor for rates. The risk and inflation premiums are then built on this floor level.
Without the demand for capital in West Germany, rates of different nations moved in different directions last year, depending on internal inflation fears. But with this new element in play, Mr. Sargan says, rates all over the globe will inevitably rise.
''I still believe the primary factors calling the shots on U.S. interest rates are domestic considerations,'' Mr. Sargen said. ''But going into the 1990's, higher real interest rates abroad become the eventual floor for the U.S. That floor is now being raised. The most difficult question is by how much, and I don't think anyone knows the answer.''
 
An End to Euphoria
 Alan Reynolds, chief economist at Polyconomics Inc., an economic consulting firm in Morristown, N.J., believes that the current euphoria about investments in Germany may subside once the difficulties of reunification become clear. For instance, he anticipates that much of the foreign money that surged into West German stock funds could flow out when investors begin to realize that a unified German economic powerhouse will not emerge overnight and that these funds have become overpriced. The deutsche mark will weaken as investors sell and covert the marks used to buy the stocks back into dollars. Interest rates will rise in Germany as money flows back into the United States and Japan and as buyers of German bonds demand higher returns to protect them against a weakening mark.
But over time, he says, interest rates in other nations will react to inflationary pressues in their own borders rather than those abroad. ''To say that all our interest rates have to go in the same direction is to say we all have to raise interest rates to the level of Britain or Australia because they have higher rates,'' Mr. Reynolds said. ''But they have higher rates for a reason - because people there expect inflation.''
 
The Limited Markets
 Besides, noted Robert Brusca, an economist with Nikko Securities Company Ltd., West Germany's role in the world economy is limited by the size of its stock and bond markets relative to those in the United States and Japan. He noted that the German equities market is only one-tenth the size of the Tokyo market and that its bond market is one-third the size of the Japanese bond market, which in turn is half the size of the United States bond market.
This means that only a limited amount of funds can flow into West German securities without driving the deutsche mark, which is needed to buy these securities, to ridiculously high levels, thereby choking off any investment value. As a result, while Germany may indeed play a special role in the European economy because of its strength, that role is inherently limited, as is the upward pressure on its rates.
''Germany is still a small niche market and that means money flows can be deflected away from the U.S. and Japan,'' Mr. Brusca said. ''But if any sizable moves in funds occur, it will be so visible that it will push up rates and prices in Germany and become a self-limiting process.''
In fact, Mr. Brusca said, as oil prices rise, Arab investors may play a more important role than the reunification of Germany in international money flows and interest rates. ''One of the things missed in all this discussion,'' he said, ''is the rise of the Arab investor and the question of where all those dollars flow.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
A Three-Sided Battle Over the Exxon Oil Spill
 
United States of America v. Exxon Corporation is looking more like United States of America v. State of Alaska. True, a Federal grand jury indicted Exxon last Tuesday on five criminal charges involving the Alaskan oil spill. But Justice Department officials immediately began to leak word that they had a difficult case based on untested legal principles. Their apparent aim: Pressure Alaskan officials to drop their opposition to a bargain with Exxon. The Alaskans objected to a deal that, while potentially costing Exxon more than $500 million, would have avoided a criminal trial and shielded the company for four years from Federal Government suits to recover billions more for environmental damage. The Alaskans said they are willing to resume negotiations. 
 
 
Sanford Weill in the Wings?
 
Will Sanford I. Weill recapture Shearson? Or, is the brokerage firm that Mr. Weill built looking for other investors? Mr. Weill has been working on a deal to merge the brokerage unit of his Primerica Corporation into Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Sandy Weill built Shearson acquisition by acquisition, sold it to the American Express Company in 1981 and then left in 1985. He returned to Wall Street by buying Primerica, parent of the Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company brokerage firm, in 1988. American Express said Thursday that talks with Mr. Weill had ended, though the door appeared to remain open. But even as Shearson contemplates becoming the nation's largest brokerage, it's becoming smaller. The firm plans 2,000 layoffs by April; more might follow.
 
 
Prince the Empire Builder
 
Prince Rogers Nelson - best known by his first name - has crowned his growing entertainment principality with a $10 million studio near Minneapolis. Madonna has come in to make recordings, producers have filmed commercials for Huggies diapers and Comet cleanser, and Prince himself is shooting his fourth feature film. Record companies are said to send artists to record there on the chance that Prince himself might join in.
 
 
Vindication for Eastern Unions
 
Members of the Eastern Airlines labor unions can say they told us so. A court-appointed examiner said Thursday that the Texas Air Corporation had shortchanged its Eastern subsidiary. The examiner, David I. Shapiro, cited an interest-free loan from Eastern to Texas Air, excessive fees and Texas Air's purchase of Eastern's computer reservations system for much less than the parent company received when it sold just half the system later. In a report Mr. Shapiro recovered, a Texas Air executive proposed to ''cherry pick'' the Eastern system to benefit the company's nonunion carrier, Continental. In compensation, Texas Air agreed to pay Eastern $280 million. Unsecured creditors can take heart that Eastern will be better able to fulfill an agreement to pay them 50 cents on the dollar. But the unions can take only scant comfort. About 12,500 of Eastern's unionized pilots, mechanics, baggage handlers and flight attendants no longer have their jobs.
 
 
'Red' Poling Must Spend
 
Harold A. ''Red'' Poling took over as chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company on Thursday, with the tough task of improving on the record of Donald E. Petersen. Mr. Petersen turned Ford into the nation's lowest-cost, most profitable auto producer. In an industry that loves to label its executives by their background, Mr. Poling is a financial man; Mr. Petersen was a product engineer. Mr. Poling picked up his nickname from his hair color, not his performance on the bottom line: he has been the company's champion cost-cutter. But analysts blame Ford's long product cycles and outdated engine designs on its parsimony. Now, they say, Mr. Poling has to invest billions in new products even as his industry slumps.
 
 
In Brief
 
Convicting her on charges of Federal tax fraud was the easy part. Persuading Leona Helmsley to quit appearing in her familiar hotel advertisements apparently took even longer. The new, Leona-less print ads will appear in April.
 
*
 
Analysts say Wal-Mart Stores Inc. is likely to become the nation's largest retailer in sales volume this year, surpassing Sears, Roebuck & Company and the K Mart Corporation. Last week, Wal-Mart reported fourth-quarter sales of $8.1 billion, up 24.6 percent from a year ago, and earnings of $425.9 million, up 31.8 percent.
 
*
 
It's 11 years behind schedule and, at $6.45 billion, costs 12 times the original estimate. But on Thursday, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission gave the Seabrook nuclear reactor in New Hampshire an operating license.
 
*
 
More than 9,000 drivers and other workers went on strike early Friday at Greyhound Lines Inc. Greyhound planned limited operations.
 
*
 
The Securities and Exchange Commission said Friday that it is investigating the large bonuses Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. paid before its parent company filed for bankruptcy protection last month.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY
 

A Weak Fourth Quarter
 
The nation's economy finished 1989 with its weakest quarter in more than three years. The gross national product grew at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter - four-tenths of 1 percent higher than the Commerce Department's original estimate, but still not a mark economists see as evidence of economic strength. A record 10.5 percent decline in January's durable goods orders, reported last week, added to the gloom. But Lacy Hunt, of Carroll McEntee & McGinley Inc., remains more optimistic than most economists. He said the quarter had ''a very decent showing'' considering Boeing and Nynex strikes, Hurricane Hugo and the California earthquake.
 
 
More Indicators Augur Ill
 
The Government's most widely followed forecasting gauge also looks as if it's leading to slow growth. The index of leading economic indicators was flat in January, the Commerce Department reported Friday. Many economists had expected a small increase. Among the index's 11 components, building permits soared with January's warm weather, but plant, equipment and consumer orders fell. The Commerce Department also revised its December index down to six-tenths of 1 percent from eight-tenths. Results from the previous months also point to tough times ahead: the index had a one-tenth of 1 percent gain in November and a four-tenths drop in October.
 
 
Central Bankers: Peas in a Pod?
 
Sometimes all central bankers seem alike. The favored pose: cautious inflation-fighters restraining rash politicians. Last week, Karl Otto Pohl, president of the West German Bundesbank, said Chancellor Helmut Kohl's plans for monetary union would have to await ''radical change'' in the East German economy. Yasushi Mieno, governor of the Bank of Japan, has favored higher interest rates, provoking a rare public dispute recently with the Ministry of Finance. And last week, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said the nation was likely to avoid a recession - implying he would keep resisting Administration calls for lower interest rates.
 
 
In Brief
 
Senate leaders and President Bush compromised on a clean air bill on Thursday. Senators demanded stronger measures than the President had proposed, but he insisted on a less costly answer to pollution problems.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
 Populism vs. Perestroika
 
Soviet politicians and planners spent the week wrestling with ideas like free enterprise and private property. Often, the reforms President Mikhail S. Gorbachev loudly announces in Moscow fail to reach the ears of distant local officials. So in southern Russia, small business owners mounted campaigns to unseat local authorities who spouted populist oratory and tried to stifle their enterprises. In Moscow, the Supreme Soviet voted on Wednesday to legalize private use of land without private ownership - by means of a law allowing land to be leased for farms and other businesses. Some legislators warned that local officials would make only their worst land available.
 
 
In Brief
 
President George Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan met at the end of the week in Palm Springs, Calif., to discuss trade issues. On Thursday, negotiators announced an agreement to improve American access to the Japanese market for supercomputers.
 
*

Road Ahead
 
New President or no, Nicaragua will need years to rebuild its economy. Washington will help; the Bush Administration said it would lift a trade embargo if President Daniel Ortega Saavedra fulfills his pledge to surrender power to Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. But after a decade of war, Nicaragua faces unemployment and hyperinflation. From 1985 to the end of 1989, prices multiplied more than 600,000 times. And the Soviet Union is more likely to concentrate on its own problems than continue its support.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Investors Are Turning Bearish On Japan

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
As Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu headed for California to meet with President Bush last week, Japan-bashing was on the rise in the financial markets.
Japan was the leading economic success story of the past 15 years, but these days it gets no respect from the world's foreign-exchange, bond or stock traders.
The Government of Japan doesn't seem to get along with its central bank, and the Prime Minister's hold on power appears tenuous despite his election victory. In negotiations with leaders of his own party last week, Mr. Kaifu's chief victory was in keeping a convicted criminal - from the Lockheed bribery scandal of the 1970's - out of his Cabinet. 
Some complain that Japanese interest rates are too high to allow the stock market to maintain its exalted levels; others moan that rates are too low to support the yen. With rates rising, share prices fell last week, and so did the yen. The dollar closed above 150 yen for the first time in more than two years.
Perhaps the ultimate indignity for Japan is that the rest of the world seems quite unconcerned about its problems. On Monday, after the Tokyo stock market had its second-worst day ever, the Dow Jones industrial average rose, as it did each day of the week, ending with an overall gain of 96.17 points, or 3.8 percent, to 2,660.36, for its best week in more than four months.
''In Japan, interest rates and inflation are rising,'' said Linda S. Mezey, the research director at Philadelphia's Provident National Bank, adding that she saw no threat here from either, and is buying stocks.
At Prudential-Bache, technician Joseph Feshbach looked up from his charts to proclaim that a strong dollar ''will be one of the biggest stories of the year,'' with the German mark turning from star to stumbler. He thinks the dollar will rise in 1990 to 157 yen and 1.85 marks, from current levels of 150.25 yen and 1.72 marks. The mark, which had been strong, slipped despite central bank intervention to support it.
In this country, much of the economic data from early 1990 looks weak, with both consumer confidence and durable goods orders falling. But who knows what to believe? With the Commerce Department having taken its second stab at reporting the gross national product for the final three months of last year, that quarter looks much better than it had.
When it put out the first figures a month ago (the ''advance'' report), Commerce painted a picture of very weak trade numbers, soaring inventories and falling final sales to consumers. Now (in the ''preliminary'' report) it says forget all those trends. Non-farm inventories were 20 percent lower than reported; the trade figures were the best in six years and final sales were up. Share prices fell on the first report, and rose on the second. The ''final'' report will be out March 28.
If the Surgeon General had jurisdiction over the Commerce Department, he might require a warning on news releases: ''Caution: Believing these numbers may be hazardous to your wealth.''

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
If a Laser Printer Ran Backwards . . .

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
The Caere Corporation, which two years ago created the first optical character-recognition system for personal computers, is preparing to introduce a $10,995 computer that is said to recognize printed words at a rate of 2,500 a minute and convert them to electronic form with a high level of accuracy. The Caere Parallel Page Reader, which is expected to be shown tomorrow at the ''Seybold Seminars 90'' electronic publishing conference in Boston, attaches to a computer network with relative ease and functions as a sort of laser printer in reverse. That is, the user feeds the printed documents into a scanner, and the Parallel Page Reader converts them into word-processing or data-base files.
The new machine is expected to appeal to government agencies, large law offices, insurance companies, aerospace companies and other computer-intensive businesses that must deal with a large volume of paper. Larry Miller, director of sales and marketing for Caere, said the Parallel Page Reader was developed as part of a special project for the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
The commission receives about 40 million paper pages of official filings a year, he said, and it was looking for an inexpensive way to convert those pages into electronic form for speedy retrieval and efficient archiving. If Caere's performance claims are accurate - and analysts who have seen the device say they appear to be - it would take 25 tireless secretaries, each typing 100 words a minute, to match the output of a single Parallel Page Reader.
''It is going to change the ground rules'' of the optical character-recognition market, said Bill Clinton, director of the computer publishing systems division of the market research firm BIS/CAP International of Norwell, Mass. ''Compared to existing products,'' he added, ''it offers a significant increase in performance and a significant decrease in price, both by a factor of four.''
Not every analyst was as sanguine. ''I don't think it's going to give Caere a long-term advantage,'' said Jennifer J. Mitchell of Dataquest Inc., a market research firm. ''It's a pragmatic approach to volume character recognition, but it could be duplicated by someone else.''
Significantly, the Caere reader will be sold in retail computer stores, which could open up a new market for high-end recognition systems, Mr. Clinton noted. Until now, high-performance optical document processors cost $40,000 to $250,000 and were too complicated for the average retailer to sell and support. With a price in the same range as a high-end PC and configured to be added easily to a company's local area network, the Parallel Page Reader breaks new ground.
Yet the machine is not a mass-market product. It would be overkill to use it for documents that include only a few words; it needs vast, dense thickets of words to really show its stuff. And because the scanners used by the Caere machine are not known for sophisticated paper handling, odd-sized or ill-treated forms may jam that end of the system.
Not everyone needs to convert millions of pages of documentation into computer files each year, of course. That is why Caere also recently introduced versions of its $795 Apple Macintosh- and PC-based software, Omnipage, which can break down a scanned image of a printed page into electrons and herd the electrons into any of 25 popular word-processing formats at a rate of several hundred words a minute.
The Parallel Page Reader breaks ground in more ways than marketing. It is one of the first commercial desktop applications of parallel processing, a technique that has been the domain of advanced computer researchers and supercomputer companies.
In parallel processing, several individual microprocessors work in tandem on a single problem. If two heads are better than one, the reasoning goes, four heads are even better. Some parallel machines comprise 16, 64, 128 or even more processors, using PC-level chips to yield supercomputer performance at a fraction of the cost.
The Parallel Page Reader is essentially an enlarged eight-slot personal computer powered by the Intel 80386SX microprocessor and backed with one megabyte of RAM and a 40-megabyte hard disk. DOS, Windows and Caere's character-recognition software are already installed on the machine. Four slots contain Caere's special page recognition cards, each with its own 16-megahertz Motorola 68020 processor and two megabytes of memory, working in parallel. The remaining slots are given to a disk drive controller, a video card, a scanner card and, if needed, a network card.
To complete the system the user would have to buy a scanner, a video monitor, a mouse and a keyboard. The system works with only threeJU scanners, but they cover a full range of choices: the inexpensive Microtek MS-II ($1,495 list, including a sheet feeder), the reliable Hewlett-Packard Scanjet Plus ($2,195), and the high-speed Fujitsu M309X series ($5,650 to $6,720), which can capture a page in five seconds.
While current high-end page recognition systems also have multiple processors, Mr. Miller of Caere said those processors do not function in parallel. Each is assigned a separate task, he said: one might handle sentence parsing, another character identification, another context analysis and still another document formatting.
In such systems, a scanner captures an image of a page, and the image is then recognized, or read, by the character-recognition software. The software looks for patterns of light and dark that resemble letters or numbers, then assigns an alphanumeric character to that area of the image. When it is done reading the page and creating a text file, the scanner captures the next screen.
The process is scan, read, scan, read and so on, and recognition halts when the scanner is active. Because reading an image usually takes longer than scanning it, some users of high-end page readers scan all the documents at once, during the day, and then process the images at night or on weekends. With the Caere Parallel Page Reader, Mr. Miller said, each of the four Motorola chips can attack a full page at once; in the rival systems, he said, each chip attacks a different part of the same page.
As a result, the Parallel Page Reader's page recognition is as fast as, or faster than, the scanning. Subsequent pages can be scanned even as the first page is being read, and the total output of the system rises dramatically. With the Windows software, the user can be proofreading the output while subsequent pages are being scanned and recognized.
Caere, which is based in Los Gatos, Calif., claims that characters are recognized at a rate of 220 to 700 characters per second, or c.p.s., as against the high of 250 c.p.s. for the current leader in high-end systems, the Calera 9000 Compound Document Processor, made by Calera Recognition Systems Inc., of Santa Clara, Calif. The other leader in character recognition is Kurzweil Computer Products Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., a subsidiary of the Xerox Corporation. Mr. Clinton, the BIS/CAP analyst, said he expected Calera to mount the most effective challenge to Caere's new machine.

HEADLINE: Tech Notes;
Bringing Diesel Up to Snuff Without Alternative Fuels

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The soot-belching city bus is headed for extinction as a result of stringent Federal emissions standards due to go into effect next year. Buses in urban areas may now emit as much as 0.6 grams of black carbon particles per horsepower of the engine for each mile driven; that allowance will be cut to one-tenth of a gram next Jan. 1.
Such alternative fuels as methanol and compressed natural gas have been advanced as the solution to the clean-up problem, and test programs involving both are underway in New York and elsewhere. The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has imposed the standards on transit systems three years before the same rules are to apply to all heavy duty diesel engines to encourage large scale tests of alternative fuels. 
Since buses return to a central storage and fueling facility each day, only one alternate fuel tank and pumping facility would have to be installed to service them, as compared with a nationwide infrastructure needed to service over-the-road trucks. But alternative fuels will require costly modifications to bus engines and servicing facilities, deliver fewer miles per gallon and may cut into passenger carrying capacity.
As a result, many bus fleet managers will simply stop buying new buses after Jan. 1 until the advantages and drawbacks of alternative fuels become clearer, according to a survey last year by the American Public Transit Association. One association member, the Golden Gate Bridge Highway and Transportation District, based in San Francisco, estimated that converting to methanol would add an additional $31,260 a year to the $130,000 annual cost of operating each bus.
This quandary may provide an opportunity for a small, Radcliffe, Iowa-based entrepeneur who has developed a system that may be able to bring standard, diesel-fueled engines into compliance at a relatively modest cost.
The system, developed by a company called Midwest Power Concepts, injects low-proof ethyl alcohol, also known as ethanol, into the engine. At the same time, it reduces the amount of diesel fuel flowing to the engine's cylinders. Warren M. Dobbertin Jr., Midwest Power's president, said the partial substitution of ethanol for diesel fuel eliminates the overfueling that is responsible for the black cloudbursts from the exhaust pipe when a diesel engine is heavily accelerated.
The water and alcohol mix in 80 proof ethanol helps cool the burning fuel, reducing the formation of polluting nitrogen oxides. In general, the hotter the temperature in a cylinder, the more the usually inert nitrogen in air is converted into nitrogen oxides.
Although the system has not yet reached the required 0.1 gram level, tests on older engines have shown the ability to cut carbon particulate emissions by more than 50 percent. ''The engines we have been testing are 1980-81 vintage, and they meet 1989 standards,'' Mr. Dobbertin said. ''Engines being made today put out about 0.2 grams. Our system will bring it below 0.1.''
The tests on the older engines were conducted by Southwest Research Institute, an independent testing organization based in San Antonio. One engine averaged 0.91 grams of particles in the unmodified state; the emissions were reduced to 0.45 grams with the addition of the Midwest Power system.
A spokesman for Detroit Diesel Corporation, the leading producer of the two-cycle diesel engines for transit buses, said the tests indicate Midwest Power's system ''may have some validity in concept.'' Nevertheless, the company plans to rely on a methanol-fueled engine to meet the 1991 standards.
A bigger booster of the Midwest Power approach is Stephen Spade, general manager of the Metropolitan Transit Authority in Des Moines, which operated 17 modified buses for three months last year to monitor changes in fuel efficiency and durability. The result was an almost identical fuel cost per mile of 24.40 cents with the modified system, compared to 24.42 cents for straight diesel. Although the modified buses got 0.19 fewer miles per gallon, the lower price of ethanol - 58 cents a gallon compared to 88 cents a gallon for diesel - more than offset the milage loss.
''I think they are on to something,'' Mr. Spade said, referring to Mr. Dobbertin and Dwayne Fossen, the actual developer of the system. ''I'm normally a skeptic about this sort of thing, but it seems to work.'' Mr. Spade said a test of longer duration involving more modern engines and more vehicles is needed to refine the data on fuel economy and operating costs.
The system, which costs $7,000 installed, consists of a control box, a separate ethanol fuel tank and pump, a device to inject the alcohol into the engine's incoming airstream and related plumbing and exhaust treatment devices. The ethanol mixture is 45 percent pure ethyl alcohol, 55 percent water and 5 percent polyglycol oil, a lubricating agent.
According to Mr. Dobbertin, the added control box intercepts the signal from the accelerator pedal before it reaches the manufacturer's control and reduces the demand for diesel fuel by up to 30 percent. Then it activates the alcohol system to start pumping the other fuel to an injector mounted in the intake manifold between the turbocharger used on many diesel engines to improve acceleration and the cylinders.
The alcohol enters the cylinder with the incoming airstream, while the diesel fuel is injected by standard means. The only time the diesel fuel and ethanol mix is in the combustion chamber, so the approach is different from the gasahol experiments with cars, where the two fuels were premixed and pumped into the same tank.
Reducing the diesel fuel flow prevents flooding the cylinders with more fuel than can be burned completely. But just cutting back the diesel fuel flow would make the vehicles unacceptably sluggish in pickup. So the clean burning alcohol is substituted, adding energy and slowing the burning process to hold down the formation of nitrogen oxides. After the bus gets up to speed and the accelerator signal is reduced, the proportion of diesel-to-alcohol is increased.
Mr. Dobbertin said the size of the ethanol tank is about 30 percent of the size of the existing diesel tank, so the two containers should empty at about the same rate. But if the alcohol tank should empty first, a limp-home mode has been provided for diesel-only operation.
Since transit buses represent only about 2 percent of heavy-duty diesel engines in operation, the 1991 rules represent a large-scale test. In 1993 they are scheduled to cover all heavy-duty diesels, which power the trucks that deliver most of the nation's goods.
Because it will be many years, if ever, before a nationwide system for distributing alternate fuels is in place, many manufacturers are relying on particulate traps on diesel-fueled engines to meet the emission standards. The traps collect the carbon particles and periodically heat up to burn off the particles.
But Mr. Dobbertin is betting that alcohol injection can compete with traps. ''We are working with two large fleets to develop a test program,'' he said. ''If we can demonstrate real-world savings, the bureaucrats in Washington will have to take a look.''

HEADLINE: All About/Machine Tools;
Fissures in the Industrial Bedrock

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Machine tool makers are part of the nation's industrial bedrock. Manufacturers rely on them for equipment to forge, cut, grind, drill, bend, trim and stamp the blocks and sheets of metal that become cars, airplanes and appliances.
The 1980's revealed the industry's weaknesses, leaving it vulnerable to the slightest economic downturn. ''The next few months will be pins-and-needles time,'' said James L. Koontz, president and chief executive officer of the Kingsbury Machine Tool Corporation. in Keene, N.H. ''If orders don't pick up, a number of companies may be in trouble.''
Weakened by foreign competition and highly fragmented, the industry is struggling to overcome a legacy of poor management and a tradition of under-investment in research. Market trends, notably the substitution of plastics for metals, limit growth prospects. 
Machine tool companies say they have also been hurt by their lack of bargaining power with the huge auto and aerospace companies, which account for half of all tool sales. The American industry also loses sales due to Government restrictions on exports of their most sophisticated products.
The problems in this cyclical industry have been partially masked by a 69 percent surge of tool orders in 1988, to $3.6 billion, which led to a leap in shipments, to $3.2 billion, last year. Many of the 350 or so companies that are the heart of the industry, and the 1,000 or so small specialty shops that make customized tools, had large backlogs of orders.
But with economic growth slowing, new orders fell 22 percent last year to $2.81 billion. New orders during January were down another 15 percent from last year's monthly average, according to the National Association of Machine Tool Builders.
 
THE IMPORT FIGHT
 
Asia and Europe Take Over Markets
 International competitiveness remains the industry's greatest worry. Many of the companies that survived the industry's contraction in the 1970's have abandoned the market for smaller machines, leaving it to Japanese, Korean, and Taiwanese companies. European companies, especially West German and Swiss, have driven smaller American competitors out of several niches for precision equipment. Industry leaders like Cincinnati Milacron and Cross & Trecker managed to cushion the financial damage by signing agreements to import and distribute equipment made by Asian firms.
The imports' share of the United States market rose from less than one-fourth to about one-half during the 1980's. The Japanese have led the onslaught, offering tools that match or surpass American quality at far lower prices. In recent years, many Japanese tool makers followed the lead of the Japanese auto makers and electronics companies that are their main customers - and sometimes part owners - in setting up factories in the United States.
Domestic companies have defended themselves by lobbying for import protection and overhauling their product lines. The industry's pressure on Washington resulted in agreements through 1991 for Japan and Taiwan to limit some tool exports to the United States to 1981 levels.
Their new products often link highly computerized machines in clusters. These manufacturing ''cells'' can feed materials to machine tools and automatically change tool heads so that one machine can perform several tasks, like boring a hole and threading it for a screw. To pursue new technology further, tool makers, their major customers and the Government joined to create the National Center for Manufacturing Sciences in Ann Arbor, Mich., in 1988.
 
THE EXPORT BLOCK
 
Battling Washington's Restrictions
 As competition at home intensifies, the larger machine tool companies are stepping up their efforts to export. Analysts say that companies with businesses in Europe already, like Cross & Trecker, may be among the early beneficiaries of Eastern Europe's need to modernize plants. To exploit that opportunity, though, American tool makers want fewer restrictions on exports to the East Bloc and China.
Tool makers claim that because their equipment has become far more sophisticated in the 15 years since the restrictions were drafted, the rules inhibit the export to these countries of virtually all today's machine tools - not just the ones that might be used by military forces. ''While our allies resolve doubtful cases in favor of exporting, we do not,'' said Jim Mack, the machine tool group's vice president in charge of Government affairs. The United States sold slightly more than $1 million in tools to the Soviet Union in 1988 while West Germans topped $500 million. So far, the Bush Administration has agreed to consider allowing more exports to Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia.
Even with the restrictions, the export outlook is improving. Sales to the Soviet Union reached $13 million in the first nine months of last year, according to Patrick McGibbon, who follows machine tools for the International Trade Administration in Washington. He estimated that overall exports were up more than 30 percent for the year, compared with 20 percent growth in imports. Asian and European demand remains strong, he said. But American tool makers are still far from matching their foreign competitors. ''Imports are two and a half times as large as exports,'' Mr. McGibbon pointed out, ''so our trade balance continued to worsen.''
 
GIDDINGS & LEWIS
 
Poised for A Competitive Leap
 No machine tool company is riding higher these days than Giddings & Lewis Inc., based in Fond du Lac, Wisc. Giddings emerged from the industry's decade of turmoil reporting healthy profits, almost no debt, and a strong competitive position in its major product lines. But the journey was a rough one, demonstrating that even far-sightedness is imperfect protection in today's competitive environment.
Giddings, founded in 1859, entered the 1980's with plans to furnish machines for what industrial visionaries called ''the factory of the future.'' Figuring that few customers would build entirely new factories, Giddings became a leading proponent of versatile manufacturing cells that could readily handle parts of different sizes and quick tool changes. More flexible manufacturing methods could reduce the amount of inventory tied up in production and allow manufacturers to modernize in small steps.
Very few of these systems were sold at first, and Giddings itself was taken over in 1982 by the AMCA International Corporation. It lost money for four years in a row in the mid-1980's. But Giddings kept plugging away at the concept, building up the computer software and engineering expertise to make it attractive.
The complexity of the systems, which cost millions of dollars, kept Giddings close to major customers and fostered a sense of partnership. It also kept the company out of the markets most affected by imports. At the same time, the company clamped down on its own manufacturing costs. Everything began to fall into place in 1988. By the time AMCA decided to spin off the company last summer, there was plenty of good news to offer Wall Street.
Giddings recently reported that it earned $17.1 million on sales of $233.1 million in 1989, with new orders increasing despite last year's decline for the industry. And William J. Fife Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, said that proposals the company had been invited to make for new orders were running 30 percent ahead of last year.

 
THE CHALLENGE OF NEW MATERIALS
During the 1980's, machine tool makers not only had to meet modern needs for precision and speed; they also had to design machines that could deal with new metal alloys, plastics and exotic composites. Some of these needs to handle new materials have been met by traditional machine tool companies. Cincinnati Milacron, for example, has become a leading supplier of plastic processing equipment.
Composites, which combine light weight and exceptional strength, are a special challenge. ''Composites have been a hot research topic for several decades but it is only in the last three years that there has been a strong scientific effort to characterize the tools and tooling needs,'' said Steven Rogers, an engineer at the Heath Tecna Aerospace Company. Most tooling for composites has developed from trial-and-error programs involving aerospace companies and small tool suppliers like Heath.
Composites, such as the blend of carbon fibers and epoxy widely used in aircraft, are molded from sheets, like plywood, not forged like traditional metals. The sheets are shaped under high pressures and temperatures that can reach 350 degrees. They are extremely tough to cut, drill or trim with traditional tools. The average steel drill bit would burn up before one hole could be made through a quarter-inch of carbon-fiber composite, according to Ken Luebbert, a cutting tools expert for McDonnell Douglas in St. Louis. As a result, users of composites have become leading customers for diamond-edge tools and high-pressure water jets.
Water jets are used in the auto industry for tasks like cutting carpeting. To cut composites, fine grains of garnet are injected into the stream. Water jets are easier to operate robotically, have less heat buildup and are less likely to produce hazardous dust than other cutting tools, according to David Ginburg, a senior engineer for Lockheed Aeronautical Systems in Marietta, Ga.
But the water jets cannot be used for drilling holes only part way through a piece of material. For delicate tasks, diamond-tipped tools have a clear advantage. Aerospace tool experts say that a diamond-coated drill bit can last for 1,500 holes, compared with just 40 for a standard bit.
With such new materials and technologies chipping away at the traditional markets, the National Machine Tool Builders Association is scrambling to broaden its base and project a new, with-it image. To its already long name, the group added a hyphen and ''The Association for Manufacturing Technology.''

HEADLINE: No.1 CONCERNS;
The New Dawn Is Casting Some Things In a Bad Light

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.

 BODY:
GEORGE BERNARD SHAW once noted that there are two tragedies in life: One is to lose your heart's desire, the other is to gain it.
Democracy is winning. The arms race is over. Villains are friendly now, or impotent. Like a roulette wheel, the globe began spinning in a glorious blur and when it stopped, the jackpot so long desired was America's. So then why doesn't it feel better? Perhaps because while the world celebrates American values, America is home watching the party on TV. Poll-takers, among others, have detected an uneasy sense that, in contrast to the powerful images of democracy transforming the rest of the world, this country is going nowhere fast. 
''Our ideals are triumphing but American wealth, influence, prestige and power are all declining,'' said William Schneider, a Democratic analyst. ''We have lost our ability to control major events.''
Republicans, of course, have rejoinders - among others, that resources are limited. But across the political spectrum, officials and business leaders worry about American schoolchildren lagging behind Asian schoolchildren, about electronic markets ceded to the Japanese, about a self-indulgent corporate culture that has thrived on short-term profits, about an American political system that has grown cynical, slashing and corrupt.
America was always confident at the center of the military universe, or so it seemed. Now it must struggle to stay at the center of an economic universe.
''We don't have the same kind of confidence about ourselves economically that we did militarily,'' said Norman Ornstein of the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington organization associated with conservative thought. ''The Japanese and the Germans seem more disciplined, with a greater work ethic and better technological capabilities. On a basic level of math and engineering, we're clearly behind.''
In California last week, President Bush talked about tackling the nettlesome problems at home: education, drugs, the environment. His speeches were full of good intentions. At the Santa Ana Bowl, with Chuck Norris, the movie tough guy, and Los Angeles Rams cheerleaders around him, Mr. Bush vowed that the days of the drug lords are numbered. But back in Washington, his Administration had conceded that the world drug crop soared last year, despite the President's high-profile drug war. In its annual report on drug production, the State Department said that South American coca production had increased 12 percent from 1988 to 1989.
Americans are measurably happy with their President. He talks about fixing what ails the country. He does not ask for money to do it, and that is fine with the electorate.
When President Bush first began to let the Western Europeans take the initiative at the Paris economic summit talks last summer, his deference was hailed at home and abroad as a refreshing change from the swaggering years of Ronald Reagan.
But now Mr. Bush has stepped back so often, keeping his White House and Washington in the wings of world events, that Americans are growing self-conscious about their secondary role, say pollsters who have conducted focus groups on the subject.
The statesmen catching the world's fancy are elsewhere: Vaclav Havel, Nelson Mandela, Lech Walesa, Mikhail Gorbachev.
Mr. Schneider echoes a view common among Democracts, but not necessily limited to them, that the country will soon start to chafe at the continuing sameness of Government, its lack of commitment to any large new undertaking.
In education, the President promises that American students will be the best in the world at math and science by the turn of the century. And the National Governors' Association, meeting in Washington last week, echoed that goal. But some educators merely shake their heads, arguing that that is unlikely. Even as the President praised the governors' interest in education, Congressional Democrats criticized the ''tepid'' 2 percent education spending increase proposed by the Administration, which holds that increased outlays are not necessarily the key to educational improvement.
But as Mr. Bush continues an advocation of limited government that has held sway in Washington for a decade, the implications of those limits are becoming clear.
To some, Washington now seems devoid of inspiration. But Peggy Noonan, a former Reagan speechwriter, says that Mr. Bush has no need of lofty rhetoric and prefers quietly chipping away at problems.
Tubby Harrison, a pollster who has been doing surveys for the Washington fund-raising group, Democrats for the '90s, said he has been surprised how often those polled expressed a yearning for an inspirational style of leadership.
The President is tetchy about complaints that he doesn't have a vision. ''The vision thing, if you will,'' he says sardonically, when he talks about it. His advisers say that by using the Presidency as a bully pulpit and eking out what money he can from the budget, he will make progress on domestic problems.
But Democrats who once thought Mr. Bush unbeatable in 1992 are begining to wonder if America will be willing to settle for incremental wishes and small-scale dreams.
