HEADLINE: REAL FOOD IN L.A.

BYLINE: By MACDONALD HARRIS; MacDonald Harris's novel ''Hemingway's Suitcase'' is forthcoming from Simon & Schuster.

 BODY:
The average person's notion of food in Los Angeles is that it's supermodern, trendy and eclectic. Like all cliches, this is largely true. There's a place on Melrose that serves Tex-Mex dim sum, and a favorite kind of sushi, with avocado, is called California maki. L.A., with its vista west to the Orient, its rich stew of immigrants, its diverse cultures, encourages strange mixtures and makes everything its own, while at the same time preserving individual flavors. Hawaiian papaya and New Zealand mussels rest together nicely in a Los Angeles salad.
Yet, often invisible to the visitor, there remain a handful of more traditional eating places, also typically L.A., that have been around since the 20's and before, and that still have a loyal following among residents who knew the town before the advent of nouvelle cuisine, carpaccio, goat cheese and the ''Califoriental'' style. 
I used to go to the Taix French Restaurant so long ago that I won't tell you when it was, but it was before World War II. In those days my parents often took me there for a Sunday dinner. Through imperfect memory, I see a glass door with lace curtains on Commercial Street, in downtown Los Angeles near the old Plaza, in a neighborhood of warehouses. Inside the door was a lady cashier dressed in black, just as in a provincial French restaurant, then the long room with two rows of tables for eight and a corridor down the middle. A ceiling of pressed tin, hanging lamps, a dark polished floor.
Taix was founded in the 20's by a family of French immigrants who had been sheepherders and bakers in the Hautes Alpes. Originally the property at 321 Commercial Street was a hotel. Marius Taix, who took over the management of the restaurant in 1927, was also a pharmacist, and he had an arrangement with a wine dealer in Oregon to supply ''medicinal wines'' to his business. This was handy for the restaurant; during Prohibition it was common to find city officials and even G-men enjoying a lunch with wine in the back room of the establishment. The food was plain French country cooking, plentiful and skillfully prepared; a full table d'hote meal of soup, salad, main course and fruit, with plenty of French bread, cost 50 cents in the mid-30's. By that time the place on Commercial Street had become a Los Angeles institution, popular with businessmen and salesmen at noon and with families at dinner. It lasted until the property was condemned in 1964 to make room for an office building.
But there still is a Taix. In 1962 the family opened another restaurant on Sunset Boulevard, and this is still operating, under the name Les Freres Taix. It's a little pocket of nostalgia for those old enough to have known the original Taix, and it's still a good place to get a moderately priced French dinner.
Les Freres Taix is not on the fashionable part of Sunset; it's in the Echo Park district, in a neighborhood ranging from faded elegance to the dingy. The large, rambling building is in a style that might be described as Los Angeles Chalet; inside it seems a perfectly ordinary old-fashioned restaurant, with a shadowy interior lighted by lamps even in the daytime, carpeted floors, imitation-leather booths and stained-glass windows. But the ghost of the old place still lingers. The food is prepared with care and served with a certain elan. The meal starts with a large tureen of soup, as it did in the old place back in the 30's. The menu is anything but trendy - it features such hardy staples of French cookery as grilled chicken diable and duck a l'orange. The place is a memory machine for anyone who has ever eaten in a country restaurant in France. The Taix family is still in charge, and a good many of the customers, to judge from their white heads, come there because they still remember the former establishment.
Although Philippe, the Home of the Original French Dip Sandwich, has moved several times since its founding, it still offers one of the best food bargains in town, and a lot of atmosphere. Its founder, Philippe Mathieu, came to California from Southern France at the turn of the century. When he opened his first restaurant in 1908, he served all you could eat plus ''a pint of good claret wine'' for a quarter. In 1927, Philippe's was bought by Harry, Frank and Dave Martin, and it remains in their family today. In 1978, they decided to raise the price of coffee from a nickel to a dime, and that's still what it costs.
The present Philippe's is on Alameda Street, near the Union Station and Chinatown. It's a commercial district; Alameda is the kind of street that has railroad tracks running down it. The restaurant is a big nondescript masonry building painted tan and brown. Inside there is sawdust on the floor, and people sitting on stools are eating at long tables that will hold 12 or more. There are several dining rooms full of these tables, and a few booths, which are not used very much. As at the old Taix, you share your table with anybody who happens to sit down next to you. There is an air of camaraderie among the customers, a kind of unspoken friendliness and consideration that's rare in a big city; at our last visit a middle-aged Asian man moved with a smile when he suspected that his cigar was bothering us. The customers are people of all kinds: shoppers, residents of nearby Chinatown, businessmen, Amtrak workers from the station, people who have been coming here for years and are now bringing their children. More than any other place I can think of, Philippe's typifies the democratic spirit of Los Angeles, its lack of any true caste system, and the tendency of the rich not to want to lose touch with what the poor do.
The way the service works is unique. There is a long counter with 12 servers, each of them with everything she needs to prepare a meal. You get into one of the 12 lines, and when you reach your server she can take care of your whole lunch: make your sandwich or fix your hot dish, serve salads or soup, give you coffee or a glass of wine, add it all up and take your money. Except for the money, it's like Mother making you a lunch. The plates are paper, the other service is crockery. There are ceiling fans, a collection of neon beer signs and a history of the restaurant in faded press clippings framed on the wall. You can make yourself at home. If you want, you can just get a beer and sit drinking it and talking to a friend at one of the long tables.
Philippe's invented the French Dip Sandwich, and whether or not this was a great contribution to international cuisine, it's the feature of the place and many people are fond of it, perhaps out of nostalgia. The recipe: slice a French roll lengthwise, pile a generous portion of meat on the lower half and, with a fork, submerge the upper half in the sauce, the drippings from roast beef. That's all there is to it. Beef is the meat that works best, although at Philippe's you can also get ham, turkey, pork and lamb. In 1935, in the middle of the Depression, the French Dip Sandwich cost a dime; a few years later they raised it to a quarter. Now it costs $3.10. Philippe's claims to deal with 3,000 customers a day, and you can see why. I was introduced to the place by my father, who used to go there in the 30's when he was a salesman for a steel company. Most older L.A. residents have a similar story to tell.
Another restaurant that was bequeathed to me by my parents is Clifton's Cafeteria, on Broadway near Seventh. It was founded in 1935, and it's still there in the same place, exactly as it has always been. In the 30's, Broadway was the center of the L.A. shopping district and the home of the fashionable department stores, Bullock's, the May Company and the Broadway. Today it's simply a big stirring-pot of all the ethnic populations of Los Angeles. The people on the street are just about in the proportions of the whole population of the city: Anglo, Hispanic, black and others. It's a garish, colorful, popular thoroughfare, a combination of a Mexican paseo, Times Square and Main Street, U.S.A.
The sidewalk in front of the cafeteria is packed with people and the street is full of buses nose to nose; many patrons of Clifton's don't own cars. Inside, the main dining room is a simulated Alpine valley; there are murals of redwoods and other forest scenes, artificial boulders, granite cliffs and redwood trunks, an alpine chapel and a real running brook with a waterfall. The tables are installed on terraces running almost to the top of this forest. (There is also seating at floor level, but a sign suggests that you leave it to those who can't climb stairs.) Above the Alpine valley there are two more floors of dining rooms. The top floor is decorated with a kind of naive bordello elegance, with red carpets, white classic columns and red-and-gold brocade on the walls. Clifton's offers a feast for the eyes as well as for the stomach.
At the rear of the main floor is the serving area. There are three identical lanes for cafeteria service. The popular items are meat and gravy, chicken-fried steaks, Southern fried chicken, turkey with dressing, short ribs and fried fish. And the trimmings: mashed potatoes, roast potatoes, rice, all kinds of vegetables, old-fashioned biscuits and the usual pies and cakes. If Philippe's is what Mother gave you for lunch, Clifton's is what you got when you visited Grandmother at the farm. The prices are reasonable, not to say cheap. The weekday special, ''chopped beef patty'' with mashed potatoes and vegetable, is $2.39. Tradition has it that Clifton's has never turned away anyone who was hungry and didn't have the money for a meal. I don't know anybody who has tested this policy, but it's still officially in effect.
You can't get a free meal at Musso & Frank, no matter how hungry you are, but it's still a nostalgic, modest and very popular place. Its Hollywood Boulevard setting, like downtown Broadway, has declined with the years. Once it was the center and showpiece of the international film world, hinged on the pivot of Graumann's Chinese Theater, where every important movie was premiered. The Chinese Theater is still there, now called Mann's, but the rest of Hollywood Boulevard is a tacky collection of record stores, souvenir stands, sex shops and stores offering far-out clothing. The Musso & Frank Grill was founded in 1919; it's the oldest restaurant in Hollywood. It's also the last restaurant in L.A., probably in the world, to serve chicken a la king.
While Hollywood Boulevard has changed, Musso's has stayed the same. The interior is dark and soothing after the garish hubbub of the street outside. There is an air of faded gentility about the place, insofar as Hollywood understands this quality. Each dark wood booth has its hatrack, even though nobody in Los Angeles has worn a hat for years. The waiters are in red jackets and bow ties, and the busboys are in green jackets. Musso's claims that its chef, Michel Bourger, is ''from Paris, France,'' and he probably is. People have been making deals here, trying to persuade producers of their talents and discussing ideas for scripts, since the 20's.
Today the clientele is varied; there are a few movie types, or people who wish to be taken for such, but the others are families, young West L.A. marrieds, tourists and oldsters (you can't call them seniors because they look too affluent for that). In the booth next to us was a Russian-American would-be actress and her grandmother visiting from the Soviet Union. This became apparent from the loud comments and compliments of the waiter, who was perhaps Russian himself. It's a good place for young women to take their grandmothers; there were several others.
The menu is pre-war, and the prices are just adjusted a little for inflation. On our recent visit, one of us had squab with bacon, and the other Welsh rarebit, a specialty of Musso's, one of the cheapest things on the menu, and one of the best - tangy and rich, and there's a dish with more sauce on the side. There are other gustatory fossils: shrimp Louie, crab Louie and stuffed tomato with crab. If you want anything green at Musso's, you'd better order it separately; the squab comes with nothing but french fries and a sprig of parsley. There is nothing whatsoever in this menu that could not be 1937, except the wine list; we got a nice California chablis for $10. If you want to find Musso's, it's opposite the star for John Barrymore in the sidewalk.
Will Rogers never heard of goat cheese, carpaccio or sushi, and if he had he wouldn't have touched them. He is one of the patron saints of the Polo Lounge, in the Beverly Hills Hotel on Sunset Boulevard. This is the expensive part of Sunset, not the Echo Park stretch where Taix ended up after it moved from downtown. Back in the 20's, the hotel had a cafe called El Jardin. Will Rogers used to have lunch there with Darryl F. Zanuck and Tommy Hitchcock; since all three were avid polo players, they persuaded the hotel to change the name of the place to the Polo Lounge. There are no polo accoutrements in it today, but it does look like the Mexican garden of its original name. It consists of a meandering set of rooms around a patio, with an ancient and gnarled Brazilian pepper tree as its centerpiece, as contorted as something in the Walt Disney movie ''Fantasia.''
Sunday brunch is a nice time to visit the Polo Lounge. The price is $27 - not Clifton's, but not outrageous. There is live mariachi music, and a trendy crowd, all talking fast. Young affluent families, the men in French jeans and leather jackets, the women in leisure high fashion, the children in designer children's clothes; undoubtedly they go to the best private schools. Magnate types, chic women, Jaguar bohemians, women of a certain age who look astonished because they have had too many face lifts. The rooms around the patio are green and white, with pink tablecloths. Outside, the patio furniture is partly green and partly pink. Both the patio and the inside rooms are crowded; the servers and the mariachis can hardly get around and past one another to do their respective jobs.
The service is a little slow. There was no soup spoon with the vichyssoise and we had to ask for it. The brunch courses are: a champagne cocktail, an hors d'oeuvre, an entree, a selection from the pastry tray and coffee. The food is now ''California French'' - decorative vegetable garnishes in Kandinsky-like patterns, coulis in geometric swirls, Norwegian salmon substituted for the ham in the eggs benedict. There is also an a la carte menu; at the table next to us a girl in a Stanford sweat shirt, with her parents, was having a hamburger ($12) with fries and ketchup. (If you want a cheeseburger, it comes with roquefort and costs $13.) The coffee is not 10 cents. There are no Chinatown residents or Amtrak workers. These people lack the bonhomie of the customers of Philippe's, but they have something else: they radiate power. Yet I suspect that some of them occasionally have a weekday lunch at Philippe's. That would be consistent with Los Angeles as I know it. The regular customers at Philippe's, however, do not occasionally have brunch at the Polo Lounge.

Clifton's Brookdale Cafeteria, 648 South Broadway, Los Angeles 90014. Specials change daily; the price of a meal of soup, entree, dessert and beverage is about $5. No alcohol is served. Polo Lounge, Beverly Hills Hotel and Bungalows, 9641 Sunset Boulevard, Beverly Hills, Calif. 90210 (213-276-2251). Sunday brunch is served from 11 to 3. Valet parking.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 865 words

HEADLINE: RADIO MOSCOW'S NEW YORK ACCENT

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN; Walter Goodman is a television critic for The New York Times.

 BODY:

PARTING WITH ILLUSIONS
By Vladimir Pozner.
324 pp. New York:
The Atlantic Monthly Press.
$19.95.
Maybe you have seen Vladimir Pozner on ''Nightline'' or ''Donahue.'' Born in France and raised in the United States, he made his career in the Soviet Union as an unaccented American voice on Radio Moscow's North American service and lately has been gracing American television, expounding on this and that. 
''Parting With Illusions'' purports to be an account of his life. He spent the World War II years in New York, where he attended Stuyvesant High School. In 1952, when he was 18, he was taken to what would become his motherland by his Russian-born father, ''a staunch supporter of socialism and of the Soviet Union'' who wanted to get away from the anti-Communism of the 1950's.
As autobiography, ''Parting With Illusions'' is not compelling; the self-revelation is entirely inadvertent. There is some sharp gossip about the way midlevel apparatchiks in Soviet journalism get ahead or get left behind, but Mr. Pozner is more interested in his own role as a liberally inclined party man who knows the best and the worst of both the Soviet Union and the United States from personal experience, and wants nothing more than to share his insights with an American audience.
Although Mr. Pozner speaks New York English, his writing has a strong accent of the Popular Front circa 1936, when Communist Party members in the United States were intent on proving that they were 200 percent American. Here he is on ''the America that means so much to me'': ''Tom Paine and Thomas Jefferson and Abe Lincoln. And the great songs of America that celebrated John Henry, Joe Hill, Jesse James, Frankie and Johnnie, and hundreds of nameless others. And the people who sang them - Woody Guthrie, Leadbelly, Pete Seeger, Billy Holiday, Bessie Smith. And the Declaration of Independence and the Boston Tea Party.'' And Irish cops and a black maid and baseball. Fans of the letters of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg will enjoy this book.
Homage to the Popular Front also takes the form of adjusting facts to suit desires. He writes of the execution in 1927 of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, the case that brought a decade of liberals and radicals into the streets: ''Today we know they were framed; the state of Massachusetts has acknowledged their innocence.'' Although the admirable proclamation by Gov. Michael A. Dukakis in 1977 apologized for some aspects of the Sacco-Vanzetti trial, it made no acknowledgment of their innocence. Mr. Pozner also is taken with the idea that the murders of John F. Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr. were part of conspiracies.
The big difference between Mr. Pozner today and the Popular Frontniks of yesterday is that he criticizes Joseph Stalin. If he had done that within the hearing of the people who ran the progressive Greenwich Village school he attended as a boy, he would have been blackballed as a redbaiter. Times have changed, and Mr. Pozner has changed with them. He apologizes now for having supported the arrest and exiling of Andrei D. Sakharov in 1980. He has no kind words now for Leonid I. Brezhnev, under whose regime he built his career. However, he has nothing bad to say about Mikhail S. Gorbachev, now presiding.
Mr. Pozner does not claim to have been a premature anti-Stalinist, only a loyal citizen who (while not uttering anything that might get him into trouble) refused to speak what he did not believe. He is critical of those who left their motherland when he was trying to improve it from within. Defectors, he writes, ''became pawns in a political game and, as such, did far more harm to their country than good.'' Take that, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, Andrei Sinyavsky, Joseph Brodsky, Vladimir Voinovich.
The persistent theme of ''Parting With Illusions'' and the line that Mr. Pozner purveys on ''Nightline'' is how much the United States and the Soviet Union have in common: ''When people ask me, 'How do you know, how can you guarantee, that you won't have another Stalin?' I ask, in turn, 'How do you know, how can you guarantee, there won't be another Joe McCarthy in America? Or even a fascist dictatorship?' ''
Readers bowled over by that reasoning will also be impressed by the even-handed treatment of the K.G.B. and the C.I.A., the news that artists face similar problems under Communism and under capitalism and the analysis of the Berlin Wall: ''It solved the problem of economic drain, but it created a far greater and much more difficult problem, both in terms of how it affected Germans on the inside of that wall and the kind of ammunition it provided for anticommunist ideologues all over the world. Extremism at its worst.''
Mr. Pozner is annoyed that some in the West ''have branded me a propagandist.'' He attributes that slander to malicious or mindless anti-Communism and hopes that when Americans come to see him ''as a normal, authentic, honest person, an honest Soviet,'' they will begin to question America's military spending, the cold war and anti-Communism. He asks: ''How many Americans have ever met - let alone know well - a single communist?'' Tell it to the Romanians, Comrade.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vladimir Pozner, right, and Phil Donahue on a 1989 television show in Pittsburgh. (Associated Press)

PUB-DATE: March 4, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1763 words

HEADLINE: THE POST-MODERN IN NOW

BYLINE: By WENDY STEINER; Wendy Steiner is the author of ''Pictures of Romance: Form Against Context in Painting and Literature'' and the forthcoming volume on fiction since 1970 in ''The Cambridge History of American Literature.''

 BODY:

COSMOPOLIS
The Hidden Agenda of Modernity.
By Stephen Toulmin.
228 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.95.
 
THE LYOTARD READER
By Jean-Fran,cois Lyotard.
Edited by Andrew Benjamin.
Illustrated. 425 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Basil Blackwell. Cloth, $49.95. Paper, $16.95.
It is hard to imagine two more different manifestations of post-modernism than Stephen Toulmin's ''Cosmopolis'' and the Jean-Francois Lyotard ''Reader.'' The analytic philosopher turned historian of ideas and the nouveau philosophe both examine the shift away from modernism. But whereas Mr. Lyotard explores ''the great narrative of the decline of great narratives'' through eloquent delvings and sightings, Mr. Toulmin, like a professorial Cecil B. De Mille, telescopes the past 400 years of intellectual history into a whopper of a story. 
''Cosmopolis'' is a popularization. Without proper footnotes, quotations or detailed research, it risks everything on its argument, and that argument, coming from such a respected scholar, is surprisingly naive. Mr. Toulmin, the Avalon Foundation Professor in the Humanities at Northwestern University, tilts at what he terms the ''standard account,'' which fixes the origin of modernity in the 17th century with Descartes and Galileo. His radical counterclaim is that modernity begins with the Renaissance. Those of us who have always assumed that the Renaissance and the advent of modernity were synonymous - that is, most humanists above the freshman level - will be surprised to find that it is not the triumph of the European vernaculars, the revival of classical learning, the rise of centralized monarchies or the instituting of such devices of realism as the perspective established by Leon Battista Alberti that characterizes Renaissance modernism. Mr. Toulmin instead finds in the Renaissance a political moderation and a relaxed acceptance of diversity, indeterminacy and difference of opinion. His chief exhibits are Montaigne, who wrote with equal passion about digestive noises, sex and God, and Henry of Navarre (King Henry IV of France), who advocated religious tolerance and was assassinated by an extremist for his trouble.
Though the persecution of Roman Catholics and Protestants in England during the supposedly tolerant 16th century escapes Mr. Toulmin's contextualist scrutiny, he is at pains to describe the importance of Henry's murder. He compares this symbolic defeat of moderation to John F. Kennedy's assassination. The young Descartes - who may have written a sonnet celebrating the deposit of Henry's heart in the college of La Fleche, but then again may not have done - must have been haunted by disorder, Mr. Toulmin opines, for he set out to eradicate skepticism and discover a secure foundation for knowledge. He and his contemporaries responded to economic and political insecurity by elaborating a universally valid, unchanging, logically based system for the human and natural worlds - a cosmopolis - whose secret agenda was the legitimizing of an aristocratic, paternalistic political system. In this way, true modernity was suppressed for over 300 years.
By 1910, the Enlightenment, the novel, Darwin, Freud and Einstein had prepared the way for a return to tolerance and indeterminacy. But the stubborn nation-states had one last hurrah. Pitching the world into war, they reactivated the rationalist terror of disorder. Philosophy and the arts responded with a formalism that outdid even the 17th century, Mr. Toulmin claims, and it was not until the 1960's that the relativism of the Renaissance returned. This constitutes what people now call post-modernity. We are thus living out the original meaning of modernity as nationalism, sexism, formalism and environmental insensitivity fade into the rationalist past.
There is a certain loony eclat in claiming that 20th-century modernism is a conservative regression. But the degree of counterintuitive thinking required to sustain Mr. Toulmin's story finally sinks it. To see the esthetic experiments of Surrealism, Constructivism, Abstractionism, Joycean syncretism, minimalism and so on as attempts to prop up a Cartesian quest for order and stability is perverse. The aim of this art was just the opposite: to create a cognitive vertigo, to overturn the time-honored hierarchies and orthodoxies of religion, convention and nationalism. The popular outrage at the avant-garde indicates just how disruptive it was seen to be. Though the shift from formalism to multiplicity and amplitude is a fair (if overly general) characterization of the passage from modernism to post-modernism, both periods have affinities with 16th-century humanism and 17th-century rationalism.
Finally, ''Cosmopolis'' is simply (or complexly) wrong. Its ''standard account'' of modernity is a straw man, and the claim that the 16th century comfortably tolerated diversity whereas the 17th century did not is unfounded. If Mr. Toulmin can cite John Donne's ''No man is an island'' to prove the 17th century's dismay at the breakdown of social cohesion, one can quite as easily point to the Renaissance horror at Richard III's ''I am I,'' an atomistic view echoed by most of Shakespeare's villains. And when Mr. Toulmin says that ''gender-discrimination (or sexism) became constitutive of the new [17th-century] state,'' he loses our confidence entirely, since sexism, like so many of the conservative ''developments'' he locates in the Cartesian moment, is characteristic of the Renaissance, and of the medieval and ancient worlds before it. Instead of a fairy-tale modernity imprisoned in a tower of reason for 350 years, we might accept the less dramatic view that a gradual dismantling of the medieval religious cosmopolis has been going on since the Renaissance and that its 20th-century state of decay has occasioned both disorientation and heady release.
Mr. Lyotard, a French philosopher who is now teaching at the University of California, Irvine, tells a more complicated and fragmented story. His essays range over Kant and Hegel, Freud, modern painting, cinema, feminism and the concept of the outsider. He writes at times like a Surrealist fantasist or a Heideggerian hairsplitter, a Derridean jokester or a Platonic dialogist. Reading his essays is like leaping into a mental maelstrom. And yet, with enough of these immersions, the vortex reveals wonderful currents of connection.
In ''The Tensor'' (1974), Mr. Lyotard distances himself from what Mr. Toulmin would consider a revival of 17th-century foundationalism, telling semioticians: ''You've remained rationalists . . . Westerners.'' But what would a nonrationalist philosophy be? Mr. Lyotard looks to the Freudian ''dream-work,'' which he describes as the interference of the figural, the visual, in language. The Jewish prohibition against graven images signals the unlawfulness of vision and desire. In this merging of philosophy, painting and Judaism, Mr. Lyotard provides a stirring glimpse of what a new philosophy might be.
These associations resurface in an excerpt from ''Le Mur du Pacifique'' (1979). There Mr. Lyotard begins with a painting, a nightmare of America as a castrater of blacks and a controller of women. This image is teased out to explore the meaning of the meteque - the outsider, in particular the Frenchman Jean-Francois Lyotard visiting at the University of California, San Diego. ''Associate Professor, don't think you come to facilitate criticism. . . . All your authors, all your assemblages of words, only reinforce this boundary, this frontier zone. . . . Come, rather, to lose your culture, to de-culture yourselves. . . . But now consider this: the centre itself is the true nomad.'' Full of intensity, wryness and paradox, ''Le Mur du Pacifique'' raises travel writing to a primary post-modern mode.
The outsider-scholar learns much from women. He says that the women's movement ''solicits and destroys the (masculine) belief in meta-statements independent of ordinary statements,'' and this derision is crucial in developing a philosophy of judgment rather than truth. In order to escape from the indeterminacy of the classical paradoxes (''I am lying'' is true if it is false and false if it is true), the philosopher of positive knowledge has been forced to distinguish between language about language and words in a speaker's concrete situation. The sphere of meta-statement is disembodied, formal, untouched by ethics. Mr. Lyotard wants to entail the speaker and the audience in the utterance, and so looks not to philosophical discourse but narration. ''We want a politics based upon narratives, which are social elements,'' he writes in ''Lessons in Paganism,'' ''and not upon knowledge, where the viri [males] are in their element.'' In an elegant exposition of the logic of the French philosopher Emmanuel Levinas, he concludes that ''the simplest prescription, instructively empty but pragmatically affirmative, at one stroke situates the one to whom it is addressed outside the universe of knowledge.'' It is this outsider sphere, beyond logical certainty but rooted in the concrete immediacy of speech, that Mr. Lyotard wishes philosophy to inhabit.
But this is art's habitat as well. Indeed, he contrasts the modernist Duchamp (with his ''Large Glass'' pointing to the future and his ''Etant Donnes'' to the past) with the post-modern Barnett Newman, painter of ''The Sublime Is Now.'' For Mr. Lyotard, the now ''is what dismantles consciousness, what deposes consciousness, it is what consciousness cannot formulate, and even what consciousness forgets in order to constitute itself. What we do not manage to formulate is that something happens.'' This fact is the basis for the theories of the sublime of Edmund Burke and Kant, for ''the sublime is kindled by the threat of nothing further happening.'' The avant-garde, which Mr. Lyotard traces from the sublime, tries to express the now of happening, ''to present the fact that there is an unpresentable.''
If Mr. Lyotard is sometimes too eager to equate post-modernism with the avant-garde - Gertrude Stein is his touchstone rather than the likes of Toni Morrison - he is unfailingly provocative. With his Poe-like titles (''Anamnesis of the Visible, or Candour'') and his deeply ethical sensibility, he creates a common ground between Gothic passion and intellectual responsibility. Dauntingly learned and intelligent, he turns philosophy toward the acts of address and obligation. And if our understanding sometimes threatens to sink into his maelstrom, this danger is itself sublime.

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:

THE SURPRISE OF BURNING, by Michael Doane. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A war photographer and his mother, an aspiring singer with a heroin problem, find that both are instinctively drawn to history's great disasters. Michael Doane ''throws together pivotal events and archetypal characters from our nation's history to create a dazzling Jasper Johns-like construction,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times in 1988. ''This is a fine and powerful novel, a testament to this young writer's rich and maturing talents.''
 
SECOND CHANCES: Men, Women, and Children a Decade After Divorce, by Judith S. Wallerstein and Sandra Blakeslee. (Ticknor & Fields, $9.95.) After spending 15 years observing the remnants of 60 families split by divorce, the psychologist Judith S. Wallerstein found that feelings of trauma and betrayal were far more persistent than many people like to imagine. For want of a control group the study is ''merely adequate'' as social science, Carol Tavris said here last year. ''But as a work of clinical observation, the book is a beautiful piece of writing, full of insights that will prove indispensable to people contemplating divorce as a necessary evil, idealizing divorce as a cure-all for their woes, or living in its muddy aftermath.'' 
 
LOVE LIFE: Stories, by Bobbie Ann Mason. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Bobbie Ann Mason writes about modern country people who like to shop at K Mart and get their wisdom from the Phil Donahue show. ''Ms. Mason dips her pen in the same ink, over and over, because her knowledge of the landlocked Middle America she writes about - most of it centered in Kentucky and Tennessee - is endless and huge,'' Lorrie Moore said here last year. ''Each small story adds to the reader's apprehension of that hugeness.''
 
IN MY OWN FASHION, by Oleg Cassini. (Pocket Books, $5.95.) The playboy fashion designer who created the ''Jackie look'' recalls his romantic life. ''Lovers, conventional and otherwise, adorn the pages of his elegant and gossipy memoir,'' Molly Haskell said here in 1987. ''If his 370 pages of delicate indiscretions are not up to Casanova's morbidly fascinating 12 volumes, it may be the closest we'll ever get in an era short on stylish lovers.''
 
THE CAGE KEEPER AND OTHER STORIES, by Andre Dubus 3d. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) In one of these stories a father takes his stepchildren on a camping trip, then spends the whole time drunk. While the effects are sometimes strained, the author ''shares with his writer father a talent for delineating the everyday pathos of obscure, unglamorous lives,'' Deborah Solomon said here last year.
 
JOHN CHEEVER: A Biography, by Scott Donaldson. (Delta, $14.95.) When this biography was published in 1988, our reviewer, Lorrie Moore, said Scott Donaldson had gathered John Cheever's life ''into a kind of mad English garden of data through which lovers of Cheever's fiction may not be able to resist a stroll.''
 
LEILA: Further in the Life and Destinies of Darcy Dancer, Gentleman, by J. P. Donleavy. (Atlantic Monthly, $9.95.) In a series of sordid misadventures, J. P. Donleavy's seedy squire, Darcy Dancer, consorts with the lower classes, including the beautiful Leila, a housemaid at his crumbling Irish manor. ''Randiness is everywhere,'' Julian Moynahan said here in 1983. ''Not only does the quality make improper advances to the help and the help to each other but even animals get into the act or come close.'' The novel is a sequel to THE DESTINIES OF DARCY DANCER, GENTLEMAN ($9.95), also reissued by Atlantic Monthly.
 
SPARROWS POINT: Making Steel - The Rise and Ruin of American Industrial Might, by Mark Reutter. (Summit, $14.95.) A former reporter for The Baltimore Sun tells how the largest steel works in the world was set on the path to ruin when Bethlehem Steel decided to forgo modernization in favor of more familiar, obsolete technology. '' 'Sparrows Point' is an important reminder that adolescent experiences and bureaucratic careers can play as important a role in great business decisions as meticulous comparison of returns on investment,'' Charles F. Sabel said here last year.
 
THE ECONOMICS OF CHAOS: On Revitalizing the American Economy, by Eliot Janeway. (Truman Talley/Dutton, $12.95.) Among this economist's more offbeat recommendations is that the Treasury Department invest Social Security and other Government trust funds so aggressively that people in the underground economy will line up to pay their taxes and get a piece of the action. Last year our reviewer, Jeffrey E. Garten, said he found most of the suggestions unworkable but called the book ''a colorfully irreverent and passionate essay.''
 
REDWALL, by Brian Jacques. (Avon, $4.50.) In the abbey of Redwall, an ancient order of peace-loving mice is threatened by an army led by a one-eyed rat. This tale is ''artfully structured to rivet the attention of young readers and listeners,'' Selma Lanes said here in 1987. ''Mr. Jacques has woven an energetic, if somewhat simple-minded, fantasy on a refreshingly old-fashioned subject: the struggle between good and evil.''
 
MOSCOW STATION: How the KGB Penetrated the American Embassy, by Ronald Kessler. (Pocket Books, $4.95.) A journalist argues that the 1987 spy scandal at the American Embassy in Moscow was a more serious matter than the public has been led to believe. Last year our reviewer, David Wise, said Ronald Kessler sometimes stretches his evidence to accommodate his theories, but ''when he sticks to unearthing facts that the Government would rather suppress, Mr. Kessler is a first-rate ferret and an industrious interviewer.''

HEADLINE: THE HIDDEN LIFE OF NEW ENGLAND

BYLINE: By CARL N. DEGLER; Carl N. Degler teaches history at Stanford University. His most recent book is ''At Odds; Women and the Family from the Revolution to the Present.''

 BODY:

A MIDWIFE'S TALE
The Life of Martha Ballard,
Based on Her Diary, 1785-1812.
By Laurel Thatcher Ulrich.
Illustrated. 444 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.
The historian Charles A. Beard liked to distinguish between history and written history - the latter being that which appeared in history books, the former that which had actually happened. Martha Ballard's life will never enter the histories that tell the story of the United States or even those of Maine, where she spent most of her life. But her life, as Laurel Ulrich, a professor of history at the University of New Hampshire in Durham, has reconstructed it, opens an enlightening window onto those ''Hidden Ones,'' as Cotton Mather once called the pious women of New England. 
Martha Ballard spent most of her life in Hallowell, a town just below Augusta on the Kennebec River. For 27 of those years she kept a diary, the entries of which were so elliptical, even incoherent, that until Mrs. Ulrich came along, no one had found much use for the document. Each chapter begins with excerpts from the original diary, and what, after all, can one make out of entries like: ''At My Sons to see John who we were aprehensive was near the Close of life?'' Then the next day: ''At my sons. Tarried again this night.'' To decipher the entry it helps to know that Martha Ballard was not only a mother but a midwife, indeed the deliverer of two-thirds of the babies in the region, despite the presence of other midwives and two male physicians. Only with the additional and careful collating of entries in the diary and scores of other contemporary documents does the story come out - that John was an illegitimate child, fathered, fully acknowledged and financially supported by a leading judge of the town, who was already married, and that John's mother was closely related to Martha's son. That revelation gives Mrs. Ulrich the opportunity to place the event in the broader history of seductions, illegitimate births and the fates of unmarried mothers.
The hard life the midwife led, traveling through storm, snow and freezing cold, clambering up icy river banks to oversee as many as 50 births a year, was hardly typical for women of the time. Yet, thanks to Mrs. Ulrich's imaginative talent, Martha Ballard's diary becomes a major source through which we can vicariously experience the rural life of early New England and reimagine the character of men's and women's economic and family existence. We can also gain fresh and valuable information about the practice of midwifery, infant and maternal mortality, the life cycle of family work and folk medicine. The book even contains an appendix listing every plant medicine mentioned in the diary.
Typical of the hidden quality of women's lives in written history is that nowhere during her lifetime does Martha's name appear in town records except as Mrs. Ballard; even her minister misremembered her name as Dorothy. Only her obituary contained her true Christian name. And as Mrs. Ulrich suggests, that personal oblivion may be why Martha felt compelled to keep her careful record, on the front of which appears in bold print: ''Martha Ballard Her Diary.'' Yet this woman, unsung until now, oversaw the births of the babies of the ruling families as well as those of lowly lumbermen; even the baby of the local male doctor's sister was brought into the world by her hands. And for good reason: Martha's skill was such that the rate of maternal deaths during her career was considerably lower than that achieved in the United States as a whole as late as 1930.
The energy expended by this strong yet supportive woman can be gauged by her frequent travels and endless work. She went from house to house, sometimes delivering two or more babies within a 24-hour period in the dead of winter at homes miles apart with no sleep in between. She also toiled endlessly, what with combing flax, which she also grew herself; ceaseless weaving, cooking, gardening, visiting with other women; and providing meals and beds for visitors connected with her husband's surveying business. In a single year she housed 69 overnight guests and provided 95 meals to people not of her own family. Significantly, only six of the overnight visitors were women.
Fatiguing as Martha Ballard's activities sound - and the above list is abbreviated - they are not the heart of Mrs. Ulrich's book. That is in the picture of a community in action over time that Mrs. Ulrich creatively teases out of those elliptical entries. The women, as one might expect, led a life separate from that of the men, but they did not stay at home as Victorian women did. Late 18th-century women were ''gadders,'' as Mrs. Ulrich calls them, working in other women's houses, visiting much and comforting much.
As a working wife Martha Ballard traveled greater distances from home than most good wives, and she collected fees (and usually promptly) as they did not. But like other women, she also moved about, trading and bartering to vary her household larder, to obtain materials for her weaving and seeds and plants for her garden. Doing their work together in their homes made it possible for women to help each other and also to socialize. Husbands and wives, on the other hand, rarely went out together, though both, along with their children, were close partners in the family economy.
The home really began not with marriage, which was almost a non-event, but when the couple ''went to housekeeping,'' which might not be for a month or more after the prescribed and modest civil ceremony. Romance seemed to play less of a part in marriage than sex, inasmuch as 38 percent of the 814 birthings Martha Ballard attended were the result of extramarital conception. At one birth, the unmarried mother ''declard my Son Jonathan was the father of the child,'' Martha duly wrote in her diary. The law, after all, required that midwives obtain that information from an unmarried woman in labor, since the court needed it to save the town from having to support the bastard. (Son Jonathan did not marry the mother of his child until four months later.) Thus men too appear in the story, and in a variety of ways, for Mrs. Ulrich draws upon documents produced by men as well as women. And men's lives could be as demanding as Martha's. Ephraim, Martha's husband, at the age of 70 spent 59 days of a single year living in the woods while surveying. Yet what men wrote about often left a quite different picture of town affairs, politics and the economy than appear in Martha Ballard's often misspelled and oblique entries. Only a grandson named DeLafayette suggests that the country's recently achieved independence affected her family's consciousness, though politics and the new Constitution figure prominently in the contemporary writings of a fellow townsman, Henry Sewall. When a local court dismissed a charge of rape against a fellow member of the gentry, Sewall accepted it casually. Martha Ballard's diary notes a rare expression of shock.
Violence was also generally masculine, as when Martha's husband was set upon while working in the woods and robbed of his surveying instruments by squatters disguised as Indians, desperate to keep the landowners away. Among the men, class was sharply defined around property or social status, but the women among themselves slipped around such barriers. Male violence usually hurt women, directly or indirectly, as when a well-off farmer, James Purrington, killed his wife and six children by slitting their throats and then his own, or when Charles Gill killed himself, leaving behind nine children and a wife without any property. ''Mrs Gills Tryal is all most insupportable,'' Martha wrote. Henry Sewall, looking at Gill not yet dead, ''was astonished at his composure - or rather stupidity - which continued to the last. He died about 1 o'clock, without manifesting any signs of repentence.''
Historians will, of course, read this story with a deep appreciation of the professional skills that have made an obscure source accessible, engaging and valuable; nonprofessional readers will be even more appreciative in watching with delight and not a little wonder as a truly talented historian, before their eyes, unravels out of those hard knots of recorded fact the fascinating life of a community that in its complexity is at once so foreign, and yet so similar, to our own. Laurel Thatcher Ulrich wears her learning lightly and her prose sings.

HEADLINE: THE HEAT IS ON

BYLINE: ROBERT KANIGEL; Robert Kanigel, the author of ''Apprentice to Genius: The Making of a Scientific Dynasty,'' is working on a biography of the Indian mathematical prodigy Srinivasa Ramanujan.

 BODY:

FIRE & ICE
The Greenhouse Effect,
Ozone Depletion, and Nuclear Winter.
By David E. Fisher.
232 pp. New York:
Harper & Row. $19.95.
 
THE NEXT ONE HUNDRED YEARS
Shaping the Fate of Our Living Earth.
By Jonathan Weiner.
312 pp. New York:
Bantam Books. $19.95. 
In 1981, a team of British researchers at a frigid, wind-swept base in the Antarctic noticed a drop in stratospheric concentrations of ozone, a variant of ordinary oxygen that helps shield our planet from harmful ultraviolet rays. This was no slight, subtle falloff but a plunge. Couldn't be, the British at first thought. Maybe their instruments were off. After all, their findings flatly contradicted those reported by an American Nimbus satellite in orbit since 1978.
The British, it turned out, were right, Nimbus wrong. By 1984, the concentration of ozone had dropped by 30 percent. There was an enormous, steadily growing ozone hole at the South Pole.
Since the Nimbus scientists were looking for only a small slip in the standard ozone readings, they had programmed their computers to disregard as spurious departures from the norm of more than a few percent. In effect, they blinded themselves to the ozone hole, leaving to the British, down on the ground, the dubious pleasure of discovering it.
This story can be read as a lesson in scientific fallibility: when it comes to the complex scientific issues besetting the planet, you'd best believe no one. Yet within the large context offered by David E. Fisher in ''Fire & Ice'' and Jonathan Weiner in ''The Next One Hundred Years,'' the story can be seen to argue for quite a different conclusion. If, as both authors abundantly show, planetary science is so tricky, so excruciatingly dependent on the assumptions made in fashioning computer models, so riven with controversy, what does it mean when the scientific community does reach something like consensus?
Such consensus, Mr. Fisher and Mr. Weiner assure us, exists: the greenhouse effect is real. The globe is warming. Humanity's hold upon the planet is threatened.
In the greenhouse effect, methane, water vapor and particularly carbon dioxide collect in the atmosphere, forming a layer of insulation around the earth. If that layer thickens on account of the burning of fossil fuels and other factors, the earth holds on to more of the sun's heat. Result? A global warming.
How much warming can we expect? Here consensus breaks down. With decisive political action and good luck, the temperature rise may be limited to, say, three degrees Fahrenheit - triple that of the heat waves of the 1980's - bringing with it mild climatic changes to which we could adjust without too much bother. But it's just as likely, many scientists feel, that there will be a rise of 10, 15 or 20 degrees - enough to melt the polar ice caps, raise sea levels, inundate low-lying lands from Bangladesh to New York, appreciably alter climate and cause economic and political chaos as the hungry and thirsty billions struggle to survive the disruption.
Mr. Weiner and Mr. Fisher cover remarkably similar ground in their books. Both tell us how the greenhouse effect comes about; how it was first revealed through one scientist's methodical tracking of carbon dioxide levels; how clearing the Amazon rain forests contributes to it; why it is so difficult to predict accurately how much warming there will be, when it will begin and how fast it will happen; and how chlorofluorocarbons - like spray-can propellants and the Freon used in air conditioners - chew up the ozone layer.
Mr. Fisher, a professor at the University of Miami and the author of ''Race on the Edge of Time'' and ''The Birth of the Earth,'' widens his focus enough to include the worldwide nuclear winter, which would likely follow any large-scale exchange of nuclear warheads. In this scenario, soot and smoke from a hundred ravaged cities would form an atmospheric blanket over the earth, chilling it and possibly extinguishing much of its life.
Mr. Weiner, the author of ''Planet Earth,'' is the more leisurely of the two authors, more confident he's got your attention, more overtly literary. Some of his metaphors are unforgettable. As a way of showing that the stratosphere, unlike the lower atmosphere, doesn't easily rid itself of pollutants, he writes, ''It is like an eye without tears.''
To illustrate how the greenhouse effect implies not just a warming of the atmosphere but a chilling higher up, he explains that if you wear a flimsy shirt in a snowstorm, snowflakes landing on it melt. But if you wear several heavy sweaters, snowflakes alighting on the outermost one, now insulated from the heat of your body, stay frozen. ''Earth,'' writes Mr. Weiner, ''is swinging through the chill of outer space, and the atmosphere is its only clothing. Adding greenhouse gases to the air is like pulling on more and more layers of wool.''
Mr. Fisher's talent is noisier, but no less effective in capturing the reader. Conversational, gently rambling, he is not above taking off on a startling digression to flesh out an idea. ''Living in this world,'' he writes, ''is something like watching an Alfred Hitchcock film: just when you think you've got the ending figured out, he - and nature - hit you with another shock. Remember Psycho?'' But ''in this case, the knife-wielding nut turns out to be a bacterium hiding from the air,'' which dwells in some termites, feasts on felled trees from the Amazon rain forest and churns out methane, a greenhouse gas.
At another point, Mr. Fisher, borrowing a metaphor from the physicist Richard Feynman, compares the difficulty of understanding the planet to discovering the rules of chess by observing moves made in some small corner of the board.
Mercifully, neither author succumbs to despair in writing about such a bleak subject. Both believe that humans can act sensibly and creatively to forestall their doom. Amsterdam, after all, lives under water, the North Sea held back by dikes. The oil shock of the early 1970's galvanized America into producing, and buying, fuel-efficient cars that have slowed the buildup of carbon dioxide. And in 1988, most nations of the world agreed to cut the use of ozone-eating chlorofluorocarbons by half within the next decade. The authors believe that similar actions, accelerated by the urgency of the crisis, could moderate the warming to come, and they offer their own laundry list of environmental prescriptions.
Little of this is new; we have been living with global warming, the ozone hole and the prospect of a nuclear winter for some time now. They have become part of our public vocabulary. Indeed, that is just the problem both writers confront: their readers have been subject to so much in the way of journalistic pyrotechnics surrounding these issues, to such a tide of seemingly contradictory headlines, that no one knows what to believe anymore. Both authors struggle against the numbing effect of such confusion.
And both succeed, with passion and credibility. You cannot read either of them and conclude anything but that, if the nations of the world fail to act, or fail to act soon enough, it will be not just our distant progeny who take the heat but our own children.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 4, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1118 words

HEADLINE: CAN ECONOMICS BE MADE EASY?

BYLINE: By ROBERT M. SOLOW; Robert M. Solow, who won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1987, teaches at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

 BODY:

THE POWER OF THE FINANCIAL PRESS
Journalism and Economic Opinion in Britain and America.
By Wayne Parsons.
266 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.:
Rutgers University Press. $24.95.
Take any potentially significant piece of economic policy, like President Bush's proposal to reduce the rate at which capital gains are taxed. What questions would a reasonable citizen or a reasonable senator want to ask before deciding whether to favor or oppose the legislation? And where could they hope to find the answers? 
A rational decision would have to rest on (a) an estimate of the pattern of losses and gains to the Treasury in the years after the tax reduction takes effect and (b) some notion of the characteristics (young, old, married, single, rich, poor) of those who would gain a lot or lose a lot from the change. In addition, since the stated purpose of the tax reduction is to stimulate investment in plant and equipment as well as research and development, and to encourage the start-up of innovative new firms, one would want to know (c) how effective the proposal would be in achieving these goals.
Providing answers to such questions is exactly the stuff of academic research papers and Ph.D. theses. I do not mean the word ''academic'' literally. The staff of the Brookings Institution, say, does exactly the same sort of work. So do many economists employed by the Federal Reserve Board, the Congressional Budget Office and some other Government agencies. I mean to emphasize that this sort of work is done by, and read by, professional economists.
Since they are communicating almost entirely with one another, it is efficient for research workers to use the shorthand jargon of technical economics and statistics. It also has to be said that different researchers, using different methods and different bodies of data, will sometimes come up with contradictory results, especially if the effects being measured are fairly small. That is hardly surprising: the same is true of research aimed at measuring the health effects of diets containing various amounts of oat bran.
This professional writing is not much use to the reasonable citizen or the reasonable senator, who will find the jargon impenetrable and will have no basis for judging the relevance or utility of alternative approaches. One might expect that a body of interpretive economic journalism would fill the gap and mediate between policy-oriented research and policy-interested citizens. There is indeed some of that. Given the importance of the issues, however, the inescapable conclusion is that there is not nearly enough serious economic journalism, and the average quality is pretty poor.
The senator can sometimes hold hearings and listen to the testimony of academic economists who may, repeat may, try to communicate the results of their research. I have to record the impression that even these exercises are usually unsatisfactory, though there have been exceptions.
''The Power of the Financial Press'' by Wayne Parsons, who teaches -government, not economics - at the University of London, is about the evolution of economic and financial journalism in Britain and America, but it does not offer any cogent explanation of the unsatisfactory state of affairs I have been describing. He does not even focus on the problem of the translation of academic research into civil discourse, perhaps because he does not even see that there is such a problem. When he mentions the body of academic research, it is usually to dismiss it for having retreated into self-indulgent and irrelevant mathematical technicality. I think there is some justice in that charge. But Mr. Parsons does not seem to realize either that there remains a body of academic research aimed at exactly the questions that must be answered if economic policy is to have a rational basis, or that without some analytical complexity it may be impossible to avoid destructive oversimplification.
Some of the issues treated, even superficially, by the author may provide clues to the failure of communication I think I see. He points out, for example, that serious but nonacademic discussion of economics in England has been dominated by a group of important journalists - Andrew Shonfield, Samuel Brittan, Michael Shanks, Barbara Ward, Peter Jay, among others - who have no real counterparts in the United States, at least none who have been able to write at such length. In contrast, popular discussion of economics in America has been dominated by a handful of leading academics, of whom Milton Friedman, John Kenneth Galbraith and Paul Samuelson have been the most prominent. (I think this observation is essentially right, though Mr. Parsons overlooks the role of Thomas Balogh and Nicholas Kaldor in Britain.) My own guess is that the explanation for this difference has something to do with the capacities of the respective audiences. It is noteworthy that the vehicle for the American academic is usually the newspaper Op-Ed piece or Newsweek column of 900 words or less, whereas the British journalists, even when they are writing in the Sunday papers, are able to go on for much longer. The American unwillingness to attend to more than a sound bite is destructive of both economic intelligence and political discourse.
Mr. Parsons notes, correctly, that economic and financial journalism has been connected historically with the dissemination of price and market information. Those who are interested enough to read one will generally want to read the other. I am not sure that anything follows from this connection. Mr. Parsons seems to think that the expansion of electronic media has some deep responsibility for the fact that the 10-second commentary on the television news on today's economic events is more likely to come from a brokerage house employee than from either a serious journalist or an academic. But it is probably no more than a matter of convenient availability. Anyway, since the content of what is said is negligible, it hardly matters who says it.
Good interpretive economic journalism has to be able to distinguish between serious research and pseudo-economics. Serious economics needs a bridge to the world of policy discussion because the people who do the research either cannot or will not build the bridge themselves. Schlock economics is all bridge. It is not certain that Mr. Parsons is clear about the distinction himself. His chapter on the selling of Reaganomics takes too seriously writers who are neither doers nor purveyors of hard research. The editorial page of The Wall Street Journal is as much part of the problem as it is part of the solution. Maybe we get the economic journalism we deserve.
