PUB-DATE: March 4, 1990

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 3549 words

HEADLINE: Battling for Tenants in a Slow Market

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
A TWO-YEAR building surge in West Midtown has demonstrated the power of public incentives to direct the path of commercial development. The big question now is how to market a spate of new offices when the New York City economy has sunk into the doldrums.
Nearly 9 million square feet of new office space, roughly the equivalent of the twin towers of the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan, have been brought to the West Midtown market in a building boom that began early in 1988. Less than half the space has been leased.
Now, with construction nearly complete, developers are under intense financial pressure because of the high costs of carrying huge blocks of vacant space. As months pass without tenants, say real estate experts, financing charges, advertising fees, security and other expenses are mounting into millions of dollars on the buildings that are slow to rent. 
As a result, developers, leasing agents and brokers are battling it out in the toughest competition for corporate office users in recent New York City history.
The construction has taken place around Times Square, north into the theater district and elsewhere in what was traditionally considered a declining, low- rent neighbor to East Midtown, the nation's busiest and most expensive office district. A dozen new office buildings were either completed over the last year or are scheduled to be complete by mid-1990.
In each case, developers received property tax exemptions and were allowed to put up larger buildings than would normally be approved in a program conceived by City Hall to shift midtown development from east to west.
Neither the city nor the developers anticipated the rapid erosion of the city's economy that began when the stock market collapsed in October 1987, just as the foundations were being laid for most of the new office towers. Corporate expansion has slowed to a standstill, tenants have vacated several older midtown buildings and the competition for new tenants is growing more intense by the day.
BUT while no one could have predicted the full extent of the economic downturn, some real estate experts say the developers, contending with two- to three-year construction schedules, should have employed more sophisticated market research to gauge what type of tenants would be in need of space, and what kind of space they would want, even in tough economic times.
''If we were talking about Colgate making a new toothpaste, they would have been to four Midwestern cities to see if it sells,'' said Maurice Solomon, manager of the midtown office of Julien J. Studley, one of the commercial brokerage firms scouring the city to find corporate tenants for the new space. The firms themselves are being aggressively courted by nervous developers.
''New York City developers don't want market research,'' he added. ''Their job is to create product, and they build.'' Among those immersed in the West Midtown office market are the following:
* Larry Feldman, a developer and partner in Feldman Equities, who has leased out more than half the space at Tower 45, a 40-story steel-and-glass tower on 45th Street between Seventh Avenue and Avenue of the Americas but still has over 150,000 square feet uncommitted. To find tenants, he has promoted the building by hosting cocktail receptions at brokers' offices, producing marketing videotapes and sending out over 1,000 miniature trees - symbolizing the rows of mature red cedars that have been set into a wall above the building's atrium -to brokers across the city.
* William Butler, a senior vice president in the midtown office of Cushman & Wakefield, one of a dozen large concerns that dominate the New York City commercial brokerage industry, who is looking for tenants ready to relocate thousands of employees to huge blocks of new space. ''There are at least a half dozen big prospects looming,'' he said. Rumors, so far unfounded, have been circulating for a year that several large-scale corporate moves are imminent.
* Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, spent two years combing the West Midtown market. It announced in January that it would bypass the new crop of buildings and move 2,000 employees into 10 floors of 1301 Avenue of the Americas, the former J. C. Penney Building between 52d and 53d Streets. ''We got a better deal,'' said Frank Scalia, the firm's chief financial officer.
* The Integrity Life Insurance Company looked at 15 buildings, including most of the new office towers in West Midtown, before signing a 20-year lease in January at one of them, the 35-story 1325 Avenue of the Americas. Despite its address, the building has no direct access to Avenue of the Americas, but sits west of the Hilton Hotel, with entrances on 53d and 54th Street.
Integrity, which will move 115 employees to its new offices by June, said it was disappointed by the uniform design of the other new buildings it inspected. ''These things came off a Xerox machine,'' said Franklin Maisano, the company's chief executive officer. ''It seems as though everybody sat down at the same time and said, 'Let's go build a Lego office building.' ''
To be sure, experts say, even if economic conditions were robust, a wave of newly constructed offices as large as the one coming on the market in West Midtown would take many months - perhaps as much as two years - to fully lease out. And some of the buildings have quickly attracted tenants.
One of these is 1675 Broadway, a 35-story tower at 52nd Street, which was completed by Rudin Management in September and is more than 85 percent leased. ''I'm not saying we know all the answers, but when you are constantly in the market, you develop a sense of where it is going,'' said William Rudin, vice president of the company, a family-owned development concern that has built 14 Manhattan office buildings.
The building's largest tenants are Lord Day & Lord Barrett Smith, a law firm; D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, an advertising company, and Entertainment Weekly, the new Time Warner magazine.
AMONG other buildings in which office space has leased swiftly is Worldwide Plaza, a huge complex of offices, condominiums and shops that takes up a full block bounded by Eighth and Ninth Avenues and 49th and 50th Streets. The office building in the complex, completed in December 1988 by the Zeckendorf Organization, is more than 90 percent leased.
At Cityspire, a slim, 73-story tower of rental offices and apartment condominiums at 156 West 56th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, over 80 percent of the commercial space has leased since the building opened late in 1987.
And 114 West 47th Street, a 26-story building completed in July by the Durst Organization, is over 70 percent leased, with the U.S. Trust Company taking all of its lower 16 floors.
But for now, several other buildings in the current wave of West Midtown construction are begging for tenants in a sluggish economy that is attracting few new companies to New York, inspiring little expansion among companies that are already in the city and leaving a huge amounts of office space vacant, even at older, less costly buildings.
''We have moved through three or four very different economic climates since these new buildings were planned,'' said John Halpern, a New York City developer and former president of Hartz Mountain Industries, a large development firm in New York and New Jersey. ''The ship was launched and there is no turning back'' he added. In one analysis of the West Midtown market, Cushman & Wakefield put the vacancy rate for office space at 15.9 percent in January and 16 percent in December. The rates are unusually high for Manhattan, where overall vacancies, although climbing steadily since late 1987, had been running below 10 percent during most of the 80's.
Experts say some increase in vacancy levels was all but inevitable, even if the city's economy had not faltered, because public incentives prompted so much new construction in West Midtown. The main incentive, a zoning bonus that allowed developers to put up buildings with 20 percent greater height or density that would otherwise be allowed, was first offered in 1982 and expired in May 1988, creating a deadline for foundations to be laid and a construction surge over the last two years.
Another incentive, still available in West Midtown, is a seven year property-tax exemption that enables developers to offer lower initial rents. Both city initiatives are targeted for buildings in a area extending north from 34th Street to 58th Street, and west from a jagged boundary the bisects the blocks between Seventh Avenue and Avenue of the Americas.
Because of the incentives offered, and because the developers who took advantage of them did so at time when the city economy was flourishing, some experts say 20-20 hindsight is now a luxury that serves little purpose.
''If there was more market research, would behavior have been different?'' asked Hugh Kelly, a consultant with Landauer Associates, which does financial analysis for developers. ''I suspect not,'' he said. ''Each developer would have convinced himself that he had some advantage in location, building design or other amenities.''
Nor do many economists or real estate experts expect the West Midtown offices to remain a hard sell indefinitely. Mr. Kelly's firm, in a forecast it has distributed to clients, is predicting that demand for Manhattan offices will remain sluggish for more than another year and then pick up sharply between 1992 and 1994.
It said several factors would contribute to the turnaround, including the relaxation of economic barriers in Europe, which should bring more international business to New York City, and an upturn in both the national economy and business on Wall Street if economic cycles that have traditionally been charted for both remain consistent in the 1990's.
For now, however, developers and their agents in West Midtown are in a bruising competition.
Several are concentrating their efforts on attracting large anchor tenants from a list of candidates that have either publicly acknowledged or been widely rumored to be in the market for new headquarters or large divisional office.
One is Chemical Bank, which has said it would either negotiate a new lease at its current headquarters, 277 Park Avenue, between 47th and 48th Streets, or seek a new Manhattan address.
Among its options, the bank said, was splitting up its offices between a headquarters that would employ up to 700 people, and a back-office and computer center that might be moved outside Manhattan, and would employ up to 3,000 workers.
A BANK spokesman, Ken Herz, said Chemical has been considering some of the new West Midtown buildings, but declined to elaborate on the status of negotiations.
Others believed to be in the West Midtown market are the News America Corporation, the publishing concern owned by Rupert Murdoch, and the Sony Corporation, which is reported to be looking for a new North American headquarters. Brokers say privately that both have been inspecting some of the new crop of buildings, but have yet to make their intentions known.
At Worldwide Plaza, the large mixed-use project facing Eighth Avenue, large blocks of space were taken by Cravath, Swaine & Moore, the law firm, and Ogilvy & Mather and NW Ayer, advertising agencies. In an unusual approach, the Zeckendorf Organization, developer of the complex, negotiated deals with the tenants in which they are taking partial equity in the building, and persuaded them to sign their leases before the office space was completed.
Indeed, some experts say that one of the lessons being reinforced by the current office surplus in West Midtown is that more tenant commitments should be secured before construction begins.
''It is always more comfortable to have a preleased tenant,'' said David Lawrence, senior vice president of Gerald Hines Interests, a development firm that has only begun work on a 40-story office tower that is scheduled for completion in 1992 over the post office at Lexington Avenue and 45th Street, just north of Grand Central Terminal.
The developer has already signed on an anchor tenant, Davis Polk & Wardwell, one of the city's biggest law firms, which will take half the 900,000 square feet of offices in the building.
Among those without pre-arranged leases, many strategies are being employed. Mr. Butler at Cushman & Wakefield said many of the developers are giving generous incentives to prospective tenants by offering to pay for the design and finishing of their offices. These work-letters - industry parlance for a developer's commitment to create interior office spaces at his own expense - are typically now costing the developers $50 per square foot of office space, much more than in the past.
Rental rates in the new buildings are also creating an incentive to some tenants whose alternatives would be buildings east of Grand Central Terminal, along Park Avenue or in the East 50's, areas that have traditionally carried the most cachet for those seeking midtown offices.
The asking rents vary, but brokers said a typical rate in the new West Midtown offices is slightly under $35 a square foot. They said developers have not reduced their asking rents, but tried to attract tenants by offering other temporary incentives that include the generous work letters and months of free rent during the initial phase of a new lease.
In contrast, most modern, well-located buildings in East Midtown have been fetching $37 to $45 per square foot of office space.
But even with the incentives offered to West Midtown tenants, the developers and their brokers are finding themselves engaged in a campaign of telephone canvassing, knocking on corporate doors and street-level promotion rarely seen before in the Manhattan office market.
''This is a very strange market to be trying to sell into,'' said Arthur H. Lerner, senior vice president of Helmsley Spear, a large brokerage that is in charge of the marketing at 1325 Avenue of Americas, the building between 53d and 54th Streets that signed on Integrity Life Insurance as one of its first tenants.
The building, developed by a partnership of Edward J. Minskoff, a Manhattan developer, and the Taubman Company, a large builder of shopping centers, offices and other properties, is in the final stages of construction. Although more than two-thirds of its space remains to be leased, it has so far been more successful in attracting tenants than some of the other new buildings.
MR. MINSKOFF said he had designed the building, which has an interior lobby covered in marble and floors designed to accommodate large conference rooms and corner offices, for high-level corporate operations, and did not intend it to be used for computerized back offices. His marketing approach, he said, was therefore intended to be conservative and dignified.
Unlike the approaches used by some other developers, he said he designed slick videotapes, had cocktail receptions and used other aggressive marketing strategies. Last summer, when the building was still far from complete, a hard-bound marketing brochure, containing photographs of what some interior spaces would look like, was produced from architects' renderings and scale-model simulation, and distributed among brokers and potential tenants.
Few potential tentants were invited to visit the building until recent months, as its elevator banks began operating and its floors, still raw and unfurnished, neared completion.
''PEOPLE can look at videos and brochures all day, but what they really want to see is the building itself,'' said Mr. Lerner. Mr. Minskoff, meanwhile, said he would be ''just fine'' if it took two years to fully lease the building, but he added, while declining to elaborate, that a large tenant was in the final phases of negotiations for a lease that would almost fill the building within months.
At Tower 45, Mr. Feldman has been taken an even more aggressive marketing posture. ''We have sent out the dog-and-pony show,'' he said. ''We want to plant the seeds of good will and interest in this building.''
The approach, he said, has largely been focused on persuading Manhattan's huge brokerage industry to turn its attention to selling the building. Beginning at the end of 1987, while it was little more than a hole in the ground, videotapes were made of elevator banks and other interior details that were similar to those planned in Tower 45.
Mr. Feldman said he compiled a list of over 2,000 brokers in New York City, and sent them all copies of the tape. A print advertising campaign was launched in publications read by brokers, including Real Estate Weekly and Crain's New York Business.
Then came the cocktail receptions, in which Mr. Feldman said he hired a bartender and visited several brokerage offices. His miniature trees went out to the brokers in early 1988.
The campaign has produced several successes. The building signed its biggest tenant, the Equitable Life Assurance Society, which took the four lowest floors nine months before it was completed in April 1989. Among the other tenants, with smaller blocks of space, are the Kelwood Company, a textile manufacturer, NEC, the Japanese electronics firm, and several small law firms.
''Up to this moment, the strategy has been to market to the industry as intensively as we can, and it seems to be working,'' Mr. Feldman said.
 
THE COURTING OF CHEMICAL BANK
AMONG large corporate tenants, none is being purused more aggressively than Chemical Bank, which for more than a year has been in the market for a million square feet of office space, enough for nearly 4,000 workers it now has in three Manhattan buildings.
Developers in West Midtown, elsewhere in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and New Jersey are in the competition. So, too, is City Hall, where Mayor David N. Dinkins has met privately on the matter with Walter V. Shipley, Chemical's chairman, according to sources at the Mayor's office and in the bank.
The high-level arm twisting may have set the stage for something similar to the 1988 campaign to persuade Chase Manhattan to move its back-office operations and 5,000 workers to the Metrotech office complex in downtown Brooklyn. Chase received many city incentives, including tax abatements and energy subsidies estimated to be worth $235 million.
Chemical declined to disclose details of its negotiations, but said it plans either to renegotiate a lease at its current headquarters, 277 Park Avenue, between 47th and 48th Streets, or move. Its lease in the Park Avenue building, where it occupies 750,000 square feet of space, will expire in July 1994.
Ken Herz, a Chemical spokesman, said the bank will keep its top headquarters staff in Manhattan. Although that might mean also keeping all the headquarters personnel in Manhattan, he added that one option is to retain as few as 600 senior executives in a smaller amount of Manhattan space than the bank now occupies, and move up to 3,000 computer operators and other support workers to one of the other New York City boroughs or New Jersey.
Indeed, the bank said it has a nonbinding option for an undeveloped building site in the Meadowlands area of New Jersey that would accommodate a major back-office installation, as well as similar nonbinding options on other undeveloped parcels at sites it declined to identify in New York City.
Mr. Herz said the bank would consider all options and announce its decision by the end of the year.
Chemical had planned to be the anchor tenant in one of the huge new office buildings at the corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue that are planned by New York State, George Klein, a developer, and the Prudential Insurance Company of America as part of the mammoth Times Square redevelopment project. But a year ago, with the long-delayed project mired in a fresh round of litigation, the bank withdrew, saying it could not be sure the office tower would be built in time to meet its needs.
Since then, real estate executives say the bank has been pursued by developers and has looked at more than a dozen buildings that are under construction or recently completed, including some of the new crop in West Midtown.
ONE site the bank is known to have considered is the northwest corner of 42d Street and Avenue of the Americas, now blighted by derelict buildings, where Douglas Durst, a principal in the Durst Organization,, has been trying to assemble a major building site.
Mr. Durst has been negotiating to acquire the last piece of land necessary to complete the site from the New York Land Company, another development concern. He said last week that negotiations with New York Land were continuing, but declined comment on whether Chemical was on his list of prospective tenants if he is able to build on the site.
At City Hall, meanwhile, Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, has met several times with senior Chemical executives to promote New York City sites.
One option being pressed by the city is for Chemical to keep a small headquarters operation in Manhattan, and move the bulk of its back-office personnel to downtown Brooklyn or Queens. - THOMAS J. LUECK

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 4, 1990

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1, Column 5; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1122 words

HEADLINE: 'Disappointing' Inauguration For Condo Plan

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
STATE officials in Hartford last week began sifting through the responses to an innovative program intended to increase the supply of housing for low- and moderate-income families in Connecticut through the purchase of condominiums. And across Fairfield and Litchfield Counties, housing officials began assessing why so many of their towns were being left out.
Calling the response to the program of grants and mortgages to help nonprofit groups exploit a glut of condominiums ''very disappointing,'' State Housing Commissioner John F. Papandrea announced an internal review to see what had gone wrong with his project, especially in Fairfield County.
''It just happened,'' said John Madeo, the executive director of Fairfield 2,000 Homes Corporation, a countywide nonprofit housing group that negotiated unsuccessfully with condominium developers in several suburban communities in Fairfield County, trying to get them to sell to the state. 
The program's start in December drew nationwide attention to Connecticut's Department of Housing. With a glutted condominium market that had pushed prices down and driven more than a few developers into bankruptcy, housing officials reasoned that lots of homes could be purchased with state bond money for less than the cost of construction.
Bids were solicited, with a goal of spreading the purchases around the state. Officials said they hoped the program would introduce some integration of income levels into areas that have become increasing composed of the rich and the elderly.
But when the Feb. 23 deadline passed for nonprofit groups and developers to apply, officials found that the program had bypassed a wide band of towns where even a solid middle-class wage cannot cover housing costs.
Although 50 applications had been filed for a total of 929 apartments, they were heavily concentrated in a few large cities, with a sprinkling in smaller towns and hardly anything in the high-priced towns of Fairfield and Litchfield. Mr. Madeo's group ended up filing only one application - for a 21-unit complex in Bridgeport. In Fairfield County, only Bridgeport and Danbury produced any large numbers, with a total between them of 141 apartments offered to the state for purchase. The rest of the county drew applications for 18 units. Only 17 apartments were offered for all of Litchfield County.
Developers and state and local officials said some of the reasons behind the disparity are already clear. Because the program allowed only seven weeks between the first announcement and the application deadline, a developer who wanted to participate had to act quickly to find a nonprofit group to co-sponsor the application and comply with other rules.
Those rules discouraged many owners, officials said, particularly the requirements that every apartment have a certificate of occupancy proving that the property is ready to live in, and that any apartment offered to the state would have to be removed from the market for 12 weeks or more while the state considered the purchase.
The officials said that Connecticut's wealthy suburban towns - unlike their larger neighbors like as Bridgeport and Waterbury, where the condominium glut is far worse - have just not suffered enough in the economic downturn to make the state's offer attractive.
''There wasn't enough pain,'' said Larry Zeigler, project manager for the Connecticut Housing Investment Fund, a nonprofit housing group that negotiatiated unsuccessfully with several Fairfield County owners.
Mr. Zeigler, whose group ended up filing three applications for a total of 15 apartments in Hartford, Windsor and Jewett City in the state's southeast corner, said he believed the state ''did a good job at trying to put together a very innovative program.''
But many developers he contacted said that even in a weak real estate market, three months of waiting for the gears of government to turn was simply too long, Mr. Zeigler said. Things might still turn up, and apartments might still be sold when spring marketing resumes, he said.
Local housing officials said that although higher prices in Fairfield and Litchfield were factors in keeping the number of applications down - especially since the state had said it would pay, on average, only about $100,000 for an apartment - the problem was not insurmountable.
 
Preliminary Agreements
In Greenwich, for example, the Housing Authority had reached preliminary agreements that would have brought 15 apartments into the program at prices ranging from $215,000 to $225,000 each, said the authority's acting executive director, Tom Crawford.
Of that price, Mr. Crawford said, $100,000 was to have been paid by the state, leaving the final occupant of the apartment responsible for a mortgage of $115,000 to $125,000, well within the limits set by another state agency, the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority, which provides mortgage assistance to middle-income first-time homeowners.
What killed both deals, Mr. Crawford said, was that the banks holding the properties, both of which were seized in loan foreclosures, were just not ready.
In Litchfield County, housing officials in Washington were able to overcome high land prices with a proposal that asks the state to spend about $60,000 in aid for for each of seven condominiums in a development called Quarry Ridge.
 
Look at the Process
The $60,000 would pay for the land under each apartment, said John Boyer, president of the Washington Community Housing Trust. The apartments would then be sold as ''improvements'' to the land, while the land itself would be placed in a land trust. The maneuver would lower the cost of the apartments to the final occupants to $135,000 to $155,000 each, Mr. Boyer said, compared to the units' original asking price of $280,000 each.
At the State Housing Department, Mr. Papandrea said that the whole application process would be re-evaluated over the next few weeks, to look for the points on which housing authorities in Fairfield and elsewhere may have stumbled. In particular, he said, the requirements for certificates of occupancy would be reconsidered, as well as the 12-week lag for a decision by the state. He said he hoped to see the pilot program expand to an ''ongoing effort.''
''We're learning,'' Mr. Papandrea said. ''We'll rewrite those areas that presented the problems.''
But some of those who came close to finding the right package but ultimately failed said they were not sure that things would get any easier.
If the condominiums' owners ''aren't able to move those units this spring, then there's certainly a potential opportunity,'' said Mr. Crawford in Greenwich. ''But right now, we just don't know where things will go.''

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Glasnost On the Island

BYLINE: By Arthur J. Kremer; Arthur J. Kremer, a former State Assemblyman, is a member of the executive board of the Association for a Better Long Island.

 BODY:
PEERING over the border for decades, each side has never hidden its mistrust of its neighbor. It is a relationship forged from years of suspicion and ruthless political competition.
Far from the Berlin wall, these neighbors straddle the Nassau-Suffolk line. It almost seems that the crumbling of the wall 10,000 miles away is the force that has compelled Nassau's Republican leadership and Suffolk's Democratic leadership to find common political ground. 
The announcement by Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta and Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin that they seek to create the Bicounty Peacetime Economic Adjustment Council is the first substantive indication that Long Island political leaders are maturing in their recognition that regional problems can only be addressed in a joint manner. Perhaps it took the historic events surrounding the collapse of the Soviet empire to put our own border disputes into perspective. Perhaps it was the recognition that the key economic component, our defense industry, may become obsolete due to the forces of perestroika and glasnost.
In addition to its mandate of keeping our best and brightest engineering talent on the Island, an equally important role would be the two-county council's efforts to shape our industrial policy in the 1990's. Today there is no one political body that can hope to confront the Island's economic shocks, which range from defense reductions to a hodgepodge of zoning policies. There needs to be an umbrella organization, free from the parochial political forces that have crippled our ability to find solutions.
To be effective, the council must force the two counties to cease their separate search for new companies, often robbing Peter to pay Paul. Instead, Nassau and Suffolk must join in a unified program of economic incentives that will make Long Island the best place to do business, as opposed to a particular county.
As New York City suffers under the pains of enormous municipal budget cuts and a deepening recession, we must be particularly sensitive to their aggressive economic incentives designed to bring business back into the neighboring boroughs. In addition, the new council should take a good hard look at the programs offered by neighboring New Jersey and Connecticut and see how we can make Long Island a more attractive place to open a new company or allow for the expansion of existing business.
If necessary, the two counties should jointly seek state legislation in Albany to expand local job producing programs. In 1978, as chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, I introduced legislation that would provide funds for precisely this purpose through the creation of the Long Island Job Development Authority, yet, to date, that resource has been untapped by Long Island.
However, an enormously exciting aspect of the council proposal is that the two county executives now recognize the critical importance of creating a working partnership of government and business to protect our regional economy. They are proposing a series of cooperative programs whereby government and business leaders hammer out plans to deal with defense layoffs, property and sales tax affects and lobbying in Washington in coordination with our Congressional delegation and the promotion of Long Island abroad.
These newly proposed actions are a far cry from the past history of using Long Island business community as convenient targets in election years or to play up to the not-in-my-backyard groups. It may also be a recognize that a hemorrhaging economy could irreparably fracture the political futures of some of the promising men and women in Nassau and Suffolk.
The new Realpolitik of Europe, Washington and New York will force Long Island to find new, innovative programs that balance the needs of our economy with the needs of our environment. The Berlin wall is a relic. The Communist Party is in tatters. McDonald's overlooks Gorky Park. And Tom Gulotta and Patrick Halpin now understand that deeds, not words, will rescue our economy, our tax base and our future.
Walls do crumble. Governments do collapse. And that immovable force of Long Island politics is beginning to respond to the reality of change. Could it be merely a coincidence that the new entity being proposed by the County Executives from opposing political parties in our bi-county region has the acronym Bipeace?

LENGTH: 1843 words

HEADLINE: Plan to Reduce Swordfish Catch Assailed

BYLINE: By States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY fishermen are normally a quiet bunch, but a plan to drastically reduce commercial swordfishing has made them enter the political fray.
The plan to reduce the United States swordfish catch by about 78 percent, proposed by the South Atlantic Marine Fishery Management Council, could put the state's long-line fishermen virtually out of business, they say. The long-liners pull in $10 million to $15 million worth of swordfish a year, up to 25 percent of the New Jersey fishing industry's $60 million annual profit.
''I don't think we're going to stay in our waters and survive - make the boat payments, the insurance payments, the gear payments,'' said James Welch, a New Jersey fish wholesaler who owns two long-line boats docked at Barnegat Light.
Unlike net fishermen, the long-liners cast out bundles of up to 1,000 fishing lines, each attached with hooks and bait, to catch swordfish, tuna, sharks and other billfish. 
Mr. Welch is one of more than 200 swordfishermen in New Jersey who have banded together to fight the swordfish restrictions, which could take effect as early as June.
Supporters of the reduction in the swordfish catch say a conservation measure is needed to save the species. They say there has been a decline in the population and average size of swordfish, evidence that the species is being overfished.
The fishermen have jammed public hearings (200 of them showed up at a meeting in Wall Township on Jan. 24), begun a membership drive for the New Jersey Commercial Fishermen's Association, lobbied members of Congress and formed an organization of their own, the Bluewater Fishermen's Association. Bluewater, which is the brainchild of Nelson Beideman, a Barnegat Light swordfisherman, and his wife, Terri, signed up 250 members nationwide during three weeks in December. About a third of the members are from New Jersey.
''They've been woken up,'' said John Hoey, government relations representative for the National Fisheries Institute in Washington, which helped Bluewater get off the ground.
Mr. Hoey said fishermen from the swordfish and tuna industry, which has grown tremendously in the last 10 years, have realized that they must speak out to survive. The New Jersey fishermen, most of whom are docked at Barnegat Light, have been particularly vocal, he said, since Barnegat is one of the top four swordfish and tuna ports in the country.
''I think it definitely represents an awakening, and a realization that they can no longer sit back and sort of ignore the management system,'' Mr. Hoey said. ''It's a frustrating thing to participate in, and certainly one of the reasons many fishermen are at sea is because they don't like to stay home and attend meetings.''
The shock that moved the fishermen into action, Mr. Hoey and other industry representatives said, was the announcement by the National Marine Fisheries Service last fall that it might impose emergency swordfish conservation measures in January. Federal official have since dropped the plan, citing the high cost of enforcing the regulations. But by then the South Atlantic Fishery Management Council's proposal also had the fishermen up in arms.
The council, an arm of the Federal Government, has proposed reducing the swordfish catch to 1.85 million pounds a year, about 78 percent less than the eight million to nine million pounds of swordfish that United States fishermen caught in 1989. The proposal allows fishermen to keep only ''bi-catch'' swordfish, which are caught while fishing for other species like tuna. The plan also prohibits fishermen from using light sticks to attract the fish at night and restricts them to six swordfish a trip.
Council officials said the measures were needed to prevent the fishery from shutting down entirely. The council estimates that the adult swordfish population declined by more than 60 percent from 1978 to 1987, while the number of fish being caught more than quadrupled. The average swordfish size has also declined, from 115 pounds in 1978 to 60 pounds in 1988, said Steven Berkeley, a council biologist.
''It tells you that the fishing mortality rate is very high,'' Mr. Berkeley said. ''It tells you that very few fish will reach adulthood, will reach spawning age, and it tells you that if you don't do something to reverse the situation, you will have a collapse of the fishery.''
The council, which is one of eight regional councils charged with establishing United States fishing regulations, expects to present its final swordfish plan March 27 and 28. The plan then goes to the Department of Commerce for approval. Lawmakers expect the Commerce Department to be receptive, given that officials at the National Marine Fisheries Service gave serious thought to emergency measures.
''The resource is being severely dropped to the point where if we don't do something drastic soon, the stock will not be able to replenish itself,'' said Richard Schaefer, director of the Office of Fisheries Conservation and Management at the National Marine Fisheries Service. ''And the longer we wait, the longer it may take the stock to recover.''
But long-line fishermen question the council's statistics, citing large numbers of swordfish and healthy catches. At 18 public hearings throughout the East Coast, held from Jan. 3 to Feb. 1, hundreds of fishermen spoke out against the plan, Mr. Berkeley said.
The restrictions would directly affect about 700 Atlantic long-line boats and about 3,500 fishermen. In New Jersey, the council's proposal would mean a net economic loss of $40 million a year, said Nils Stolpe, director of the New Jersey Commercial Fishermen's Association.
According to the National Marine Fisheries Service, 162 long-line boats are registered in New Jersey. Industry officials said about 25 percent of those boats primarily catch swordfish.
But Mr. Beideman warned that the state's $15 million tuna industry could be cut by 70 percent if the swordfish restrictions took effect. Tuna fishermen inevitably haul in swordfish and would have to stop fishing completely once they caught their swordfish limit.
In addition, the fishermen said, each long-line boat supports a series of related industries, from truck driving to distributing bait, fuel, tackle and ice, all of which would be jeopardized by the plan.
''I feel they have not explored the economic impact of their proposal,'' Mr. Welch said of the council. ''And as it is written, I think we would be pretty much devastated.''
Another of the fishermen's complaints is that the council's proposal would not affect the many foreign boats catching swordfish in the Atlantic. Mr. Hoey of the National Fisheries Institute estimates that United States fishermen are responsible for only 29 percent of the North Atlantic swordfish harvest.
Officials at the National Marine Fisheries Service put that figure at closer to 50 percent. But since swordfish are migratory, New Jersey fishermen said, it makes no sense to regulate only half the ocean.
''It's not really a management plan,'' Mr. Beideman of the Bluewater Fishermen's Association said. He added that the proposal did not address ''the drastic economic impact and consequences of shutting down the domestic fishery, and would provide very little - if any at all - conservation benefits.''
''Unilateral actions,'' he said, ''simply do not work with highly migratory species.''
Mr. Beideman questioned the council's data, which he said were ''tilted, slanted, massaged and assessed from every different angle.'' Since foreign fishermen would continue to catch swordfish in large numbers, he said, the council's proposal would fail to protect the fishery while putting American fishermen at a disadvantage.
''Why sacrifice the U.S. industries when we'll have to turn around and import fish products and export jobs?'' he said.
Some New Jersey lawmakers are wondering the same thing. Representatives Frank Pallone Jr., Democrat of Long Branch; William J. Hughes, Democrat of Ocean City, and H. James Saxton, Republican of Southampton, took steps to combat the stringent swordfish regulations in their rewriting of the Magnuson Fishery Conservation and Management Act, which governs Federal fishing laws.
 
Plan to Change Management
House members approved a two-year reauthorization of the act on Feb. 6, including a provision to take swordfish management out of the hands of the South Atlantic council and make it the joint responsibility of the five regional councils that have swordfishermen in their districts.
''In this case, I'm not sure the fishermen have gotten a fair shake,'' said Mr. Saxton, who sent an aide to a council meeting in December to make sure that the 50 New Jersey fishermen who attended would have their say. ''I don't think there was any intention of listening to them until we got involved.''
Mr. Saxton and his New Jersey colleagues also included a ''sense of Congress'' provision in the new Magnuson Act calling for broader industry representation on the fishery management councils. Fishermen say the councils are deaf to their concerns.
''Many of the fishermen do not feel that they have been represented on the councils,'' Mr. Hughes said, ''that the resource has not dwindled as much as has been suggested, that there is not sufficient research to establish that there is a need for draconian reductions in catch. And they feel in many instances that they are alien to the process.''
 
Need for Conservation
New Jersey fishermen said they recognized the need for conservation, but would prefer a more moderate plan that sets minimum size limits for the swordfish and closes off designated areas. Mr. Hoey of the National Fisheries Institute said industry representatives had not prepared a detailed proposal, but believed that conservation measures should be international.
The problem, conservationists said, is that international swordfishermen are resistant to change. Spanish officials said at a November meeting of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas, ''As for our country, if a choice has to be made between man and fish, it would first choose man.''
D. W. Bennett, executive director of the American Littoral Society, a coastal conservation group in Sandy Hook, said: ''It's an absolute fact that the swordfish is in trouble. And one of the main measures is that the size of swordfish landed keeps dropping. Which means that it's overfished. There's no question about it.''
Mr. Berkeley of the South Atlantic council admitted the plan would hurt fishermen. In a sense, he said, the long-liners are victims of their own success. Rising swordfish prices and rapid strides in fishing technology, from electronics to light sticks and more sophisticated tackle, have made long-lining increasingly profitable, popular and efficient.
''Some of the fishermen may have to go out of business,'' Mr. Berkeley said. ''The other side of the coin is that if they don't take action, the fishermen may put themselves out of business, and then the fishery may never recover.''

GRAPHIC: Photo; Fishermen contend that proposed limits on swordfish catch could ruin their business (NYT/Ray Fisk)

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 25, Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1862 words

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE

BYLINE: By Roland Foster Miller

 BODY:

 
Trafficking
The Boom and Bust of the Air America Cocaine Ring
 
By Berkeley Rice
Charles Scribner's Sons, 303 pages. $22.95.
Here is the story of several middle-class young men getting together to fulfill the American dream of accumulating wealth, prestige and happiness.
It is also the carefully researched story of the Air America cocaine ring that those men ran, which at the time of its breakup had brought nearly 10 tons of cocaine into the United States from Colombia.
As the Government prepared to take the case to a grand jury, Attorney General Edwin Meese proclaimed that the Air America ring was responsible for ''the largest documented amount of cocaine ever smuggled into this country by a single trafficking organization.'' 
Berkeley Rice, a former foreign correspondent for Newsweek and senior editor for Psychology Today, has written three other books, including ''The C-5A Scandal,'' about defense contracting.
In ''Trafficking'' we find that a Westchester resident and neighbor of Mr. Rice played a role in the case, which drew national press and television attention.
As Gordon Zubrod, the assistant attorney general who prosecuted the case put it: ''We've been arresting the pillars of the community all over the country.''
Forty-year-old Michael Phillippo was one of those pillars of the community. But he was also holding more than $3 million in drug money for an Air America friend in a secret hiding place behind a wine rack in his basement.
''He and his family lived a few blocks from my home in an affluent suburban neighborhood in North Tarrytown, in New York's Westchester County,'' Mr. Rice writes in ''Trafficking.'' ''Phillippo is a husky, likable, good-natured fellow, described by one friend as 'a great big teddy bear.' A graduate of Cornell's School of Hotel Administration, he was the manager of the Ardsley Country Club. When questioned by reporters after the arrest, club members vouched for his diligence and character.''
Mr. Rice, who said he and Mr. Phillippo were Little League coaches together, emphasized that his neighbor was really a small fry in the cocaine ring.
''I couldn't believe he was involved in something like a cocaine ring, because he seemed like such a nice guy,'' Mr. Rice said of his neighbor. ''When I learned about the rest of the ring, of which he was just a small part, they were all thought to be nice guys - educated, well respected, not criminals, not Mafiosi, not Colombians. They could be anyone's next-door neighbors.''Air America, a company in Scranton, Pa., that added extra fuel tanks and made other modifications to small planes to enable them to fly great distances nonstop. When Mr. Luytjes flew loads of cocaine into the United States, he reportedly earned $1 million a trip, and officials said he took a cut of the $1 million when he assigned other pilots to transport the drugs.
Mr. Rice said a very important key to completing his book was the Federal Government's release of a 600-page debriefing document from Mr. Luytjes.
''Rik is a wonderful storyteller,'' Mr. Rice said. ''He had an incredible memory. He told his entire story about Air America the way he would want it to be told, as a romantic adventure. I realized also that he was a compulsive liar. If not outright lying, he always colored things that made him look innocent or more romantic than he was. You see, I had heard those same stories from other members of the ring.''
''Trafficking'' has gone into a second printing and a third printing has been ordered. The book is a best seller in the Scranton area, where several figures in the Air America ring lived.
Mr. Rice lives in North Tarrytown with his wife, Annegret, an artist and real estate agent. They have two sons. ''She was not overjoyed with the subject,'' Mr. Rice said of his wife's reaction to his work on the book. ''I think she got tired of the dinner-table conversation about cocaine and drug smuggling. About dinnertime on Sundays, I would get collect calls from prisons.
''I joke about these guys looking upon this as an adventure, but it was sort of an adventure for me to just be involved in it.''
Mr. Rice said he wrote the book for people like himself, people who had read the papers and watched the evening news and heard about big cocaine busts.
''We don't connect them with us,'' he said. ''All those stories are about criminals, about evil people. All of us don't believe that those can be our neighbors.
''As my neighbor said - and I quoted him in the book - he was annoyed that all of his neighbors said, how could you have done this sort of thing? He said, 'Do you really think none of my neighbors would have been at least tempted if they had had the same opportunity? Of course they would say no quickly. Perhaps too quickly.' ''
 
The Trial Of Levi Weeks
Or the Manhattan Well Mystery
 
By Estelle Fox Kleiger
Academy Chicago Publishers. 224 pages. $18.95.
If the reader is interested in traveling nearly two centuries into the past and visiting the sights and sounds surrounding America's first recorded murder trial, then ''The Trial of Levi Weeks'' is the proper transportation.
The time is Dec. 22, 1799. The place is lower Manhattan, then the center of New York City. A 22-year-old woman, Gulielma Sands - known as Elma - leaves the home where she boards with the respectable Quaker family of a cousin. She has said privately that she is to be married this night to another boarder, Levi Weeks.
Elma Sands does not return, and her bruised body is found a week later in the depths of the Manhattan Well. Levi Weeks stands accused.
The Elma Sands case stirred the passions of the city's 60,000 residents. Here was a woman of good family found in a most horrible condition. As a witness at the well when her body was recovered testified:
''It looked like a person who had been walking against the wind - flush but not so much so as she appeared a few days after. Her appearance was horrid enough - her hat and cap off, her hair hanging all over her head, her comb was yet hanging in her hair, tied with a white ribbon; her shawl was off; her gown was torn open with great violence, and her shoes were off.''
The curious public went to the boardinghouse in such numbers that her body was taken to the porch for public display.
Levi Weeks, a carpenter, was the brother of Ezra Weeks, a builder who erected Alexander Hamilton's estate house, The Grange, which still stands on Convent Avenue in upper Manhattan. He also dealt with Aaron Burr and supplied wood for pipes for the Manhattan Company water system, which owned the well in which Elma Sands's body was found.
Hamilton, Burr and Brockholst Livingston represented Levi Weeks. The prosecutor was an assistant attorney general, Cadwallader David Colden, who 10 years after the Weeks trial would be Mayor of New York City and later yet a United States Representative. Four years after the trial, Burr would kill Hamilton in a duel in Weehawken, N.J.
This is the first book for Estelle Fox Kleiger, who has published articles in American History Illustrated. The 15-year resident of Scarsdale said she began collecting material for the volume many years ago, when she saw a reference to the case in a small exhibition at the New-York Historical Society in Manhattan.
''The Trial of Levi Weeks'' offers the full transcript of the first murder trial recorded in the United States, which was taken in shorthand by William Coleman, a clerk of the circuit court.
''I'm not greatly interested in crime, but I am interested in social history,'' Mrs. Kleiger said. ''I've found that sensational crime was a good way of finding the thinking of the time, the social mores and just about everything else.''
The defense team attacked the prosecution on two main points. One, that there had been no murder at all, that the young Sands woman had committed suicide. Two, that the defense had accounted for all but about a half-hour of Weeks's whereabouts that evening.
''I don't think that Elma could have made her way to the well alone,'' Mrs. Kleiger said. ''It was supposed to have been a terrible night. I don't think she could have found it. I think someone must have led her there.''
Murder, or no murder? Was Weeks found guilty, or not guilty? A partial answer lies in the book.
Mrs. Kleiger, who has two grown children, said she has begun collecting material on a murder that took place in 1836. ''This, too, was a very sensational one - a murder in a brothel,'' she said.
 
On an Average Day
By Tom Heymann
 
Fawcett Columbine. 228 pages. $6.95.
What is average? What happens in America on an average day? Well, Tom Heymann, who fashioned his first book ''On an Average Day'' out of his interest about statistics and demographics, lets the reader know, in an easy-to-digest form.
''I've always been a trivia buff,'' said Mr. Heymann, who lives in Chappaqua with his wife, Grace, an assistant grants officer for the Council for the Arts in Westchester. They have a son, Gabriel, 1 1/2 years old. Mr. Heymann employed statistics and demographics in his previous job as vice president for program development for Lorimar Home Video in California. ''I wanted to find a way to share that kind of information that would be acceptable and fun for the general population.'' ''On an Average Day'' has been plugged on the Arsenio Hall show ''Arsenio Hall used the book in his monologue one night,'' Mr. Heymann said. ''He was talking about the number of people who still call Elvis Presley [four call Graceland daily asking to speak to the King] and the number of people who use condoms [1,109,589 are sold; 443,836 to women]. Regis Philbin focused on economics - how many Americans begin work each morning for a Japanese company [214]. A lot of people are using it in groups and putting it into a game format and quizzing each other about it. I know of a teacher in New York City who is using the book to get students in the third to fifth grade turned on to numbers.'' The book does have an addictive quality to it. Some examples: ''On an average day American children watch three-and-a-half hours of telvision, during which time they will see, 5 beer and wine commercials, 33 acts of violence and 38 sexual references and innuendos''; ''On an average day, 1 American is injured by lightning, 35 are injured by fireworks, 68 are injured playing golf, 104 are injured while shaving, 153 are injured using chain saws, 189 are injured using lawn mowers, 307 are injured in the bathtub or shower.''
Mr. Heymann noted that his first writing outside of a business context would not be his last: ''It's becoming a series and the next book to come out - in the fall - will be 'On an Average Day in the Soviet Union.' ''
The author said he continues to act as a consultant on educational videos and audio cassettes but added that with his ''efforts in the book area, I've been doing less.''
''I'm enjoying writing,'' he said. ''It's a very solitary pursuit but you don't have to worry about office politics. At the same time, however, you don't have a lot of people to bounce ideas around with. You have to govern yourself.''

HEADLINE: Social Events

BYLINE: By Robert E. Tomasson

 BODY:

Dance for the Environment
March 6 - Since its founding in 1970, the National Resources Defense Council has been lobbying Federal, state and local governments on environmental and public health issues. The group's annual spring dance will be held at the Manhattan Opera Studios, 311 West 34th Street. Cocktails at 7 P.M. will be followed by dinner and dancing to two bands. Black tie. Tickets: $300; 212-727-2700.
 
Tips on Home Management
March 6 - The Duchess of Devonshire will be at Christie's in New York with the Duke to talk about the ancestral home and the joys and tribulations of maintaining a residence north of London with 175 rooms, including 21 kitchens, and 17 staircases. The talk on Chatsworth, one of England's great estates, will benefit the Courtauld Institute, a center for the study of art history at Somerset House in London. Cocktails at 6 P.M., lecture at 7 and dinner at 8. Tickets: $100 for lecture and cocktails, or $250 including dinner, or $10,000 including a reception in the spring at Somerset House with an opportunity to meet the Queen Mother; 212-546-1121. 
 
Auction and Cocktails
March 6 - God's Love We Deliver prepares and delivers more than 1,000 meals a week to the homes of AIDS patients. A benefit auction and cocktail party will be held at Sotheby's starting at 6 P.M. To be auctioned are trips to Kenya, the Virgin Islands and Monte Carlo and jewelry, art works and a ride in the Batmobile used in the movie ''Batman.'' Tickets: $100; 212-874-1193.
 
Briefly Noted:
March 6 - The fashion house Hermes is holding a cocktail party at its salon at 11 East 57th Street from 6:30 to 8:30 P.M. to benefit the Rain Forest Alliance and the New York Botanical Garden's Institute of Economic Botany. Tickets: $35; 212-575-0735.
March 7 - The Harlem School of the Arts will benefit from a cocktail reception at the Lincoln Center Library at 6 P.M. followed by a recital by Jessye Norman at Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets: $250; 212-926-4100.
March 7 - The American Dance Series at Sadler's Wells in London will benefit from a Royal Gala Dansant at the Puck Building, Lafayette and Houston Streets. Princess Margaret is expected to attend. The black-tie evening will start with cocktails at 7:30 P.M. Tickets: $350 or $200 for those 35 and under; 212-838-2660.
March 8 - The United Negro College Fund's 46th anniversary dinner, at the Sheraton Centre, will start with cocktails at 6 P.M. Whitney Houston will be a guest of honor and Bebe and Grace Winans and Take 6 will perform. Black tie. Tickets: $125 for alumni of any of the fund's 41 member colleges, $500 for others; 212-326-1221.
March 8 - A preview of what is termed the first major exhibition of the ancient sculpture and artifacts of the Cyclades Islands of the Aegean will be shown at the Merrin Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue at 57th Street. The cocktail party from 6 to 9 P.M. will benefit the Brooklyn Museum's department of Egyptian, classical and ancient Middle Eastern art. Tickets: $250; 212-757-2884.
March 8 - The New York City Opera will hold a benefit for the company with the opening night performance of its production of ''The Sound of Music'' at the New York State Theater. Dinner and a dance at the theater will follow the 6:30 P.M. performance. Black tie. Tickets: $300; 212-765-2550.

A champagne supper follows at the Citicorp Center. The benefit is sponsored by the Design Industries Foundation for AIDS. Tickets: $50, $75 or $150 for the show alone, $300 including dinner; 212-727-3100 or 212-496-7070.
March 8 - The experimental Creation Production Company, which combines art forms in its productions, is holding its annual benefit at 8 P.M. at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street near Varick Street, with the Akoshia String Quartet. A champagne reception follows. Tickets: $100; 212-228-8780.

Winter Ball at the Waldorf
March 9 - One of the mainstays of charitable work in the city for 89 years, the Junior League of the City of New York has 2,300 members who donate more than 120,000 hours of volunteer time annually to numerous programs. The league's annual Winter Ball is its main fund-raising event. The black-tie evening at the Waldorf-Astoria starts with cocktails at 7:30 P.M., with dinner at 9. The Bob Hardwick Orchestra will play from 9 P.M. to 1 A.M. in the grand ballroom and the Dynamic Upsetters will play from 9:30 P.M. to 1:30 A.M. in the Jade and Astor Rooms. Tickets: $135, or $65 for dancing alone; 212-288-6220. At the door, $75 for dancing alone.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Smith;
For a Fund-Raiser, Women Develop A Calendar of Men

DATELINE: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.

 BODY:
A new Smith College calendar portrays unusual representatives of a women's college - men.
The calendar, called ''The Men of Smith,'' mocks pinup calendars at the University of Southern California and elsewhere, which feature men with hairy chests wearing G-strings.
''The Men of Smith'' is not beefcake, its promoters say. Instead, it features professors and staff members. It is intended to show brain, not brawn, said Marie Macri, a senior art major from West Hartford, Conn., who came up with the idea for the calendar. 
Selling for $8 each, the calendars are intended to help pay the $2,000 in printing costs of Smith's annual humor magazine, the Porcupine Rag. Ms. Macri, one of the magazine's founders, said she had been concerned that students might consider the calendar sexist for excluding women, but she said their reactions have been positive.
''If it were sexist, we'd be portraying men as empty vessels,'' said Karen Libsch, a sophomore classics major from Salt Lake City.
Many students said they would not have wanted a beefcake calendar. ''Why should we insult men by putting them in bathing suits, showing their hairy chests, when we complain about women in bathing suits being plastered all over posters and calendars?'' said Gwen Lohse, a sophomore government major from Attleboro, Mass.
The staff members of the Porcupine Rag chose popular male faculty members and men from the security and service staffs for the calendar. Timothy Contant, a short-order cook at the student center, who is Mr. February in the calendar, said he was nervous about the venture. ''When you know your face is going to be spread all over campus, you begin to wonder how you're going to look,'' he said, adding, ''I was born in February, so I wanted that month.''
William Hurley, a security officer who was shown with a fellow officer, Robert Young, said he had no reservations. ''There are so many men on campus,'' he said, ''I was honored they picked me.'' Smith, which enrolls 2,700 women, employs 520 men and 898 women, a college spokeswoman said.
Stanley Lewis, an assistant professor of art, is shown in the calendar surrounded by his sculptures. Randall Bartlett, an economics professor, is shown holding his son, David, and reading from an economics book he wrote.
But not all models were humans. The male for March is a dog that the college president, Mary Maples Dunn, had owned. The dog, called Harpo Dunn, died in December. In an editor's note, Ms. Macri said she was not trying to equate men with dogs.
The only nude in the calendar is on the cover. It is a sculpture by Rodin.

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2, Page 52, Column 1; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 742 words

HEADLINE: A Stronger Profile For Culture Is Urged

BYLINE: By BARBARA GAMAREKIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
As the governors of the nation met here this week for the National Governors Conference, a dozen state cultural advisers gathered at the Library of Congress to engage in a little networking.
The mood was upbeat as the cultural representatives told of new political power coming from state legislators' recognition that an enhanced quality of life brings economic benefits to their districts and their states, not only in the form of tourism but also in business opportunities.
''Twenty-five years ago, state arts and humanities councils were just coming into being,'' said Sondra Myers, cultural adviser to Gov. Robert P. Casey, Democrat of Pennsylvania, who organized the meeting on Tuesday. ''But today, the breadth and depth of the cultural presence in government have grown tremendously, and I thought it important to develop a greater sense of solidarity and collegiality.'' 
The advisers met with James H. Billington, the Librarian of Congress, and Representative Mary Rose Oakar, Democrat of Ohio, who has introduced a bill calling for a cabinet-level office for the arts and humanities. Those attending discussed their programs and methods to attract the support of legislators for cultural projects.
Joining them were several national cultural leaders, including Milton Rhodes, president of the American Council on the Arts; Jonathan Katz, director of the National Assembly of State Arts Agencies, and John Hammer, of the National Humanities Alliance.
 
'An Attack on Creativity'
''This kind of a meeting bringing the arts and the humanities together is unusual,'' said Jamil Zainaldin, president of the Federation of State Humanities Councils, before the forum.
''Events of the past year with Mapplethorpe have made us aware that an attack on the arts is an attack on creativity, and we can't let the arts take that beating,'' he said about the furor last summer over an exhibition of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe and the ensuing Congressional effort to curtail governmental financing of artwork deemed obscene. ''The specter of Congressional regulation of creativity has helped to bring us together for some common conversation.''
Patric Dorsey, secretary of the Department of Cultural Resources of North Carolina, said: ''Industry looks very closely at the environment of a community before they decide to move into it. Now legislators are asking, 'What are you doing in my county; in my district?' ''
Ms. Myers said: ''I used to be ignored by the lowest staff person on a legislator's staff. These days, I don't know one legislator who doesn't have a theater they want to reclaim for restoration.''
 
On Securing Attention
Pat Clubb of the Texas Commission on the Arts said she discovered that doors were opened to her in the state legislature when the arts were linked to public policy and social issues. ''Most legislators think in terms of broader agendas than just the arts,'' she said. ''So you get their attention by talking about the drop-out rate and what kinds of arts education programs you can put into schools to alleviate dropouts, and you talk about rural arts programs, about minority participation.''
Joan Baldridge, director of the Department of Arkansas Heritage, said: ''We keep in constant contact with state legislators. We inform them of every program and how it helps them in their district. Giving that information to your state legislators is vital: it enables them to share in your success.''
The participants heartily endorsed Representative Oakar's proposal for the creation of a position called Secretary of the Arts and Humanities. She urged their support in lining up co-sponsors for the bill, which she introduced in January.
 
'Where Is Our Revolution?'
''There is nothing like having someone right in the room with you around that cabinet table when you are discussing national priorities,'' she said.
She mentioned that she had just returned from Eastern Europe. ''When we asked, 'What do you want from us?' their priorities amazed me,'' she said. ''They want cultural exchanges, artist exchanges, Peace Corps volunteers to teach English. I must confess, I was a little jealous. I had to ask myself: 'Where is our revolution? What are we doing in our quest for loftier things?' ''
Mr. Billington said: ''We are living in a world where increasingly we have to live by our wits rather than our strength. More and more people are playing the arts-and-humanities game.''

SECTION: Section 3; Page 23, Column 5; Financial Planning Guide: Your Taxes

LENGTH: 692 words

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
Saving to Retire? Tax Code Helps

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
RETIREMENT can be the time to enjoy the fruits of a life's labor, or it can be a time of penny-pinching uncertainty. To be sure it is the first, an understanding of the role tax laws play, both in saving for retirement and during retirement, is essential.
''We're doing a lot of pre-retirement planning, and probably the single most common comment is: 'I wish I had done it 20 years ago','' said George E. L. Barbee, executive director of Price Waterhouse Personal Finance Service, Waltham, Mass.
''Anyone contemplating retirement should ask himself or herself three key questions,'' Mr. Barbee continued. ''One, obviously, is: Can I afford to retire? Secondly, what do I have going for me now in financial terms? Thirdly, what should I do between now and then?'' The answers to these questions will vary greatly, depending large part on a person's age. 
Those who start well in advance can take advantaged of tax-deferred compounding to save for their retirements, for Congress has recognized the need to provide an incentive for retirement savings and has offered a powerful one by shielding money placed in qualified retirement plans from taxation until it is withdrawn.
Even so, Mr. Barbee noted, those under 40 years of age can find retirement savings difficult because they are focusing on raising children, their education, career plans and, increasingly, caring for parents unable to provide for their own health and financial needs.
For this group, the best investment can be the equity in primary or secondary homes, company pensions, health and other insurance, he said. But they should also take advantage of tax-sheltered retirement accounts, such as I.R.A.'s, company-sponsored 401(k) plans - particularly when an employer makes matching contributions - and Keogh plans for the self-employed, he added.
The 40- to 55-year-old group often finds itself in a much tougher position. They are tugged at both ends -meeting college costs and the needs of parents, as well as of rising health-care costs, so their own retirement plans may get short shrift.
One way out of this financial bind for those over age 55, Mr. Barbee suggested, may lie at home. Many parents continue to maintain larger homes than they need.
The parents can often pare living expenses and receive a one-time windfall to invest by selling those homes and buying smaller ones, for homeowners over 55 can escape Federal taxes on capital gains of up to $125,000 on the sale of a home.
The first step in retirement planning is to project cash income and living costs, which can be difficult.
Laura Shanley, tax partner in Ernst & Young, said, ''These projections are often overly optimistic because they are based on the belief that living expenses will decline after retirement. She cautioned that inflation has become one of the most important variables in planning ahead.
Mr. Barbee pointed out that at a 4 percent inflation rate, which is a bit less than the 4.6 percent the Government calculated for 1989, an expected $117,000 of future income would be reduced to $100,000 by 1993; $122,600 would be worth $60,500 in 2007; $142,000 would shrink in value to $42,100 in 2020.
Once a person reaches retirement age, or changes jobs and is vested in a pension plan, a crucial decision is how to take the money out. Withdrawals must begin by age 70 1/2.
''If you want the distribution of lump sum payouts to provide a stream of income throughout retirement,'' Mr. Barbee said, ''it is generally preferable to roll the funds into an I.R.A. The funds will not be initially reduced by taxes, and the portion not withdrawn will continue to earn interest deferred.''
Despite the political furor over how to fund Social Security, the system will continue to play a large role in the retirement plans of most people.
Andrew E. Zuckerman, senior manager of employee benefits and compensation at Grant Thornton in Washington, advised those planning to retire to consider carefully when to start receiving Social Security. For those under age 70 earnings can cause a loss of Social Security benefits, and other income can subject Social Security payments to taxation.

And Bear in Mind
 (Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest.)
DARM OBSESSION: A True Story of Incest and Justice, by Shelley Sessions with Peter Meyer. (Putnam, $21.95.) The finely detailed and thoroughly shocking narrative, both personal and social, of a Texas teen-ager who found all too little family or institutional support in trying to escape from an incestuous stepfather.
RED VICTORY, A History of the Russian Civil War, by W. Bruce Lincoln. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) Between 1919 and 1921 the Soviet state was created out of chaos by armed force, this timely and thorough account by a university historian reminds us.
DIVORCING THE DICTATOR: America's Bungled Affir With Noriega, by Frederick Kempe. (Putnam, $24.95.) OUR NAM IN PANAMA: How General Noriega Used the United States - and Made Millions in Drugs and Arms, by John Dinges. (Random House, $21.95.) Much in these two accounts by professional journalists (Mr. Kempe of the Wall Street Journal, Mr. Dinges of National Public Radio) has been known to our Government all along but kept secret. Both books are excellent guides through the undergrowth of America's affair with the Panamanian dictator.
THE FULL CATASTROPHE, by David Carkeet. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) With humor and insight, Mr. Carkeet's fourth novel addresses the commonest of social diseases - a failing marriage - with the least likely of therapies: a live-in linguist.
THE END OF LIEUTENANT BORUVKA, by Josef Skvorecky (Norton, $18.95.) Five stories, camouflaged as police thrillers, about a good man's melancholy trajectory through the corrupt and corrupting Prague of post-Dubcek, pre-Havel Czechoslovakia.

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Portland, Me.;
1866 Building Gets a Reprieve

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

 BODY:
SPURNED in its application for a permit to demolish the 124-year-old, downtown Tracy-Causer building, the Fineberg Group, a Wellesley, Mass., developer, has decided instead to restore the 1866 structure.
Preservationists say the decision shows the benefit of the city's demolition ordinance, which was passed in 1988 after a public outcry over the demolition of two other historic properties. The ordinance forces property owners to prove a building proposed for demolition has no economic value. 
''It shows how effectively an ordinance can work,'' said Deborah Andrews, executive director of Greater Portland Landmarks, a private nonprofit preservation group. ''Without the law on your side, you have a hard time saving old buildings.''
The three-story Greek Revival building was put up shortly after a fire in 1866 destroyed much of this city. It is historically significant because most of the buildings built after the fire were of the more popular Victorian style. It was done in the older style because the owner, John Tracy, a tinsmith, wanted it built quickly to house his business and a grocery.
''It is one of the few remaining examples of what commercial architecture looked like after the fire,'' said Martha Deprez, director of preservation services for Greater Portland Landmarks.
Restoration is to start in the spring, to a design by CSS Architects of Wakefield, Mass., with completion expected by fall, said John Sherman, project manager for the Fineberg Group. So far, a restaurant is the only tenant for the building, which will have 8,000 square feet of space, plus a two-story, 3,000-square-foot addition to the rear. It will occupy the basement and first floor and part of the second. The rest will be office space. Leasing rates have not been set.
Without disclosing figures, Mr. Sherman said it was going to cost more to renovate the building than it would have to raze it and start afresh.
''We are very fortunate that Portland withstood a lot of the urban renewal thrust of the 1960's,'' Ms. Andrews said. ''Neighborhoods are remarkably intact.''
For years, developers, buoyed by Federal tax credits, seemed more interested in restoring buildings than in tearing them down, but this changed when the tax credits were removed in 1986. Last week the City Council passed an ordinance requiring city review of any remodeling or additions to historic properties.
''At long last, the city has been convinced that it must take the lead in preserving public buildings,'' Ms. Andrews said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tracy-Causer building, 124 years old, will be restored instead of demolished in Portland, Me. (The New York Times/Gary Guisinger)
