LENGTH: 1455 words

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY Q & A: BILL MATHESIUS;
Favoring the Legalization of Illicit Drugs

BYLINE: By JEFFREY HOFF

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
BILL MATHESIUS, the Mercer County Executive since 1980, is the most prominent elected official in New Jersey to support publicly the legalization of drugs like marijuana, cocaine and heroin. He is a former Mercer Prosecutor and an assistant United States attorney.
A Republican, Mr. Mathesius has been speaking before Chambers of Commerce and other groups about drug abuse. He says he hopes his statements will initiate a broader debate on the issue in the state.
His first public mention of legalizing drugs came in his October 1988 State of the County Message. By his 1989 State of the County Message, he had solidified his own position, and he spoke strongly in support of legalizing drugs. When he was Mercer County Prosecutor from 1973 to 1975, Mr. Mathesius said, he was opposed to legalization of heroin and cocaine. 
Mr. Mathesius, a law graduate of Seton Hall University, lives in Hopewell Township with his wife, Michelle.
Q. Why legalize drugs?
A. Legalization is an imprecise term that means different things to different people. To the parents of a 14-year-old who may believe their kid will suddenly have access to drugs, that is not what I mean.
I speak in terms of controlled access and controlled distribution. The simple reason I am for something other than what we are doing is that what we are doing now does not work. We are kidding ourselves and the public to suggest that you can lock everybody up. We don't have the money. We don't have the jail cells and we don't have the capacity to ruin generations of minorities, which is what is happening.
Q. Do you find there is any ability to stop the use of drugs on the streets?
A. I say without any equivocation we can't stop it. We can't stop it the way we are trying to stop it and with the system that we have.
Q. What do you see as the failure of law enforcement?
A. The criminal-justice system has become so overburdened with delays it costs approximately $2,000 per arrest. You don't have an economical system. You don't have a system that is dispensing justice. It has no reliability, and it is now being overburdened by a fantastic influx of drug cases.
It costs $100,000 to build a jail cell. If I was going to take all the money available from the Federal ''war on drugs,'' you could absorb $7 billion in New Jersey to build the capital facilities needed and you still would have to operate them and then have the rest of the country to worry about.
In Mercer County I have a prosecutor who wants another $500,000 in his budget. I had an uprising in the jail, where most of them are small-time druggies, and we are not proving anything by putting them in a box.
Q. Are you saying we are treating people unfairly? Instead of building jails, we should be offering other solutions?
A. Absolutely. It's much more of a medical problem than a criminal-justice problem. It's got to be oriented to rescuing people rather than disposing them in jails.
What happens in jails? The best that happens in jail is you are in a holding pattern for months or years of your life, and you get out no worse than you went in. The actual fact is you will tend to come out more sophisticated and more hopeless than you went in.
Q. What do we know about who is in jail?
A. Eighty percent are in for simple possession. So you are talking about a lot of chumps in jail. You can argue all you want about the moral issues about permitting a person to abuse himself with drugs, with alcohol, with nicotine. As far as I am concerned, what people want to do to themselves is a secondary issue. When they start hurting other people, then I get upset. And that is what jails should be for. To protect other people. Not to protect a person against themself.
Q. There are people who feel that is the point. That we need to keep people off the streets so they don't hurt other people. That is what jails are for.
A. The reason they have to go to jail is that they can't get the drugs that they want. So they rip people off. They mug, they sell, they use, and if they were provided access to drugs, perhaps they would not have to mug as many old people or stick up as many bars or burglarize houses.
Q. How do you envision providing access to drugs? Do you see marijuana, cocaine and heroin being available the way bourbon is or the way methadone is or the way Valium is?
A. You have to start from a broad substance-abuse policy that is consistent. That would include more controls on alcohol, more control on cigarettes, on all the panorama of drugs.
Q. You see that as part of a package?
A. Yes, that is part of the whole picture. Increased control on substances which people use and abuse. Then you have to gradate those substances. You have to determine the severity of the implications of their use.
When I was Prosecutor in Mercer County, I functionally decriminalized marijuana in Mercer County. I told my investigators we were not prosecuting people who were using marijuana and leaving other people alone. We had Princeton University, which at that time probably could have put to sleep the entire community with the use of marijuana, with no damage done.
Other drugs I am open to suggestion, to experimentation of how you dispense them. Perhaps with a doctor's certification, similar to the way you dispense drugs per se.
Q. How does legalization work in terms of policy, say in Mercer County, if one were no longer arrested for possession of heroin, cocaine, crack? Perhaps you would be saving money?
A. If you assume there are 10,000 people who could be locked up today in the City of Trenton, that is 10,000 people are violating drug laws, and you multiply that by the $100,000 it costs per jail cell, that is $1 billion. Be conservative and say 5,000 people; that is $500 million that could be used primarily for education.
The Head Start program happens to be the best anti-drug program going. The conditioning, the imprinting upon young people, is the best anti-drug program. Take the money we are throwing away in prison and redirect it toward education, toward rehabilitation, toward drug treatment, as opposed to incarceration. So if the 9-year-old addict shows up, you might be able to help him.
Q. How do you respond to the national drug policy director, William J. Bennett, who believes drug education does not work?
A. I have found many of the so-called drug czar's statements so bizarre that I welcome them because they fall on their face as illogical. People can see they are wrong.
Q. How do you as a County Executive begin to look toward a program within your own budget?
A. How I do it is I am not going crazy building jails. I am not going to fund a prosecutor $500,000 more so he can hire four more prosecutors, six more investigators, so he can do more investigation of drugs. For him to convict more people does not prove a thing, and we would not be getting at the root. We would be dealing with a symptom.
Q. How do you respond to those people who say perhaps we cannot stop it, but it is ethically, perhaps morally, wrong for society to say this is O.K.? Are you saying this is O.K.?
A. I am saying it is a moral question on which reasonable people disagree. If people are not hurting other people, if people are making considered choices of their own.
Q. But you would be in favor of increased restrictions on cigarettes and alcohol? You give two messages there.
A. No. No. The increased restrictions relate entirely to the effect on people and how they operate under whatever it is they are abusing. If a person wants to sit in a corner of his house and smoke marijuana until his ears catch on fire, God bless him. I am not going to make a moral judgment for him.
Q. But while you accept the right of individuals to do what they want, you are also in favor of programs in schools telling children this is not a healthy way of life.
A. Absolutely. You are making a clear message similar to the message that has resulted in the decrease in smoking. And we tell them if you are going to use coke, maybe your heart will fibrillate and you will die. There should be appropriate warnings that you may be Len Bias or Stanley Wilson. You might drop dead.
Q. Could you have this discussion at the State House?
A. It is very dangerous for politicians to discuss this subject. I have been threatened with my position on drugs. In the last campaign, people ran against the Republican Freeholders saying that Mathesius wants to legalize drugs. It is an exposure that most politicians are not willing to make. Politicians come up and say to me, and police do the same thing, ''You are right, but I can't say anything about it.'' None of them who run for office would have the temerity to do so.

GRAPHIC: Photo; Bill Mathesius, the Mercer County Executive, has been a strong supporter of the legalization of some drugs (NYT/Laura Pedrick)

PUB-DATE: March 5, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1061 words

HEADLINE: To the Dying, Life Policy Can Bring Money Now

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
For anyone who is terminally ill, with 18 months or less to live, Rob T. Worley Sr., of Albuquerque, N.M., has an offer: Assign a life insurance policy to his company, Living Benefits Inc., and get up to 80 percent of the policy's value, now.
Mr. Worley's two-year-old company was apparently the first of its kind, but the concept of cashing in life insurance policies early is gaining popularity as more people confront the rising cost of dying, and more business owners see what looks like a low-risk profit.
But in most states, insurance regulators have not come to grips with what some say is a potentially exploitative business.
''Some people make it sound like you're a crook or you're doing something ghoulish,'' said Mr. Worley, who works with his son, Rob T. Worley Jr., an insurance agent. ''But all you have to do is go to a hospital and talk to people who are dying, and you will see what a great need there is for this. If sick people have cash, they can get better-quality health care and live with dignity. Without cash, they can't.'' 
 
Enthusiasm From One User
What Living Benefits offers is a contract under which the company is assigned the life insurance policy as the sole beneficiary; it takes on responsibility for any premiums due, while the policyholder is given 55 to 80 percent of the face value to spend. The exact amount depends on prevailing interest rates and on a determination by the company's medical panel of how long the policyholder is expected to live.
''It has made all the difference in the world to get the cash that lets me survive independently,'' said David F., who spoke on the condition that his full name not be used. A Los Angeles AIDS patient, David has cashed in four policies, getting more than $100,000 from Mr. Worley. ''They have been nothing but first class with me, and I cannot express the state of elation I feel to be able to pay my own bills and reap my own harvest in a way you never expect when you buy life insurance.''
Mr. Worley said he had bought about 50 policies since starting the company two years ago. Business has been picking up, he said, and another 50 applications are under review.
New Mexico last year became the first state to address the legality of contracts for such benefits, passing a law authorizing them. The law, prompted by Mr. Worley's operations, requires companies to make sure that the seller is of sound mind and understands that he is terminally ill. Insurance departments in several other states are investigating the issue.
 
Practice Labeled as Illegal
In February, in response to an inquiry from a Manhattan druggist who asked if it would be legal to start such a business, the New York State Insurance Department published an informal opinion that it is against the law to solicit or buy a stranger's life insurance policy.
''If you're terminally ill and destitute, and your relative says he'll give you money if you make him your beneficiary, that's O.K.,'' said Alan Rachlin, the insurance department lawyer who made the ruling. ''But if a stranger who has no insurable interest in you advertises to buy it, that violates the law. It's against public policy to speculate on death.''
In January, the Prudential Insurance Company of America announced a plan that would let policyholders have the bulk of their life insurance benefits if the policyholder has six months to live or less or has spent six months in a nursing home and is unlikely to leave. The new plan is to be offered at first to policyholders in 10 states where regulators have approved it and then expanded as other states approve it.
One drawback to the Prudential plan and other such programs has been that life insurance benefits paid before death are usually taxable, while those paid after death are not. But legislation introduced in Congress last week would make benefits tax-free for policyholders with less than a year to live. The sponsors said many Americans with cancer or AIDS need programs like Prudential's to handle astronomical health costs.
''Two more insurers, Connecticut Mutual and Metropolitan Life are considering plans similar to Prudential's,'' said Robert Waldron, a spokesman for the American Council of Life Insurance, an industry group. ''Everyone knows there's a great need for help in this area, with the costs of medical care, especially for people with AIDS.''
 
Several Follow the Leader
Several people around the country have seen business potential in meeting that need.
''We were the first on the face of the earth to do this, but I've had calls from all kinds of people who see the market in it,'' said Mr. Worley, who says he has used several of his other business interests, including a baking company and a leasing company, to finance Living Benefits.
Mr. Worley said that he knew of people who were offering cash for life insurance policies in Miami and New York and that he had had queries from a mortgage banker in Dallas, a lawyer in San Antonio and others about starting similar businesses.
While some expected insurance companies to cut into business, Mr. Worley said he did not.
While some expected insurance companies to cut into business, Mr. Worley said he did not.
''The people we're dealing with don't want to wait until they have a life expectancy of less than six months,'' he said. ''They want to use the money to extend their lives or improve the quality of their care. We have gotten clients with Prudential policies, even after they announced their plan.''
Some AIDS groups say that getting death benefits before entering the terminal stage of an illness could do more harm than good. For one thing, those who get substantial death benefits may lose their eligibility for Medicaid. Then, too, the groups say, those who think of themselves as about to die may give up the fight to live.
''I can see the justification where you are clearly terminal,'' said Lewis Katoff, director of client services at Gay Men's Health Crisis in New York. ''But you can't predict whether someone with AIDS is going to live 15 months or five years. I was diagnosed three and a half years ago, when the evidence suggested I would live about nine months, and here I am. Psychologically, it would have been very damaging to give up, stop working and wait to die.'' Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Metropolitan Life Insurance

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 199 words

HEADLINE: A Generous Reply to the Neediest

 BODY:
The 78th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases collected a total of $4,372,283, surpassing last year's record by more than $332,000.
The city's economy may be less than exuberant, but citizen generosity appears to be at an all-time high. The two phenomena are, of course, closely related: greater and more visible need has sparked an even more compassionate response than in any previous year.
This demonstration of concern has been achieved in response to the fund's traditional low-key appeal, which offers the assurance that all contributions flow entirely to those in need, without any deduction for fund-raising or administration.
All that remains now is for The Times to offer heartfelt thanks to all who have shown how much they care, and to underscore one vital point: while the official drive has ended, the need continues. As in the past, the fund operates throughout the year.
Contributions and bequests from here on will be credited to the 79th appeal, which begins next December. Such donations, tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law, should be sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, P.O. Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087.

HEADLINE: I Quit To Sound An Early Alarm

BYLINE: By Ariel Sharon; Ariel Sharon was Israel's Minister of Industry and Trade.

DATELINE: TEL AVIV

 BODY:
I resigned from the Israeli Government because I fear that its present political initiatives, even if founded in a sincere attempt to achieve peace, reward the Palestinians for their terrorism and increase the risks of war.
What Israel should be doing immediately is putting an end to the Palestine Liberation Organization's terrorism, which has claimed hundreds of innocent Jewish and Arab victims in the last two years alone.
The Government's initiatives include movement toward Palestinian elections in Judea, Samaria and the Gaza Strip. They are paving the way for establishment of a second Palestinian state in the land of Israel, west of the Jordan River, in addition to the existing one, the Kingdom of Jordan. 
But no democratic elections would take place because of the P.L.O.'s on-going terrorism; instead, the state would be created by the P.L.O. Such a state would control strategic mountainous terrain on the West Bank overlooking the coastal plain.
This means the width of Israel's coastal plain (where two-thirds of the Jewish population lives) would, on average, shrink to about 14 miles. This would constitute a death sentence, for Israel's main infrastructure would be at the mercy of Palestinian and Arab missiles, rockets and artillery, as well as terrorism and a large-scale conventional invasion.
The Government's policies are also leading to a renewed division of Israel's sovereign and eternal capital, Jerusalem.
Predictably, the Arab states will take our policies as an indication of weakness, and will begin a campaign of total military aggression. The continued state of war between Israel and the Arab states (apart from Egypt) has no logic or justification.
If regional piece is to be reached -in the near future, I hope - it can be achieved only if the following conditions are met:
First, an opening of the bridges between Israel and Jordan. Second, democratization of the totalitarian regimes in the Arab countries. Third, reduction and equalization of the military might of the two parties. Fourth, a solution to the problems of Palestinian refugees in the Gaza Strip. Fifth, conclusion of a formal peace treaty between Israel and the Arab states.
The long-term pressure exerted by the U.S. undoubtedly has contributed to the political tremors in the Soviet Union and elsewhere in Eastern Europe. Today a similar U.S. effort must be directed toward the Arab regimes, for the best guarantee of real peace is genuine democracy in the Middle East.
A stable peace can be achieved only by a drastic reduction of the great military threat. Surely we can reduce and equalize the military strength of the two parties, even as relations between NATO and the Warsaw Pact are undergoing a historic change. First, the long-range arms systems should be reduced, and then tactical forces like armor and combat aircraft. The aim would be to return to the force levels of the 50's, when the mutual military threat was minimal.
Mideast disarmament must be dealt with at the global level. In contrast to the Soviet Union, which is reducing its armed forces, the Arab states are escalating the arms race in our region. Their tremendous purchasing power and the surpluses created by the force-reduction agreements in Europe are making disarmament more difficult to accomplish.
Pressuring Israel to reach immediate solutions to the differences with its neighbors instead of first guaranteeing democratization and disarmament throughout the Arab world amounts to asking Israel to be prepared to commit suicide for the sake of peace.
A more fruitful approach would lie in working out interim procedures so that Israel and the Arabs states can test each other and gradually build mutual trust. For example, it is necessary immediately to open the bridges between Israel and Jordan in the same way the Berlin wall was pulled down and barbed wire dismantled in Eastern Europe.
Once the Jordan River bridges are open, the free traffic in both directions would help create a climate of peace. Instead of symbolizing enmity and suspicion, the river would signify hope for peace talks between the Israelis and Palestinians.
The Arabs cynically chose to turn the Palestinian refugee problem into a political weapon. The U.S., European countries and Israel must join together to assist these refugees. It is possible to start toward this goal by urbanizing and industrializing the Gaza Strip, where hundreds of thousands of refugees live.
Several Arab countries could well be the first to enjoy the dividends of peace if my program were instituted. Egypt, for example, is undergoing a chronic and ever more acute economic crisis. Why is it using a large part of its U.S. aid for military growth? Why does it need to maintain a gigantic army? Why does it need the 700 new tanks the U.S. is about to give it at no cost? Who is threatening Egypt, especially since Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, is now its close friend?
Jordan, too, is undergoing a crisis and is investing vast amounts in armaments. Against whom will these arms be used - Israel?
One of my intentions in resigning from the Cabinet was to make sure no one would be able to ask why no member of the Government's inner circle stood up in time to warn against what was likely to happen (as they now ask of the Jewish leaders of Europe in the 30's and America in the 40's).
Freed from Cabinet restraints, I am trying to exploit the golden opportunities resulting from the relaxation of international tensions so that Israel can move further down the road toward genuine peace.
More than 13 Likud members of the Knesset who share my opposition to policies advanced by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir have been working with me and two Cabinet ministers to try to push the peace process the right way.
The proposed summit meeting of the Israeli, Egyptian and U.S. Foreign Ministers is the wrong way. It would not encourage the peace process but rather would lead to false expectations and more bloodshed.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
What Savings Crisis?

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
One of the peculiar complaints of the Japanese - presumably repeated by Prime Minister Kaifu to President Bush at the Rancho Mirage summit meeting - is that Americans don't save enough. We are accused of spending too much on Japanese cars and other imports, thus increasing our trade deficit through no fault but our own.
Mr. Bush agrees; he wants to attract savings by setting up special accounts into which individuals could deposit up to $2,500 annually, with interest tax-free. The Democrats also agree; they're backing a 50 percent tax deduction on the original deposit (up to $2,000) in an individual retirement account. 
There are at least two problems with these proposals. The first is that they won't work. The second is that what they're supposed to fix ain't broke.
They won't work because most of the ''savings'' that would go into these accounts would be shifted out of other forms of investment, not increasing the total. That was the problem with the I.R.A. scheme of several years ago, now defunct. Even if such ideas did result in some additional savings, banks would only re-lend the ''saved'' funds for consumer spending - most conspicuously through credit cards.
Don't take my word for it. The economics writer Robert J. Samuelson pointed to these flaws in an article in The Washington Post. He suggested that both plans actually formed ''a respectable pretext for enacting new tax relief for the middle class,'' and probably would ''end up reducing national savings.''
Mr. Samuelson also provides authority for the assertion that there is no U.S. savings problem that needs fixing. ''The great savings debate,'' he declared in The Post, ''is mostly a political charade.'' Similarly, Robert Eisner, an economist at Northwestern University, referred in an article in The New York Times to a ''phantom savings problem'' that is ''badly overstated.''
What are the facts? Mr. Samuelson wrote that ''between 1980 and 1988, the private savings rate [in the U.S.] averaged 16.7 percent of gross national product, down negligibly from the 16.8 percent average between 1950 and 1979.'' Personal savings did fall, leading to the perceived ''savings problem''; but three-fourths of new savings result from the retained profits and depreciation of business -which rose. The increased business savings rate offset the personal savings drop, as it has for a century.
Mr. Eisner pointed out that ''we are not alone.'' Net national savings in Japan declined by 7.9 percent from 1976 to 1987; savings usually decline as nations reach higher income levels and growth rates fall off. On the other hand, as Mr. Samuelson noted, the Soviet Union has a higher investment rate than the U.S., but its poorly managed economy is a basket case nevertheless.
What about the Federal deficit? Doesn't it prove that the U.S. doesn't save enough? Mr. Samuelson disagrees; but he does regard the deficit as a ''drag'' and favors deficit reduction over tax-cut boondoggles ostensibly aimed at enhancing savings.
Deficits, however, stimulate the economy; they inspire not only consumption but more private investment, as businesses respond to increased sales by adding to plant and equipment. In Mr. Eisner's view, this leads to more than enough additional private saving to finance the greater deficits. Reducing the deficit, if it slowed economic growth, might therefore actually reduce savings, too.
Besides, U.S. savings are calculated less inclusively than those of most countries, Mr. Eisner asserted. Most count as savings ''government investments in roads, airports and other infrastructure''; if the U.S. savings account included such investments, he calculated, ''our net national savings would have risen by $53 billion in 1988, from 2.95 percent of net national product to 4.17 percent - an astonishing 41 percent.''
He gave this homely example: If a family spends money to educate its children, surely that family is ''saving'' for the future - but the costs of education are not counted in U.S. national savings, nor is spending on the environment or on research and development.
Mr. Eisner therefore advocates more realistic accounting and greater Federal investment in ''the public, national saving that provides the real defense of our future'' -education, for the best example. Isn't that more practical than those deceptively political savings schemes? Doesn't it make more sense than pouring additional billions into the military, to guard against a threat ''crumbling before our eyes''?

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Thank You, Jesse

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Republicans are joyful that Jesse Jackson has chosen to become the black Stassen.
He could have run for and easily won the mayoralty of Washington, a war zone passing for an American city. He could then have made demands on the Congress for enforcement and education, exhorted the drug-imperiled kids in need of a role model, and built a reputation of a politician willing to put his future on the line in a great cause.
In short, he coulda been a contender. As an elected official who paid his dues in the trenches, he might have earned a spot on the Presidential ticket in 1992, perhaps the top spot in '96. 
But when his moment came, Jesse Jackson choked.
None of that dreary day-to-day responsibility for a man who has tasted adulation at a national convention. Instead, last month's prediction by the columnist A. M. Rosenthal that Jesse would demur proved prescient.
Mr. Jackson fantasizes about being a ''shadow senator'' against the day that the District might become a State. This pitch for representation by geography rather than population subverts the principle of one person, one vote.
Don't hold your breath waiting for that. First, Staten Island would have to secede from New York City and establish a pattern of electing Republicans. Then it would have to be paired for admission with Democratic D.C., as Hawaii and Alaska were, so that neither party would gain an advantage.
Then, in a decade or two, we might have four unnecessary new senators, necessitating another new Senate Office Building. All because one star thought that serving as mayor was too demeaning an audition.
Now to why his decision to turn tail and run for President again has caused such G.O.P. elation.
Let's project ahead two years. Mario Cuomo will be basing his convoluted campaign on Vincentian reasoning (only last week, this iconoclastic pol knocked George Washington as a ''lousy soldier'').
Al Gore will be older but greener; Bill Bradley, under Sidney Pollack's Hollywood direction, will be slam-dunking third-world debt down voters' throats; and Sam Nunn or Chuck Robb will try to sell an economic-defense buildup against the Axis powers.
Against that field, Mr. Jackson will do as least as well as last time out in the Iowa caucuses, but probably dip to 10 percent in the New Hampshire primary, getting only the traditional what-the-hell vote, dismissing a Cuomo or Bradley victory as a Northeast ''hometowner'' win. Then may come California, on the verge of moving its primary up to March 3. Democrats there figure on a low Republican primary turnout because George Bush will be unopposed in 1992, and a big Democratic turnout in a fight for Senator Alan Cranston's seat; that's why Democrats want to put a few propositions on the ballot. California Republicans say no, but national leaders want that primary early because of the Jackson factor.
Mr. Jackson won 38 percent of the vote in California in 1988, a state with a black and Hispanic population of 25 percent and a significant gay vote. He may not do as well as last time, but in a five-man white and nonliberal field, Mr. Jackson will probably win the nation's largest state.
Super Tuesday follows right on. Mr. Jackson will do poorly in Florida, but almost as well as before in Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, North and South Carolina. (''And to my friends in Virginia, I want to say that I never considered General Washington to be a 'lousy soldier,' as my Yankee friend Mr. Koo-mo does.'') By the end of March, 60 percent of the delegates will have been chosen, with Mr. Jackson well out front; in mid-April, he will be the only outsider to challenge Governor Cuomo in the New York primary, and will grab a third of those delegates.
Thus will the Democratic Party be a national laughingstock. Its front-runner cannot be nominated because he chose the fun of national campaigning over the work of local governing; all he can do is threaten to bolt and accuse the party of racism if he is not given the Vice Presidency.
Damned if it does not and deluged if it does, the convention must turn to a serious black elected official: Andrew Young if he is elected governor of Georgia, or Gov. Douglas Wilder of Virginia (''and let me say in defense of my fellow Virginian, General Washington . . .'') But Democrats already have 90 percent of the black vote. Thanks to Jesse Jackson, the party will spend all 1992 polishing its racial bona fides, while - barring a major recession -the Bush-Quayle ticket breezes in. That's why Republicans are so delighted Jesse turned down a serious job.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Schools: Rich, Poor, Unequal

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 1

 BODY:
The urban school system here and the suburban district in nearby Millburn are separated by only six miles. Academically, socially and economically, they are worlds apart.
Millburn spends about $1,400 more for each school child in a year, thanks to a wealthier tax base. Its high school's programs are broader than those in the two high schools in East Orange, and its ninth graders score far better on New Jersey's standardized basic skills test.
The differences in the East Orange and Millburn schools - and similar ones in many other urban and suburban districts across New Jersey - are central to a landmark court fight on the constitutionality of the state's school-financing system, its heavy reliance on local real-estate taxes and its inbred advantages for property-rich suburban districts. 
 
A Nine-Year Fight
After nine years of protracted hearings and preliminary rulings, including a state administrative law judge's finding that the system is unconstitutional and the rejection of his decision by the State Education Commissioner, Saul Cooperman, the State Supreme Court is now preparing a final ruling on the issue. It is expected in the next few weeks.
Foes of the existing system want radical changes. The Education Law Center of Newark, which filed the pending challenge in 1981, has urged the Supreme Court to order creation of a uniform statewide per-pupil spending level between $6,200 and $7,000 and to allow automatic increases for poor urban pupils enrolled, say, in compensatory education or bilinqual courses.
Average per-pupil spending statewide was nearly $5,200 last year. Higher Income Tax? Advocates of a new system say the most logical source of any new financing the court orders would be an increased income tax or perhaps creation of a form of regional property tax.
In recent months, the high courts of Texas and Kentucky have ordered equalized per-pupil spending in decisions that struck down their states' school-financing formulas.
Marilyn J. Morheuser, head of the Education Law Center and its chief lawyer in the current court fight, says a uniform per-pupil spending level could require a handful of high-spending suburban districts to reduce programs or staff to get within a proscribed level.
Under her plan, 95 percent of all educational spending would fall within the equalized per-pupil rate and local districts could spend only 5 percent more per child.
''If there is any local leeway, it would be very narrow,'' Ms. Morheuser said.
Kentucky, which is revising its formula, is considering allowing wealthy districts to exceed an equalized rate by 30 percent, said Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, in Denver.
''Wealthy districts say: 'We can do more. Why should our kids be held back? Why should we be denied?' '' Dr. Newman said. ''That's a big debate. The constitutional question is: Can you hold back the wealthy district?''
Any deep cuts in surburban school spending in New Jersey under an equalized-rate system would likely bring sharp protests from local boards. They have long cherished local control over school spending, and home rule is deep-seated in New Jersey.
Commissioner Cooperman, who is leaving office in June, has fought the lawsuit partly on that ground that local districts are entitled to shape their own programs and spending. He says local districts satisfy the state Constitution's guarantee of a ''thorough and efficient'' education as long as they pass the state's criteria for certification, no matter what they spend per pupil.
In its last major ruling on school financing, in 1973, the State Supreme Court ruled that the constitutional guarantee of a ''thorough and efficient'' education required that all public schoolchildren receive an ''equal educational opportunity.'' That ruling threw out the existing financing formula and led to the Legislature's enactment of the state income tax and a new spending formula in 1975. Both were intended to equalize per-pupil spending.
But the Education Law Center's 1981 suit contends that the formula still relies too much on local property taxes and perpetuates the urban-surburban disparities found unconstitutional by the high court in 1973.
These disparities abound in Millburn and East Orange.
Millburn is rich in property values. Its spacious homes on quaint country lanes fetched an average sales price of $370,000 in 1988, compared with East Orange's median sales price of $84,000. The gulf in real-estate wealth allowed Millburn to spend $6,247 on each school child last year, while East Orange spent $4,867.
The spending variation leads to educational differences.
When Scott High here needed a new library six years ago, a gymnasium was converted. Millburn High's new library was built in a spacious courtyard. Millburn High offers its athletes golf, fencing, ice hockey and lacrosse and its top-level students 14 advanced placement courses. East Orange has nothing similar.
On average, East Orange's teachers have 14 years of experience and earn $35,000 a year, school officials say. Millburn's teachers average 20 years of experience and $41,520 a year.
The pupil-teacher ratio in elementary schools in East Orange is 27 to 1; in Millburn it is 18 to 1.
 
A Bulging High School
Millburn High has plenty of classroom space. Scott High, built here 52 years ago for 800 students, is bulging now with 1,200. The other day, Deborah Mayes's American history class was squeezed into the music room, next to the piano. Ester Lundy was teaching a freshman business course in the typing room as her students tried to balance their open texts atop typewriters.
Scott High's principal, Irene Nichols, said, ''I need three new math teachers, but if I got them, I'd have no place to put them.''
The school-financing fight is reaching a climax at a precarious financial time for New Jersey. A $500 million deficit in the current budget has to be eliminated, and Gov. Jim Florio is struggling to find money to balance a 1990-91 budget he is to introduce on March 15.
A year after the 1975 financing system now under challenge was created, the State Supreme Court found that it was constitutional, if the state gave local districts all the money required by the spending formula.
The Legislature, however, has fully financed the formula only twice in the last 14 years. Money raised for schools and spent elsewhere in the budget since 1975 now totals $657.1 million. Much of that would have gone to poorer urban districts. #56% From Property Taxes Reliance on local property taxes has grown and accounts this school year for nearly 56 percent of all educational spending in the state. Last year, local taxes provided 52.4 percent. Only 14 states relied more heavily on local spending.
Should the court overturn the current financing system and order revisions requiring millions of dollars in new spending for poor urban districts, East Orange's Superintendent, T. Josiha Haig, has a broad shopping list in hand.
Topping his wishes are statewide pupil ratios for teachers, administrators, librarians and social workers; a new 16-room wing at Scott High and a new school for fifth and sixth graders, and more teachers, including two per class in lower elementary grades, to reduce the current 27-to-l pupil-teacher ratio to 17 to 1 in kindergarten to third grade and 21 to 1 from fourth to eighth.
He also wants all-day kindergarten classes, half-day classes for 4-year-olds and an afterschool program for latchkey children.
Equally important, Dr. Haig said, is money for more psychologists, social workers and counselors to help East Orange's students overcome the disadvantages of poverty and the emotional scars of drug, alcohol and child abuse found in some homes here.
In addition, Dr. Haig, who is black, said many of East Orange's students came from households headed by women. ''Many of our young black males don't have enough role models and strong black images in their homes. Our job is to compensate for that. We just need more services.''
Continuity of classroom instruction, Dr. Haig said, is continually disrupted by a turnover in teaching staff, which he said is directly related to under-financing, and by the transiency of East Orange's population. Between 70 and 80 of East Orange's 900 teachers leave annually, most to seek higher-paying jobs in other school districts, he said.
 
Higher Dropout Rate
In the last school year, nearly 22 percent of Scott High's 1,200 students entered or left the school. Another 6.4 percent dropped out. Millburn High's equivalent figures were 2.4 percent and .1 percent.
The stresses of family instability and homelessness on children increases nonacademic burdens on teachers, said Ms. Nichols, principal at Scott.
She told the story of a girl who came to the district recently from California and tried to cut her wrists because of sexual abuse by an uncle.
''We have to deal with her,'' Ms. Nichols said. ''Everybody in this building is locked into children's problems. And the problems are very deep. For many, this school is a sanctuary, a place of peace. We do a lot of hugging of our children. And we need more support in schools than we did 10 or 20 years ago.''

GRAPHIC: A school system that relies heavily on property taxes has created differences in two New Jersey schools. Students at Scott High School, above, an urban school in East Orange, taking a history class in a music room. Students at Millburn High School, a suburban school with a wealthier tax base, being tested in a computer science classroom. (The New York Times/Bob Glass)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
American Express will buy Shearson's outstanding shares, after trying for months to find an outside investor so that it could reduce its 68 percent stake. Talks with Primerica nearly produced an agreement but broke down over financial issues, said Sanford I. Weill of Primerica, who built Shearson into a powerhouse and then sold it to American Express. [Page D1.] Amid growing bearishness over the securities business following the bankruptcy of Drexel Burnham, American Express decided to buy all of Shearson. News analysis. [D2.] 
 
Eastern still faces large hurdles in its effort to emerge from bankruptcy protection as a profitable regional carrier. [D1.] Eastern's striking machinists marked the one-year anniversary of their walkout with demonstrations at several large airports. [D1.]

THE MEDIA BUSINESS

HEADLINE: Job Growth in Health Care Soars

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The number of jobs in American health care is soaring at a rate three times faster than the growth of the population, troubling experts concerned about the sharp rise in the nation's medical costs. Thirty-seven of every 1,000 Americans worked in health care last year, compared with about 28 for every 1,000 just 10 years earlier.
Wages in the industry are also rising much faster than in the rest of the economy. The Labor Department said that in the last five years, the median weekly pay of salaried doctors increased 30 percent, nurses 31.1 percent and physical therapists 25.8 percent, compared with 16.3 percent for all full-time wage and salary workers.
Experts on the economics of health care attribute some growth to the increasing number of older Americans and to advancements in medical technology that require additional people to push the buttons and decipher the printouts. But many new jobs also owe their existence to the rapid growth in 25 years in the number of people covered by Government and private health insurance and in the kinds of treatments covered. 
 
Unintended Jobs
Attempts by insurers to limit costs by shifting some care outside hospitals have also had the effect of creating extra jobs without an equal reduction in jobs in the hospitals. And the number of record keepers has risen sharply as hospitals and doctors have scrambled to meet demands for paperwork from Federal and private insurers.
All told, the number of health-related employees working for wages or salaries has surged 43 percent, to 8.7 million in 1989, from 6.1 million in 1979, while the population has grown only 10 percent. There were at least 260,000 self-employed doctors and 137,000 dentists last year, compared with about 200,000 self-employed physicians and 117,000 dentists a decade ago.
By the end of the 1990's, at least 12 million Americans will work in health services, even though the growth in population is slowing, the Labor Department and Census Bureau estimate. Based on present trends, the Labor Department said, 7 of the 10 fastest-growing occupations in the 1990's will be in health services.
The rapid growth in spending on health has encouraged comparisons with increases in military spending. ''The medical-industrial complex is larger than the military-industrial complex,'' said Dr. Philip R. Lee, director of the Institute for Health Policy Studies at the University of California at San Francisco Big Part of the G.N.P.
Health care, which cost $599 billion last year, absorbed 11.5 percent of the gross national product, up from 8.3 percent in 1975. About 60 percent of the $599 billion went to labor costs. And the nation's spending on health is expected to increase by between 10 percent and 14 percent in each of the next five years, exceeding $1 trillion in 1995 and reaching about 15 percent of G.N.P. in the year 2000, the Government estimates. Military spending peaked at 6 percent of G.N.P. during the Reagan Administration and is currently about 5.5 percent.
To be sure, many Americans strongly approve of spending on health care, and the progress in medicine, while seemingly expensive, has made life considerably better for many people. What is more, the jobs that health care provides are warmly welcomed by most public officials and business groups. Hospitals, for example, are important employers of minority and entry-level workers in cities like New York and Boston. The Texas Medical Center complex is Houston's largest employer, with a $2 billion payroll.
But many experts warn that the huge increases in medical expenditures are sopping up money sorely needed by business and government for other national priorities.
 
Other Social Needs
''The problem is that we have other social needs,'' said Dr. Lee, who is also chairman of the Federal advisory commission on payments to physicians. ''The educational system is deteriorating; so is the infrastructure,'' he said. ''And research, except for military research, is not adequately financed.''
Given these other needs, many experts have expressed concern about unnecessary spending in health care. ''We're spending $100 billion more on health care than any other country would spend if it had a population as large and the same per capita income as the United States,'' Dr. Lee said.
''The health people hate it when you draw the analogy to the Defense Department,'' said Stuart H. Altman, chairman of the Federal hospital payment advisory commission and dean of the Heller School for Social Welfare Studies at Brandeis University. ''But to me, there is a lot of similarity.''
But where the biggest excesses lie is a matter of much debate between the insurers and individuals, and the hospitals and doctors.
 
Consequence of Insurance
On one side are the people trying to control costs. They argue that because Federal and private insurers have in recent decades paid most of the medical bills, patients and health-care providers have seen little reason to hold back on expenses.
Dr. Altman criticizes ''the number of hospital administrators and what we pay them.'' He also thinks that too many consultants, lawyers, strategic planners, marketing people and specialists on selling bonds are on hospital payrolls. Many hospitals could be reduced in size and staff by 10 percent to 20 percent, he said. With these and other cuts in the system, ''easily $50 billion to $60 billion'' could be saved each year, he added.
Experts also attribute the rise in medical costs to the fact that the number of physicians has grown far faster than the population. There were 142 physicians per 100,000 people in 1960. ''We are close to 240 per 100,000 this year,'' said Eli Ginzberg, director of the Conservation of Human Resources project at Columbia University.
 
Increased Competition
The argument goes that with the increased competition for patients, many doctors will perform extra and unnecessary tests and procedures on the patients they do get.
''Physicians are responsible for about 75 percent of all health-care expenditures,'' Dr. Ginzberg said. ''They admit people to hospitals and nursing homes, write prescriptions for drugs, order extra nurses. The constant increase in the number of physicians has a lot to do with the increase in health expenditures.''
Some health economists say there are too many specialists, who have the training, knowledge and inclination to order expensive services, and too few general practitioners or primary-care physicians, who may be less likely to order costly treatments.
Trying to hold down costs, insurers have begun programs that scrutinize medical claims to uncover and prevent excessive spending.
 
Increased Paperwork
But the hospitals and doctors argue that such reviews have vastly increased the amount of paperwork, forcing them to hire extra people to take care of it. Many in the medical field say the insurers' efforts to control costs have made the problem worse. They resent what they call third-party efforts to interfere with the proper care of a patient. And they say that many patients demand certain tests and treatments even if they are not called for.
Critics of insurers' attempts to control costs also say that efforts to reduce the use of hospitals have had distressing side effects. Services provided outside the hospital have often escaped the controls on costs and quality in hospitals. And as patients are increasingly cared for outside hospitals, doctors have expanded their offices, hiring nurses and technicians to run tests and clerks to file reports and send bills - duplicating many hospital services.
''We have one of the highest administrative costs for health care of any country,'' Dr. Lee said. ''Almost every doctor's office has somebody to do the billing and somebody to deal with the managed-care plans,'' he said, referring to the health maintenance organizations and discount arrangements that require extensive record-keeping.
 
Clear Phenomenon
While the best way to deal with surging health-care labor costs may not be clear, the size of the phenomenon certainly is.
Hospitals are still the largest medical employers by far, with 4.6 million workers last year, up 24 percent from 3.7 million in 1979. More than 1.1 million hospital employees are nurses. The number of nurses working inside and outside hospitals rose 50 percent, to 1.7 million, in 10 years, five times as fast as the population increased.
This growth came in part because hospitals have doubled the ratio of nurses to patients since 1975. (Because of cost-conscious efforts to keep people out of the hospital, the patients who go to hospitals now are on average sicker than years ago and require more nursing care.) Also, nursing jobs have opened up outside hospitals, in health maintenance organizations, nursing homes and home health care.
Physicians' payrolls for nurses, technicians and clerks rose sharply, to 1.2 million employees last year, from 739,000 a decade ago, said Dan Hecker, an economist at the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. And the number of doctors, self-employed and on salary, working with patients rose 39 percent, to 373,747 in 1988, from 268,578 in 1978 and may reach 500,000 at the end of the 1990's, the American Medical Association said.
 
Hiring Outside of Hospitals
Employment is also growing fast in the offices of other independent health practitioners like physical therapists, who move out of a hospital to start their own practice and hire assistants, Mr. Hecker said.
The Labor Department said that among the fastest-growing occupations in the 1990's will be medical assistants, home health aides, radiology technicians, medical records technicians and secretaries, physical therapists and surgical technologists.
Wages are also rising in the health-care industry. As hospital workers joined labor unions and the flow of Federal dollars soared, the wages of rank-and-file health workers rose faster than general inflation, ''outpacing employees in the rest of the economy,'' said Victor R. Fuchs, an economist at Stanford University.
For instance, the median weekly wages of registered nurses rose 31.1 percent, to $569 in 1989, from $434 in 1985. Over that period, the salaries of all full-time workers increased by 16.3 percent, barely keeping ahead of the 15.3 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index.
As for self-employed physicians, the average income after office expenses was $160,000 in 1988, up 29 percent from $124,500 in 1985.
In hopes of slowing the growth in spending, members of Congress are discussing ceilings on Government-paid doctor's fees, like those already in force for hospital care. The Government has already begun to adjust its payments to doctors for the patients it covers, paying more for consultations with patients and less for surgery and other procedures.

GRAPHIC: photo: Some critics say the rapid rise in the number of health-care workers in the United States and the salaries they earn is caused by the many new health plans now available that require extensive record-keeping and extra employees. Above, workers at a health maintenance organization near Philadelphia. (The New York Times/Sal DiMarco Jr.)

LENGTH: 1141 words

HEADLINE: Talks End, Wait Begins

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 4

 BODY:
In an era in which the cold war is ending, the Germanys are moving toward reunification and the South African Government has legalized the major black opposition, is it possible to resolve trade disputes with Japan?
The grand strategy that President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu espoused in their weekend talks was to accelerate the internationalization of Japan - giving it a greater voice in world councils and a greater appetite for the world's goods and services.
Should the strategy succeed, Japan's surpluses with the United States and other countries would recede, dampening retaliatory sentiments in Washington. And more yen would be plowed into Latin America, Eastern Europe and other areas hungry for capital. 
 
Vision of the Dangers
If Mr. Kaifu left Palm Springs with a conceptual framework for greater Japanese political influence in the world, he also had a vision of the dangers if he fails to internationalize his economy.
The President told White House reporters Saturday, after Mr. Kaifu left for Tokyo: ''I had, in that one-on-one, the opportunity to be just as clear as any Congressman would have liked me to be on what needs to happen to keep this terribly important relationship on track.''
The President had come to the meeting with letters from lawmakers warning of protectionist reactions if the Japanese, after a decade in which they accumulated $400 billion of trade surpluses with the United States, did not open their markets.
While Mr. Kaifu said all the right things about his determination to make trade problems ''one of the top priorities of my new Cabinet,'' there is still some healthy skepticism about whether he can deliver.
As the President himself put it, ''I think the proof of the pudding is in the eating.''
The House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, who has been a sharp critic of Japan, observed today that over the last decade Japanese prime ministers and American Presidents have had any number of meetings at which trade breakthroughs were supposed to have been made, to little avail.
''Nothing has changed,'' Mr. Gephardt said on NBC-TV's ''Meet the Press.''
Taking note of the generalities that both Mr. Kaifu and Mr. Bush used to describe their talks, Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee's trade subcommittee, commented today, ''in trade the devil is in the detail.''
 
'U.S. Is Serious About Trade'
But Mr. Baucus, who has also been highly critical of the Japanese, noted that ''the very fact that the summit was held will send a message that the United States is serious about trade.''
The President spoke Saturday of a ''trialogue'' among the United States, Japan and the European allies to promote economic development and ''to think about how Japan can more fully play a leading role in the world's political and economic institutions.''
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama have already begun exploring ways to develop the ''trialogue.''
One possibility would be for a Japanese to become head of either the World Bank or the International Monetary Fund, the two most prestigious global economic institutions, in the next few years.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Kaifu, in their closing statements after the talks, also hinted at deeper monetary understandings, renewing a pledge to cooperate in foreign exchange markets. The dollar has recently climbed in value against the yen, which threatens improvement of the trade deficit by making Japanese goods less expensive.
As an export-oriented superpower, Japan has done very well capitalizing on global free trade while restricting foreigners in its market. Powerful industry groups in Japan have a vested interest in maintaining the status quo.
But in some ways the Japanese consumer has gotten short shrift. Mr. Kaifu is trying to build a power base by allying himself with the consumer.
His plans for deregulation, increased antitrust enforcement, more effective land use, a more efficient distribution system and other structural changes in Japanese society -all of which would help internationalize the economy - are being sold politically not as concessions to the United States but as essential ingredients to improve the quality of Japanese life.
President Bush was asked Saturday how confident he was that Mr. Taifu would produce results.
 
'I Wish Him Well'
''Well, he's just won a good victory there,'' he said, referring to the Liberal Democratic Party's victory last month. The President continued: ''He's solidified his party's position. He himself emerges as, I would say, a dynamic new leader. And so we will simply wait and see. But I wish him well.''
Mr. Bush is under pressure from American trade law, which sets deadlines for retaliation against nations that trade unfairly. In coming months, deadlines loom for trade disputes in such sectors as telecommunications, forest products, satellites, supercomputers, shipbuilding and the broader area of structural differences between the United States and Japan.
The deadlines are the result of stepped-up efforts by Congress in 1988 to deal with mounting business complaints about unfair trade abroad, chiefly in Japan.
They also reflect frustrations about the rising trade deficits, even though a greater cause of those deficits, most economists agree, is the weak competitive position of the United States, a condition whose causes include low savings, high consumption, high budget deficits and a corporate emphasis on short-term profits.
The Bush Administration does not want to have to retaliate. As the President noted, it is better to resolve trade imbalances by expanding exports, rather than limiting imports.
 
Retaliation Less Likely
Because of Mr. Kaifu's promises, the weekend meeting between the two leaders probably makes retaliation less likely. Despite the deadlines, the President retains flexibility if he can assure Congress that progress is being made.
Although the business community favors keeping pressure on Japan, it too has little stomach for retaliaion, at least this year. Instead, it is pinning its hopes for trade gains and profits on the international free trade negotiations currently under way that are known as the Uruguay Round.
These talks, conducted by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that oversees trade, are scheduled to end in December. The agenda includes providing international protecton against theft of patents and copyrights, as well as expanding trade in agriculture and in financial and other services.
Jerry Jasinowski, president of the 13,500-member National Association of Manufacturers, commented, ''I think there is general support for moving ahead with a strong Uruguay Round and a reluctance to have bloody battles with our trading competitors.''

HEADLINE: Kaifu Returns to Political Outcry in Tokyo

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, March 5

 BODY:
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu returned to Japan on Sunday from his meeting with President Bush in California to face what politicians and commentators agreed was a severe test of his leadership.
Some opposition politicians, serving notice of the obstacles that Mr. Kaifu faces, criticized the Prime Minister, asserting that he had made concessions on trade and security matters without pushing Mr. Bush on any issues in return.
Accounts of the sessions in Palm Springs dominated the news here all weekend, suggesting that Mr. Bush had pressed the Prime Minister hard to commit himself on a range of actions to resolve the mounting trade disputes between Japan and the United States.
 
Sentiment of Local Boosters
Amid the pictures of Mr. Kaifu relaxing in Palm Springs were articles giving an indication why American criticism of Japan often puzzles the Japanese. 
On the one hand, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, was quoted as saying that Japanese investment in the United States was a matter of concern. On the other, attention was given to comments by people in Palm Springs saying that they hoped the meeting would bring an infusion of Japanese investment to their valley.
The Desert Sun, a newspaper in the Palm Springs-area, was quoted as saying, ''The summit comes at a time when this valley is aching to attract more Japanese tourists and real estate investors.''
Mr. Kaifu pledged to ''firmly tackle'' the trade difficulties as ''one of the top priorities of my new Cabinet.'' This promise became a focus of commentary pointing out that the Prime Minister's leadership of his own party is tenuous, with two major Liberal Democratic leaders eager to oust him at the first opportunity. Lack of Resourcefulness? A leader of the main opposition party in Parliament did not even wait for Mr. Kaifu's plane to land on Sunday night before criticizing the Prime Minister for what he said was a ''lack of his own individual diplomacy'' in the sessions with Mr. Bush.
Tsuruo Yamaguchi, secretary general of the Japan Socialist Party, said it appeared that the Prime Minister had too readily accepted Mr. Bush's demand that Japan undertake major structural changes to make it easier for foreign products to be purchased and accepted by Japanese.
He was referring to the American demand that Tokyo undertake a major program of spending on public works, reduce the power of business cartels and to make changes in Japanese laws that would encourage large retail stores to expand and replace small ''mom-and-pop'' stores in many neighborhoods.
These and other adjustments are deemed by United States negotiators as essential in opening Japanese markets.
 
Where the Power Lies
But in order to make these changes, Mr. Kaifu would not only have to step on the toes of the opposition, which controls the upper house of Parliament, but also offend major constituents of his own ruling party.
Business cartels are the party's main power base, for example, but Japan's huge network of tiny retail outlets are so politically powerful that they have for years kept intact laws permitting such stores to band together in neighborhoods to block the establishment of large retail stores.
In addition, the Finance Ministry and other Government agencies are wary of major public works programs that could add to inflation, budget deficits and the problem of rising real estate values.
In an editorial this morning, the newspaper Yomiuri, which is normally friendly to the Government, said Mr. Bush had taken a ''surprisingly tough'' stance toward Japan.
 
Request Is Criticized
''It is rare for a United States leader to ask a Japanese Prime Minister to intervene politically on individual trade problems,'' the paper said. ''This request will severely test Kaifu's leadership ability.''
Besides the Socialists, other opposition parties indicated some support for Mr. Kaifu's notion, articulated in Palm Springs, that there should be new emphasis on the needs of the Japanese consumer, but leaders said they would question him on what he meant.
More serious for the Prime Minister are lingering indications of opposition within his party. Mr. Kaifu angered two faction leaders, Shintaro Abe and Michio Watanabe, by excluding their proteges from his Cabinet.
 
Criticism Turned Back on Him
The reason he cited was that these politicians were tainted by various influence-peddling scandals, including the one last year involving gifts to politicians by the Recruit Company. Mr. Watanabe has responded by demanding that Mr. Kaifu clear up his own record of receiving gifts from Recruit.
Mr. Kaifu, 59 years old, was chosen Prime Minister in August after the party lost the elections for the upper house of Parliament because of the party scandals and controversy over its enactment of an unpopular sales tax. Last month, he led the party to its victory in elections to the more powerful lower house.
The Prime Minister has a small power base of his own and owes his position to a group of kingmakers who are described as ready to turn against him should he falter in relations with the United States, or in resolving the controversy over the tax increase.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Steady Rates Expected If Dollar Stays Strong

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Fuzzy signals about the domestic economy and rising foreign interest rates are likely to create a standoff and keep interest rates in the United States in a narrow trading range - as long as the dollar remains strong, many analysts say.
''If the dollar holds, the negative implications of rising interest rates abroad can be largely mitigated,'' said Robert M. Giordano, a partner and director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''If the dollar comes under pressure, the results in our bond market would be far worse.''
A strong dollar suggests that despite rising interest rates abroad, investors continue to put money in dollar-denominated financial assests instead of investing in yen- or mark-denominated stocks and bonds. 
 
Uncertainty Overseas
Political and economic uncertainty in West Germany and Japan has buoyed the dollar even as interest rates in those two countries have soared.
Yields on 10-year bonds rose to 7.16 percent in Japan late last week and to just under 9 percent in West Germany.
Under different circumstances, those rates might prove highly attractive alternative sources of investment to Treasury securities of comparable maturity. At the end of last week, the Treasury's 8.5 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.54 percent. Although the Japanese bonds are at a lower yield, they normally would be seen as a better investment because inflation in Japan has historically been well below that of the United States.
The state of affairs in West Germany and Japan is unsettled enough that analysts said the dollar was likely to remain attractive against the yen, the mark and other major currencies for the near term at least.
 
Confusion About U.S. Economy
To a certain extent, the market's fixation on the dizzying increase in interest rates abroad stems from the fact that for the past few months it has been difficult for analysts to interpret what is happening in the domestic economy.
Weather, strikes and inventory-related cutbacks in production in the auto industry have clouded the picture.
Some reports, like the sharp drops recorded in January durable-goods orders and new-home sales that were reported last week, suggest weakness. But construction expenditures were strong in January, and the February survey of the nation's purchasing managers suggested that conditions in the manufacturing sector improved slightly from the previous month.
Analysts said special factors had much to do with the conflicting data. Testifying before Congress last month, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said a clearer picture might not emerge until spring.
For the most part, private analysts agree.
''There were weather distortions in the latter part of 1989 that impacted the economy and took a few months to get worked out,'' said William N. Griggs, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm, referring to an abnormally cold December. ''Then we had the Boeing strike, and the shutdown in the auto industry,'' he continued. ''March would be the earliest you might expect to see the numbers start to lose some of those distortions. But those data won't be available until April.''
In the meantime, Mr. Griggs said, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 are likely to remain in a tight trading range of 8 3/8 to 8 5/8 percent.
At the close of a volatile week, the closely watched issue was offered at a price to yield 8.53 percent, down 2 basis points, or hundredths of a point, from its close on Feb. 23.
 
'Can't Trust Them'
Erratic movements in the economic numbers have also played havoc with portfolio managers. Some said that for the time being they have had to adjust their trading strategies to compensate.
''There is so much noise in the numbers that you can't trust them,'' said Roberta D. Olsen, a fixed-income portfolio manager at the Banc One Asset Manangement Corporation in Columbus, Ohio. ''In that sort of an environment you take a day-trading approach rather than establish big positions. But at the same time we don't want to get caught short, because longer-term we think that rates are going to come down.''
Special factors - ''noise'' in Ms. Olsen's parlance - are likely to influence the February employment data to be released on Friday.
By most estimates, returning auto workers, an infusion of census takers and a weather-related rise in construction employment increased non-farm payroll employment by about 250,000 last month. But that sort of a gain would overstate the strength in the economy, analysts said.
''Layoff patterns and the winter's seasonal vagaries probably distorted the measure,'' Alan Levenson, an economist at Salomon Brothers, writes in the firm's weekly Comments on Credit.
 
No Shift by Fed
''Adjusted for these factors, activity in the goods-producing sectors likely stayed tepid, while the pace of hiring in service-producing sectors remained sufficient to support modest growth in consumer incomes and spending.''
The Federal Reserve Board is mindful of the special factors, but private analysts said that even without those considerations the employment numbers are likely to be strong enough that the Fed will not choose to ease monetary policy.
''If 250,000 or a shade above that is the number we are talking about, then the Fed will remain on hold,'' said Steven Slifer, a senior vice president and financial market economist at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. ''For the moment, the markets are priced about where they should be, and are likely to remain at these current levels for the next couple of months.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
World Bank's Lesser Role in China

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 4

 BODY:
More than any other foreign institution, the World Bank has had enormous impact on China's economic transformation of the last decade. It was not just a large lending institution but a bank of ideas.
While many experts say the World Bank is inching toward resuming normal lending to China, the institution is unlikely to regain its previous role and influence.
During China's economic change, when Chinese economists debated vigorously about stock markets and privatization, the World Bank was there, its data-sheet wizards and worldly economists offering strategy tips and lectures on how to create economic progress. And the bankers were always ready to back up the ideas with money. 
The bank had a direct line to China's research organizations, even to some of the nation's top leaders, who were willing and eager to absorb advice on how to make China economically strong. And the bank has been a consultant on China's five-year economic plans.
 
Ready to Resume
Much of that relationship and all new lending were frozen after the military crackdown in June. The Chinese were furious, and the topic immediately became a central issue in Chinese-American relations, with the Chinese apparently suggesting that lending had to resume before the dissident Fang Lizhi could be allowed to leave his refuge in the United States Embassy.
Now, with the approval on Tuesday of a $60 million agricultural loan for one of China's poorer provinces, the World Bank appears poised to resume a normal lending pattern. The next loan proposal is expected to be presented within weeks. Last month, the bank approved a $30 million loan to help earthquake victims.
While World Bank officials dispute it, many bankers and economists say the organization has lost some influence with China's policy makers, mainly because the environment for economic change is different. They note in particular the fall from power of Zhao Ziyang, the former Communist Party General Secretary who took a special interest in the bank.
''China was their biggest success story in the world,'' said Richard E. Feinberg, the executive vice president at the Overseas Development Council, a Washington-based research group. ''Macroeconomic performance of the country was terrific, and there were good policy changes. No doubt they had the ear of senior officials.
''The general line of the World Bank in the 80's was to accompany projects with some reforms and policy changes in that sector.Now, the World Bank may not have enough clout to do that today.'' $780 Million in Loans Suspended After the Government cracked down on the democracy movement in June, the United States and six other industrialized countries on the World Bank's board decided to suspend approvals on seven projects requiring $780 million in new lending to China. Many private banks then decided to postpone their lending to China until the World Bank returned.
The commercial banks have not yet moved back toward China, apparently waiting to see a normal, steady flow of World Bank loans.
The two loans approved last month are regarded as humanitarian loans and are not enough for the financial community.
The Japanese Government, the largest single Government lender to China, will wait for all seven projects postponed by the World Bank to go forward before it will proceed with a financing package worth about $5.6 billion, a Japanese official said.
But some government lending has resumed. Early last month, the Export-Import Bank, a United States Government agency that supports American exports, announced two loans totaling $32.85 million.
Many foreign banking analysts and diplomats say the decision to halt lending to China was motivated more by political protest than by economic changes. In turn, the suspension of loans made China more cautious and less willing to discuss radical changes with the World Bank and other foreign institutions.
''The interest in the World Bank is still there,'' said one economist familiar with the bank's operations in China. ''But the World Bank is increasingly being viewed, at least at the top, as a lending institution rather than as a place that generates new ideas. China is still interested, but in the long run that sort of interest is not enough to make the World Bank's role in China grow.''
One American diplomat characterized the Chinese view of the World Bank loans approved in February as ''page one, paragraph one of negotiations with Americans'' in bilateral disputes.
 
Little Impact Felt
The suspension of new loans had little immediate impact on the economy. Of the World Bank's previously arranged loans of $8.5 billion, about half had not been completed, and these loans have continued to provide money to the Chinese without interruption. Because any new loans would have taken months to disburse, the suspension's impact was greater psychologically than economically.
While the bank appears to have lost some influence, particularly at the top levels of China's Government, it will continue to have power simply because of its vast resources. And China's appetite, perhaps even desperation, for loans, is great, especially for loans to finance projects in basic infrastructure, like power and transportation.
Money has already been earmarked for 78 projects that range from improving the life of the underfed in Gansu Province in western China to building hydroelectric plants in coastal Fujian Province to developing freshwater fish ponds in China's cities.
The bank continues to have ties to all levels of Chinese economic life.
Through links with thousands of provincial, local and midlevel officials with whom it collaborates on projects, the bank has helped raise China's understanding of modern methods of project design and feasibility, cost-benefit analysis and implementation. Since much of the advantage also goes to the regions where the project is carried out, local officials are still eager for World Bank involvement.
''You've got to distinguish between the decision makers, that is, the leaders, and the rank-and-file cadres in China,'' said a Chinese familiar with the World Bank operation. ''The cadres are willing to collaborate with the World Bank. They are aware of what's going on in the economy and know that the market economy is the way to go.''
The bank's role has also been complicated because the environment for change is different. China's retrenchment program, with its emphasis on greater central planning, has slowed growth to 4 percent last year from double digits a year earlier. Under the program, begun a year and a half ago, any fundamental economic changes will proceed more slowly than Western economists had hoped for.
 
Too Much Administration
''We believe the Government is relying too much on administrative measures, which causes a hard landing rather than a soft landing,'' said the bank's chief in Beijing, Edwin R. Lim. ''The reliance on administrative levers makes it difficult to solve fundamental problems in the economy.''
Mr. Lim, who disagrees with the assertions that the bank's role has changed, cites continued contact with Chinese research institutions. Indeed, the bank is promoting seminars and lectures on topics like industrial policy, wage reform and even privatization of state-owned enterprises.
Mr. Lim, a Chinese-Filipino economist who has been influential among China's policy makers, still calls China's economy ''one of the best in the world.''
''As a development institution, the bank has to look beyond one to two years,'' he said.
