HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Manhattan,inc. Seeks to Revive Its Fortunes

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
D. Herbert Lipson, the owner of Manhattan,inc., has been getting a lot of calls lately from admirers - and not just from people praising the magazine's splashy behind-the-scenes business articles. Some callers want to buy the magazine.
But Mr. Lipson says Manhattan,inc. is not for sale, even though advertisers have cooled to the once-sizzling magazine.
''It has been financially disappointing,'' said Mr. Lipson, chairman of Metrocorp, which publishes the New York business monthly and Philadelphia and Boston magazines. ''But I'll stand behind it. I have an emotional attachment to the magazine.'' 
 
At Least $8 Million in Losses
Magazine industry analysts estimate that Mr. Lipson has lost at least $8 million in the last five years. During the last three years, advertising pages at Manhattan,inc. have dropped nearly 28 percent, to 660 pages in 1989, from a peak of 912 pages in 1986. Mr. Lipson said the magazine would not make money for ''two or three more years.''
Despite the magazine's troubles, interest in Manhattan,inc. is high. Mr. Lipson, while he did not identify the potential buyers, said he had both American and foreign suitors. And John Veronis, chairman of Veronis, Suhler & Associates, an investment firm specializing in media properties, said people were fascinated with the magazine. ''As long as the magazine has editorial vitality, it will ultimately be successful,'' he said.
The magazine certainly looked like a hit when it was started five years ago. Under its founding editor, Jane Amsterdam, it became one of the most talked-about new magazines.
Readers were attracted by articles that took a sometimes titillating look at the powerful people making news in New York's supercharged business climate. Advertisers liked the magazine's rich demographics. Subscribers tend to be the same kind of people that the magazine writes about - big income business executives.
 
Two Powerful Blows
But in 1987 the magazine was dealt two powerful blows. First, Ms. Amsterdam and several other top editors left. Ms. Amsterdam resigned in a dispute with Mr. Lipson over his role in the magazine's coverage.
Then, the October 1987 stock market crash virtually wiped out financial advertising, the magazine's most important category.
As a result, the magazine has been struggling in the New York magazine market, which has become even more crowded. Now, it must compete for a shrinking pool of financial, retail and real estate advertisements with new rivals like 7 Days and Spy, along with well-established competitors like New York and Avenue.
Since Clay Felker replaced Ms. Amsterdam as editor, the magazine seemed to flounder, media experts say. The magazine also lost some of its edge when top writers like Ron Rosenbaum and John Taylor left.
 
Showcasing Young Talent
Mr. Felker has tried to replenish the magazine's roster by hiring such writers as Michael Lewis, the author of ''Liar's Poker,'' and by showcasing such young talent as Jennat Conant, a former Newsweek writer.
Over all, though, morale is low, people at the magazine said. Co-workers characterized Mr. Felker as volatile, bad tempered and inflexible. In working with editors and writers, these people said, Mr. Felker often sees an article only from his point of view and will insist an article be done his way. Frustrated by what they called Mr. Felker's ''autocratic'' style, several top editors have left the magazine.
Mr. Felker acknowledged that he could be ''pretty passionate about his work.'' But he said he was not harder to work with than any good editor. ''I don't think my way is the only way, but it is an editor's job to give a publication a vision,'' he said.
Media experts say Mr. Felker, who founded New York magazine, blurred the magazine's focus by trying to turn it into a national business magazine. ''The magazine lost its way editorially,'' said David Lehmkuhl, a magazine consultant. ''Suddenly there was nothing special about it.''
 
Looking Beyond New York
Mr. Felker introduced fiction and non-business articles. He also broadened the scope of the magazine to include articles about business personalities outside of New York.
The focus has narrowed recently. ''When Clay joined, he was figuring out what to do,'' Mr. Lipson said. ''He broadened the focus to cover too wide a territory. Now, he is clicking.''
For his part, Mr. Felker said that although the magazine now included some articles about people outside of New York, it was not his intention to make Manhattan,inc. into a national business magazine. ''It is not the same magazine, of course,'' he said. ''The business world is different. But the strategy is the same.''
Some media analysts are concerned that Mr. Felker might leave Manhattan,inc. to run The Battery News, a biweekly newspaper in lower Manhattan, which he acquired in April. But Mr. Felker said he was ''in for the long haul at Manhattan,inc.''
 
'Too Narrowly Targeted'
The magazine has also suffered from a self-imposed restriction. By its very nature, Manhattan,inc. appeals primarily to readers curious about New York's business community. But big advertisers want to reach large numbers of consumers.
''The magazine's biggest problem is that it is too narrowly targeted,'' said John Power, a group vice president at Vitt Media International, a buying service for advertisers. ''It reaches too small an audience.''
Manhattan,inc.'s publisher, Sandra Ourusoff, is trying to change that perception. Since she joined the magazine a year ago, circulation has jumped to about 113,000 last month from about 90,000, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations.
The price, however, has been high. Subscriptions are selling for as little as $6 a year, an 83 percent discount on the magazine's $3 cover price.
Manhattan,inc. is also offering a bargain of sorts to its advertisers. Most publications raise advertising rates as circulation climbs. Not Manhattan,inc.: This year a full-page color ad in the magazine will cost $11,265, the same as in 1989.
Media experts said the magazine had been hampered by high turnover of its advertising sales staff. Mrs. Ourusoff acknowledges that this ''is a big problem.'' She is the third publisher in the last two years.
Manhattan,inc. has a thornier problem. The magazine rose with New York's economic resurgence in the 1980's. ''The magazine made its name covering the people who created the Wall Street boom,'' Mr. Power said. ''Writing about the decline makes for a less interesting magazine.''
Mr Felker does not agree. ''This is a bumpy period, but New York is still the financial capital of the world,'' he argued. ''It isn't possible to run out of first-rate stories in New York.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Arabs Fear End of Cold War Means a Loss of Aid and Allies

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAMA, Bahrain

 BODY:
The changes sweeping through Eastern Europe represent a major strategic setback for Palestinians and other Arabs, regional officials and experts say.
The consensus of dozens of officials, scholars and businessmen interviewed in the Persian Gulf region and Western Europe is that Arabs, especially the Palestine Liberation Organization, have begun to see a steep decline in the open political, moral and material support that they have received for more than a quarter of a century from Eastern Europe.
Many of those interviewed expressed the view that the end of the cold war has upset basic Arab strategies for dealing with the 40-year Arab-Israeli conflict.
 
Like a Military Defeat
When those results are combined with the rapid melting of the Eastern bloc's freeze-out of Israel after the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, some policy makers and Arab commentators go so far as to suggest that the decline of Communism in Eastern Europe is comparable to the defeats suffered in 1948, when Israel was established, and 1967, when the West Bank and Gaza were lost in the Arab-Israeli war. 
''There is a sweeping feeling among Arabs that they have lost an ally of the kind that stood by them at times of crisis,'' said Fouad Zakaria, a philosophy professor at Kuwait University.
''From now on, the Soviets' interests, as well as those of Eastern Europe, will be focused on getting closer to Western Europe and diminishing tensions with the United States,'' he said. ''The Middle East may well rank last on the scale of interests.''
 
Palestinians the Biggest Losers
By far the biggest losers appear to be the Palestinians. Palestinian leaders say they no longer have access to military training and weapons supplies, and that they fear a loss of medical assistance and the hundreds of scholarships granted to Palestinian students for study in Eastern Europe.
The Warsaw Pact countries, which over the last three decades offered military training to 5,000 to 6,000 guerrillas from the P.L.O. and other Palestinian organizations, according to estimates, have largely ended that cooperation.
Bases of operation for extremist Palestinian groups like the Abu Nidal organization, which worked out of Warsaw and East Berlin, have been disbanded. Palestinian officials assert that the new Governments of Poland and East Germany have supplied intelligence to Western agencies.
''Our mistake was that we formed relations with the Governments of these countries, not with their peoples,'' said Radwan Abu Ayash, a leading figure among Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and head of the federation of Arab journalists there.
 
Fewer Advisers in Syria
Militant Arab nations like Syria, Southern Yemen, Algeria and Libya are also feeling a sharp impact from the decline of support from the Soviet Union and the Eastern bloc.
Andrew Duncan of the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies said the number of Soviet military advisers stationed in Syria has dropped significantly since the winds of perestroika began to blow through Moscow.
In its yearly publication ''The Military Balance,'' the institute reported that the number of Soviet military advisers in Syria dropped from 4,000 in 1988 to 3,000 last year. ''We expect the figure will be further reduced by June,'' Mr. Duncan said.
The Soviet Union has also served notice that it will no longer support President Hafez al-Assad's decade-long quest to put Syria in what he calls ''strategic parity'' in armaments with Israel.
Most important, one senior Soviet diplomat said in an interview, Moscow has told Damascus that it will not back Syria in another war with Israel.
As a result, Syria and even Libya, which had stood firmly against the reintegration of Egypt into the Arab League and opposed moderate pro-Western Arab regimes, have substantially toned down their militancy. Both countries have resumed ties with Egypt and are eagerly seeking to reintegrate themselves into the Arab mainstream.
 
Hard-Liners Begin to Soften
''None of this is lost on Assad,'' an Israeli diplomat said of the new Soviet attitude. ''He is readjusting his policies vis-a-vis Egypt, the P.L.O. and the peace process. Militarily, he realizes that the Soviets today are not the Soviets of 10 years ago. He cannot depend on them in the same way.''
The softening of the hard-liners' stance has given more freedom to conservative Arab nations led by Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Morocco, which are slowly shaping new outlines for Arab policies, advocating peaceful settlements of disputes in Lebanon and with Israel.
But it is not evident that the collapse of Communist governments in Europe and the shift in Soviet strategy is all that profitable for the moderate oil-producing regimes of the Gulf either.
''We in Kuwait always balanced our relations with the United States with our ties to the Soviet Union,'' said Abdullah Y. al-Ghanem, who heads one of Kuwait's largest trading companies. ''When the U.S. refused to sell us F-16's, we went to the Russians. Now that the two superpowers are playing ball together, what are we supposed to do?''
For the moment, the most insistent Arab and Palestinian fears center on the relaxation of of Soviet restrictions on the emigration of Soviet Jews, a move that is sending tens of thousands of Soviet immigrants to Israel every month and upsetting a basic tenet of Palestinian demographic calculations.
 
Soviet Emigres Seen as Threat
For years, the Palestinians, and many Israelis, have argued that one of the biggest incentives for Israel to cede the occupied Arab territories of the West Bank and Gaza Strip is that the rate of population growth among the Arabs in Israel and the occupied territories is so much higher than among Jews that by the end of the century the demographic balance will tilt in favor of the Palestinians. Those calculations are being scrambled by the flow from the Soviet Union.
Moreover, ''the professional qualifications of arriving Soviet migrants, who are almost all educated and well-trained professionals, further enhances Israel's technological superiority in the face of all its Arab neighbors,'' said Abdullah al-Nobari, business editor of the Kuwaiti newspaper Al Taliaa.
Ghassan Salameh, a Middle East affairs expert at the University of Paris, argues that Moscow has come to look upon some Arab, and some Muslim but non-Arab, Middle Eastern countries like Iran and Afghanistan, as potential menaces, because of the effect that Islamic fundamentalist currents emanating from them could have on the Soviet Union's Muslim republics, like Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan and Kirghizia.
The dominant sentiment in this region was summarized by Abdullatif al-Hamad, a former Kuwaiti Finance Minister and head of the Arab Fund for Economic and Social Development, who said, ''We suddenly find ourselves alone on a stage from which we should have exited some time ago.''

CORRECTION-DATE: March 9, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Arab and Palestinian political setbacks in light of the changes in Eastern Europe misstated the number of Soviet Jewish immigrants to Israel. The highest monthly number of immigrants was roughly 5,000, in February.

HEADLINE: Reports Indicate Mounting Efforts To Free U.S. Hostages in Lebanon

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
There are growing indications from Washington and the Middle East of a flurry of diplomatic activity to free the American hostages in Lebanon.
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today that ''there is a lot happening'' behind the scenes, although he said there was no indication that the hostages would be freed soon.
''We cannot say that there is any movement,'' he said. ''We know of no imminent release.'' 
Mr. Fitzwater made his remarks amid a swirl of rumors and speculation in recent days that the United States was secretly negotiating with Iran to win the freedom of the eight American hostages, rumors that Mr. Fitzwater and other senior Administration officials have strongly denied. [Excerpts, page A14.] His remarks also coincided with hopeful statements from Iran, Syria and Lebanon saying the hostages should be freed soon.
The 8 Americans are among at least 16 Westerners held in Lebanon, many of them by kidnappers thought to have connectons to Iran. Responsibility has been claimed in the name of at least eight groups, several of which seem to represent the same organization.
 
Anderson Held the Longest
The hostage who has been held the longest is Terry A. Anderson, who was the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press when he was abducted on March 16, 1985.
One statement about the hostages was made by The Teheran Times, a pro-Government Iranian newspaper linked to President Hashemi Rafsanjani. The paper said in an editorial to be published on Tuesday that Western hostages in Lebanon could be freed before the end of the year, Reuters reported from Nicosia, Cyprus.
''Our own assessment indicates that this thorny issue can be sorted out in the near future in a sincere spirit by sincere people,'' the editorial said. ''An attempt is being made even right now as we go to press.''
The editorial followed a meeting on Sunday between Mahmoud Hashemi, the brother of the Iranian President, and the Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, in Damascus. The two officials reportedly discussed efforts to free the hostages.
 
Activities of Intermediaries
In an elaborate statement that some Administration officials characterized as an unofficial message to Iran, Mr. Fitzwater described the activities of intermediaries around the world acting on behalf of American hostages, including what he called ''freelance people'' like businessmen and other people who have contacts in Iran and Lebanon, foreign diplomats and family members and other representatives of the hostages.
''I will never rule out meetings anywhere, any place, anytime, by anybody on the hostage question, because these meetings are happening,'' he said.
Mr. Fitzwater said the intermediaries often claimed to represent the United States, which he said was untrue.
''Many of them have had contacts with the U.S. Government,'' he said. ''They have told us what they are doing. They have asked us for advice.
''And when all this comes out later, I don't want it said they were working for the U.S. Government.'' He added that many of the intermediaries had received advice and comments from the Administration.
''So there's a lot happening, and I don't want to be discouraging,'' Mr. Fitzwater said.
 
Clarifying Quayle's Statement
Mr. Fitzwater's remarks were intended in part to clarify an ambiguous statement on Sunday by Vice President Dan Quayle. When asked on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation'' about talks between the United States and Iran on the hostages, Mr. Quayle did not issue an outright denial, but replied, ''There is no negotiation on a quid pro quo basis.''
There is no consensus within the Administration on the significance of the recent encouraging signals about the hostages' fate. One Administration official who has followed Iranian affairs for more than a decade said he was ''very optimistic.''
But a senior State Department official said, ''I've seen as many reports as anyone, but don't see any analytical basis for any conclusion this is going to lead to the release of a hostage or group of hostages.'' The official said the United States had not sent any official message to Teheran through the Swiss Government, which represents United States interests in Iran, since the flurry of positive signs from Teheran and elsewhere began.
Some Administration officials have complained that there has been a tendency in the White House for several months to overreact to small signals abpit the hostages. These officials said many of the statements about the hostages came from people close to Mr. Rafsanjani. The officials said Mr. Rafsanjani had believed for some time that the hostage issue was an impediment to Iran's economic recovery and had long sought to resolve it.
Nevertheless, Administration officials agree that recent signals about the hostages are positive.
 
Unconditional Release Urged
Reflecting an important recent departure from long-held Iranian policy, the editorial in The Teheran Times said the hostage issue should be solved without any preconditions. The newspaper also dismissed reports of secret talks between Iran and the United States about freeing the Americans among the hostages.
The first encouraging signs from Teheran came on Feb. 22, when an editorial in the same paper said the hostages should be freed because they had become a propaganda tool of Iran's enemies. The next day, Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, a leading Shiite Muslim cleric in Lebanon, said that the hostages were being used by the West to distort the image of Islam and that a means should be found to free them.
 
Interview With Iranian Cleric
That was followed by an interview with Ayatollah Mohammed Yazdi, a senior Iranian cleric and head of the Supreme Court, who said that the taking of hostages was un-Islamic and that Iran opposed the practice.
Ettela'at, Iran's second-largest newspaper, which is linked to President Rafsanjani, said in an article at about the same time that the hostages should be released without preconditions on Islamic and humanitarian grounds.
Administration officials said they were encouraged that recent Iranian statements had dropped preconditions for the release of the American hostages. Until recently, Iranian leaders have linked their release to the release of Iranian financial assets frozen after the seizure of the American Embassy in Teheran in November 1979.
In addition, these officials said there had not been denials or criticisms in Iran of the conciliatory statements. But officials said that Iran had only limited control over the hostage-takers in Lebanon and that some Iranian factions might still oppose the hostages' release.

HEADLINE: Big Shortfall in Corporate Taxes Thwarts Key Goal of 1986 Law

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Corporate income taxes have produced much less revenue than was predicted when the monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986 was enacted, and individuals have made up the shortfall.
One of the main political selling points of that law, which changed the income tax system more than any other legislation since World War II, was the expectation that $120 billion in taxes would be shifted from individuals to corporations in the first five years.
But for reasons Government experts and outside economists do not completely understand, corporate tax receipts, while higher than they were under the old law, ran $20 billion to $30 billion less each year than anticipated in the three full fiscal years since the law was enacted. The shortfall in years to come is expected to be even larger. 
 
A 'Revenue Neutral' Bill
Lawmakers were told when they passed the sweeping legislation in the fall of 1986 that it would be ''revenue neutral'' over the first five years, meaning it would generate almost exactly the same amount of total money for the Government as the old tax law.
So far, that has proved to be the case. Tax receipts from individuals have exceeded expectations by more or less the same amount that corporate receipts have lagged.
Experts agree on why tax payments by individuals have been higher than was estimated four years ago. The economy has performed better than was anticipated, giving people higher incomes and, thus, higher tax bills.
But most Government officials and private economists who have studied the matter say they are not sure why tax receipts from corporations are so far off the mark.
In early 1987, shortly after the new law was enacted, the Treasury Department and the Congressional Budget Office, using different computer models of the economy, predicted the effects of the law on revenues. Each study overestimated corporate tax receipts by about the same amount.
After checking with tax specialists at the Treasury, Roger Bolton, Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs at the Treasury, said the department's view was that the shortfall in corporate tax receipts can be almost entirely explained by the fact that corporate profits have been lower than anticipated.
''It's not that tax reform didn't do what was predicted but that the economy didn't do what was expected,'' Mr. Bolton said. Other economists and tax experts agreed that was part of the cause, but they said they doubted it was the full reason. They say that the Government's overestimates of corporate profits varied enormously: The estimate was $23 billion too high in the fiscal year 1987, $9 billion in 1988 and $60 billion in 1989.
By contrast, the shortfall in taxes paid by corporations did not vary by nearly so much. It was $20.9 billion less in 1987 than the estimate the Treasury made right after the tax law was passed, $22.7 billion less in 1988 and $25 billion short in 1989.
Rosemary D. Marcuss, assistant director for tax analysis at the Congressional Budget Office, said she and her staff studied the issue carefully last year and finally threw up their hands in frustration, unable to determine why corporate tax payments had not met expectations.
Other economists in Congress and outside the Government suggested these other possibilities:
* With leveraged buyouts and other structural changes, corporations took on much greater debt in the late 1980's than was foreseen when the law was passed, and that reduced their tax burden.
* The computer models used in estimating revenues did not take account of the negative effects on the economy in general and corporations in particular of the abolition of various tax breaks.
* Foreign ownership of American businesses increased dramatically at the end of the decade, and the American subsidiaries of foreign companies have underpaid their taxes.
* Some small businesses became partnerships instead of corporations or changed their accounting practices to lower their tax bills.
* Some corporations took deductions to which they were probably not entitled and were able to do so without fear of prosecution because the Treasury took so long to produce regulations interpreting the new law.
The 1986 law changed the tax landscape for corporations. The top corporate tax rate, previously 46 percent, was lowered to 40 percent in 1987 and to 34 percent thereafter. The investment tax credit, which had saved companies billions of dollars a year in taxes, was abolished; a stiff minimum tax was imposed; depreciation schedules were made much less generous, and many accounting rules were made less favorable.
Scores of highly profitable corporations that had used tax breaks to cut their taxes to little or nothing have been making large payments under the new law. For example, the Walt Disney Company and the General Dynamics Corporation received tax refunds from the Government between 1981 and 1985, but paid more than 30 percent of their profits in taxes in 1988, according to a study by Citizens for Tax Justice, a research organization sponsored by labor unions.
Because of the changes, corporate taxes have increased as a proportion of total Government revenues from about 8.5 percent just before the law was changed to about 10.5 percent now. Income tax payments by individuals have remained at about 45 percent of all income.
All the experts interviewed agreed that at least part of the shortfall in corporate tax receipts was the result of lower-than-expected corporate profits.
Tax specialists at the Treasury use estimates for corporate profits that are made by the Council of Economic Advisers and the Office of Management and Budget. Almost invariably over the years, the estimates have been too high.
C. Eugene Steuerle, a top tax policy specialist at the Treasury for many years and deputy assistant secretary for tax analysis in the last years of the Reagan Administration, said officials in other agencies often made unrealistic estimates of profits so that their projected budget deficit would be smaller.
But that does not explain why the Congressional Budget Office, using a different computer model, also overestimated corporate profits. Officials of the office said they had no reasonable explanation.
 
The Effect of Debt
Many economists said that leveraged buyouts, the hottest trend on Wall Street in the late 1980's, surely reduced overall corporate tax payments somewhat. In those deals, a group of investors using borrowed money, often raised by issuing high-yield ''junk bonds,'' buys up the stock of a company. Such a substitution of debt for stock reduces taxes because a corporation can take a tax deduction for interest payments on debt, but gets no deduction for dividend payments on stock.
The economists said, however, that leveraged buyout activity was not large enough to have caused more than a small fraction of the total shortfall in corporate tax payments.
No one can guess how much increased foreign ownership of business may have changed the tax equation, but Robert S. McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, is one of the economists who believes it must have played a part in the lower corporate tax receipts.
Internal Revenue Service officials have said they suspect that many American subsidiaries of foreign companies are not paying their fair share of taxes, and the agency has begun an investigation of the matter.

HEADLINE: Few Willing to Help Britain Help Hong Kong Emigrants

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 5

 BODY:
Facing a British political backlash to her plan for granting up to 225,000 Hong Kong residents full British citizenship, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is trying to persuade the United States and other Western nations to make similar offers to the people of Hong Kong.
The 5.7 million people of Hong Kong, the vast majority of them ethnic Chinese, have become increasingly nervous about their fate after control of the British colony reverts to China in 1997. Britain wants to encourage them to stay, not emigrate. London hopes that the granting of British passports, and the similar action it wants other Western countries to take, will calm them. 
Asked about the British request, an American diplomat here said: ''We have agreed to look into it and do what we can after looking into it.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, have discussed the matter, she added.
But she cautioned that the United States was unlikely to act quickly. She noted that Britain wants the United States to substantially increase the allowed number of immigrants and to grant special visas that would not have to be used immediately, which she said ''would mean a major change in U.S. legislation.''
 
Action in the Senate
The Senate has passed a bill that would double, to 10,000 a year, the number of permanent visas granted to Hong Kong residents. The bill is now before the House.
One big complication would be to take action that treated Hong Kong as a special case.
Under current law, a foreigner who is granted a visa entitling him to permanent residence in the United States must show an intent to do so once he has picked up the visa. So someone who got such a visa and then continued to spend most of his time in Hong Kong might have it revoked.
Britain has reportedly also approached Japan, Singapore and some other members of the Commonwealth or the European Community. These reportedly include Australia, Canada, France, Italy and the Netherlands. A spokesman for the British Foreign Office would say only that ''we're talking to a very wide range of countries.''
 
Italy Trying to Help
Although some British newspapers indicated that some agreements might be imminent, Mr. Hurd, the Foreign Secretary, said at a news conference in Budapest on Thursday that the prediction was ''slightly premature,'' according to Reuters.
An Italian diplomat said it was ''the political will'' of the Italian Government ''to find a way to help these people,'' and that Italy was exploring ways to change its laws to do so.
Canada, whose annual quota on immigration from Hong Kong is now 23,000, has a law like America's that requires foreigners granted permanent residence to move to Canada. It has no intention of changing the law, said Raphael Girard, Minister of Immigration and Consular Affairs at the Canadian High Commission in London. ''Changing the law solely for the benefit of residents of Hong Kong doesn't fit the context of Canadian constitutional guarantees for equality,'' he said.
Taizo Watanabe, a spokesman for Japan's Foreign Ministry in Tokyo, said British newspaper articles suggesting it was prepared to offer passports to Hong Kong citizens were ''totally speculative,'' Reuters reported.
One of Britain's goals is to do a better job of calming the fears of Hong Kong residents about Chinese rule. Since the current plan calls for Britain to take only the families of 50,000 people deemed essential to the colony, there have been doubts that it would stem the heavy emigration, which is averaging about 1,000 a week, Emigration totaled about 42,000 last year. In the year that ended Sept. 30, 8,861 emigrated to the United States. Last year, 1,150 emigrated to Britain from Hong Kong.
In response to the reports of Britain's efforts to get other countries to help Hong Kong, a spokesman for the Hong Kong Government in London questioned on Thursday if any actions would be great enough to make a big difference. ''Obviously the people of Hong Kong welcome any other efforts to build confidence and help people stay in Hong Kong,'' he added.
The violent suppression of the democracy movement in China last spring sent shock waves through Hong Kong.
Diplomats and analysts say Mrs. Thatcher also hopes that if the Hong Kong initiative becomes an international effort, it will become more palatable for the British.
 
A Worrisome Rebellion
Indeed, Mrs. Thatcher is having to contend with a worrisome rebellion within the Conservative Party that is endangering legislation to enact the plan, which is now before Parliament. As many as 86 Conservative Members of Parliament are threatening to vote against the legislation. The Labor Party, the major opposition, is against the plan, arguing that it is elitist.
Political commentators say they believe Mrs. Thatcher is especially eager to diffuse the anger over her Hong Kong policies because it is not the least of her problems. The Conservative Government, which is now trying to put into effect a controversial change in household taxes, also has to contend with a host of economic problems: 7.7 percent inflation, mortgage rates that just rose above 15 percent and an anemic economy. This helps explain why the Conservatives are trailing Labor by as much as 18.5 points in opinion polls.

HEADLINE: Seeking Aid, Chamorro Advisers Present Economic Plan to Baker

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Aides to the President-elect of Nicaragua, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, met today with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to lay out an economic recovery plan, plead for United States aid and discuss a timetable for demobilizing the Nicaraguan guerrillas.
Under the plan, Mrs. Chamorro would sell off state enterprises, eliminate Government subsidies for many industries, slash Government regulation of the economy and introduce a new currency with a fixed rate of exchange tied to the United States dollar.
With such changes, the Chamorro advisers told United States officials today, Nicaragua could look forward to economic growth of 10 percent a year for five or six years. That, they said, would return Nicaragua to the output of goods and services that prevailed in 1977, before the Sandinista revolution. 
 
Chief Economic Adviser
The delegation was led by Mrs. Chamorro's chief economic adviser, Francisco Mayorga Balladares, and by Alfredo Cesar Aguirre, a former contra leader who returned to Nicaragua in June to work in the election campaign.
In the elections last month, Mrs. Chamorro led a coalition of parties known as the National Opposition Union, or UNO. Mr. Mayorga and Mr. Cesar today gave American officials a document titled, ''The UNO Agenda for Economic Recovery.''
It says Nicaragua urgently needs assistance so that farmers can plant new crops. The inauguration of Mrs. Chamorro as President is scheduled for April 25. ''Because the rainy season occurs shortly after the new Government will take over, time is of the essence in securing necessary supplies such as seed, fertilizer and fuel,'' the plan says.
Mrs. Chamorro's plan, written mainly by Mr. Mayorga, says that ''all state companies in the production of goods and services will be privatized.'' Moreover, it says: ''All of the state companies will pay taxes and social security and interest on their bank loans, and repay the principal. They will now pay for public services. We will try to avoid all subsidies and privileges.''
Under United States law, Nicaragua is ineligible for most types of economic aid until it clears up arrears of $65 million to $70 million. However, Congress could pass legislation canceling the old debts, most of which were incurred when Anastasio Somoza Debayle was President of Nicaragua.
Though sometimes described as Marxists, the Sandinistas say their economic policy is an eclectic mix of elements drawn from socialism and capitalism. In the last year, they have imposed economic austerity measures to combat inflation.
The Chamorro plan offers incentives for contras and other exiles to return home. ''Amnesty will be decreed for political offenses so that all exiled Nicaraguans who wish to return can do so enjoying full human rights,'' it says. The Government will also help pay ''repatriation expenses.''
Jorge I. Dominguez, a professor of government at Harvard University, said the Nicaraguan economy was so depressed that he could imagine ''a jump-start recovery'' with robust growth of 10 percent in the first year, provided that Managua got ''a flood of money from outside donors.'' But, he said, ''sustained economic growth of 10 percent a year over five or six years strikes me as wholly unrealistic.''

HEADLINE: Gallup Shifts Emphasis Toward Market Studies

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
The Gallup Organization, which helped invent the public opinion poll more than 50 years ago, is scaling down that business and taking on more market research instead, several current and former Gallup employees said.
Since Gallup was bought 18 months ago, its new owner, Selection Research Inc., a market research company based in Lincoln, Neb., has been slashing staff at Gallup's office in Princeton, N.J., and de-emphasizing research on social issues, former and current employees say.
The company's new owners concede there have been structural changes.
Jim Clifton, a former SRI executive and now the president and chief executive of Gallup, said the ratio of public opinion polling to market research polling was 50-50 when his group bought Gallup. Now, he said, 30 percent of the work is in public opinion research, and the rest is work for health-care companies, hospitals, banks and insurance companies, trade associations and newspapers. But he said the commitment to public opinion research remains the same. 
 
How to Pay for It
George Gallup Jr., co-chairman of Gallup with his brother Alec, and son of the founder, who died in 1984, said: ''My father would have understood. The Gallup Organization remains dedicated to public opinion research on a broad scale. Market research is a way of paying for it.''
Many longtime Gallup employees disagree with that view, and in recent months four top executives have left and formed their own polling companies. One hundred and fifty people were working at Gallup's headquarters when the company was bought in September 1988; now there are fewer than 60.
''When they bought Gallup, what they were really doing was buying the name,'' said Neil Upmeyer, a former vice president of public affairs research and one of several senior employees to leave the company recently. ''My feeling is that six months from now, there won't be anything left of Gallup as it used to be.''
''The culture inside Gallup has changed,'' said Andrew Kohut, who was president of the Gallup Organization before the acquisition and division president afterward, until his departure.
 
Change Is No Surprise
Observers say the new emphasis is not surprising in an industry where profits have been flat in recent years. ''It's very difficult to make money in the public polling business,'' said Norman M. Bradburn, director of the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago. ''You make money essentially in the commercial side of it.''
Nonetheless, the unrest at Gallup concerns many in the opinion field.
''I think that Gallup has lost the people who are strong in the public opinion area, and I don't see who is going to do the kind of work that made them what they are,'' said Warren Mitofsky, the executive director of voter research and surveys for the newly combined exit-polling efforts of the three major over-the-air television networks and the Cable News Network.
Both Gallup and SRI are privately held, and neither SRI nor Gallup officers would reveal the purchase price. Mr. Gallup said his company ''was not in the black'' when it was sold.
SRI was founded in 1969 to develop psychological screening tests that help employers find employees for particular jobs.
When SRI offered to buy Gallup, Mr. Clifton spoke to the company's employees and assured them nothing would change. But change did come.
 
Phone Interviewers Dismissed
First the company moved from its old building to a suite in a new office building nearby. Then the entire staff that conducts telephone interviews, about 40 people, was dismissed and all telephone work was assigned to the 800 SRI interviewers in Nebraska.
''We expected that,'' said Diane Colasanto, former senior vice president for opinion research at Gallup who has joined Mr. Kohut and formed a new company that does business with Gallup. ''Their strength is telephone interviewing.''
In another change, the SRI marketing staff in Nebraska has now become the marketing staff for Gallup, Mr. Clifton said.
The personal-interviewing staff -people who went to homes for in-depth interviews - was cut, Mr. Upmeyer said, from 15 employees to two or three. He said the coding staff -trained to interpret answers to open-ended questions - was also cut.
These methods, particularly personal interviewing, can sometimes be more effective. But personal interviewing is much more expensive than a standard telephone poll, and companies are cutting back on the practice.
 
In Some Ways the Same
The Gallup Poll has stayed essentially the same, although it was assigned a new chief last month. It still comes out once a week and is syndicated to 100 newspapers around the country.
It is the Poll that most people think of when they think of Gallup, and it has been described as the ''public face'' of the company. But that department is only one of several in the organization.
To be sure, Gallup has always worked for corporate clients. Sometimes the clients wanted to know which colors or flavors the public prefers. That was considered market research. Sometimes the questions were broader - for instance, an airline seeking information on public safety issues, or a newspaper wanting to gauge opinion on abortion for a series of articles. That was considered social public opinion research.
The Opinion Research division of Gallup, headed by Mr. Kohut, was responsible for the latter. Although its staff remained intact after the purchase, employees say they saw a blurring of the traditional line between the two types of work done for corporate clients.
Mr. Kohut left Gallup last autumn, and Ms. Colasanto followed soon after. The two were credited in polling circles as being the backbone of the organization.
No one has been named to fill Mr. Kohut's job. Mr. Upmeyer, who left Gallup last week, said Mr. Kohut's Public Opinion division has been ''dismantled'' into smaller groups.
But Mr. Clifton of SRI said the complaints by former employees are out of proportion. ''There is nothing wrong with making money,'' he said. ''The changes allowed us to be profitable. And being profitable is the only way any to get any research done.''

HEADLINE: Selection of Jurors Is Started for Trial of Poindexter

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Jury selection started today in the trial of John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser accused of concealing the Reagan Administration's actions in the Iran-contra affair from Congress.
Drawing from a pool of 206 potential jurors, Judge Harold H. Greene of Federal District Court summoned more than two dozen people on the panel to his courtroom, questioning them individually about their backgrounds and their knowledge of the case.
By the end of the day, Judge Greene had qualified 21 jurors, representing a broad cross section of the city's residents. They included an unemployed truck driver, several health care workers, a janitor, a cook and a real estate lawyer who worked as a volunteer in the Bush campaign for President in 1988. 
It is from a pool of some 50 prospective jurors that lawyers for each side, who are allowed to challenge for cause in the current winnowing process, will be permitted peremptory challenges. Eighteen people will be chosen for the Poindexter trial, 12 regular jurors and 6 alternates.
 
Dismissed for Prior Knowledge
Judge Greene dismissed several prospective jurors because of prior exposure to Iran-contra matters. One man said that ''when the whole thing was going down'' after public disclosure of the affair in November 1986, ''all you heard was North and Poindexter.''
In response to questionnaires completed by each of the 206 prospective jurors, 76 of them answered that they had some knowledge of the affair.
 
The Names Are Familiar
But most of those 76 who were questioned by Judge Greene today said that their knowledge did not go beyond an ability to recognize the names of Mr. Poindexter and other prominent figures in the affair, like Oliver L. North, the former National Security Council aide who has been convicted on three counts.
Mr. Poindexter, a retired rear admiral, was Mr. Reagan's national security adviser from December 1985 until he resigned in November 1986 when the Government announced that it had been engaging in covert arms sales and had discovered that some of the proceeds had been diverted to Nicaraguan rebels at a time when aiding them was prohibited by Congress.
The defendant faces five criminal charges, including accusations that he obstructed Congressional inquiries and made false statements to Congress.
 
Poindexter Watched the Show
At today's session, Mr. Poindexter leaned back in his chair watching the questioning of people who will decide his guilt or innocence. He smiled occasionally when defense lawyers pointed him out to prospective jurors who were sometimes unsure whether they could recognize him. His wife, the Rev. Linda Anne Poindexter, sat in the first row of the gallery.
Judge Greene said exposure to Mr. Poindexter's testimony at the Iran-contra Congressional hearings would not automatically disqualify a juror even though the admiral testified on the condition that none of his statements could be used against him at his trial.

HEADLINE: Debut of Commercials on School TV Renews Debate on Programs' Value

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNION, N.J., March 5

 BODY:
The camera pans the Berlin wall as the narrator discusses the divided city and the outbreak of the cold war.
Cut to a cartoon cheetah. Students at Union High School laugh as the animal is flattened by trucks and falls into manholes in his pursuit of Cheetos, the cheese snack. Fade out for the first day of Channel One, a news program for teen-age students complete with commercials.
Zoom across the state line to Peekskill, N.Y. There Michael E. Griest's students watch news too, but without commercials. Mr. Griest uses the program CNN Newsroom to test his government and economics students' understanding of current topics, from world events to geography to marketing principles. 
Television news has arrived in the classroom, and today's debut of Channel One in 400 schools across the country brings one of the fiercest educational battles in years to a new phase.
Banned in New York, California, and Rhode Island, Channel One has been branded a pernicious, cynical attempt to make profits from school children under the guise of educational television. Others call it visionary, applauding the idea of tailoring a news program for teen-agers and arguing that the much-needed video equipment that schools receive free for subscribing to the program outweighs two minutes of commercials a day.
 
Education Concerns Raised
The furor surrounding Channel One raises other, broader educational concerns. Is television the way to reach the majority of teen-agers who say the tumult in Eastern Europe leaves them cold - and who do not bother to vote? Can a brief daily news program interest and inform them or does it present too simplistic and fragmented a picture? Is this a genuine educational innovation or a quick fix for historical and geographical ignorance that will not deepen knowledge?
Both programs, Channel One and CNN Newsroom, aim to teach teen-agers about world events and to counter political apathy. But whether either program will achieve its goal depends on their formats and how well teachers use them, say experts.
''Learning about contemporary events from television, it's a natural,'' said Sam Gibbon, director of the award-winning science television program, ''Voyage of the Mimi,'' from Bank Street College of Education in New York City. ''As far as the power of television to transport students to other worlds, to teach, to introduce a variety of subjects to the classroom, I think its power is very well established.''
But Herbert Kohl, a former teacher and author of several books on education, worries that the brevity of the program will leave students with superficial knowledge of world affairs. ''You can put this on, let it play, and have no responsibility for going deeper,'' he said. ''It won't provide extra learning that teachers don't provide, but administrators find this a cheap and easy way to look good.''
While teachers have used educational television programs in classrooms for years, last year Whittle Communications was the first company to announce a daily news program for teen-agers. So far the company, a unit of Time Warner Inc., says 2,700 schools across the country have signed on.
 
Programs Have Similar Formats
The Cable News Network, which had the same idea a few months after Channel One was announced, got its program on the air first, starting CNN Newsroom last September. The Turner Broadcasting System Inc., which operates CNN, says 7,000 schools have signed up to receive the program, and more than half show it regularly.
Channel One and CNN Newsroom have similar formats, opening with fast-paced news reports, slowing to focus on a few topics in more detail, cutting to graphics like pop quizzes or quotations of the day, slowing again for one or two longer features.
The 12-minute Channel One program broadcasts a five-part series every week on one topic, like Eastern Europe, drugs or summer jobs. The 15-minute CNN Newsroom includes daily longer features, like reports on American Indians' anger over celebrations of Columbus's discovery of America, or a debate on whether to end Baylor University's 145-year-old ban on dancing.
Channel One has flashier graphics and more music; CNN Newsroom looks more like standard news.
Educators who have seen both programs say their producers need to slow the pace and create more material tailored for teen-agers. Even more important than the format, said Terry Baker, dean of the research division at Bank Street College, is how teachers use the programs.
''If this is used by itself, it's not going to be used effectively,'' he said. ''It depends on whether teachers prepare to do something with it.''
In Peekskill, Mr. Griest has written the main themes of Friday's CNN Newsroom program on the blackboard: the debate over the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant, civil disobedience, a compromise on the clean air bill, a debate about ending the dance ban at Baylor. Standing by the television set, he tosses out questions as the program unfolds.
 
Teacher Detects Improvement
''Who started civil disobedience?'' he asks as CNN Newsroom shows nuclear plant protesters being dragged by police. ''What American used it in the '60's? What worldwide figure used it?'' His students correctly answer: Henry David Thoreau, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mohandas K. Gandhi.
After the broadcast, he leads a discussion on the pros and cons of nuclear power and tells his students, to their dismay, that he favors Baylor's dancing ban.
Mr. Griest has shown CNN Newsroom to his government and economics students every school school day since September, and he believes he can detect improvement in their ability to find countries on maps, their knowledge of world affairs and their understanding of economics and government. He said the program particularly appeals to students who are uninterested in textbooks.
''It gives us more knowledge about the world and what's going on.'' said Aaron Paige. ''A lot of people don't know about East Germany, or why the wall is coming down. This makes you a worldly person. You can talk about anything.''
At Union High School, students generally liked their first look at Channel One. In Rita Duane's journalism class and Tom Quinn's social studies class, they watched as Channel One moved quickly through some top reports: the death of a college basketball star, the Cuban defector who windsurfed to the United States, President Bush's meeting with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan, the landing of the space shuttle Atlantis.
The program offered special reports on a Japanese high school in Tennessee, the history of the Berlin wall and the stricter educational requirements of the United States Army. Some students watched the screen; some quietly painted their nails or applied lipstick and hair spray.
 
High School Piques Interest
The Japanese high school clearly sparked the most interest.
''What I don't like is the Japanese can get a scholarship before another guy,'' said Don Matera. His teacher pointed out that a student interviewed on the program had expressed the same fear, but that it had been shown to be not necessarily true. Many students expressed resentment that Japanese lived in the United States, but did not choose American high schools.
The report did not explain that the Japanese high school was founded because Japanese students educated overseas often fall behind their classmates at home and then fail the competitive examinations necessary for college in their country.
Such problems with sophistication and nuance were evident with both programs. For instance, even though the students had been watching discussions of Eastern Europe on CNN Newsroom for months, few moved beyond comments like, ''Communism is really falling apart.'' In both schools, discussion of the programs was fairly brief, given the constraints of 45- to 50-minute class periods.
Under contracts with Channel One, schools must show the program to most children 92 percent of the time. No videotaping or deleting of the commercials is allowed. Whittle will check compliance by installing monitoring devices, with permission of the schools, in certain sets. Participating schools receive, for the contract's three-year duration, a satellite dish, through which they receive the program directly; two video recorders, and televisions for most classrooms.
Turner Broadcasting, which briefly considered including commercials but dropped the idea after meeting stiff opposition, offers CNN Newsroom free. Local cable companies will connect schools to cable systems without charge. Schools, which must be in areas that have cable television available, pay $1 a day to receive the teachers guide through electronic mail, but get no free video equipment.
Explaining the need for the programs to slow their pace, Carla Seal-Wanner of Columbia University's Teacher's College said her research shows that teen-agers learn more from formats that include historic background and emphasis on people their age.
Ms. Seal-Wanner, director of the graduate program in instructional technology, praised Channel One's longer reports with their focus on teen-agers, but she found the program too simplistic.
CNN Newsroom did a better job presenting the news, she said, but failed to adapt the news to its audience.
''CNN has skewed it a little too much to making a news program and repackaging it for kids,'' she said. ''Whittle tried to make it too entertaining, assuming that kids aren't going to be interested.''

At Peekskill (N.Y.) High School, Michael E. Griest, a social studies teacher, uses CNN Newsroom to test his government and economics students' understanding of current topics. (The New York Times/Suzanne DeChillo)

HEADLINE: GROWING CRITICISM FOR CLEAN AIR BILL

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Governors Mario M. Cuomo of New York and Jim Florio of New Jersey today criticized the clean air bill offered as a compromise last week by Senate leaders and the Bush Administration, saying it would impede their ability to fight air pollution.
Mr. Cuomo said in a statement that the compromise had valuable provisions but that amendments would be needed ''to attain our goal: assuring every American citizen healthy air to breathe.''
Mr. Florio expressed similar concerns in a letter to the Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine. Mr. Mitchell was a chief architect of the compromise, which was reached after a month of negotiations with the White House. 
The legislation would amend the Clean Air Act of 1970 to deal with unsolved air pollution problems, including acid rain, urban smog and toxic airborne chemicals. Senate leaders, giving ground to White House demands for a less costly effort, agreed to less stringent standards and a slower cleanup schedule. That concession angered some environmentalists and lawmakers.
 
Stiffer Controls Are Urged
Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, said the bill proposed insufficient controls on tailpipe emissions, which are a major contributor to smog; on small factories and shops that also create smog, and on toxic chemicals in the air. Mr. Lautenberg said he would introduce amendments to strengthen these and other provisions.
The associations of state and local officers who administer the Federal air pollution law also criticized the agreement today and called for changes that would strengthen their authority to crack down on polluters. ''If we are to be successful in providing our citizens with healthful air,'' they told Senator Mitchell in a letter, ''we must have strong regulatory tools with which to work; this agreement falls short of providing us with those tools.''
James M. Lents, the president of the local air pollution control group, said the proposed compromise could lead to ''a new economic war between the states.'' Without a provision requiring the Federal Government to step in when states or cities are not complying with the law, he said, the way would be cleared for polluting industries to ''shop around from state to state to find those areas promising the least regulation.''

HEADLINE: Breaking the Ice With Japan, Again

 BODY:
President Bush's weekend talks with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu produced yet another Japanese pledge of economic reforms that could ease the two nations' tension over trade. Previous Prime Ministers have been unable to deliver as much as they seemed to promise but Mr. Kaifu introduced a welcome new element. His aim, he said, is to improve the quality of life in Japan - that is, to make changes because Japan needs them, not because America demands them. 
The bilateral friction turns on Japan's huge and seemingly intractable $50 billion surplus in trade with the United States. Removing Japanese barriers to imports won't remove the surplus but should reduce it.
It is unrealistic for Washington to demand a revolution in Japan's consensus-bound society. But Japan's friends in America and Europe grow increasingly impatient with a supposed ''partner'' who exports aggressively while limiting imports.
Mr. Bush proposed the meetings on the spur of the moment after Mr. Kaifu's re-election last month. If the President meant to convey frustration over the lack of progress in current trade negotiations between Washington and Tokyo, he surely made his point. If he sought an immediate breakthrough, he pounced too soon.
Mr. Kaifu had barely patched together his Cabinet before he was off to California to discuss fundamental issues he hasn't yet resolved at home. As Prime Minister, he has much less governmental power than a U.S. President. And Mr. Kaifu is further handicapped by the lack of a political following. He was a compromise choice of the long-dominant Liberal Democratic Party when its leaders were disgraced by scandal. To make matters worse from the American perspective, all the major candidates took tough positions on trade issues.
There are two negotiations under way, both forced on Japan by last year's U.S. trade legislation. In one, on specific products, Washington is pressing the Japanese to open their markets for supercomputers, communications satellites and wood products. In the other, broader talks, both governments seek basic changes. The U.S. wants Japan to open up its retail distribution system, to crack down harder on antitrust violations and to encourage consumption. Japan says America should reduce its budget deficit, raise its savings rate and improve education.
In terms of pure economics, both sides are talking good sense - about the other side. America could improve its competitiveness by doing what Tokyo urges; even President Bush agrees, but offers half-measures. Japan, in its turn, could improve the lot of the Japanese, and its acceptance as a world power, by opening up. Its hostility to foreign commerce and investment serves neither its own interests nor anyone else's.
No one should expect miracles from the new Prime Minister, still struggling to establish his grip. But his willingness to meet on short notice and his positive response to the President's arm-twisting demonstrate a welcome tilt toward comity.

LENGTH: 303 words

HEADLINE: No Grand Turkish Alliance Looms on Horizon;
What 'Ethnic' Conveys

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I would caution against the tendency to refer to political demands by non-Russians in the Soviet Union as ''ethnic unrest,'' while referring to similar demands by Russians in ethnically neutral terms. Just because people are ''ethnic'' doesn't mean that so are their demands. 
I was struck by the difference in terminology in your two Feb. 15 reports on Soviet civic unrest. One article describes how Russians in Volgograd took to the streets to protest deteriorating economic conditions and calls this ''democratic, populist'' politics. Another article on the same page reports Tadzhiks in Dushanbe involved in ''ethnic violence.'' But a closer reading shows that the Tadzhiks too marched on Communist Party headquarters to demand the resignation of the local party chief and ''more action by the party to improve living standards in the impoverished area.'' Granted, the demands started after rumors were spread that Armenian refugees would be given scarce apartments, but the core of dissatisfaction is bad living conditions, rather than ethnic conflict.
More is at stake than linguistic exactness. People of all nationalities in the Soviet Union increasingly engage in assertive grass-roots politics and attack the Communist Party for political and economic mismanagement. Communist Party leaders are fighting back by raising the specters of anarchy and ethnic violence.
Granted that democratic traditions and ethnic tolerance need strengthening in the Soviet Union, but the way to do this is through more democracy and negotiation, rather than through martial law and an autocratic presidency.
 
RASMA KARKLINS
 Chicago, Feb. 18, 1990
The writer, associate professor of political science at the University of Illinois, is author of ''Ethnic Relations in the U.S.S.R.'' (London).

HEADLINE: G.M. Layoffs: Wait It Out? Start Again?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: LINDEN, N.J., March 5

 BODY:
The 1,600 people laid off from the night shift at the General Motors assembly plant here 10 days ago find themselves at a crossroads.
Should they try to get by on unemployment insurance or temporary jobs and wait for G.M. to call them back? That might take two years. Or should they forget the high-paying assembly line and find new, more stable jobs?
''I don't expect ever to come back,'' said James Craig of Maplewood, who has worked for General Motors more than 20 years. ''And being 50 years old, it's kind of difficult to find something new. I'm just living day-by-day.'' 
Mr. Craig was one of about 30 unemployed workers who showed up at the United Auto Workers Local 595 union hall today as state employment counselors laid out options for them. An upstairs meeting room has been turned into a temporary hiring hall, and starting today workers will come here for advice, job referrals and unemployment checks. Some workers doubt that G.M. would shut down the Linden plant completely; it is one of the most modern that the company operates. It was built in 1937 but rebuilt and highly automated four years ago to turn out small Corsica and Beretta cars.
This layoff - which will last indefinitely, the company says - is to help reduce a backlog of inventory. Workers who plan to tough out the period of idleness expect to go back to some of the sweetest factory jobs in the state, with average wages of $15.36 an hour.
 
Other Jobs Are Limited
But the auto industry has been in a slump for more than two years, and if they are rehired, the workers know they could find themselves collecting unemployment insurance again someday.
Job hunting for factory workers is not what it used to be in New Jersey. According to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, 220,000 production jobs disappeared in the 1970's and 1980's and were replaced by office jobs. For workers with only assembly-line skills, finding work in an office is a long shot at best.
As they sat around long tables at the union hall smoking or sipping coffee, some of the G.M. workers appeared lost. Others looked like students in a classroom, listening with blank stares as job counselors cautioned them to be wary of expensive private technical schools promising quick careers. There wasn't much joking. ''I never thought I'd be laid off with 14 years on the line,'' Nancy R. Vine of Howell Township said during a coffee break.
 
Alert Given in December
Having been through a yearlong layoff when the plant was rebuilt, Mrs. Vine wasted no time deciding what to do when the recent layoffs were announced last December. She plans to start computer programming classes March 21 at the Brick Computer Science Institute, a private technical school near her home.
Mrs. Vine, 33, said she was going to try to make her way in a completely new field because her assembly-line experience - she worked on dashboards - cannot easily be transferred to other work.
She asked the counselors if G.M. would pay the $3,600 for her computer programming course. G.M. reimburses each laid-off worker up to $5,500 in tuition. But Mrs. Vine took a course in computer repair when she was laid off four years ago, and that cost $3,600, leaving her just $1,900 of the $5,500 to spend.
''They said come back next week to take an aptitude test,'' Mrs. Vine said.
 
'It's Going to Be Tough'
During the last layoff Umberto Pecoraro of Linden took a $2,000, two-week course in how to drive a tractor-trailer at the Smith & Solomon School in New Brunswick. ''But it's four years, and I didn't touch a truck,'' he said. He wants to take a refresher course, but he is not sure if G.M. will pay for it, because workers cannot take the same course twice.
The counselors could not give Mr. Pecoraro an answer either. They asked him to wait, but he said he could not wait long. He has a mortgage to pay and three children, 5, 6 and 9, to support. His wife does not work outside the house. ''It's going to be tough,'' he said.
Some of the more optimistic of the unemployed hope they can replace workers who retire from the day shift, where 1,700 people build about 430 cars a day. They do not plan to do anything but wait. Arnold J. Ricerca of Cranford is one. A maintenance worker with more than 16 years' seniority, he says he is not worried.
''We Italians are never insecure,'' said Mr. Ricerca, who came to the United States from Sicily 33 years ago. ''I don't have a big mortgage. I have a few thousand in the bank. The only thing is that it's hard, when you're 56, to put some money aside for retirement when all of a sudden you don't have a job.''
 
'How Much Can You Take?'
The uncertain nature of the auto industry, where one-month layoffs occur regularly and permanent shutdowns are always a possibility, has pushed some workers to their limits. ''I'm thinking of going down to Florida if I can find a job there,'' said Joseph Paprocki of Clark. ''I'm getting tired of G.M. throwing us out.''
Mr. Paprocki worked at the company's Hyatt Bearing plant in Clark for more than a decade before it closed in 1981. Then he shifted to the Linden plant. This is his second major layoff there. ''G.M. has been good to me all my life,'' he said, ''but how much can you take?''
Besides the tuition reimbursement, workers receive supplemental benefits to augment state unemployment checks. These benefits can equal 70 percent of their regular salaries and last for a few weeks to two years, depending on seniority.
Laid-off workers can be rehired by G.M. if they take other jobs, so long as they are not laid off longer than they worked at G.M.
 
Just Waiting Not Advised
The president of Local 595, Charles L. Marshall, has advised workers not to just collect their benefits and wait to be called back. He has urged them to go to school or get retraining, just in case they have to find another job.
Most of the 30 workers at today's workshop seemed to have accepted the union's advice. But some said they just did not care. While the unemployment counselors were interviewing workers upstairs, Stanley E. Drake sat downstairs at the union local's bar, tipping back a few drinks.
''There's a good chance that I'll be back, but I don't know.'' said Mr. Drake, who has worked on the line since 1976. His wife works, he has no car payment to make, no credit cards to pay and only a small mortgage on his house.
''If I have to, I'll wait the 11, 12 months until my benefits run out,'' Mr. Drake said, ''and then I'll start worrying.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: The 1,600 General Motors employees recently laid off must decide whether they will wait to be called back, which could take up to two years, or whether they will leave the assembly line and find a new career. Some of the workers listened yesterday to employment counselors at the plant. (The New York Times/William E. Sauro)

HEADLINE: 'Sense of Belonging' Keeps Carril at Princeton

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
Every now and then an offer would be made, and Pete Carril would have to decide, again, whether he wanted to remain the basketball coach at Princeton University or depart for a place where a coach's life could be simpler.
How simple? There is that world out there where scholarships are awarded on the basis of athletic ability, where centers are 6 feet 10 inches and taller, where athletes perform feats of great skill and coaches are paid major dollars to direct them. Even now, the thought of having that type of athlete in Jadwin Gym pushes his eyebrows upward.
''Pretty good, right?'' he said. ''But the response comes back: If he was 6-10 or 6-11, he wouldn't be playing for you.'' 
 
The Telling Sign
The reality could have been changed if Carril said yes when that other world was calling with some frequency. But when it did, something strange would happen. ''When I have a difficult decision to make,'' he said, ''I get a paralysis in my left arm. It's like anxiety. Once the decision is made, it begins to disappear.''
In an era that has seen games transformed into highly marketable properties and coaches abandon athletes they recruited for the sake of security or opportunity, Pete Carril's 23d Princeton team has secured an eighth appearance in the national collegiate tournament.
Next season, depending on the outcome of a computer evaluation of the relative strengths of conferences, the Ivy League's entry into the national tournament may not be so simple.
With 31 conference champions eligible for the field, and only 30 automatic bids in the 64-team field reserved for those teams, the leaders of the two lowest-rated conferences will have to compete for a position in the field. Which would mean that the Tigers, who one tournament ago were one controversial call away from the chance to defeat a No. 1-seeded team, could be placed in the position of a qualifier.
''I think it's wrong,'' Carril said the other day. ''It's unacceptable. But it's understandable. And it's unavoidable. For the schools that are concerned about revenue, they're going to get the same amount of revenue. We're not concerned that much about the revenue. What we're concerned about is a sense of belonging. You'd like to have a little sunshine in your life.''
Princeton (20-6) won the league championship with home victories over Cornell and Columbia last weekend, and now a National Collegiate Athletic Association computer will dictate some low-seeded position for the Tigers and they will be dispatched anywhere from Hartford to Long Beach, Calif., to meet one of the best 12 teams in the nation, and perhaps one of the top 4.
And then the Tigers will attempt to produce the type of effort that last March gave the tournament one of its more unlikely moments in years: the 50-49 loss to top-seeded Georgetown on St. Patrick's night. That loss in-spired congratulations for weeks and restored some self-esteem to Ivy League programs, but it did not change the role of the Tigers in the national basketball marketplace. ''The supermarket goes up,'' Carril said, ''and the little guy down the block has to sell his oranges. Milk costs more. Meat costs more. So the little guy goes out of business.''
 
No Network Offers
Princeton's most recent moment of athletic glory did not inspire network officials to beat down any doors. ''Let's say we opened the season this year with Georgetown,'' Carril said. ''We could have gotten on TV with that.'' It was mentioned that John Thompson, the Hoyas' coach, made it clear he had seen enough of Princeton.
''I might say we had enough of them, too,'' Carril ididanansmsmedede At a time when the offices of coaches are littered with videotape cassettes, Carril sits in a room that is dominated at one end by reminders of Princeton's past: neatly stacked and carefully labeled reels of film. A brown paper bag rests on the floor, near his left foot. A paper cup of soup, which has just been removed from the bag, is lunch.
''We don't have great basketball players in our league,'' he said. ''We have very good players and good players. I don't think anybody can expect more, considering the way things are done in the Ivy League, academically and in a financial way. It's not going to happen.'' The emotional national discussion of how to deal with athletes with combined college board scores of less than 700 points out of 1,600 takes place a solar system away. Academic credentials have always limited the league's pool, but economics have intensified Carril's limitations. There are roughly 21,020 reasons each year why a motivated student and outstanding athlete would choose to go elsewhere, and not even Carril can argue with that.
''When it comes down to Princeton and Duke, are you going to go to school for free, or are you going on your savings?'' he asked. ''That one is tough, because Duke is a good school. Not as highly ranked as ours, but it's a good school.''
 
Finally, He Really Is 59
All the while, as he has writhed in his seat on the Tiger bench as the result of a player's mistake or an official's judgment, or forcefully lent his players post-game criticism - constructive or otherwise - the Carril era has often given every appearance of self-inflicted torture. At 59 years, after 408 victories, 395 of them at Princeton, Carril is only now beginning to reach the age he has looked for years.
When the phone rang with opportunities - once, he said, from a professional team, the rest from colleges - the coach's left arm held proof that the genuine torment would be the contemplation of a goodbye. ''Every time I thought about it, I always had a guy on my team I liked, that I felt responsible for, and to,'' Carril remembered. ''The first time, Armond Hill was a freshman. I really liked that kid. I wanted to coach him. Then I had Frank Sowinski and Billy Omeltchenko. I really liked them, too. I said, 'No.'
''And then the next time, I had Craig Robinson, Richie Simkus and Gordon Enderle. The next time, I had Billy Ryan. Whenever it happened, there was someone I liked. It created a little dilemma. Thank goodness it's a little dilemma.''
Combine enough dilemmas and the result is an era. Carril estimates this one will last five more seasons, and then he has this idea of retirement:
''I wouldn't mind hooking on with a pro team,'' he said. ''I really would. I'd like to help some young guy out. Tell him some individual things. I wouldn't even sit on the bench. Sit in the press box somewhere and watch the game. And at halftime go down there and tell him what I saw. Nothing big.''
That is how his life could become simpler. Carril could play a part in the game without being dominated by the games. ''Just work on fundamentals,'' he said. ''Go in there and say hello to the head coach and say, 'What do you want me to do today?' '' Another Serious Problem? That is a question for another era. His oranges are still worth buying, and there will soon be another opportunity to force a highly ranked, high-profile operation to look at a first-round game as a suddenly serious problem.
Not that Carril would gloat about that. Until Princeton's latest championship weekend, he considered Yale a team of destiny and the only vibrations he felt were bad. At the start of another March, the coach would like you to believe the Tigers are on their own.
''Like I've told them,'' Carril said, ''if they're waiting for me to teach any more basketball than I've taught them, I don't know any more.''
