HEADLINE: Defender of Rain Forest Is Named Secretary of Environment in Brazil

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 5

 BODY:
A pioneer conservationist is about to become Brazil's new Secretary of Environment.
The official, Jose Antonio Lutzenberger, was named last Friday by Brazil's President-elect, Fernando Collor de Mello. He will assume his new duties when the government takes office here on March 15. 
Over the last two decades, Mr. Lutzenberger built a worldwide reputation by assailing Brazilian governments over the burning of the Amazon rain forest, uncontrolled use of pesticides and invasions of Indian lands.
''It's stupefyingly positive - no one has more consistently fought for environmental awareness and legislation in Brazil than Jose Lutzenberger,'' Stephan Schwartzman of the Environmental Defense Fund in Washington, a longtime critic of Brazil's environmental policies, said today.
''It is difficult to imagine someone with a more solid international and national reputation on the environment,'' said Mr. Schwartzman, who is an anthropologist.
 
Repairing Brazil's Image
Indeed, a desire to repair Brazil's international image on environmental issues undoubtedly pushed Mr. Collor in recent days to assiduously court Brazil's crusty, 63-year-old environmental pioneer. Mr. Lutzenberger, an agronomist who speaks fluent English, French, German and Portuguese, emerged in the 1980's as an international spokesman for Brazil's fledgling environmental movement.
In 1984, he testified before the United States Congress against a World Bank loan for development of the Western Amazon. In 1988, the Swedish Parliament awarded him the ''Right Livelihood'' award, an environmental distinction billed by the parliamentarians as an ''alternative Nobel Prize.''
To win the support of the internationally respected environmentalist, Mr. Collor appears to have given ground on a key issue in the Amazon - the construction of a highway linking the untapped hardwood forests of the Western Amazon with Peru's Pacific Ocean ports.
''The private talks I had with Mr. Collor lead me to think that the road is not going to go forward,'' Mr. Lutzenberger said in a telephone interview today from his office in the southern Brazilian city of Porto Alegre.
''The only people really interested in that road are the Japanese wood industry,'' said Mr. Lutzenberger. ''It would be disastrous for the Amazon.''
As Brazil's top environmental official, he will have authority over environmental units that Mr. Collor promises to create in each of Brazil's 12 ministries. Mr. Lutzenberger will also oversee the Institute of Environment and Renewable Natural Resources, whose president, Fernando Cesar Mesquita, steps down in 10 days. $117 Million Loan Unlike his predecessor, Mr. Lutzenberger may have the means to carry out his plans. Last week the World Bank approved a $117 million loan to Brazil for environmental education, research and protection.
''Priority No. 1 is Amazonia; we have to reverse the devastation there,'' Mr. Lutzenberger said today. Mr. Lutzenberger, who in 1971 helped found one of southern Brazil's most militant ecological organizations, spent years in the 1950's studying soil science and agricultural chemistry at the University of Louisiana.

The Economy
Corporate income taxes have produced much less revenue than was predicted when the monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986 was enacted, and individuals have made up the shortfall. A main political selling point of that law was the expectation that $120 billion in taxes would be shifted from individuals to corporations. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: Melamed Leaving as Head of Chicago Merc

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 5

 BODY:
Leo Melamed, whose leadership transformed the Chicago Mercantile Exchange from a sleepy backwater where mostly agricultural products were traded into a leading arena for the management of interest-rate and currency risks, announced today that he would relinquish his exchange duties at the end of the year.
Mr. Melamed, whose name has become synonymous with commodity and financial futures trading, said that he would step down from his $500,000-a-year job as chairman of the exchange's executive committee and as special counsel to the exchange's board.
Mr. Melamed, 57 years old, said that after 23 years in the exchange's leadership he had sacrificed enough and would now devote himself to his family, to trading for his own account, to managing the commodity firm he owns and to writing his memoirs and fiction. In 1987, Bonus Books of Chicago published Mr. Melamed's science-fiction novel, ''The Tenth Planet.'' He plans to write a sequel. 
''I want to recapture my life,'' Mr. Melamed told a crowded news conference here. ''I want to smell the flowers along the way while I can.''
No successor to Mr. Melamed was named, and the indications were that there would be none. Exchange officials suggested that Mr. Melamed's responsibilities would likely be shared by William Brodsky, the exchange's president and chief executive; John T. Gelderman, the chairman of the exchange's board of governors; Jack F. Sandner, a senior policy adviser to the exchange, and by other top exchange officials.
''Leo is irreplaceable,'' Mr. Brodsky said. ''In two short decades, he had led the futures industry to unparalleled dimensions, and he has shaped the Chicago Mercantile Exchange into a world-class institution. To say he will be missed is the ultimate understatement.''
The announcement caught the brokerage industry by surprise. ''I'm shocked,'' said T. N. Grant, the president of Refco Group Ltd. of Chicago. ''His retirement is a tremendous loss to the industry. He has made an enormous contribution and he will be missed.''
Indeed, Mr. Melamed is leaving an indelible imprint - not only on the mercantile exchange but on financial markets in general.
 
Futures Trading
Mr. Melamed's biggest contribution was to develop the idea of a financial future. In the early 1970's, he proposed a currency future that would allow banks, insurance companies, and other corporations to shield themselves from swings in currency rates. The financial future, like any other future contract, is an agreement to deliver a set amount of a commodity or cash in the future at a fixed price.
Working with Milton Friedman, the Nobel laureate in economics, Mr. Melamed won Government approval in 1972 to trade contracts based on movements in the Swiss franc, the West German mark, the Canadian dollar and the Japanese yen. Later, what the exchange came to call its International Monetary Market was expanded to cover the Australian dollar and the British pound.
It was not until 1981, however, that the importance of Mr. Melamed's concept was to be fully appreciated. That year, the exchange introduced the first futures contract to be settled in cash. It allowed corporations to protect themselves against swings in interest rates.
And one year later, in 1982, Mr. Melamed's concept was again put to use, this time in the creation of a futures contract whose value would be tied to the level of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Since then, these ''index futures'' have come to be used by institutional investors around the world as a way to speculate on the direction of the stock market or to provide a level of insurance against a decline in the market, what investment professionals called ''portfolio insurance.''
 
Factor in Crash
To the extent, however, that portfolio insurance can cause declines in stocks themselves, the mercantile exchange has had to defend itself against criticism that its financial futures contribute to market instability. That is what happened in October 1987, when outsiders accused traders in the S.& P. 500 index of contributing to the stock market crash.
Mr. Melamed, however, came to the traders' defense. An often fiery orator who holds a law degree, he first placed advertisements in national newspapers to defend his exchange's activities. He then proved to be a convincing industry spokesman before Congress, providing testimony that helped stave off legislation that would have severely restricted commodity trading.
Mr. Melamed soon faced a new problem: the threat of tighter regulation by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission after disclosure of a ''sting'' operation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the exchange's floor and at its larger rival, the Chicago Board of Trade. Worried that news of the sting might destroy the futures industry's image, Mr. Melamed assembled a panel of experts to recommend changes in commodity-trading practices and regulation. While the futures industry must now operate under tougher constraints, it remains largely self-regulated.
Critics have noted that it was on Mr. Melamed's watch that these abuses took place, saying that the exchange's leadership failed to take preventive steps.
Lately, Mr. Melamed's attenton has been focused on Globex, the after-hours electronic trading system he was also instrumental in developing. Globex is running behind schedule and has caused some internal battles at the exchange, but most experts agree that the computerized system will help insure the continued competitiveness of the exchange at a time when futures markets worldwide are competing for business.
 
Emigrated From Poland
Born in Poland, the son of Yiddish teachers, Mr. Melamed moved with his parents to Chicago in the early 1940's. Years later, Mr. Melamed drove a cab to pay his law-school tuition and to support his wife and child. Shortly after graduating from law school, he borrowed $3,100 from his father to begin trading egg futures at what was then the mercantile exchange's predecesor. Striking it rich, he organized young members of the exchange into a coalition that in 1967 elected him to his first position in the exchange's leadership, a seat on the exchange's board of governors.
When he joined the board, stock traders in the East either thumbed their nose at the Chicago exchange or considered it to be populated by ruffians and hayseeds. By persuading corporations of all stripes to hedge their currency and interest-rate risks at the exchange, Mr. Melamed helped raise the self-esteem of its members, and the exchange's reputation and influence grew.
''We've achieved a level of respect,'' Mr. Melamed said. ''We're an equal in our industry.''

HEADLINE: Rate Moves: No Firm Global Link

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
When interest rates go up in one major industrial country, must they also do so in others? The recent rise of West German, Japanese and American rates, in tandem, has given that impression. But plenty of room still exists for the United States to control its own interest rates, even going against the trend in other countries.
The United States, in fact, has been quietly going against the global grain for over a week. While people buying German and Japanese bonds have insisted upon somewhat higher interest rates in return for their money, those buying American securities have settled for rates that have remained essentially unchanged since late February.
''Interest rates in one ocean bay are affected by rates in another bay,'' said Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economic science. ''But they don't mingle perfectly. There is considerable room for differences.'' 
The differences stem from such distinctly national phenomena as whether investors consider a particular country a safe place to put their money and whether a nation's inflation rate is rising or falling.
These differences, however, did not show themselves in January, when German and Japanese interest rates suddenly rose and American rates went up with them. The phenomenon seemed to confirm the often-cited ''pool of money'' thesis, which holds that a worldwide pool of savings exists, one that moves easily across borders, seeking the highest rate of return, as measured by interest rates. The rates are offered to attract money for such things as financing the American budget deficit or the rebuilding of East Germany.
There is such a worldwide pool of savings and it does move across borders, but not as easily as theory suggests and not in such single-minded response to the highest bidder, economists say. The problem is that the demand for loans is rarely as great as the worldwide supply of savings, so rates do not have to rise to compete for funds. ''Using the concept of funds flowing across borders to explain interest rate movements is a trap,'' said Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant. ''Rates can change in one country or another without any great demand for money.''
 
Behind the Divergence
As if to demonstrate the point, American, German and Japanese rates have begun to decouple, marching once again largely to their own tunes. Economists cite two major reasons for the divergence.
One is safety or, more specifically, whether investors feel sure that money invested in one country's securities will not suddenly disappear or suffer an accident. Right now, concern is growing about the safety of money in Japan and Germany. Japanese stock prices have plunged in recent weeks, suggesting that the Tokyo stock exchange might be flirting with a crash. And investors are nervous about the economies in Eastern Europe.
In these uncertain situations, American securities are often thought of as a safe place to park money, even though Japanese and German interest rates keep rising, as they have in recent days to lure the money to Tokyo and Europe.
 
Inflation Concerns
The second reason why interest rates go in different directions is the most important, involving a distinctly national phenomenon that money brokers everywhere refer to as their ''expectations'' about inflation. ''Right now, they expect the inflation rate to rise more in Japan and Germany than in the United States,'' said Nicholas Sargen, chief of bond research at Salomon Brothers.
The mechanics are plain enough. When inflation seems to threaten in Germany, for example, an investor thinking of buying German bonds reasons this way: Why purchase a bond that yields 9 percent when inflation in that country might rise to an annual rate of, say, 6 percent or 7 percent, diluting most of the income's purchasing power, not only in Germany but probably elsewhere as well. Better to buy an American bond that pays 8.5 percent interest and count on the American inflation rate of 4.5 percent to remain unchanged.
If the expectation about the American inflation rate turns out to be correct, then only about half the purchasing power of the income from the Treasury note would be eaten up. The ''real'' return would be 4 percent (the 8.5 percent yield minus the 4.5 percent loss to inflation) while the real return on the German bond would be only 2 or 3 percent.
 
Seeking the 'Real' Return
Just this sort of thinking is now in evidence. Interest rates on German and Japanese 10-year bonds have risen by one-quarter to one-half a percentage point since Feb. 22, reaching 7.12 percent yesterday in Japan and 8.97 percent in Germany. But the rate on 10-year United States Treasury notes has held steady at just above or just below 8.5 percent, closing yesterday at 8.63 percent. Americans, and also foreign investors, have gone for the higher ''real'' return on American securities, and as they bought the dollars needed to purchase them, the dollar rose in value.
Never mind that actual inflation is less of a problem in West Germany and Japan today than it is in the United States. The annual inflation rate in the United States is now 4.5 percent, compared with rates in Germany and Japan of less than 3 percent. But the expectation is that inflation will get worse in Japan because of its booming economy and in West Germany because of the financial strain in rebuilding East Germany.
A third factor that makes interest rate movements a national rather than global phenomenon is the power of the major central banks to manipulate interest rates on short-term securities. Changes in these rates usually influence long-term rates, independently of international forces.
 
'Large Exaggeration'
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, weighed in on this point in Congressional testimony last week. He said that while there is influence from rising rates in Germany and Japan, ''the presumption that it ties our hands and makes our monetary policy ineffective is a very large exaggeration.''
If all this is true, why then did American, German and Japanese rates rise in unison from early January through mid-February? Some economists, among them A. John Steigmann, research director at the Ford Motor Company, call what happened ''largely a coincidence.'' Three factors came together in December to create the global rise in rates.
One was the view that the American economy had finally gotten as weak as it was going to get and would rebound in the new year, pulling up the American inflation rate as the demand for goods intensified. Suddenly, a 7.7 percent yield on the 10-year Treasury note did not seem so appetizing, and it rose to offset the expected erosion from a higher inflation rate, reaching 8.66 percent last month before expectations changed again. Fresh data about the American economy have convinced the bond market, for the moment, that last year's 4.5 percent inflation rate might continue unchanged, after all, into 1990.
Simultaneously in December, rates rose in Japan because a new chief of the Bank of Japan called attention to the potential for a higher inflation rate in that country, and tried to head it off by pushing up Japanese interest rates. That was a classic tactic of central banks. Higher rates discourage spending financed with loans, thus reducing the demand for goods.
Also in December, expectations changed in West Germany. The Berlin wall was breached and suddenly there was talk of extending the West German currency to East Germany, giving 15 million East Germans, in one fell swoop, the wherewithal to buy West German goods. That is potentially inflationary.
What's more, the expectation arose that West Germany would need higher interest rates to attract billions of dollars from the world's pool of savings to finance the rebuilding of East Germany. ''Markets run in anticipation of real events that might never materialize,'' said Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economic consultant.

HEADLINE: End-of-Month Vehicle Sales Decline 7.9%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 5

 BODY:
Sales of domestic cars and light trucks fell 7.9 percent in late February, dimming hopes that a sales surge at the beginning of the month had signaled an end to the automobile industry's slump.
''The industry still has not emerged from the woods,'' said Maryann N. Keller, an auto industry analyst with Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney. ''The fact that sales are down in February compared with January is not a good sign.''
On a seasonally adjusted basis, cars sold at an annual rate of 6.8 million for the entire month of February, down from 7.1 million a year earlier and well below the January sales rate of 7.5 million. But the seasonal rate improved from December, when cars sold at a rate of 6.5 million. 
 
One Encouraging Sign
The lackluster results were still encouraging to some analysts, who noted that vehicle sales actually picked up after a dismal reporting period in the middle of the month.
''The auto industry has reduced inventories dramatically, and it looks poised for a very nice second quarter,'' said John V. Kirnan, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company.
Sales of light trucks, which account for nearly a third of vehicles sold in the United States, also declined by 10 percent in late February. For the month, light-truck sales dropped 6.7 percent.
Sales of cars and light trucks, including imports, fell 4.6 percent in the month, to a total of 725,153 cars and 330,694 light trucks.
The sales results for February suffered by comparison with last year, when the big auto makers kicked off a round of incentives that resulted in higher sales. Some analysts suggested that big discounts in January had contributed to the monthly sales decline, by drawing buyers who might otherwise have waited and bought cars in February.
 
Dealers Wait to Order
But dealers reported that they were still holding back on orders for many new cars and trucks, as showroom traffic and sales volume dwindled during a normally slow month.
Some analysts suggested that potential buyers were concerned about a slowing economy, postponing new vehicle purchases. ''It's more of a weakness in consumer confidence rather than a downturn,'' said Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's survey of consumer attitudes.
The Ford Motor Company's car sales plunged 24.5 percent for the 10 days, and the Chrysler Corporation suffered an 11.6 percent downturn in car sales.
''Ford's 10-day performance results from being extremely lean in inventory,'' Mr. Kirnan said.
The General Motors Corporation fared relatively better than its domestic rivals, with car sales down 3.8 percent for the 10-day period and down 6.4 percent for the month.
Ford's truck sales fell 10.8 percent in late February.
 
End of Rebates Hurts Chrysler
Chrysler suffered the results of discontinued rebates on its mini-vans. Sales of Chrysler's light trucks dropped 21.3 percent in late February, and car sales fell 11.6 percent.
''Chrysler took incentives off the most important vehicle, Voyager,'' said Joseph C. Masterpaul, sales manager at South Bay Chrysler-Plymouth in Torrance, Calif., referring to one of the popular mini-van models. ''And that one move made February a slow sales month.''
The Voyager normally outsells all other Chrysler cars and trucks at his dealership, Mr. Masterpaul said, accounting for half of the dealership's sales. While South Bay is continuing to stock up on mini-vans, ''we're still holding off on orders for other Chrysler vehicles until we can see signs of something positive happening,'' he said.
The Japanese producers that build cars in the United States - known as ''transplants'' - posted gains for the 10 days and the month, with the exception of the Nissan Motor Company.
The Japanese transplants accounted for 10.2 percent of February car sales, up from 7 percent in 1989. Import sales volume for the month remained steady at 26.5 percent of the market this year and last.
The foreign brand share of the car market, consisting of imports and transplants, amounted to 36.7 percent of sales in February, compared with 33.5 percent last year.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief Executive Post For Armco President

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Armco Inc., the nation's fifth-largest steelmaker, announced yesterday that Robert L. Purdum would be the company's next chief executive, succeeding Robert E. Boni.
Mr. Purdum, 54 years old, is currently Armco's president and chief operating officer. He will assume his new post April 27, the date of the annual shareholders meeting. He will continue as president. 
Mr. Boni, 62, chairman and chief executive, will stay on as chairman and devote his efforts to board matters as well as strategy and technology, the company said.
The announcement held no surprises. Mr. Purdum is a longtime Armco executive who is likely to keep the company on its present course. Neither Mr. Boni nor Mr. Purdum was available for interviews yesterday, an Armco spokesman said.
In a statement, Mr. Boni said his decision to step down as chief executive was ''part of a succession plan we have had in place for some years.'' He added that ''the time has come for me to turn over the day-to-day guidance of this company to a man who has more than earned the opportunity.''
Under Mr. Boni, Armco, which is based in Parsippany, N.J., struggled back from the brink of financial disaster and is now showing a profit. But its income for the fourth quarter of last year dropped 51.6 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier. The company cited a softening economy, particularly in the auto industry.
Last year, Armco sold 40 percent of its Eastern steel division to the Kawasaki Steel Corporation of Japan for $350 million in a bid to make its operations more efficient and to lower costs.
Mr. Boni gives Mr. Purdum some of the credit for pulling the company through in the years of its worst financial problems. ''Bob Purdum and I have worked together over the past five difficult years, first to survive, and then to build this company into a strong, competitive force in the industry,'' Mr. Boni said.
Mr. Purdum joined Armco in 1962 after graduating from Purdue University as a civil engineer. In an interview when he was named president in 1986, Mr. Purdum said he had ''grown up with Armco'' and held a wide variety of jobs in most of its units. He and his wife, Arlene, have three sons.

HEADLINE: G.M. Plans To Merge Engine Units

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 5

 BODY:
In a move that analysts say may cut costs and improve efficiency, the General Motors Corporation disclosed plans today to consolidate its two engine operations into a single division.
The action further blends the identities of G.M.'s once-distinct car divisions, which were merged in 1984 into two automotive groups, Chevrolet-Pontiac-G.M. of Canada and Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac. Critics of the reorganization suggest that G.M. has lost some of its distinctiveness as a car maker, saying brand distinctions have blurred and lookalike cars have emerged from the two groups. 
 
Focusing Resources
But G.M. officials say the new engine division will bolster the company's market appeal by cutting out redundant operations and focusing resources on engine development.
''Outwardly, G.M. has worked hard to differentiate its models and get away from criticism that all of its cars look alike,'' said Michael M. Luckey of the Luckey Group, an auto industry consulting firm. ''At the same time, in their effort to make money and control costs, G.M. is trying to consolidate a lot of the things that are not outwardly visible, like engines.''
Company officials declined to say how much money could be saved by the consolidation. But they acknowledged some overlap in the cost-intensive design and engineering activities that go into developing engines.
''The recommendations to form a single engine division were not put together with the goal of idling plants and laying off people,'' said Charles C. Licari, a G.M. spokesman. ''On the other hand, we know there are efficiencies to be gained by integrating the operations.''
The auto maker now employs 20,000 in the engine-making operations of the two groups, which manufacture 19 different engines.
 
Stempel's Stamp Is Seen
The project bears the imprimatur of G.M.'s president, Robert C. Stempel, an engineer and a backer of the Quad 4 multivalve engine.
Industry analysts say many G.M. cars do not meet the demands of performance-conscious car buyers.
''Engines are super-important,'' Mr. Luckey said. ''One of the reasons that the Japanese continue to gain market share is because their multivalve engines give higher performance and better fuel economy.''

HEADLINE: Volvo Accord With Renault

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 5

 BODY:
The chairman of Volvo A.B., the Swedish auto maker, said today that it could take until the mid-1990's for the fruits of its alliance with France's state-owned Renault to show up in the form of higher profits.
Pehr G. Gyllenhammar said that while cost-cutting measures could be carried out almost immediately, significant payoffs from the alliance would take much longer. ''The big money will take four to five years, I think, because it has to do with the components and products that we can develop jointly,'' Mr. Gyllenhammar said.
The two auto makers on Feb. 23 announced an agreement in which they will take stakes in each other and work jointly in the future in such areas as research, product development and purchasing.
The accord aims to achieve economies of scale and to extend the reach of both companies, although each will remain legally independent. Executives at both companies say the Volvo and Renault brand names will remain distinct.
Renault's president, Raymond H. Levy, accompanying Mr. Gyllenhammer at a news conference, declined to say when he thought profits would improve as a result of the alliance.
Mr. Gyllenhammar reiterated that the decision to forge the agreement with Renault did not represent an effort by either of the partners eventually to take over the other.
Asked about rumors that Volvo was in talks with Mitsubishi Motors of Japan and the Chrysler Corporation of the United States on possible cooperation agreements or joint ventures, Mr. Gyllenhammar said, ''There's an ongoing dialogue in our business.''
Under terms of the accord with Renault, each partner can enter joint ventures and partnerships with other companies, provided that the other partner approves, he said.

HEADLINE: Kaifu Defends Trade Talks

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 5

 BODY:
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu told Parliament today that his meeting with President Bush had produced ''very good results'' in reducing economic friction and was not a case of one-sided yielding to United States pressure on trade issues.
''Do you really believe dialogue is bad?'' Mr. Kaifu asked the chairwoman of the Japan Socialist Party, Takako Doi, who delivered lengthy criticism of the policies of his Liberal Democratic Party. ''To avoid going backward, we must continue cooperating.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Down Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply in light trading yesterday as dealers, facing losses from a weakening market, chose to liquidate positions.
A number of factors contributed to the selloff, traders said, including revived rumors that the Bank of Japan is almost sure to raise its discount rate, currently at 4.5 percent, by at least half a percentage point. A rise in Japan's discount rate could lead to a further increase in Japanese market rates, which, investors fear, could have an adverse impact on interest rates in the United States.
In addition, market participants took little comfort from comments by Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. Mr. Parry, a well-known inflation hawk, said the inflation rate, currently at about 4.5 percent, is not likely to move lower until 1991. Bond prices move higher when inflation falls, so market participants are not likely to be encouraged by the forecast of inflation remaining at current levels for the foreseeable future. 
 
Effect of Auto Report
On the other hand, dealers for the most part shrugged off a report that showed auto sales weakened in February from the month before. The nation's Big Three auto makers sold a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.8 million vehicles last month, down from 7.5 million in January.
''The market is not paying any attention to fundamentals right now,'' one government-bond trader said. ''All of the economic news right now is bullish, but the Street got trapped long, and now they are getting out.''
Bad news for the economy, like the lower auto sales report, is good news for the bond markets because it is generally assumed that slower economic growth will lead to lower inflation. Lower inflation means higher real rates of return on fixed-income securities.
Dealers said the dollar, which declined slightly on foreign exchange markets in the face of concerted selling by major central banks, was not an influence in yesterday's selloff.
''The dollar was off a little bit, but not enough to explain the magnitude of the decline that we have had,'' said David Green, manager of government-bond trading at Chemical Bank.
 
Full-Point Declines
Price declines of more than a point, or more than $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, were recorded for some long-term issues.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at 98 14/32, down 37/32, to yield 8.64 percent. In late trading on Friday, the closely watched issue was offered at a price to yield 8.53 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 5/32, down 22/32, to yield 8.62 percent. Meanwhile, the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offerd at 99 18/32, down 14/32, to yield 8.59 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 29/32, down 1/8 of a point, to yield 8.55 percent.
Rates rose on new three-month and six-month Treasury bills offered at the weekly auction yesterday.
Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.85 percent, up from an average rate of 7.72 percent at the bill sale a week earlier. It was the highest rate on a three-month bill since the auction of Sept. 5.
Six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 7.79 percent, compared with 7.70 percent at the sale last week. The new rate was the highest since the six-month bill auction on Oct. 2.
 
Link to U.S. Rates
Despite concerns about a possible rise in the Japanese discount rate, analysts suggested that such an increase was not likely to move interest rates in the United States up by very much.
''Long-term interest rates in Japan are only 1.5 percentage points below where they are in the United States, yet inflation there is only about half a percentage point lower than it is here,'' said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides analysis on activity in the credit and foreign exchange markets. ''On that basis, it seems to me that the Bank of Japan has plenty of room to tighten monetary policy.''
In other fixed-income markets, traders said that prices of most actively traded investment-grade corporate bonds dipped by about 3/8 of a point in sympathy with the decline in Treasury prices.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, market participants said that prices of most issues fell by between 1/4 of a point and 3/8 of a point in light trading.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops After Selling By the Main Central Banks

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar dropped yesterday after a round of coordinated selling by central banks including the Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan, the West German Bundesbank and eight other European central banks.
The surprise of the day was that the Federal Reserve intervened by selling dollars for West German marks in addition to selling dollars for yen, which it has been doing since Feb. 23. The West German central bank, the Bundesbank, and the other European central banks all sold dollars for marks, traders said. The sale of dollars depresses the dollar's value. 
The dollar selling for marks by the Federal Reserve, which traders said the Fed did once, seemed to add to the belief that a joint effort was under way to keep the dollar from rising against the mark. This was taking place even though the dollar has been at the bottom of or below the range of 1.70 marks to 1.90 marks that the United States and its economic allies are believed to have agreed on.
In late trading in New York, the dollar was valued at 1.6965 marks, down from 1.7150 on Friday. Against the yen, the dollar was at 148.96, down from 150.25 on Friday, its highest close in New York trading in two and a half years.
The British pound continued to fall against the dollar, a decline that traders said reflected growing concern about inflation in England and worries about the future of the Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government. The pound fell to $1.6443, down from $1.6500 on Friday and $1.6983 a week earlier. The dollar also declined against other major European currencies and the Canadian dollar.
The decline of the dollar yesterday meant that the intervention had more impact than a similar round on Friday, when the Bundesbank first showed its concern about the rising dollar as it sold dollars for marks for the first time since Jan. 4. The dollar rose against the yen and fell only slightly against the mark.
The effort to prop up the yen has gone on for several weeks. The declining yen has been a significant factor in the fall of Japanese stock market. But there is still a stalemate in Japan over the decision to raise interest rates, which would help support the yen.
''You add a little bit of mystery with the Fed,'' said James T. McGroarty, senior vice president of Greenwich Captial Markets Inc., in Greenwich, Conn. He said the action seems to indicate that there ''still is a preference to see the dollar lower'' than the 1.70 level at the bottom of the range.
Mr. McGroarty acknowledged that the Fed selling of dollars for marks could signify less than he suspected. The Fed simply could have sold dollars for marks at the request of the Bundesbank, a courtesy extended between central banks.
The dollar's rally against the mark has reflected uncertainty over the inflationary consequences of the unification of the two Germanys and doubts about the Bundesbank's ability to contain that inflation.

HEADLINE: Careers;
A New Look At M.B.A. Education

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
NOT all M.B.A. students are created equal, a problem that has bothered faculties and deans for years.
Some of those working toward a master of business administration degree have majored in engineering, others in liberal arts. Some are foreign citizens with different cultures; others have personality difficulties. Many lack communications skills; some lack a knowledge of history, mathematics or languages that can give depth to careers. Most need more understanding of international affairs. 
Last week David H. Blake, since January the dean at the Edwin L. Cox School of Business at Southern Methodist University, presided at a regional meeting of liberal arts and business school professors. The conference, titled ''International Dimensions in U.S. Higher Education: New Directions in Business School and Liberal Arts Cooperation,'' was held at the Peat Marwick training center in Montvale, N.J.
Dr. Blake summarized the group's findings. One was that ''so many students lack language ability'' and another was that ''exposure to history, culture and political issues is so crucial to international understanding.''
In an interview, he said there would be a new ''commitment to individual assessments'' at his school to recognize differences in students' backgrounds.
Assessing such differences is an idea whose time has come in a world where diversity is widespread, Dr. Blake said. ''We now are trying to focus on the individual.''
Individual assessments are already being made at a few other schools, like Case Western Reserve University's Weatherhead School of Management, which measures each student's management abilities as a guide to developing the most effective program for that student.
Listing changes already in place at S.M.U.'s Cox school, Dr. Blake spoke of ''the effort to weave international and ethical considerations into courses.'' In another year there will be a business school requirement that students take at least one international course in area studies, like the Pacific Rim, or in cultural anthropology.
Citing the importance of a multi-disciplinary approach, he explained that as a professor ''I always talked about balance-of-payments problems in my political science courses.''
To strengthen the curriculum, he said, there would be more recognition of the value of a multi-disciplined faculty. In the past, when he was dean of the Rutgers University Graduate School of Management, he hired psychologists, sociologists, philosophers of science and even an art historian. ''It forces faculty members to think more broadly and talk to each other,'' he explained.
Dr. Blake, 49 years old, a Dartmouth College graduate who got his M.B.A. from the University of Pittsburgh and a Ph.D in international politics from Rutgers, was a professor at the Rutgers business school and later dean until his move to S.M.U., in Dallas.
Since 1974, he said, S.M.U. has called upon top corporate executives to meet the students. Because executives are not expected to provide jobs, the relationship remains relaxed. The discussions concern job opportunities, company problems, international aspects and executive life. For example, a top executive of a Dallas company took a half-dozen students in the corporate jet to a New York securities analysts' meeting at which he spoke.
In addition to its 11-month-long M.B.A. program with 160 students, S.M.U. offers the degree in evening classes for 350 students. In addition, 80 executive M.B.A. students are spending about two years in part-time studies to complete the program and take a trip abroad, this year to Britain.
One interesting, and largely undocumented, change at graduate business schools, he said, involves the growing use of endowed chairs, both to attract new faculty members and to encourage those already on the staff. The chairs, usually named for a donor, enable schools to offer higher pay. S.M.U. has about a dozen business school chairs, he said. As a lure for younger faculty members, S.M.U. has ''named professorships,'' which last five years.
One indication of this trend came last week when New York University's Stern School of Business named Dr. Richard Sylla, a leading economic historian, to its new professorship of the history of financial institutions and markets, endowed by the economist Henry Kaufman.
Dr. Sylla was most recently a professor and associate head of the economics and business department at North Carolina State University. His history specialty is one that many graduate school deans like Dr. Blake say will have growing importance at a time when the nation faces crises like the failure of many savings and loan institutions, the overlending by major commercial banks to developing countries, and the collapse or near collapse of some large investment houses.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Webster and Cheney at Odds Over Soviet Military Threat

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
The Director of Central Intelligence and the Secretary of Defense are at odds over whether the Soviet Union will continue to pose a serious military threat to the United States and the West.
The dispute, embarrassing to an Administration that has tried to keep divisions hidden from public view, arose last week when the Director of Central Intelligence, William H. Webster, said American intelligence experts believed it unlikely that the Soviets would pose a major conventional military threat in the forseeable future, even if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is replaced by hard-liners.
Mr. Webster's assessment drew a pointed response over the weekend from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who said in a television interview that Mr. Webster's remarks were ''not helpful'' to his efforts to win approval of the Bush Administration's defense spending proposals.
 
Dispute Over Core Issue
Mr. Cheney seemed nettled by the timing of Mr. Webster's comments, which were made to the House Armed Services Committee at a time when the Defense Secretary is seeking to persuade the same committee not to make large cuts in military spending. 
But the two men appear to be in disagreement over the core issue of whether the Soviet Union will remain a rival to the West in the long-term future. Mr. Cheney has repeatedly argued that Moscow will pose a potentially serious military threat for some time, regardless of who is in power.
''No one predicted what's transpired in the Soviet Union in the last few years,'' he said on Sunday. ''So I'm a little reluctant to make hard and fast judgments about the future that assume that the Soviet peaceful intentions will continue, that Gorbachev will be successful and that the Soviets will never again adopt a hostile policy toward the rest of the world.''
 
Differences Played Down
A Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, said today that Mr. Cheney and Mr. Webster differ ''on predictions for the future'' but basically agree on the current state of the Soviet military and the nation's political situation.
The White House played down any difference between the two men. President Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today that their views of the Soviet military capability ''are not mututally exclusive, but indeed give us a good picture of the problem.''
The White House said today that officials there had read Mr. Webster's remarks before they were delivered to the Armed Services Committee and saw ''no problems'' with them.
A Pentagon spokesman said today that Mr. Cheney had not seen Mr. Webster's testimony before it was delivered. But a Bush Administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity said copies of Mr. Webster's remarks were given in advance to the National Security Council and to aides to Mr. Cheney and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.
 
Political Implications
The dispute has important policy and political implications because estimates of the Soviet threat are a key consideration in the preparation of the defense budget and military strategy, and are also likely to play an important role in Congressional discussions about whether to make deeper cuts in the Pentagon budget.
Within the intelligence community, Mr. Cheney's suggestion that Mr. Webster should hedge the conclusions of his analysts to suit the Bush Administration's effort to sell its Pentagon budget is regarded as an insult to the integrity of the intelligence system.
Mr. Webster's predecessor, William J. Casey, was sometimes accused of shading the judgments of C.I.A. analysts on such sensitive subjects as Nicaragua to manufacture support for the Reagan Administration's political goals. The accusation is regarded as an especially serious breach of ethics among intelligence experts.
A spokesman for the C.I.A., Mark Mansfield, today refused to concede even that Mr. Webster and Mr. Cheney disagreed, and he would not comment on Mr. Cheney's weekend criticism.
 
A Scheduled Breakfast
Asked several times to address the difference of opinion, Mr. Mansfield eventually replied, ''Our job is to provide the best information and analysis that we can, and that was reflected in Judge Webster's testimony to the House Armed Services Committee.''
Another Government official said the two men were expected to discuss the matter more thoroughly at a scheduled breakfast in the next few days.
Mr. Webster's testimony was his most extensive public statement to date on the Soviet military situation. In it, he acknowledged for the first time the possibility that Mr. Gorbachev might be ousted from office and succeeded by reactionaries who favor rebuilding the nation's offensive military capacity.
But even so, he said, ''there is little chance that Soviet hegemony could be restored in Eastern Europe.''
 
A Conflicting View
''A successor regime would face the same types of economic and political pressures that President Gorbachev has, and would probably continue to pursue arms control agreements with the West,'' he said. ''It would be unlikely, in addition, to seek a broad reversal of the changes that have occurred in Eastern Europe, or to try to reverse the Warsaw Pact.''
That view conflicts with Mr. Cheney's stated opinions on the Soviet conventional military threat. The Secretary's 1990 budget proposal states on its first page that Mr. Gorbachev's reductions in Soviet military capabilities in Europe and elsewhere ''are still relatively easy to reverse,'' and that the United States ''must be prepared to remain in long-term competition'' with the Soviets.
Similarly, Mr. Cheney told a Houston audience in January that changes in the Soviet Union ''are potentially reversible'' and that ''it would be very risky business for the United States to make policy based on the assumption that the transition we now see in the Soviet Union will continue on a peaceful, orderly basis.''
The Commerce Department is reworking proposed Federal limits on the export of high-performance computers to Western allies, agency officials said. Business Day, page D2.

LENGTH: 1637 words

HEADLINE: Daimler-Benz and Mitsubishi Negotiating Cooperative Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 6

 BODY:
In what may prove to be one of the most far-reaching industrial linkups, the largest business groups in Japan and West Germany, Mitsubishi and Daimler-Benz, said today that they were negotiating a plan of ''intensive cooperation'' in automobile technology, aerospace, microelectronics and a number of service industries.
If the agreement is completed, as executives on both sides said they anticipated, it will create a series of joint ventures that will give Daimler access to some of Japan's best technology and give the giant Mitsubishi empire a desperately needed foothold in Europe before that market is integrated in 1992.
The arrangement could also pose an enormous competitive challenge for the United States, pitting its biggest businesses against the combined talents and marketing skills of the two most aggressive industrial groups in the booming German and Japanese economies.
 
Areas of Interest
Japan is particularly interested in Daimler's jet engines and the prospect of building cars with the world's leading maker of luxury cars, Mercedes-Benz; Germany's main interest is electronics, high-technology equipment and space technology, all areas in which Mitsubishi excels.
In separate statements today, both companies said they would meet soon to work out specific accords, but Daimler said that they regarded the talks as ''promising of success.'' 
The announcement came after a secret meeting this weekend in Singapore involving the top executives of Daimler-Benz and the presidents or chairmen of the four biggest of the 29 Mitsubishi companies - Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Mitsubishi Motors, Mitsubishi Electric and the Mitsubishi Corporation. The Mitsubishi Corporation, the leader of the group, is one of Japan's biggest trading companies. The meeting was apparently suggested by Edzard Reuter, the energetic chairman of Daimler's managing board.
Neither side would say whether the two groups planned to take an equity interest in each other or whether the arrangement would go beyond cooperation in technology and marketing. But Daimler said, ''The independence of both groups will be respected.'' Daimler-Benz had sales of $37.3 billion in 1988, before its recent acquisition of Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H., the aerospace concern; the combined Mitsubishi companies had sales of about $82 billion.
In an unusual statement, Japan's powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry appeared to give its blessing to the deal tonight, saying, ''We welcome the two groups entering into broad-ranging cooperation at a time when international cooperation is seen in so many areas.''
But a senior ministry official acknowledged that the proposed alliance was rife with political problems. Members of the European Community are deeply suspicious of Japan's rush to enter the European market before 1992. On Monday, amid renewed debates over restraints on Japanese ''transplant'' auto plants in Europe, Edith Cresson, France's Minister for European Affairs, said Japan's ''strategy is to set up plants in Japan, Europe and America wherever they can and switch production so they can destroy U.S. and European auto makers.''
Moreover, both companies are closely associated with the rise of the Axis powers 50 years ago, a history that, one Japanese official said recently, ''will never go away.'' Mitsubishi Heavy Industries built the Zero, the durable fighter that led Japan's invasion forces throughout Asia; Messerschmitt built much of the Luftwaffe. Even today, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries is Japan's largest arms maker and Daimler is one of Europe's largest.
Japan is barred from exporting arms or arms technology, except for special agreements with the United States. And a Mitsubishi spokesman, Masao Takemoto, said tonight that the exchange of ideas and technology would ''specifically exclude defense.'' It is unclear how the two companies would handle what the military terms ''dual use technologies'' that can be used for both commercial and military purposes, like electronics or high-temperature metals used in jet engines.
The announcement of the agreement comes as a number of Japanese companies are scrambling to link up with European partners, or build their own operations in Europe. Most of Japan's leading car makers, for example, have announced plans to build plants within the European Community, except for Mitsubishi Motors, which has long been rumored to be negotiating with Mercedes for a production partnership. Mitsubishi helps market Mercedes in Japan.
 
To Relax Frictions
At a news conference today, attended only by Japanese reporters, Yoshio Taniguchi, vice president of Mitsubishi, reportedly said the company hoped the business alliance would relax trade frictions between Japan and the European Community. But he gave no specifics of the arrangements, saying only that the companies had scheduled further meetings.
The Singapore meeting, he said, was attended by Yotaro Iida, chairman of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries; Toyoo Tate, chairman of Mitsubishi Motors; Moriya Shiki, president of Mitsubishi Electric, and Shinroku Morohashi, president of the Mitsubishi Corporation. In addition to Mr. Reuter, Daimler was represented by its deputy chairman, Werner Niefer, who is also chairman of Mercedes-Benz.
The Japanese executives negotiating with Daimler run one of the most powerful industrial groups in the world, made up of the remnants of one of Japan's leading zaibatsu, or interlocking business groups. It was broken up by Gen. Douglas McArthur when he headed the postwar occupation.
Today the companies are perhaps more closely linked than at any time since the end of the war, sharing technology, holding one another's stock. The United States has protested that these ties give the Japanese companies an unfair advantage over American concerns trying to enter the market here.
Internally, the Mitsubishi group calls itself the ''Kinyokai,'' which literally means ''Friday meeting,'' an outgrowth of end-of-the-week meetings of top leaders of each of the companies.
 
Corporate Turnaround
Over the last decade, that meeting has been the breeding ground of a sweeping corporate turnaround involving most, though not all, of the Mitsubishi members. Until the early 1980's the group was known for steady but plodding growth and little imagination. Today revenues and profits have soared, and the group has edged out its three main competitors among the conglomerates in Japan - Mitsui, which includes Toshiba); Sumitomo, which includes NEC, and Fuyo, which includes Nissan and Hitachi. Mitsubishi has also been involved in some of Japan's biggest and most controversial projects.
Moreover, Mitsubishi's reach within Japan is unusually long, presumably the main reason Daimler sought it out in the German company's diversification plans. Its members make Nikon cameras, Kirin beer, steel, petrochemicals, rockets and luxury cruise ships, and they include the huge Mitsubishi Bank and the real estate group that bought a controlling interest in Rockefeller Center last fall. It also owns most of the central business district in Tokyo, purchased in 1890 by the company's second president, Yanosuke Iwasaki, when it was still covered with grass and bamboo.
''To the Japanese consumer, we are like the air: invisible but pervasive, providing essential things to sustain life,'' Yohei Mimura, the company's chairman, said some time ago.
 
Needed Technologies
For all of its power, though, Mitsubishi is in great need of several technologies that it may gain from Daimler. Many are in aerospace. Although Mitsubishi Heavy Industries is building the FSX fighter jet with General Dynamics, and is one of three companies working with Boeing on a new aircraft, it has never been able to design its own aircraft engines or develop a successful commercial plane. Daimler owns an engine maker and, through Messerschmitt, owns West Germany's 37.9 percent stake in Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium.
Mitsubishi Motors, meanwhile, is engaged in a big struggle at home to remain a main force in the Japanese auto market, where it is virtually tied for third place with Honda Motors. The company has had a long association with Chrysler, but the American car maker's recent troubles have sent company executives in search of a stronger partner. An alliance with Mercedes would be a coup, especially at a time that Mitsubishi Motors' two largest domestic rivals, Toyota Motors and Nissan Motors, are bringing out luxury cars directly aimed at the market dominated by Mercedes-Benz and BMW.
 
More Pressure on U.S.
American reaction to the announcement of talks between Daimler-Benz and Mitsubishi suggested that an alliance between the foreign giants would intensify the pressures on American companies to become more competitive.
''Certainly American industry is not in a position to criticize two private-sector companies getting closer together,'' said Howard Lewis, vice president for international economic affairs at the National Association of Manufacturers. ''It goes on all the time. This is increasingly the way the global environment works. But to the extent that this cooperation makes a competitive world even more competitive, it is all the more incumbent on America to wake up and put our own economy in a more competitive posture. We better get our act together.''
And John Ettlie, an associate professor of operations management at the University of Michigan,, said: ''It's definitely an important event with important implications. Clearly this puts more pressure on the European agenda. Up to now, I think there has been a relaxed attitude among American companies that the West Germans were reluctant to do joint ventures with the Japanese. This signifies a softening of that position.''

LENGTH: 1372 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans to Shift Responsibility For Many Road Pojects to States

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is drafting highway legislation that would concentrate Federal spending on major national arteries, while imposing on the states costly new responsibilities for building and maintaining local roads.
The Administration intends to pay for the Federal role without raising the Federal motor fuel tax, in keeping with President Bush's promise not to raise taxes, while urging states to raise their own fuel taxes.
Most of the Federal spending would be drawn from a highway trust fund made up of revenue from the Federal taxes on gasoline and diesel fuel. The fund has a surplus that officials estimate can support substantial increases in Federal highway spending for three years. The current level of Federal highway spending is about $14 billion a year. 
 
Routes of Special Significance
The program, say senior Transportation Department officials, would commit the Federal Government to expanded spending on about 160,000 miles of highways that are considered to have special national significance because they connect population and economic centers. The roads would include most of the Interstate System, many other expressways and some smaller highways crucial to their region.
In addition, about 740,000 miles of other roads would remain eligible for Federal aid, but under the Administration's thinking the responsibility for these routes would shift significantly toward state and local governments.
For motorists, the major concern about the highway program is whether it will achieve its goal of providing some relief to the growing congestion that plagues even the largest and most sophisticated roads. On Interstate highways in 1987, congestion bogged down 65 percent of urban rush-hour traffic and 17 percent of rural rush-hour traffic, the Administration's figures show.
 
Plan Long in the Making
The plan's premises will be set forth Thursday when President Bush presents a comprehensive new national transportation policy that has been under development for many months. Later that day, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner will discuss it at a Congressional hearing.
Its full details will not be published for several months, and Congressional debate about the proposals is likely to extend into next year.
No matter how the costs are shared, it seems virtually certain that motorists will be paying new fuel taxes, tolls and other fees, if not to the Federal Government then to states.
Reaction to the plan, which Mr. Skinner has explained at recent meetings with state highway officials, has been mixed.
''The Federal role has been shrinking steadily throughout the decade,'' said David Ernst, an official of the New York State Transportation Commission. ''This would shrink it further. We don't know quite what their definition of nationally significant highways is, but we're concerned they won't include most of our roads.''
But Carl B. Williams, assistant director for fiscal policy of the California Transportation Department, praised the Administration's approach. ''It permits each state to identify its priorities in the context of its own environment,'' he said. California already has a ballot initiative under way to raise its fuel tax by nine cents a gallon.
 
A Shift in Emphasis
Mr. Skinner said in an interview today that ''there is always going to be a major Federal role'' in highway systems. ''But traditionally,'' he added, ''the Federal Government has assumed an 80 percent role, in some cases a 90 percent role. That is not realistic.''
He said that if states ''have to come up with a 50 percent local share, they are going to pay much more attention to how the money is spent.''
Although the costs of the proposed program cannot be calculated until legislation to carry it out is submitted, it would clearly be in the billions of dollars. Some lawmakers say the highway program should exceed $100 billion over the five years beginning in September 1991, when the current five-year program expires.
The Administration's plan probably would probably increase the Federal budget deficit in its first few years as the trust fund shrinks and the Administration and Congress debate whether there should be an increase in the Federal fuel tax.
Mr. Skinner said the Administration was eager to speed up the rate of withdrawals from the fund to pay for the Federal road work. ''If we possibly can, we want to do it,'' he said.
The current surplus in the trust fund exceeds $10 billion and is growing each year. While highway spending is about $14 billion a year, fuel tax receipts total more than $16 billion a year.
Although some lawmakers favor increasing Federal fuel taxes, Mr. Skinner said the Administration remains opposed. As he has in the past, Mr. Skinner noted approvingly that many states have already raised their fuel taxes. He added that the opportunity to increase them further might be lost if the Federal Government ''pre-empted'' this source of revenue.
 
Most Extensive Program
The national highway program, which must be renewed by Congress every five years, is the nation's most extensive public works program and interest in the impending revision has been high among state and local governments, members of Congress and industry groups.
The Interstate System, 43,000 miles of highways begun by President Dwight D. Eisenhower, is 98 percent complete, but it is afflicted with congestion and decay, and policy makers have been pondering solutions for some time.
The highway program enacted in 1987 provoked a bitter fight after Ronald Reagan's veto was overridden by Congress. President Reagan said the bill was too costly and contained too many projects of strictly local benefit.
Gene McCormick, deputy administrator of the Federal Highway Administration, which is part of the Transportation Department, said in an interview that the agency was writing legislation to focus Federal money on modernizing and expanding the 160,000 miles of major roads, including most Interstates, that are essential to commerce and to regional transportation.
The additional 740,000 miles of roads that would remain eligible for Federal aid under the Administration's proposal states would require states to pay a larger share of the costs. States would be urged to increase their fuel taxes and would allowed to impose more tolls with a removal of the ban on tolls on most roads built with Federal assistance.
 
Changes in Fees Studied
The Administration is considering, but has not yet decided upon, changes in Federal methods of charging highway users for the enormous costs of roads. One possibility would be to charge commercial trucks fees based on their weight and the distance they travel, reflecting more accurately than a flat fuel tax the disproportionate damage the big vehicles do to roads and bridges.
Administration officials say the highway proposals are intended to complement other transportation projects, like urban mass transit systems, airports and passenger railroads. The entire transportation strategy is meant to address even broader social issues, like safety, environmental protection, urban renewal and rural growth, international trade and economic competitiveness, officials say.
Accounting for more than half of Federal spending on transportation, the highway proposals typify other parts of the broader transportation policy, calling for an increasing reliance on the states and local governments, additional user fees to pay for new investments and incentives for the private sector to bear a greater share of the investment burden.
''The highway system obviously is our most extensive transportation system and the one most people rely on most of the time,'' Mr. Skinner said. ''Anything we do on highways is going to be the most important part of our transportation policy.''
Representative Norman Y. Mineta, a California Democrat, said many members of his party believe highway spending will have to rise from the current $14 billion to as much as $23 billion a year to meet pressing needs. Mr. Mineta last year changed his role on the House Public Works and Transportation Committee so that he could head its surface transportation subcommittee when the new bill is drafted.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 2057 words

HEADLINE: Selma 1990: Old Faces and a New Spirit

BYLINE: By GAY TALESE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SELMA, Ala., March 6

 BODY:
The writer of the following article, a reporter for The New York Times from 1955 to 1965, was among those covering the civil rights march in Selma, Ala., in 1965.
Twenty-five years ago, after borrowing a tail-finned Cadillac hearse from the mortuary owned by his family in this onetime plantation town in south central Alabama, a young man named Randall Miller joined hundreds of other blacks as a volunteer ambulance driver in a civil rights march that was soon scheduled to head east to the state capital, Montgomery.
The distance to the Governor's office, where the marchers would protest the lack of voting rights for blacks in the Deep South, was a little more than 50 miles. But it would take 19 days to complete the journey, for it was marred by tear gas, billy clubs and the bullets of white racists.
 
Beyond Brutality
The moss-draped rural town of Selma, with its white-columned mansions and its many monuments to Confederate heroes, would continue for years to symbolize white racism in America. But now - a quarter century after the highway clash that was commemorated this past weekend by returning veterans of the march - Selma reflects much advancement in the quest for racial harmony. 
Not only interracial harmony, but also, on occasion, interracial love. Last weekend, the former ambulance driver, Randall Miller, now 51 years old, was married here to a 38-year-old white woman, Betty Ramsey.
They were married in the presence of 20 white and black friends in Mr. Miller's house, in an integrated neighborhood within hearing of the cheers from the thousands who attended the commemorative ceremonies. It is also within hearing of the screams of demonstrators re-enacting the terror of 1965, although on this occasion they were fleeing machine-blown smoke rather than the gas canisters that had stunned the original marchers while awakening the national conscience.
A Voting Rights Act was passed by Congress in the late summer of 1965, prompted in part by the brutal harassment of the demonstrators -especially during the first day's outing, on March 7, 1965. That afternoon, as millions watched on national television, a charging wedge of Alabama state troopers and a sheriff's posse gassed and battered marchers whom Randall Miller and others would rush to the few hospitals that accepted blacks; more than 80 were hurt.
The new law encouraged more black citizens to vote than ever before and in time led to the election of many more black candidates than ever before, not only in the South but throughout the nation.
Many of the 1965 activists who made speeches this weekend from a sound truck across the bridge are now paunchy and balding. As often as not, they went unrecognized by the young onlookers, whose sense of history is limited to their own short lifetime. This occasion was, in a sense, Old Timers' Day for those in the Selma vanguard.
But while parading through the center of town and crossing the steel bridge that arches over the muddy Alabama River, they were spry of step and smiling as they waved to the crowds and the television trucks that preceded them. On the bandstand along the highway, where some of them made speeches, they recalled the pain of Selma with words of lasting pride and satisfaction.
One of the speakers was John Lewis - at 25 a battered figure on the highway, at 50 a member of Congress representing Georgia's Fifth District. Microphone in hand, he told the crowd, ''I shed a little blood here, but I was blessed to make a small contribution.''
Near him stood the gray-bearded Hosea Williams, one of the lead marchers in '65; the Rev. L. L. Anderson, the slightly frail but erect 70-year-old preacher from Selma who was once a frequent guest in Southern jails; and his colleague in offenses against the sensibilities of Southern sheriffs, the 70-year-old F. D. Reese, who on the bandstand, resplendent in a kelly-green suit with lapel adornments, suggested a dignitary reviewing a St. Patrick's Day parade.
 
Confederate Statues, And One of King
Appearing in a well-fitting dark suit with a white shirt and subdued maroon silk tie, and looking very Presidential, was Jesse Jackson, the only speaker who truly required no introduction. He stood not far behind the seated Coretta Scott King, who said nothing to the crowd but by her presence lent exaltation to the sun-sharpened surroundings.
In this town there are now street signs and a monument in the name of her late husband, the leader of the Selma-to-Montgomery march, but more prominent still are the statues and larger monuments honoring those white Southerners who, during the Civil War, had no higher aspirations for black people than slavery. Higher than all the community landmarks is the bridge itself - bearing in bold lettering the name of Edmund Pettus, a Confederate general and later a United States Senator who went to his grave in 1907 believing in the supremacy of whites. He is buried in Selma. Most though not all of Selma's white citizens - 48 percent of the town's 25,340 people - stayed away from the weekend's commemorative activities. But one who was in evidence was Selma's loquacious white Mayor, the 60-year-old, bifocaled, chain-smoking Joseph T. Smitherman, to whom photo opportunities are a narcotic he can no more resist than cigarettes.
A onetime appliance salesman, and before that a brakeman for the Southern Railway, Mr. Smitherman has been Selma's Mayor, with a brief interruption, since its first days of televised notoriety. Since then he has been interviewed thousands of times and has an anchorman's ease in front of a camera. In 1965, when he was 35, he weighed 145 pounds; now, at 60, he is 56 pounds heavier, but he says he has never been happier.
 
A New Look In City Hall
As he stood on the sidewalk with other members of Selma's first family, waving toward the passing procession of blacks whether they greeted him or booed him, he said in several interviews that egalitarianism had never risen to such heights as exists these days in Selma. Although the Selma Country Club and the old-line Elks Club still refuse to admit blacks, he said, the rest of the city bears little resemblance to the Selma of 1965.
The Mayor, who still keeps a Confederate flag in his office, points out that 35 percent of the police force is black, as against zero in 1965. Blacks make up 25 percent of the firefighters and more than 90 percent of the sanitation workers. He cites similar statistics among other municipal employees, City Council members and teachers, and he minimizes the current dispute over the decision by the white-majority school board not to renew the contract of the city's first black Superintendent.
The Mayor considers the new wave of black activists impossible to please, insufficiently appreciative of the gains won by the previous generation. ''But,'' he conceded, in the philosophical tone he exuded in network interviews last week, ''the blacks are now doing the same thing we did 25 years ago. We hollered for 'segregation,' and played on the white people's fear of integration - and this got us elected. Now, 25 years later, the black elected officials, and black leaders not elected, are hollering 'white racism,' and 'de facto segregation' and 'economic oppression' to get elected, and they're doing a good job.''
One of the most powerful black figures in city government, the occupant of an office in City Hall that the Mayor complains has more space than his own, is the onetime volunteer ambulance driver and the town's most recent bridegroom - Randall Miller. After taking over the family funeral business in partnership with his aging father, he was appointed in 1972 to head the city's urban renewal program. In 1985 Randall Miller became the city's Director of Personnel, overseeing hiring and placement of the 300 employees in the police, fire, sanitation, public works, recreation and cemetery departments.
 
Integrated Schools, Integrated Couples
Mr. Miller did not take part in the voting rights celebration this week, being preoccupied with his wedding. Both he and his wife agree that her race signifies nothing except that interracial couples can carry on a courtship and have it culminate in a peaceful and pleasant wedding. (Both were married before, within their own race, and divorced.) Concurring in this opinion were other guests at the wedding: the bride's two daughters, age 18 and 15, who flew in from Arkansas (where they attended all-white schools, and where their father teaches in an integrated high school); and the groom's three sisters and brother, all natives of Selma who have taught in its once all-black school system.
The public schools in Selma are now integrated, although, as in cities throughout the nation, there are private schools here for those usually more affluent white parents who prefer a color balance in their favor.
Much as Randall Miller might wish to attribute little social significance to this weekend's wedding, the fact remains that only one other married interracial couple is known to be living in Selma. They are John Farris, 42 and white, and his wife, Roslyn, 36 and black, who teach at the Westside Middle School. Married in 1983 and both natives of Alabama though not of Selma, they have lived here since their wedding. They teach in a school that has an almost equal racial balance and whose acceptance of their interracial marriage is rather typical of the town.
''If you're open and honest about your relationship,'' Roslyn Farris said, ''and don't hide it and sneak around, they'll respect it - even in Selma.''
Another interracial married couple first met in Selma during the confrontations of 1965, and remain married today. They are Dr. and Mrs. John L. S. Holloman of New York City. Long affiliated with the William F. Ryan Community Health Center on West 97th Street, Dr. Holloman, who is black and will soon be 70, flew into Alabama in 1965 after the highway incident and lent medical support to the marchers continuing on to Montgomery.
Dr. Holloman was then part of the Medical Committee for Human Rights, the national organization formed in 1964 to give aid and a ''sense of medical presence'' to the civil rights demonstrators throughout the South and elsewhere. When Dr. Holloman arrived in Selma in 1965, some of his out-of-state colleagues were already busy treating the hospitalized marchers.
One of them was Dr. Alfred Moldovan, also of New York, the first doctor across the bridge after the cavalry of militia had begun to beat the marchers to the ground. With Dr. Moldovan and several other physicians and nurses, Dr. Holloman later accompanied the regrouped marchers on to Montgomery. A member of their medical team was a Brooklyn-born nurse from Kings County Hospital, Patricia Ann Tatje, whose bus-driver father she later identified with Archie Bunker.
 
Fellowship Recaptured
Midway along the road to Montgomery, Patricia Ann Tatje administered medical aid to the feet of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who had been wearing new shoes and was so blistered that he could not conceal his limping. Pausing briefly while she daubed his bare feet with Benzoin, Dr. King then again put on his shoes and socks, thanked her and, concealing the limp, continued on his way.
The nurse and Dr. Holloman, who fell in love after their return to New York, had by then divorced previous mates and were ready to marry - a union that would produce two daughters. They have also kept ties to their earlier families. And when Mrs. Holloman's daughter by her first marriage was married on Feb. 6, 1988, she walked up the aisle with her white natural father, Dr. Thomas Leo, and her black stepfather, Dr. Holloman.
Last week in New York, Dr. Holloman reflected on that happy day and reminisced about the bond that existed 25 years ago between the blacks and the out-of-state whites in Alabama after the highway confrontation. The wedding two years ago restored for him some of the blissful feelings he felt back in 1965, after the tear gas had faded.
As he walked up the aisle of the chapel, he was back on the path with whites toward a common cause. It was as it had been on the road between Selma and Montgomery, when everybody advanced together and held hands and rocked from side to side and joined in singing, ''We Shall Overcome.''
