HEADLINE: Iranian Report on Hostages Seen as a Signal to the West

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 6

 BODY:
West German and French officials said today that an Iranian newspaper editorial calling for freeing the Western hostages in Lebanon represented an Iranian admission that the West will widen economic and diplomatic ties with Iran only after the hostages are free.
The officials, who closely follow relations with Iran, said the editorial in The Teheran Times today was an early signal that Teheran's leaders acknowledge the significance of settling the hostage issue in a satisfactory manner, after five years of insisting that the hostages are bargaining chips.
The officials did not have any independent confirmation that a flurry of current moves on the hostages would lead to their early release. But a West German foreign affairs official said there were clear ''indicators'' of Iran's appreciation that ''there is no no further advantage in holding the hostages.'' 
''We all have hostages and our signals have always been clear that if Iran wants better ties with the West to reconstruct the country they have to go through the hostage doors and demonstrate respect for international law,'' said the official, who asked not to be identified. #1990 'the Last Year'
As the European officials discussed the editorial, Irfan Parviz, editor of The Teheran Times, insisted in a telephone conversation from Teheran today that the newspaper's editorial expressed only the view of the publication, but added that many people in the Government ''may also share this view.'' The paper, which is known to have close ties to Iranian Foreign Ministry circles, said in its editorial that ''1990 can and will be the last year of the captivity'' for Western hostages.
West German and French officials said one incentive for Iran to move on the hostage issue may be the severely deteriorating economic situation in the country and Iran's failure so far to break the unofficial economic freeze imposed on it by Western countries.
Over the last 18 months Iran has been able to secure limited credits for industrial projects from West Germany, France, Italy and Japan, but they fall far short of the enormous financial and technical assistance Iran needs to rebuild its shattered economy, particularly its vital oil industry.
While there have been reports from the Iranian opposition of widespread demonstrations against the Government, the Western officials dismissed them as exaggerated.
 
Questions of Dissatisfaction
They said there was a pro-monarchist demonstration in Teheran on Feb. 16, and that incendiary bombs were thrown twice at a fundamentalist school. But the officials reported that their embassies in Teheran did not agree that dissatisfaction with the Government has reached the point of threatening the clergy's rule over Iran.
One Iranian official based in Western Europe said the flurry of activities surrounding the hostage issue may not lead to the release of any of the 16 Westerners, including 8 Americans, held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian militias. The official said his ''guess'' was that non-American hostages were likely to be released first.

HEADLINE: Gephardt Proposes Aid to Soviets

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, said today that the United States should offer direct aid to the Soviet Union to insure that its reforms succeed.
''We should be investing in our own self-interest,'' Mr. Gephardt said. ''And stability, democracy and a market economy in the Soviet Union are in America's strong self-interest.''
The proposal brought immediate criticism from some quarters.
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said, ''The Soviet Union doesn't want direct aid.''
Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, also said that Soviet officials had not requested help from the United States and that if they did, the aid would be wasted without economic reform. ''Unless they reform the economy, it's going down a rathole,'' Mr. Bradley said.
Others on Capitol Hill said that although they thought that Mr. Gephardt's proposal would spark a useful debate, the idea would fall on disapproving public ears.
''If you're going to start giving foreign aid to the hated commies of 70 years' worth, you've got a real sales job to do in the United States,'' said Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming.
The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, said he agreed with Mr. Gephardt.
''It's a dramatically different circumstance from a few months ago,'' Mr. Foley said, noting that local elections that had taken place in the Soviet Union and the existence of political opposition to the Communists.
''Those changes are coming on very fast,'' Mr. Foley said, ''and we have a stake in this country in supporting those changes.''

HEADLINE: Postal Service Proposes Rate Increases

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
The United States Postal Service today proposed an increase in all classes of mail that would raise the price of a first-class stamp to 30 cents and increase costs to businesses for second- and third-class mailings by billions of dollars a year.
The Postal Service, which faces a $1.6 billion loss this years, expects to raise $7 billion a year in additional revenue from the rate increases.
The proposed five-cent increase in first-class mail is the biggest since universal rates were introduced 127 years ago. That proposal, along with the other proposed increases, now goes to the Postal Rate Commission, which has 10 months to make a recommendation to the Postal Service Board of Governors, which makes the final decision. 
A few rates would decline under the proposal. For example, volume advertising sorted by letter-carrier route and weighing no more than three ounces would drop to 9.6 cents from 10.1 cents.
Business and consumer groups are already mounting strong opposition campaigns.
 
'Customers Aren't Happy'
Businesses that advertise and sell by mail, including catalogue marketers, banks, credit card companies, insurers automotive manufacturers and magazines, would face significant increases in costs, ''Our customers aren't happy,'' said Anthony M. Frank, the Postmaster General as he outlined the proposals at a news conference here. ''For them it's a case of too much too soon.''
''To be honest, we agree,'' he added, noting that the proposed increases substantially outpace the rate of inflation in the general economy.
If the proposed rate increases are approved, they would take effect next February. If they do, it would mean mailing costs will have gone up an average of 19 percent since April 3, 1988, when the last increase took effect. Over the same period, inflation is expected to increase by 13 percent, according to the Postal Service calculations.
Mr. Frank said the increases are needed to meet rising wage and benefit costs, including new responsibilities for paying some of the costs of retiree health benefit and pension plans that have been transferred from the Federal Government. The Postal Service employs about 757,000 full- and part-time workers, making it the nation's largest private employer. Labor costs account for 83 percent of its $35 billion a year budget.
 
Businesses See Mismanagement
But business groups, which did not dispute the Postal Service's financial difficulties, blamed the problem on mismanagement and a failure by Postal Service officials to achieve the improvements in productivity that were supposed to result from the introduction of new technology and more automated mail processing systems.
''As mail users we recognize the inevitability of periodic rate increases, but there has been a waste, an enormous waste of postal resources over the past two years,'' said Gene Del Politio, executive director of the Third Class Mail Association, which represents businesses advertising by mail.
Mr. Del Politio said that while his group plans to seek relief from some of the increases in third-class mail rates, the rate fight is in many ways a side show to the more important issue of expiring labor contracts with the four major unions that represent the vast majority of Postal Service workers. Negotiations to renew the contracts are scheduled to begin in August.
Mr. Frank said the Postal Service was committed to keeping its costs at 2 percent below the inflation rate over the next five years in an effort to ''pay back'' the amount by which the new increases would exceed inflation.
 
Postal Rate Called Bargain
Vincent R. Sombrotto, president of the 315,000-member National Association of Letter Carriers, said that even at 30 cents, the cost of mailing a first-class letter would still be a bargain for Americans compared to costs for first-class mail in other industrialized countries. Using figures that were also cited by the Postal Service, he noted, that first-class postage is 59.9 in West Germany cents and 42.8 cents in Japan.
Robert Setrakian, chairman of the board of governors of the Postal Service, acknowledged that the rate increases would have a significant impact on businesses, but said they would not overburden the average household. He esitmated that they would raise the average person's postal bill by about $10 to $11 a year.
Business representatives disputed that assessment, warning that quite apart from the increases proposed for second- and third-class mail, increases in first-class mailing costs for businesses would ultimately affect customers as well. The American Banker's Association estimated, for example, that each one-cent increase in the nation's first-class postal rate would cost banks and their customers an additional $50 million annually.
''The proposed increase will encourage large mail users such as the banking industry to reduce the number of pieces they mail, which could result in a loss of revenue for the Postal Service despite the higher rates,'' said Vincent A. Liguori, chairman of the A.B.A.'s Postal Service committee and a vice president of First Chicago Trust Company of New York.
Mr. Liguori said banks may find that private couriers, electronic fund transfers, facsimile machines and other high technology delivery systems may become an increasingly less expensive alternative to first-class mail if rates continue to rise at rates that greatly exceed inflation.
Business groups are hoping to make their case to the rate commission for further reductions in costs for mail that requires minimal handling by Postal Service employees. In challenging previous rate increases, business users have had some success in convincing the rate commission to make changes in some of the sub-category rate hikes sought by the Postal Service.
Ralph Nader, the consumer activist, said that none of the bargaining that will go on over the next 10 months will represent the interests of consumers. ''The iron triangle of postal managment, postal unions and commercial lobbies are controlling the process to the exclusion of 120 million first-class users,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Bennington Journal;
Is the Statehood Honeymoon Over?

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BENNINGTON, Vt., March 4

 BODY:
In 1791, Vermont patriots gathered here, voting to join the union as the 14th state. Almost two centuries later, in a pristine clapboard church a few yards from the site where that historic decision was made, an assembly of Vermonters voted by a 2-to-1 margin to secede from the United States.
The nonbinding vote today came at the end of a debate on secession sponsored by the Vermont Statehood Bicentennial Commission. It was the first of six debates being held this month as part of the state's anniversary celebration. 
''We thought there was no better way to get people to focus on statehood than to discuss secession,'' said the commission's director, Carolyn Crowley Meub.
But while Ms. Meub describes the debate as ''half whimsical,'' at least one debater, Frank Bryan, a professor of political science at the University of Vermont in Burlington, appeared to be in earnest.
''Vermont is America's conscience,'' Dr. Bryan told the audience of nearly 200 people who gathered at the First Congregational Church 199 years to the day after Vermont was admitted to the union. Many applauded as he denounced the impersonal ''mega- , macro-bureaucracy'' that he said the Federal Government had become. He said that secession would be a ''sharp slap on the cheek'' to the rest of the country, and that ''a century hence, America will say 'thanks, I needed that.' ''
His remarks were variations on a theme he embraced three years ago with the publication of ''Out! The Vermont Secession Book,'' a humorous tract. ''Pogo was wrong,'' Dr. Bryan and his co-author, Bill Mares, wrote. ''We have met the enemy and he is not us. The enemy is you guys, and we're leaving.''
''America has given up on democracy,'' the authors continued. ''We haven't. We tried to tell you a thousand times. But you wouldn't listen. Well maybe you'll pay attention to this: Get lost!''
The task of supporting the union in the debate fell to John Dooley, an Associate Justice of the Vermont Supreme Court. Secession, he said, would be the ''easy way out,'' the kind of solution the American journalist H. L. Mencken would have called ''neat, simple - and wrong.''
Judge Dooley argued that the United States would erect trade barriers against a nation of Vermont. He said the state's personal, low-key government would become just as bureacratic as the Federal Government to cope with complexities like taxation, economic policies, human service needs and environmental pollution. Vermont needs the union, he said, adding, ''A cute little government will not stop acid rain.''
Dr. Bryan countered that ''all those Americans who like eating Ben & Jerry's'' ice cream, made in Vermont, would not stand for trade sanctions.
The idea of secession is not new to Vermont. The State Archivist, Gregory Sanford, says the most frequently asked question concerning the state's constitution is from angry Vermonters who are convinced that there is an ''escape clause'' providing for secession, and who demand to see it. There is none.
''I think in the end that people seeking secession are seeking escape, rather than solutions, to the problems in our society,'' Mr. Sanford said.
But the idea appears to be gaining some popular support. On a recent call-in program on Vermont Public Radio, the vote was 20 to 1 in favor of secession.
''There is a sense out there that the Federal Government is out of control and that we can handle things better here,'' said Rod Clarke, the producer and host of the program.
''Vermont is small, and we don't have much of an impact in Washington, but we have great ideas,'' said Mary Ann Pembroke of Bennington, who, with her husband, Richard, a State Representative, voted for secession after the debate today. ''This might make Washington take notice of how we really feel.'' The majority of the 164 audience members who voted on the issue agreed, casting 99 votes for secession.
Lieut. Gov. Howard Dean, who moderated the debate, called the event ''good history, good politics and good theater.''
But Dr. Bryan has dreams of something more:
''You know what I hope? I hope that the Bicentennial Commission has opened a Pandora's Box. I hope that a few months from now, they'll have occasion to say: 'Wow! We had no idea what we were doing!' ''

HEADLINE: 250 Million Now in U.S.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
The nation's population reached 250 million today, according to the Census Bureau, but no one in Washington seemed to know how - or if - they should react to the milestone.
On November 20, 1967, when the Census Bureau clock struck 200 million, President Lyndon B. Johnson made a speech celebrating the nation's size. 
But since then the country has gone through mood swings on the population question, as one vision of demographic apocalypse replaced another. In 1968, Paul R. Ehrlich's book ''The Population Bomb'' gave widespread currency to the notion that big was bad. Then in 1987, Ben J. Wattenberg weighed in with ''The Birth Dearth,'' warning of the dangers of economic and political decline inherent in a grow-slow philosophy.
Whatever the reason, official Washington remained unexcited by the latest landmark, which is based on the assumption that the country is growing by 6,300 people a day. It is likely to be another 29 years before the milestone of 300 million is reached, according to current projections. Next month's census is expected to provide a more accurate picture of the nation's exact size.
''It looks like we're going to have a commemoration on Thursday,'' said James Gorman, a spokesman for the Census Bureau, who said he expected Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher to speak. Why March 8, when the press release said the magic day was March 6? ''We couldn't get it together,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Studies Cause Confusion on Impact of Teen-Age Pregnancy

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
New research on teen-age mothers has produced seemingly contradictory results and created confusion and concern among those working to prevent teen-age pregnancy.
In late January, researchers at the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health announced that unmarried black teen-agers who chose abortions fared better economically and educationally than those who bore a child.
Three weeks later, researchers announced the results of two other studies involving teen-age pregnancy. One, from Johns Hopkins and Columbia University, found that teen-age mothers were no more likely to drop out of school than their childless classmates. 
The other, from the University of Michigan School of Public Health, suggested that teen-age child-bearing did not decrease the mother's long-term economic status, perhaps because childbearing helped teen-age mothers form alliances with the father's family and receive help from their own mothers. That study also found that in very poor communities, infant mortality rates for teen-age mothers were lower than for mothers in their 20's.
 
Geronimus Study Criticized
This study, by Dr. Arline Geronimus, immediately generated criticism. ''Her facts are misrepresentative, her premise is wrong, and the policy implications of her arguments are perverse,'' said Karen Pittman of the Children's Defense Fund, which works to prevent teen-age pregnancy.
But the apparently contradictory findings of these studies can be read to shed new light on why girls become teen-age mothers.
''One way to look at the studies is to see what they say about which teens choose abortion and which choose to bear the child,'' said Dr. Jacqueline Forrest, an expert on teen-age pregnancy at the Alan Guttmacher Institute. ''They are two very different groups. The teens who choose to give birth tend to be those with low grades, few options and few aspirations toward the future. So those who abort do better educationally and economically, and those who have babies do better at becoming tied into a dependent status in their families.''
 
Abortion and Independence
Looked at that way, Dr. Forrest said, the studies are almost mirror images. The study released in January, by Dr. Lauri Schwab Zabin, shows that teen-agers who choose abortion are more likely than those who did not to be successful at building an independent life, Dr. Forrest said.
In contrast, she said, the Geronimus study suggests that teen-agers who have babies are likelier to live with their parents and to get help from an extended group of people that may include the father's family.
''I think it's selling those girls short to consider that a success, though,'' Dr. Forrest said. ''Most teens don't want a future of living with their mothers.''
Dr. Geronimus emphasized that she did not advocate teen-age parenthood but said it might be a rational choice for a small group of poor teen-agers.
''The teens who choose to have babies are the poorest of the poor, and within that group, they're the ones who performed worst in school and were not likely to go on in school anyway,'' Dr. Geronimus said. ''Teen-age childbearing is not the cause of their problems. The same things that explain the decision not to abort explain the outcomes for the mothers.''
 
Deteriorating Health
For socioeconomic reasons, the health of women who are poorest deteriorates rapidly, Dr. Geronimus said, so the women likely to become teen-age mothers are healthier in their adolescence than they will probably be in their 20's, and their infants are likely to be healthier if the mothers do their childbearing early.
Ms. Pittman attacks that finding, saying that it is based on neonatal mortality rates only for the infant's first month of life. ''You have to look at what happens over time, and what you find is that teen mothers do not care for babies very well, and the mortality rates are higher than for older mothers,'' she said.
Neither the Geronimus study nor the Hopkins-Columbia study included data comparing girls who chose abortion to those who had babies. And like the Zabin study, the Hopkins-Columbia study does find educational disadvantages among teen-age mothers.
 
Return to School Unlikely
''Early childbearing did have an effect on high school graduation rates, but not in the way people had thought,'' said Dr. James McCarthy, an author of the Hopkins-Columbia study.
The study showed that teen-age mothers were no more likely to drop out than their childless classmates. But among dropouts, those who were mothers were less likely than others to return and to complete high school.
What Dr. McCarthy concludes from that is perhaps the only common ground among the researchers into teen-age pregnancy.
''My conclusion is that the baby doesn't cause the problem, but the baby is an outgrowth of the girl's problem,'' Dr. McCarthy said. ''But even if it's the basic background factors, and not having the baby, that are responsible for the poor educational outcomes, the implications are pretty much the same. To change things, you have to improve the life options of young girls, keep them in school and give them more control over their lives, including their reproductive lives.''

HEADLINE: N.A.A.C.P. in Hiring Pact With South Carolina Mall

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., March 6

 BODY:
In an agreement with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, a shopping mall has pledged to hire more blacks and stop detaining black teen-agers under a 1960's trespassing law.
The civil rights group's national chairman, William F. Gibson of Greenville, S.C., announced the agreement with the Columbia Mall on Monday, saying it was the first pact reached with a shopping mall on the hiring and treatment of blacks. He encouraged other N.A.A.C.P. chapters ''to negotiate similar agreements.'' 
The agreement, negotiated over the last month by officials of the N.A.A.C.P. and the mall, calls for the mall management to hire and promote more blacks and encourage the 128 stores in the mall to do the same, and for using more black contractors and suppliers.
Mr. Gibson said the civil rights group had planned to call a boycott of the mall if an agreement had not been reached.
 
'Spirit of Cooperation'
Civil rights groups asserted last summer that about 50 black teen-agers had been detained by mall security officers under the trespassing law, which permits the detention of anyone ''disorderly and boisterous.'' The youths were photographed, their names were placed in security files and many were told not to return to the mall for six months. In most cases, no criminal charges were filed.
George Forbes, a lawyer for the mall owner, Jacobs, Visconi & Jacobs of Cleveland, said the agreement was reached in a ''spirit of cooperation'' but was not legally binding.
''The Columbia Mall does not, it has not and it will not discriminate as regards to race, creed or color,'' said Mr. Forbes, who is a member of the N.A.A.C.P.
In December, two black teen-agers were wounded by gunfire by other shoppers at the mall. Two other shooting incidents occurred at the mall earlier last year.
In an interview after the December shooting, Sheriff Allen Sloan of Richland County was quoted in The State, a Columbia newspaper, as saying the best way to reduce violence at the mall was to ''keep the niggers out.'' Sheriff Sloan denied making the statement.
 
Pact Called 'Long, Long Overdue'
State Senator Kay Patterson, who led other black officials in calling for the sheriff's resignation, said the pact with the mall was ''long, long overdue.''
''I think when you hire people and give them economic opportunity, it has a tendency to cut down on some of the racial strife,'' Mr. Patterson said.
In the agreement, the mall owners also offered to sponsor a job fair, create an employment center, advertise in black news media, provide sensitivity training for employees in dealing with minority members and work with the N.A.A.C.P. to monitor the mall's relationship with blacks.
Mr. Forbes said the mall owner was committed to hiring minorities. One of the mall's four administrators is black, he said, and blacks are 35 percent of its security force. ''We think that is not only good sense, but it makes good business,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Bank Law Reform for Panama and for Us

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a former financial executive covering Panama, diplomat and senior trade officer, let me compliment you for ''Panama Is Resisting U.S. Pressure to Alter 'Inadequate' Bank Laws'' (front page, Feb. 6).
It may be expected in a country Panama's size, for centuries an international trade hub, that everyone from the president down is linked to whatever is going on, the good, the bad and the ugly. The Panamanian banking system's growth was triggered not purely by drug lords and our favorite usual suspect, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, but by the capital-destructive policies of many Latin American nations. While the populations of those countries have taken tremendous economic blows in recent years, it isn't surprising that their elites have banked in Panama. And in Miami (as your article implies), New York and elsewhere.
Instead of bringing pressure on Panama, a fragile economy, even in better times, wouldn't it be better (a) to be much harsher on the United States drug trade in penalties and exemption from the witness-protection program (they're running around free as birds in southern Florida) and (b) to consider liberalization of United States banking restrictions and reporting requirements, so that we, the other 99.9 percent, aren't put through the hoops?
If Federal and state investigators weren't so lax, such measures wouldn't be necessary. With the crisis in United States banking, particularly the savings and loan associations mess, it's amusing to watch Washington attempt to graft its solutions onto Panama.
 
LOUIS V. RIGGIO
Hollywood, Fla., Feb. 19, 1990

HEADLINE: For Eastern Europe, a $25 Billion Aid Package

SERIES: Designs for Europe; An Occasional Series

BYLINE: By Zbigniew Brzezinski; Zbigniew Brzezinski was President Jimmy Carter's national security adviser. (A longer version of this article will appear in the spring issue of The National Interest.)

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The external Soviet empire lasted 45 years. It is shattered, beyond redemption or repair.
The Soviet Union, suffering from a bad case of imperial fatigue, itself is struggling for survival. The internal crisis - simultaneously ethnic, economic and political - will be of long duration. 
In the meantime, a new geopolitical reality in the very heart of Europe is emerging. Today, Eastern Europe is again Central Europe - which it has always been historically, culturally and philosophically. This post-Communist region is threatened by chaos and instability even as it yearns for a Western European style of life and for Western-type institutional arrangements.
Central Europe's economies are in a shambles. Its political systems have to be rebuilt from scratch. The threat of national and territorial conflicts overhangs the internal difficulties that every Government will have to overcome on the way to the stable democracy all profess to seek.
A policy that responds creatively to all these overlapping dilemmas will have to be comprehensive geographically and ambitious politically.
It must be capable of harnessing Western popular support and of captivating the political imagination not only of the Central Europeans but also of the many Soviet nations. It must build on the success of Western policy, not diluting but enhancing the processes of Western European integration while also seizing the moment in Central Europe to capitalize on that integration's ripple effects.
That policy should be founded upon the grand concept of a trans-European commonwealth with the European Community at its core but embracing Central Europe and being open also to eventual association with the Soviet Union.
Such a strategic vision should include the following seven specific but interconnected and historically ambitious policy components:
Acceleration of Western European integration; enhancement of trans-Atlantic ties; consolidation of democratic reform in Central Europe; negotiation of a German confederation within an all-European security framework; facilitation of cross-cutting multilateral cooperation; promotion of Central European regional cooperation, and encouragement of a new Soviet confederation.
These components have to be viewed as a package, with the pursuit of one facilitating and necessary to the attainment of the others. The end result of the effort should be the emergence of a more stable, cooperative and democratic all-European order as well as the termination of the American-Soviet rivalry over the fate of Europe.
Accordingly, it will be critically important to the success of the entire agenda for Western Europe's political integration to be accelerated further. Indeed, that integration must serve as the cornerstone of any eventually wider European commonwealth and as an attractive, and badly needed, example of successful multilateral cooperation for the Central Europeans and Russians. Without such integration, any attempts to promote the regional recovery of Central Europe will lack the necessary source of stability and support.
American support for European integration is consistent with the fostering of even more intimate trans-Atlantic ties. Firm linkage with the U.S. would make it easier and safer for the Europeans to try to foster a more genuinely cooperative relationship, beyond Central Europe, with the Soviet Union. A continued - even if significantly diminished - American military presence in Europe is, therefore, in the self-interest of Europe and America.
The promotion of stable democracy in the post-Communist countries will require a major and immediate commitment of Western resources, far beyond existing commitments. In the first half of 1989, it appeared that only Poland - the spearhead and historic catalyst for the collapse of the Soviet bloc - and Hungary would require Western assistance. It is now obvious that all Central European countries will have to be aided in the extraordinarily difficult transformation of their economic and political systems.
The level of Western capital needed to prevent the region's slide into political and economic chaos might well range from $25 billion to $30 billion. Since this figure may appear at first glance appallingly large, it should be viewed in historical perspective.
Between 1946 and 1955, the U.S., then with a gross national product about one-third of today's, contributed a total (in 1989 dollars) of $171 billion to Western Europe's recovery. That came to an annual contribution of $17 billion. The result was a historical triumph.
The economic response to the challenge of Central Europe certainly should not be America's burden alone. Western European countries likewise have a stake in Central Europe's stability. Japan, with a G.N.P. more than half that of America's, also should play a role.
The peaceful transformation of Central Europe will require a stable security context, one that is reassuring to the West and East alike. Accordingly, the West, in embracing the cause of German unification, should move forward with a comprehensive plan for a German confederation and for special security arrangements to accompany it. Indeed, German acceptance of the existing frontiers is the sine qua non of international acceptance of unification.
Moreover, for an agreed transitional period, NATO and the Warsaw Pact should retain some military contingents in the two parts of united Germany, thereby guaranteeing a secure transition to the new European order.
Members of the two political-and-military alliances should also be free to choose their economic associations through memberships in multilateral organizations. Thus, the Central European states, as they move toward market economies, should be permitted and encouraged to seek some form of association with either the European Free Trade Association or eventually the European Community - even while they remain Warsaw Pact members.
The West should also encourage the Central Europeans to develop new forms of regional cooperation among themselves. Western economic and ecological assistance could even be made conditional to some degree on the recipients' willingness to engage in multilateral cooperation.
Finally, the Soviets must be constructively encouraged to see their future in trans-European cooperation. The option of participation in the expanding European adventure should be explicitly held open to a new and genuinely pluralistic Soviet confederation in the event that Mikhail Gorbachev's perestroika does lead to fundamental reformation of the Soviet Union.
A necessary concomitant to any process of creating a genuinely voluntary Soviet confederation will be the right of secession. Some parts of today's Soviet Union may choose to exercise that right. But such secession could become more tolerable to the Soviet Union if it led to new forms of association between the seceding states and the remainder of the current Soviet Union with an emerging trans-European commonwealth.
It is not too early for Europeans and Americans to start thinking about the implications of the epochal fact that the Eurasian map, as much of this century has known it, is being shaken. Given the accelerating velocity of history, we should begin charting deliberately the next phase in its trajectory.

HEADLINE: Dinkins, in Washington, Seeks Aid for Cities

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
David N. Dinkins sat in the front of a packed Senate committee room this morning, surrounded by Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, Alan Cranston of California and Paul Simon of Illinois. Just when it seemed the Mayor of New York City could not bask in a warmer spotlight, in walked Elizabeth Taylor.
The occasion was a news conference to discuss the Senators' proposed bill to provide emergency-relief money to the areas hit hardest by AIDS. For Mr. Dinkins, his third visit here in nine days was part of a steadily building strategy to style himself as a national spokesman for urban areas. ''If we can't begin to address the health-care crisis now, in the midst of a public-health disaster far worse than the polio or tuberculosis epidemics, then we might as well permanently resign ourselves to the fact that this nation doesn't really care about the health and well-being of all its citizens,'' Mr. Dinkins said. 
 
An 'Urban Agenda'
Because they lead the nation's largest city, New York City mayors have historically had more prominence than most municipal chief executives.
Now, with New York facing problems from AIDS to crack to homelessness, and with the state and city struggling to fill huge budget gaps, Mr. Dinkins's advisers say he is determined to use his position as mayor to be heard in and seek help from Washington.
''We're trying to build a coalition of urban centers,'' said Mr. Dinkins's deputy, Bill Lynch.
The two arrived for a day that included the AIDS news conference, another on the census, a lunch with the New York Congressional delegation, a meeting with the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development about housing financing and another news conference with a Soviet citizen, Carmella Raiz, whose family is not being allowed to immigrate to Israel. ''The message we want to send is that New York City can't do it alone,'' Mr. Lynch said.
On a visit last Monday, Mr. Dinkins told the National Press Club that conservatism was dying, and said it was time for the nation and its cities to build ''a new foundation upon the rubble of the conservative decade.''
Today, after testifying before a House budget committee hearing on AIDS, Mr. Dinkins elaborated.
''It's not because I'm trying to run for national office, because I'm not,'' he said. ''But it's because that's one of the better ways to assure the kind of assistance and sympathy we need for New York. I just can't tell you how pleased I am. D'Amato, all of those guys, they're on board on this stuff.''
Mr. Koch was no stranger to Washington, where he served eight years as a Congressman before becoming mayor. Neither is Mr. Dinkins, who spent four years here as a mathematics major at Howard University in the late 1940's.
Today Mr. Dinkins came as New York's mayor, and the treatment was different. Two bodyguards drove down at 4 A.M. with a back-up security car. The District of Columbia police met him at National Airport with a blue Lincoln Continental 'You Get Treated Differently ''There's a difference,'' Mr. Dinkins said softly. ''It's nice to come back here. Just as Joe Citizen you get treated differently and as mayor of the greatest urban center on earth you get treated still differently.''
The Mayor made it plain that he speaks with special feeling for disenfranchised people. At a news conference in his role as co-chairman of the United States Conference of Mayors' task force on the census, he faulted the Census Bureau for its reluctance to adjust its count to compensate for expected undercounting, which especially affects minorities in big cities.
''This to me is as bad as the early days of our country when the census said we will count African-American slaves as three-fifths of a person,'' he said.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who appeared with Mr. Dinkins at several events, said, ''I think our Mayor already in two months has established himself as a leading voice for urban America.''
''He has an extraordinarily strong voice, a tough voice when it's needed, but a voice with gentility - gentleness, I meant, I guess.''
At that Mr. Dinkins interrupted, ''Whatever works, Chuck.''
Just how well the Mayor's approach will work remains to be seen, but he seems to be winning some good will.
''Thank you for being so outspoken on the national issues that are so important to us,'' said Representative Frank J. Guarini, Democrat of Jersey City, after the budget hearing.
For his part, Mr. Dinkins said, ''I think we're making some progress.''

HEADLINE: Fernandez Plans Schools in Workplaces

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
New York City Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez plans to open a network of elementary schools inside office buildings and other workplaces, where young children can attend classes as their parents work nearby.
The plan hinges on the willingness of the city's businesses to contribute space and amenities, and yesterday Mr. Fernandez invited a large gathering of executives to join him in setting up such schools as early as September, starting with a program for children in kindergarten through second grade.
 
Businesses Asked for Day Care
Mr. Fernandez said he would provide the teachers and books, and he asked the business leaders to furnish the classrooms, maintenance, heat and electricity and after-school day care. Mr. Fernandez has a track record for establishing ''satellite learning centers'' in workplaces. In Miami, where he was superintendent, he set up three such schools - at an insurance concern, a community college and the city's airport - and 11 more are planned. 
To sell his plan in New York yesterday, Mr Fernandez offered a vision of working parents talking with their children on the way to school, doing their jobs with the ''peace of mind'' that comes with having their children close at hand and visiting their children during lunch breaks.
Employers could attract workers by offering them ''the perk'' of having a school at the job site, he said; attendance and punctuality by workers should increase.
 
Help With Overcrowding
''Bringing schools to the workplace,'' Mr. Fernandez said, would also free space in the city's overcrowded schools and provide greater economic and racial integration in a system whose students are largely minority-group members and poor.
''We could have the vice president's kids sitting next to the janitor's kids,'' he told a breakfast of over 700 members of the Association for a Better New York, a private civic group of business and government leaders.
So far, Mr. Fernandez's staff has sent feelers or begun discussions with a handful of businesses or institutions, including a Queens real-estate developer, and it has invited other business executives for a briefing next month. There are hopes that a pilot school could open as early as September, the start of the next school year, and that additional schools could be set up soon after in corporate headquarters, airports, hospitals, or even shopping malls, Mr. Fernandez said. He said no specific sites had been chosen.
 
Seen as Harder in Manhattan
Several executives interviewed after the breakfast expressed interest in the proposal, including Lewis Rudin, the association's chairman and a major real-estate owner in the city. Many businesses have struggled to hold onto female employees with young children and have looked into day-care arrangements. But some executives cautioned that satellite schools could be set up more easily in quieter boroughs like Queens and Brooklyn than in the hurly-burly of midtown and lower Manhattan. The program would be available free only to city residents.
While supportive of the proposal, Meyer S. Frucher, an executive vice president at Olympia & York, the world's largest commercial real-estate developer, pointed out that employees are sometimes reluctant to take small children on crowded subways and through the frenetic atmosphere and heavy traffic of Manhattan's streets.
As a former director of labor relations in the administration of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mr. Frucher helped set up 32 day-care centers at mental hospitals and state prisons, but he said he did not get a receptive response from employees at large office buildings like the World Trade Center.
 
Plans for a Survey
Mr. Fernandez has already put together a resolution asking the seven-member Board of Education to approve the concept in principle, and Amina Abdur-Rahman, Deputy Chancellor for External Programs and Community Affairs, has scheduled a meeting in April with interested executives.
Ms. Rahman said she wanted the employers to understand the school system's requirements for adequate space, access to toilets and the like. She also wants to use the meeting to design a survey so the Board of Education can find out how many workers are likely to enroll their children. Roughly 25 children would be required for each classroom, she said.
Amy Linden, executive director of the Division of School Buildings, said she has been talking with Dominik Ciampa, a Queens developer, about setting up such a school at a new office complex Mr. Ciampa is building in Flushing. Other sites under consideration, she said, include LaGuardia Airport and Kennedy International Airport, which are operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the Metrotech complex of four office buildings under construction in downtown Brooklyn, and the new Citicorp skyscraper in Long Island City, Queens.
''As Mr. Fernandez says, 'it's a win-win situation,' '' Ms. Linden said. ''It's such an easy concept and everyone immediately grasps it. Parents think of all the hassles of getting their kids to schools and the worries they have when they go to work all day. This solves all those problems.''
 
Costs Said to Be Minimal
As superintendent of Dade County's school system, Mr. Fernandez installed satellite schools for young children at the American Bankers Insurance Group, at Miami International Airport and at Miami-Dade Community College. Mr. Fernandez said the program, which began in August 1987, has been well received.
Ms. Rahman said the satellite schools would not cost the system any more money. Parents who sent their children to such workplace schools would have to obtain waivers from the school near their homes. State and city money would essentially follow the children to the satellite schools.
For athletic activities and assemblies, children from a satellite schools would have to visit a nearby elementary school. Since the school day ends at 3 P.M. and most workers in the city work until 5 P.M., companies would have to pay for day care for children in the intervening hours. The schools would be confined to the early grades, officials said, because legal requirements for such amenities as gymnasiums were less stringent.
 
Help for 'Latchkey Children'
In unveiling the proposal at yesterday's breakfast at the New York Hilton, Mr. Fernandez pointed out that 60 percent of the city's public school children have only one parent at home and that many are ''latchkey children'' who come home to empty apartments. Satellite-school children, he said, would be brought home by their parents.
When the satellite school was set up at the American Bankers Insurance Group, employee turnover dropped to 4 percent from 11 percent, he said.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Women's College Struggles to Keep Its Identity

BYLINE: By KATHERINE BISHOP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., March 6

 BODY:
The official T-shirt of the small liberal arts college here reads: ''Mills College: Not a girls' school without men, but a women's college without boys.''
But this winter, many Mills students on this graceful, wooded campus have joined their counterparts at other women's colleges in wearing an unofficial one. It reads: ''Mills College: Better Dead Than Coed,'' an acknowledgement that their school, too, may be faced with the necessity to change or perish.
As at other women's campuses that have faced the possibility of transition to a coeducational institution, the students here are strongly opposed. Admitting men ''destroys the whole mission of the college, which is the empowerment of women,'' said Robyn Fisher, a senior who is the president of Mills' Associated Students. 
Alexa Pagonas, a junior from San Francisco, said, ''We need women's colleges because a woman needs to find herself, and go with that, instead of with the male model.''
But the message from the Mills board, which will vote in May on the issue, is that this campus must quickly find a way to increase enrollment by nearly one-third, to 1,000 students.
 
National Predicament
Mills, founded in 1852, is the latest victim of the national predicament in women's higher education: Despite the enthusiastic support of their graduates, women's colleges find it increasingly difficult to attract and hold enough students to sustain them.
The number of high school graduates in general has been declining, and for the select group of approximately 230,000 students who meet the high admissions standards of schools like Mills, competition is intense. And while gifts from alumnae remain high, financial aid from the schools to deserving lower-income students is increasing, thereby decreasing net tuition income.
With only 777 undergraduate students for the fall 1989 semester, Mills is less than half the size of Mount Holyoke at 1,939. Wellesley, with 2,145 students, is nearly three times as large. Mills believes it must have no fewer than 1,000 to maintain its standards and survive financially.
''It's very clear that the college cannot keep going the way it is,'' said F. Warren Hellman, chairman of the Mills board. ''Nearly every college that has gone down this track has gone coed.''
To some degree, the college's problems are made worse by its location in California, which has an extensive system of excellent, tuition-free public universities, including the prestigious Berkeley campus just a few miles north of Mills. With annual tuition at $11,900 and room and board charges at $5,100, Mills costs $17,000 a year for the 80 percent of its students who live on campus.
 
Decrease in Women's Colleges
Peter Mirijanian, spokesman for the Women's College Coalition in Washington, says there are only 94 women's colleges today, down from approximately 300 in 1960. That number may decrease as 121-year-old Chatham in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania's oldest women's college, will make its decision on April 22 whether to approve its trustees' recommendation to admit men in 1991.
Dr. Mary S. Metz, who has been president of Mills since 1981, said: ''It's a great dilemma because of the evidence that attending women's colleges makes a difference in the lives of women. It has truly empowered women, and they've gone on to do greater things.''
Dr. Metz cited statistics showing that nearly half the women in the 101st Congress and one-third of those on the boards of the 1,000 largest American corporations attended women's colleges. Conversely, she said, studies have found consistent patterns of women getting less attention and being more frequently interrupted in coeducational classes.
''A lot of research shows that women do best in an atmosphere that is affirming and supporting in a way coeducational colleges have not replicated,'' Dr. Metz said. ''Even small coeducational schools have a problem with dynamics in the classroom when men dominate class discussions and take more time of the professors.''
Jodi Preston, a junior majoring in psychology who transferred to Mills this year after two years at another college, said such considerations were part of her decision.
''Everything in the other college was run by men,'' Ms. Preston said. ''I felt stifled most of the time. I felt I wasn't living up to my potential.''
 
Issue of Male Dominance
Dr. Virginia Smith was president of Vassar in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., for a decade beginning in 1977, seven years after that college began admitting men. She said it is harder to nurture women in a coeducational setting. But as a member of the Mills board, she said she had not decided how she would vote on whether the college should admit men.
''Most schools are not really coeducational because they are male-dominated,'' she said. ''If women are to be served well in a coeducational setting, there may have to be more awareness by teachers and administrators that women may have to be given more support.''
Mr. Mirijanian said that if Mills is to remain a women's college it must ''reposition itself in the market.'' Because women's roles have changed, he said, institutions like Mills are now challenged to change the perception of women's colleges, emphasizing the success of their graduates in the marketplace as their selling point, ''They can say they are leaders in the business community, that they go into Congress, that they have more women in science, economics and math than coed schools do,'' Mr. Mirijanian said. ''Their women are going into Fortune 1000 companies and other male-dominated institutions and they're better prepared.''
One possible alternative is to recruit in the ''secondary markets'' of women over 25 years old and foreign students, a strategy followed, with apparent success, by Russell Sage College in Troy, N.Y., which decided to remain women-only in 1987, and which this year has 1,000 undergraduates, one of the highest enrollments in its history.
''Women's colleges must go after these women as a way to supplement their student body,'' said Mr. Marijanian, who cited a recent report showing that in five years the majority of undergraduates at colleges will be over 23 years old.
''There is a huge, growing market for part-time and resuming students,'' Mr. Hellman said. At present, fewer than 20 percent of Mills undergraduates are ''resumers,'' students over 23 who have returned to school after a break to work or rear children.
The issues, as Mr. Hellman sees them, are: ''What can Mills do to get these markets and do we then end up with an institution we're proud of?''

HEADLINE: K Mart Gambling on Renovation

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TROY, Mich.

 BODY:
When it comes to merchandising revenues, the K Mart Corporation, Sears, Roebuck & Company and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. are now so close that it is difficult to say which of the three is the nation's largest retailer. But when it comes to merchandising profits, K Mart is a weak third.
Dismayed by earnings declines in the last three quarters and a loss of market share, K Mart is responding with a huge gamble. Accelerating and increasing the scope of a program announced last October, the company said last week that it would spend $2.3 billion over the next five years to enlarge 930 of its discount department stores and to give all 2,190 of its stores a fresher look.
To be sure, when the company completes the task in 1995, its stores will still have all the things that have made it a fixture in American retailing: bluelight specials, ''Attention, K Mart shoppers'' announcements, and enough synthetic-fiber clothing to retain its industry nickname - the Polyester Palace. Is the Risk Worthwhile? The risk is that K Mart will open bigger and better stores and nobody will come, or at least not enough people to make the company anything more than an also-ran in its industry. ''They could open up all this new space and find that there is simply not enough additional business to have made it worthwhile,'' said Kurt Barnard, the editor of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report, a leading industry newsletter. 
Any retailer faces such a risk when it expands. What makes K Mart's expansion at once striking and perilous is its speed and scope.
Retailers of all stripes are working with bigger spaces so they can display more merchandise and, they hope, garner more of a shopper's purchases. K Mart has determined that roughly 42 percent of its stores are too small to be competitive, and they will either be closed, moved to larger quarters or expanded in their present locations. The goal is to increase the average size of these stores to 85,000 square feet from just more than 60,000 square feet at present. In addition, K Mart plans to open 250 new stores by early 1995, all in the 85,000-square-foot format.
At the same time, K Mart plans to give all of its stores a new look. Heartened by the increased sales being reported by three prototype stores, K Mart will widen the aisles in its stores, install track lighting, use splashy graphics and replace worn display shelves with wider, taller ones. The company will also be purging product laggards and loading up on good sellers. The latter move is aimed at building an image as a merchant on the cutting edge of consumer tastes. The store face lifts are intended to make K Marts more inviting places to shop and to convey a sense of a store brimming with fresh merchandise.
''Presentation, presentation, presentation,'' said Marc Buchi, manager of the prototype K Mart store in Oak Park, Mich., outside Detroit.
 
Industry Slowdown
By the time K Mart completes its expansion in early 1995, the company will have enlarged its selling space by a third from the beginning of 1989, to roughly 174 million square feet, or by roughly 5.5 percent a year. This is more than double the rate at which K Mart expanded its store space between 1983 and 1988, and more than triple the industry growth rate, according to James P. Ruf, an analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company, the Wall Street firm. But this new space will be available in years when, in the view of most retail analysts, sales at discount department stores will be growing slowly, if at all.
To justify the huge outlay for additional selling space, K Mart must add $7.6 billion to its merchandising revenues of $23.2 billion just to maintain sales per square foot at their current level. K Mart's chairman and chief executive, Joseph E. Antonini, who declined to be interviewed for this article, told securities analysts last October that his goal is to increase sales to $40 billion by 1994.
Such an accomplishment would mean taking market share from competitors, including Wal-Mart, Target, Ames, Caldor and, for some merchandise, Sears. Doing that would mark a big departure from K Mart's recent performance. After increasing its sales and profits rapidly in the 1970's and through much of the 1980's, K Mart of late has been a font of disappointing news.
K Mart is almost at the bottom of the profitability heap. Partly as a result of charges relating to its modernization program. K Mart is expected to soon report less than $200 million in profits for 1989, according to analysts' estimates. Sears recently reported that its merchandising group's profit was $646 million; Wal-Mart's merchandising profit was $1.1 billion.
K Mart's pretax profits have been about 4.5 percent of sales in recent years, compared with 6.5 percent at Wal-Mart and 5.4 percent at Target Stores. At Sears, it was 3.6 percent.
Sales increases at K Mart stores open for at least a year have been running at only about 3 percent -less than the rate of inflation. Analysts blame factors from poorly chosen merchandise to dingy, cramped stores to a lethargic sales staff for the sluggish growth in same-store sales.
Meanwhile, returns from K Mart's specialty stores, which include Waldenbooks, Pay Less Drug Stores and Builders Square home-improvement centers, have been depressed badly by expansion expenses. The specialty stores account for roughly 15 percent of K Mart's revenues.
In the three quarters ended last Oct. 31 - figures for the most recent quarter have not yet been released -K Mart reported lower earnings. One reason was a move to a policy that keeps prices low every day instead of offering many advertised sales. The company also said that inclement weather in the winter and spring of 1988 depressed sales of gardening tools and spring apparel.
 
Wal-Mart Moving Up
In terms of revenues, K Mart, which traces its roots to 1899 with the founding of the S. S. Kresge Company, will report about $27.5 billion in domestic merchandising sales for 1989, according to analysts' estimates. Sears also had an estimated $27.5 billion in domestic merchandising sales last year. Wal-Mart reported recently that its 1989 sales were $25.8 billion, but its double-digit sales increases should push it ahead of K Mart and Sears by the end of this year.
Given K Mart's difficulties, even the company's most vocal critics agree that the retailer must do something to stem its decline. But some outsiders are skeptical of K Mart's expansion and renovation program. ''What they have talked about is purely housekeeping issues,'' said Sidney Doolittle of McMillan & Doolittle, a Chicago-based industry consultant. ''They need to work on the strategic edge of K Mart: Who is K Mart going to be?''
Indeed, the prevailing view of retailing experts is that for now K Mart would be better off maintaining its current size and focusing instead on building its position in a few product categories in which it can dominate. K Mart stores already sell a huge amount of live plants and gardening equipment.
Herbert Fisher, who runs the Jamesway Corporation, a big discounter based in Secaucus, N.J., pointed up the risk of an expansion: ''Unless one of our stores is doing a fantastically large volume, it just doesn't make sense for us to expand it right now,'' he said. ''The added overhead would eat us up. We'd have to price ourselves out of the market.''
But K Mart argues that its larger stores perform better than its midsized stores and that small stores perform the poorest. It says that sales at some 83 K Mart stores enlarged in the last year and a half have already begun to improve.
 
'This Will Work'
''The weight of evidence is that this will work,'' said Orren Knauer, a K Mart spokesman. ''If we sit still with these undersized stores, we risk being eaten alive by the competition.''
Like K Mart, Sears, Montgomery Ward & Company and other retailers have been renovating their stores -making them brighter and more inviting through the use of better lighting and display shelves. They have also been narrowing their product lines to focus on better-selling items.
Mr. Knauer argued that in many product categories K Mart does not compete with Sears or Montgomery Ward. He argued that consumers would choose K Mart over competitors because K Mart stores would have better prices and better locations than rivals. They will also have better customer service than the competition, Mr. Knauer contended, and they will have fewer out-of-stock goods because K Mart is installing an advanced inventory-tracking system.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Fall By 5.4%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
Orders received by the nation's factories fell in January at the steepest rate in 15 years, the Commerce Department said today, reflecting a slump in the nation's manufacturing sector.
Factory orders in the month fell 5.4 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $227.7 billion, primarily because of a sharp drop in transportation orders. Orders had a slim four-tenths of 1 percent gain in December.
''This is consistent with a picture of definite economic sluggishness,'' said Cynthia Latta, senior economist with DRI/McGraw Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass. ''But there's really nothing that suggests a drift to recession,'' she added. 
 
Biggest Drop Since '74
The January drop in factory orders was the biggest one-month decline since December 1974, when they fell 7 percent. The increase last December was revised downward, from the 1.9 percent originally reported.
Excluding the volatile transportation sector, factory orders fell 1 percent in January, after a decrease of three-tenths of 1 percent in December, the department said.
One-third of the decline in orders reflected a steep drop in commercial aircraft orders after an unusual spike in sales that followed the November settlement of a strike against the Boeing Company, the nation's largest aircraft manufacturer.
 
Aircraft and Parts Down
Transportation equipment orders over all fell 28.8 percent in January, after gaining 4.7 percent in December. Within that category, aircraft and parts orders were down 27.3 percent, after a 9.3 percent December rise.
Auto orders weakened, while orders for military tanks and ships fell by 72.5 percent in January after more than tripling in December.
Noting that manufacturing makes up 25 percent of the economy, Ms. Latta said, ''There has been some spillover of the existing decline in the industrial sector to the services side, but there's no evidence yet of serious repercussions.''
Last month, the Government reported that orders for durable goods - items designed to last three or more years - fell 10.5 percent in January after a 1.2 percent increase in December.
Jean Sundrla, an economist with Evans Economics, a forecasting group in Washington, said the weak orders could signal lower investment spending by big companies.
''This falloff portends a damper on capital goods expenditures,'' the economist said, because corporations will try to tighten up outlays to avoid running up inventories.
 
Shipments Fall
In the report, factory inventories expanded by seven-tenths of 1 percent in January after being drawn down by five-tenths of 1 percent in December. Shipments also fell 1.9 percent after falling eight-tenths of 1 percent in December.
Laurence Meyer, president of Laurence Meyer & Associates of St. Louis, said the January inventory buildup was troubling because it pointed to an oversupply of goods.
''What we're seeing is weakness in orders at the beginning of the year and weakness in shipments, but the falloff in production is lagging the drop in demand,'' Mr. Meyer said.
Recent indicators have presented a mixed picture of the economy. Personal income and construction spending rose strongly in January, but housing sales fell sharply for a second straight month.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said last week that he thought the economy's weakest point had passed and put the chance of a recession at less than 50 percent.
Still, manufacturing jobs fell for a 12th straight month in February, according to a survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management published last week. Government employment figures for February are due Friday.
 
Electrical Orders Drop
The Commerce Department said factory orders for nonelectrical machinery rose 2.4 percent in January after falling 4 percent in December. Electrical machinery orders fell 15.5 percent after a 5.4 percent December gain.
Military orders for capital goods, which fell 13.3 percent in December, dropped 28.8 percent in January.
Excluding the volatile military category from both months, factory orders fell 4.4 percent in January after a 1.1 percent rise in December.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Global Warming: China Perplex

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE bad news, say Alan S. Manne of Stanford University and Richard G. Richels of the Electric Power Research Institute, is that it would probably cost Americans trillions of dollars to reduce their output of ''greenhouse effect'' carbon dioxide gas by as little as 20 percent. The really bad news, the two economists say in a new, unpublished paper, is that a 20 percent cut would almost certainly be offset by increased emissions from poor countries.
The Manne-Richels estimates are, of course, no better than the computer simulation that generates them. And many environmentalists contend that the simulation assumes away the possibility of rapid technological change under pressure - of finding ways to decouple economic growth from increased use of carbon fuels. 
But it is hard to be optimistic about the prospects for ''clean'' growth in the third world, most notably in China. If the two economists are even close to right, the costs of a successful global effort to control atmospheric warming would be daunting.
Europe, America and what used to be called the Soviet bloc generate 71 percent of the world's carbon dioxide. Suppose they agreed to stabilize emissions at current levels, and then gradually reduced them by 20 percent by 2020. That goal, almost everyone acknowledges, could be achieved by conserving energy and switching to less polluting fuels.
According to the Manne-Richels model, Europe and Japan could manage the task by sacrificing 1 to 2 percent of national income. Hitting the 20 percent target would cost the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe much more - perhaps 4 percent of income - because capital is more expensive and the prospects for technological fixes more problematic. America, with a 3 percent loss of potential income, is in between.
If it were widely accepted that the only alternative was ecological catastrophe, it might well be possible to build a political consensus for sacrifice. But properly calculated, the cost would be awesome.
The ''present value'' of the cumulative loss over the next century would be roughly $1 trillion for America alone. And the benefit in the absence of a similar commitment to conservation from the third world, where the rate of growth of energy use is double the world average, would be modest. If, for example, China and other poor countries agreed to limit carbon emissions to just double the current level, total carbon dioxide emissions would increase by 15 percent by 2030.
Doubling seems a generous allowance; surely, even the penurious passengers on spaceship earth would accept a tougher constraint?
Do not count on it. According to the model, the doubling constraint would reduce the potential income of coal-rich, capital-poor China by a distressing 10 percent. To limit the level of sacrifice to 3 percent of income, China would have to be allowed a fourfold increase in carbon emissions.
Put the problem another way. Suppose China was permitted to quadruple emissions while the rest of the third world was limited to just a twofold increase. To reduce the total output of carbon dioxide to 80 percent of the 1990 level, the industrial countries would have to cut emissions to zero.
Necessity, one is told by environmentalists, is the mother of energy conservation. It is conceivable that the developed countries could manage an aggressive program for constraining carbon emissions, and subsidize a more modest technical fix for poor countries. But the depressing conclusions of the Manne-Richels simulations suggest the need to look hard at alternatives to carbon constraints.
One possibility would be to focus efforts on containing other greenhouse-effect gases. The class of chemicals known as CFC's are wreaking havoc with the earth's ozone layer, as well as helping to warm the atmosphere. Since the industrialized countries are already committed to phasing out their use, it might make sense to accelerate the process.
Another potential target is methane, a byproduct of rice cultivation and animal husbandry. No one is suggesting that Asians switch to Wonderbread or that Americans become vegetarians. But it may be possible to limit methane pollution by modifying agricultural techniques.
Last, but hardly least, it might pay to roll with the greenhouse punch, accepting some increase in atmospheric temperature and mitigating the consequences. That might, for example, include irrigation of regions that lose rainfall, or building dikes around coastal cities threatened by rising ocean levels.
Rolling with the greenhouse punch would cost a small fortune. But if the Manne-Richels numbers are on the mark, confronting the problem directly would cost a large one.

HEADLINE: Slump in Securities Industry

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
Four senior securities executives told Congress today that their industry was in a period of economic decline, but said only minor legislative changes were needed.
In general, the executives testified that the securities business was cyclical, with any downturn followed by an upturn. 
''There is no question that the industry is at low ebb right now, economically, and to some extent, in its public image,'' said Robert N. Downey, chairman of the Securities Industry Association, the leading industry trade group.
John H. Gutfreund, the chairman and chief executive of Salomon Inc., said: ''The problem of the 80's - in terms of the excess leveraging - nature has taken care of that. There is no question that we can do very well in the 90's in our industry.''
W. Lucas Simmons, managing partner of J. C. Bradford & Company, a Nashville-based brokerage, and Philip J. Purcell, chairman and chief executive of Dean Witter Financial Services Group, also testified.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat who heads the securities subcommittee of the Senate Banking Committee, had asked the executives for their appraisal of the securities industry, especially in the wake of the recent collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
The panel unanimously endorsed only one recommendation: giving the Securities and Exchange Commission exclusive regulatory authority over stock-index futures. At the moment, the Commodities Futures Trading Commission regulates those stock-index futures.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Shifting Auto Gears by Computer

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
Sports cars and automatic transmissions have never mixed well. Car enthusiasts say automatics rob a car of performance and fuel economy while giving the driver less control than a manual gearbox.
Now Porsche A.G. hopes to change all that with the Tiptronic, a new automatic that uses a microprocessor and an array of electronic sensors to provide better performance, economy and control. It was co-developed with Robert Bosch G.m.b.H., the German electronics concern, and ZF-Getriebe G.m.b.H., the German transmission manufacturer. 
The Tiptronic is already being sold in Europe on the Porsche 911 Carrera 2, and will be available on that car in the United States in late spring or early summer. Auto analysts say variants are likely to appear soon in other sports/ luxury cars, beginning with those from the German manufacturers BMW and Mercedes. And some executives say that similar electronically controlled automatic transmissions will not only become common in the 1990's, but may be essential in meeting more stringent emission and fuel economy standards.
While conventional automatics respond to a very limited set of mechanical data in determining when to shift - engine speed, road speed, the position of the gas pedal - the Tiptronic considers 40 kinds of data, responding to electronic sensors that measure lateral forces in a turn as well as forward acceleration, engine and air temperature and even the driver's driving style. It also compensates for altitude and wear.
Some contemporary automatics allow the driver to choose between ''sport'' and ''economy'' modes of shifting; the Tiptronic chooses for itself, among five shift patterns. For example, sensors detect whether a driver presses the accelerator more rapidly than normal, something that alerts the gearbox to shift into its ''performance'' program. Drivers can also use the gearbox manually; here, too, the Tiptronic differs from other automatics.
 
'A Two-Personality Gearbox'
The Tiptronic's shift lever moves in two planes, one marked with the normal Park, Reverse, Neutral, Drive and gears one through three; the other plane, to the right of the normal selector panel, is labeled Plus and Minus. In that setting, tipping the lever forward shifts up one gear and backward down one gear, much the way the shift pedal on a motorcycle works. This prevents the overshifting that can occur when a driver tries to shift from, say, first to second gear on a conventional automatic.
''It's a two-personality gearbox; it acts almost like any automatic gearbox but it's a bit smarter than most,'' said Victor H. Elford, a former Porsche racing driver who now manages promotional activities for the company in the United States. ''It almost thinks for you.''
Even using the Tiptronic in manual mode, ''you can't make it do anything wrong,'' Mr. Elford said. ''When you get to the red line it will shift anyway, even at full throttle, so smoothly you hardly notice it,'' he said. ''It almost makes a traditional manual transmission obsolete.''
 
Microprocessor Is the Key
Internally, the Tiptronic is similar to other automatic transmissions. What sets it apart is the microprocessor, the computer-on-a-chip found at the heart of personal computers and, increasingly, in automobile engine control systems. The microprocessor interprets the input from the various sensors and selects among the five shift patterns stored in memory.
It also helps eliminate many of the unpleasant traits of conventional automatics, like undesired shifting back and forth between two gears or shifting at the wrong moment. With other automatics, if a driver lifts off the accelerator pedal in a tight turn, a shift to the next higher gear occurs, which can cause a loss of control. The Tiptronic electronically senses that the car is in a turn and will hold the gear until an upshift is appropriate.
Peter Albrecht, engineering editor for Sports Car International, an enthusiasts' magazine, said that he and most other Porsche lovers would probably still prefer a car with a clutch pedal, but that the Tiptronic was the most capable automatic available. ''If you have to have an automatic, this is the best way because you can have your cake and eat it too,'' he said. ''It gives you a far greater degree of control than a normal automatic does.''
 
Meeting the Requirements
Porsche calls the Tiptronic ''transmission technology for tomorrow,'' and Mr. Albrecht said this might be more than just sloganeering. ''Porsche thinks that in the future it may be necessary for all cars to have automatics just to meet emission and fuel efficiency requirements,'' he said.
Indeed, the Tiptronic transmission already equals the performance of manual transmissions for those two standards; engineers expect future electronic transmissions to be more efficient than manual ones. By controlling shifts electronically an engine could be held in the proper range of revolutions per minute at all times to maximize economy and minimize pollutants. The Tiptronic, for example, raises the r.p.m. of the points at which it shifts when an engine is cold in order to warm up the catalytic converter faster, thereby reducing emissions.
Performance suffers slightly for the Tiptronic-equipped 911, which accelerates from 0 to 60 miles an hour in 6.3 seconds, compared with 5.5 seconds for a similar Porsche equipped with a five-speed manual gearbox. Fuel economy is similar. Porsche expects a fifth of Carrera 2's sold to be equipped with the Tiptronic, but at this stage the technology is not cheap. The Tiptronic adds $3,255 to the $58,500 base price of a 911 Carrera 2.
 
Broad Use Expected
Nevertheless, this kind of technology is likely to appear in a wide array of cars in a few years. Auto analysts say that just as electronically controlled engines and antilock breaking systems have moved from elite sporting vehicles to mass-production cars, so too will electronically controlled automatic transmissions.
''In the near term, we will have a sizable volume in electronically controlled transmissions,'' said Donald L. Runkle, the General Motors Corporation's vice president, advanced engineering staff. As a long-term research effort, General Motors is developing electronic automatic transmissions with seven or eight speeds, compared with the typical three or four.
''We are spending quite a bit of energy on electronic control of the shift schedule, and interfacing the transmission with the engine,'' Mr. Runkle said. By linking the engine and transmission electronically, one microprocessor can control both, which would reduce costs and optimize fuel economy and reduce emissions.
