HEADLINE: Market Place;
Looking Beyond The Debt Burden

BYLINE: By Phillip H. Wiggins

 BODY:
AS the fallout from the heady days of overleveraging continues, investors have abandoned the stocks of many companies with high levels of debt on their balance sheets.
Doubtless most of these are deservedly abandoned. But some Wall Street specialists say the selloff of these stocks has left good buys among some leveraged companies that generate enough cash flow to manage their debt and still record strong profits.
''The prices of some quality, highly leveraged companies may not reflect the underlying value of the stock,'' Neil R. Feldman, an analyst at Gruntal & Company, said in a telephone interview. ''It appears that investors have tended to discount these companies, given their heavy debt load. As a result, many of these stocks are trading at undervalued levels.'' 
Finding bargains among the highly indebted is not a game for everyone. Several analysts, including Mr. Feldman, are quick to warn that highly leveraged companies remain vulnerable to an economic downturn or rising interest rates - either of which could hurt their ability to pay off the debt or indeed to survive.
To evaluate companies with lots of debt, some analysts recommend that investors focus on cash flow because it can be indicative of the earning power of a company. Cash flow is generally defined as net income plus depreciation minus preferred dividends. But looking at cash flow may not be enough. Some analysts say investors should also calculate the cash-flow-to-price ratio. To do this, an investor needs to first obtain a cash flow per-share figure by dividing the dollar amount of cash flow by the company's total shares outstanding in the latest full fiscal year. The cash-flow-to-price ratio is achieved by dividing the stock's price by the cash flow per share.
According to Wall Street analysts, stocks are now trading at about eight times cash flow and investors should seek companies trading at less than that.
Joseph Arsenio, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco, points to the IDB Communications Group, as an example of a company with a low cash-flow-to-price ratio. The company, an independent supplier of satellite transmission services for radio and television programming in Culver City, Calif., trades on the over-the-counter market.
Recently, IDB announced that Teleglobe International U.S., Inc. had purchased a 20 percent stake through the acquisition of a little more than 1.2 million shares at $11.165 a share. With the Teleglobe investment, IDB's debt-to-equity ratio was reduced from 5 to 1 to about 2.6 to 1; its long-term debt decreased by $13 million, to about $90 million. Mr. Arsenio's 1990 earnings estimate is 51 cents a share. Based on a projected 1990 cash flow per share of $1.80 and a closing price of $9 a share yesterday in over-the-counter trading, IDB is selling at five times cash flow, making it attractive.
Superior Teletec Inc. of Atlanta is a $108 million manufacturer of copper telephone wire and cables, test equipment for transmission lines, and specialty fiber optic products for the telecommunications industry. The company's customers include independent telephone companies, like the GTE Corporation, and regional Bell operating companies, like Nynex.
Analysts say that the company's debt was incurred under an earlier management and in a completely different business that did not generate the cash levels necessary to service the debt. Some analysts also say that cash flow for the fiscal year 1990 ending March 31 is expected to be 80 cents a share, and earnings are likely to increase to between 45 cents and 50 cents a share.
The fiscal year 1989's net income was 30 cents a share. Some analysts rate the stock, selling at 5.5 times projected 1990 cash flow, as a buy. The stock closed yesterday at $4.375 on the American Stock Exchange.
Mr. Hackel of Systematic Financial focuses solely on ''free cash flow,'' or the maximum amount of cash a company can distribute to its stockholders.
''VF Corporation, at 8.3 times its four-year average operating cash flow and 12 times free cash flow, and Ethyl, at 8.7 times operating flow and 12 times free cash flow, are two consistent free cash flow producers, and only moderately leveraged,'' Mr. Hackel said. ''Both stocks have needlessly declined so far this year.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Notes and Bonds Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in thin trading yesterday, as many dealers who sold securities on Monday turned around and bought them yesterday.
''For all practical purposes, prices are as low as they have been all year, and that led some folks to figure they should go ahead and take a shot,'' one government bond trader said.
But the buying that was going on was largely done by the dealers themselves, not retail investors, market participants said.
''This bounce is not retail-inspired,'' the bond trader said. ''This is a largely professional trading market.'' 
A report that new factory orders in February posted their largest one-month decline since 1974 had no impact on the credit markets. Analysts said the next important piece of economic data will not be released until Friday, when February employment statistics are expected.
 
Drop in Factory Orders
''The big decline in factory orders reflected the big drop in durable goods orders we saw last week,'' said Stephen W. Gallagher, a money market economist at Kidder, Peabody & Company.
Mr. Gallagher said that while the coming employment report had the potential to move the prices out of the narrow trading range they have occupied for the last two weeks, it would probably take more data to move the market.
''We probably need to see a good round of inflation numbers for February before we can get out of these ranges,'' he said.
Yesterday's price gains made up most of the losses that were recorded Monday.
In late trading, the 8 1/2 percent Treasury bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 99 1/4, up 25/32, to yield 8.56 percent. Late Monday the closely watched issue was quoted at a price to yield 8.64 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 19/ 32 late yesterday, up half a point, to yield 8.56 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 100, up 3/32, to yield 8.50 percent.
 
Bill Rates Are Mixed
Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.87 percent, up four basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged, at an offered rate of 7.77 percent. And one-year bill rates dipped by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.69 percent.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, a $114.8 million offering of bonds from the New York State Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency was tentatively priced through an underwriting syndicate led by WR Lazard & Laidlaw Inc.
The issue consists of serial and term bonds.
Coupons on the serial bonds range from 6 percent on securities maturing in 1991 to 7.40 percent on bonds that mature in 2002.
Among the term issues, the 7.70 percent bonds maturing in 2010 were priced to yield 7.75 percent, while the 7 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were priced to yield 7.79 percent.
The issue is rated A by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the new issue market for investment-grade corporate bonds, the First Boston Corporation acted as lead manager for a $150 million offering of 10-year notes for the Japanese Finance Corporation for Municipal Enterprises.
The 9 1/8 percent bonds, which are guaranteed by the Japanese Government, were priced at $99.709, to yield 9.17 percent, 52 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/2 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's and S. & P..
Participants in the secondary markets for tax-exempt municipal bonds and investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most actively traded issues were unchanged. Activity was said to be very sluggish in both markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Higher in U.S. After Declining Overseas

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mostly higher in domestic trading after falling overseas in the absence of any major developments to move the foreign exchange markets.
The dollar closed in New York at 149.85 yen, up from Monday's 148.96 yen. And it rose to 1.7035 West German marks, from 1.6970 late Monday. 
The dollar declined in early trading because of speculation that an interest rate increase in Japan was imminent. Such a rise would bolster the yen against the dollar. When the increase did not materialize, the dollar recovered some ground in Europe, although it still closed down from Monday's levels.
The dollar then moved higher against most currencies in New York. Robert Ryan, senior foreign exchange trader with the Bank of New York Company, said the market shied away from testing the upper end of the dollar's trading range, the point at which central banks, including the Federal Reserve, would be expected to step in and try to push the dollar down.
 
Bank of Japan Acts
The Bank of Japan intervened in Asian dealings overnight, pushing the dollar down. Dealers said the Fed sold dollars for yen late in the day in the European market, but the impact was minimal.
The rise in the dollar yesterday came after it fell sharply on Monday following a coordinated round of dollar selling by the Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan and the West German Bundesbank.
The Bank of Japan and the Fed have been selling dollars against yen for two weeks in an effort to support the yen, whose weakness was widely cited as a reason for the recent sharp fall in the Tokyo stock market.
The Bundesbank signaled its unhappiness with the rise of the dollar against the mark by selling dollars Friday. The Bundesbank wants to keep the mark strong to help it fight the inflation that might result from the unification of the two Germanys.
In Europe, the dollar closed at 149.75 yen after slipping by 0.45 yen in earlier Tokyo trading to 149.50 yen.
Mr. Ryan said traders generally were awaiting the Labor Department's employment report for February, scheduled for release Friday. The market expected the nation's non-farm payroll to have expanded by 225,000 jobs, indicating that the economy is stronger than many have thought.
Such a report is expected to move the dollar higher because the Fed is less likely to nudge interest rates down - which would diminish returns on dollar-denominated investments - when the economy shows signs of strength.
The dollar fell against the British pound yesterday. In New York, sterling was quoted at $1.6475, up from $1.6445 late Monday, and in earlier London dealings, it rose to $1.6495 from $1.6390.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, were: 1.5000 Swiss francs, up from 1.4970; 5.7565 French francs, up from 5.7330; 1,257.00 Italian lire, up from 1,252.00, and 1.18565 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18905.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Fictional and Factual Views On the Future of China

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Heavy Wings
By Zhang Jie
Translated by Howard Goldblatt. 308 pages. Grove Weidenfeld. $19.95.
 
'Tell the World'
What Happened in China and Why
By Liu Binyan with Ruan Ming and Xu Gang
Translated by Henry L. Epstein. 195 pages. Pantheon Books. $18.95. 
The clouds of censorship that still hover over Tiananmen Square are parted in two newly translated books in which dissidents voice their most intimate ideas and dreams about China today and tomorrow. As readers who have followed recent events in Eastern Europe have discovered, the first truths about freedom or the lack of it often appear in novels, plays and reports from the underground.
Zhang Jie's novel, ''Heavy Wings,'' first published in China nine years ago, foreshadows the frustrations that erupted in student demonstrations last year and led to the democracy movement. Her fictional characters are not simply political puppets but vividly realistic women and men whose family goals and working problems appear universal. At heart this is a story about the struggle of a small group of people to break out of a rigid social and economic structure and seek the right to express themselves as individuals.
The main characters in ''Heavy Wings'' have experiences that resemble some in the author's life. She graduated from People's University in Beijing in the late 1950's, then worked as a government statistician until she was sent to the countryside for ''re-education'' and given a factory job. After the Cultural Revolution, she began to write this outspokenly critical novel about the unswerving hold of China's society before and after the Communist takeover.
In her novel, the fictional Morning Light Auto Works in Beijing is the center of the struggle between reformers and party hard-liners. The novel's family includes a deputy minister of heavy industry, his unhappy wife and a rebellious daughter who wants to marry a man with a checkered past for love. The dialectic is present, but it would be an oversimplification to call this another boy-meets-girl-meets-tractor story.
We watch as government intrudes on the personal lives of these characters. Here, for example, is a glimpse of the author's boldness in describing a morning at the factory: ''Strange how a branch secretary who has dished it out to disgruntled workers for over 20 years can suddenly fall prey to the same discontent himself. How has it come to this? At first he was angry, as though someone had moved his memorial tablet in Heaven.''
There are some 30 characters in ''Heavy Wings,'' often making it difficult to distinguish among them. But it is worth the effort for American readers willing to meet a Chinese novelist of knowledge and courage.
Zhang Jie now lives in Connecticut and teaches at Wesleyan University.
In '' 'Tell the World,' '' Liu Binyan, probably China's best-known investigative reporter, describes what happened in Tiananmen Square in June 1989 and why. Because of his earlier reporting of corruption in the Communist Party, he lost his job on People's Daily, was expelled from the party and now lectures in the United States. His co-authors are Ruan Ming, a former party theoretician who is at Columbia University, and Xu Gang, a poet who participated in the democracy movement last year and now lives in Paris, where he edits Chinese Writers, a journal. The book was translated from the Chinese by Henry L. Epstein.
In an unusually frank interpretation of the motives of the Tiananmen Square demonstrators, this is how Liu Binyan characterizes the young men and women who, for one brief shining moment, dominated Beijing and astonished the world:
''They were the most selfish generation since 1949. They were cynical, contemptuous of all authority, had no hope of nor good feeling toward the Communist Party. They did not think China had a future; nor did they think they had a responsibility for their country and society. However, precisely because they valued their own feelings and individuality so highly, they could, compared with previous generations, least tolerate the suppression of individuality, the limits on freedom and anything else against human nature that was imposed by the tradition created by the Communist Party. They grew up at a time when all traditions had lost their effect, so they never gave themselves up to the constraint of any party or ideology.''
Although helicopters instead of kites now fly over Tiananmen Square, the author writes that the Chinese people will no longer allow what he labels ''the Gang of the Old'' to control their destiny. He predicts that ''a people's movement will expand from the bottom up'' and that ''relatively moderate'' leaders will emerge to replace the hard-liners in the next Chinese Government.
Unlike ''Heavy Wings,'' which appeared during a period of openness in Beijing, '' 'Tell the World' '' has not been published in China.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1004 words

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
GORBACHEV WANTS LITHUANIA TO PAY BILLIONS TO SECEDE

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 7

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has demanded that Lithuania pay compensation equivalent to $33 billion if the republic goes ahead with plans to secede from the Soviet Union, Lithuanian officials said today.
Mr. Gorbachev also challenged Lithuania's boundaries for the first time, suggesting that the republic must surrender the major Baltic port city of Klaipeda and other territory before going its own way.
Lithuanians rejected the demands but said Mr. Gorbachev's readiness to begin negotiating the terms of separation was a clear sign that the Kremlin had accepted in principle the republic's right to leave the union.
 
Independence Move Expected
The Lithuanian Parliament has scheduled a meeting Sunday at which it is expected to declare the restoration of the independent nation that existed before the Baltic republics were forcibly annexed by Stalin in 1940. 
In an interview tonight on Lithuanian television, Algirdas Brazauskas, the Lithuanian president and Communist leader, said Mr. Gorbachev had told him that Moscow's financial claims would have to be paid in Western currency rather than Soviet rubles.
''We don't have this kind of hard currency, and to be sure we won't have it for some time,'' Algas Zukas, an aide to Mr. Brazauskas, said in a telephone interview.
The Soviet ruble is nonconvertible -that is, its exchange is strictly controlled by the Government. Western currencies like the American dollar, the Japanese yen and the West German mark are all hard, or convertible - their value is determined by market forces and they can be freely exchanged for other currencies.
It could not be learned what hard currency, if any, the Lithuanians now have. But if they become sovereign, the Lithuanians could conceivably try to borrow from Western banks, countries or international lending agencies.
Mr. Brazauskas, who has generally supported a gradual, negotiated secession, bristled tonight when the television interviewer suggested that he and Mr. Gorbachev were trying to frighten Lithuanians into postponing independence.
 
Argument With Gorbachev
The Lithuanian leader denied that he was trying to slow the process of independence, and reported that he argued with Mr. Gorbachev on several points during the 90-minute meeting.
The Lithuanian leader did not disclose the size of the Soviet leader's financial claims, but in the Lithuanian capital, the Vilnius radio said Mr. Gorbachev presented documents putting the republic's obligations to Moscow at 17 billion rubles for capital investment in the republic and 4 billion rubles for undelivered production.
Lithuanian officials confirmed the sum, which would amount to $33 billion at official exchange rates. [The Lithuanian press agency, Elta, quoted Mr. Brazauskas as saying that the Baltic republic's annual trade with the rest of the Soviet Union amounts to about $13 billion a year, about one-third of its annual national product.] Mr. Gorbachev has also indicated that Moscow wants the republic to pay relocation costs and compensation for any Russians who choose to leave Lithuania.
''Gorbachev said that if Lithuania proclaimed independence, its economic relations with the Soviet Union should be legalized as relations between two independent states, and accounts will have to be settled in freely convertible currency,'' Mr. Zukas said.
 
'No Extreme Measures'
''This can be interpreted as recognition that if independence does come about, no extreme measures will be taken, but relations will be established as between two states,'' the party aide added. ''That is the way we see it.''
Lithuanians demonstrated their support for secession in elections Feb. 24, when the pro-independence movement Sajudis swept the ruling Communist Party from power. Sajudis candidates hold 90 of the 116 seats filled so far in the Lithuanian Parliament.
On Sunday, the Lithuanian Parliament is expected to declare the formal establishment of an autonomous state, and initiate negotiations as equals with the Soviet Government in Moscow on future relations.
The key questions would be removal of more than 30,000 Soviet troops based in the republic, the division of industrial assets, the clarification of boundaries, and financial claims of Russian- or Polish-speaking citizens who want to relocate to Russia.
 
Claims by Lithuania
Moscow's financial claims are disputed by Lithuania, which argues that Soviet investments are offset by Lithuanian claims - including the use of Lithuanian ports and military bases, the right-of-way used to pipe Soviet oil to Eastern Europe, and the compensation for thousands of Lithuanians interned at forced labor or killed after the Red Army occupation, which followed the Soviet-Nazi nonaggression pact of 1939.
Anticipating that Moscow may try to apply economic pressure, economists in the republic have already prepared detailed reports on coping with an economic blockade.
Mr. Zukas said that Mr. Gorbachev had raised the issue of borders, questioning Lithuania's right to at least two cities.
 
Status of Klaipeda
The most contentious element is likely to be the port of Klaipeda, an important base of the Baltic fishing fleet and a center of shipbuilding and electronics.
Historically a German port, Klaipeda, then called Memel, was administered by the Allied Powers after World War I and then given to independent Lithuania. Hitler reclaimed it in March 1939 by threat of force.
The Soviet Union took over the port in 1945, and Mr. Gorbachev now apparently claims that since it was ceded directly to Moscow, it is Soviet, not Lithuanian territory.
''It is asserted that no official documents exist certifying the annexation of Klaipeda to Lithuania,'' Mr. Zukas said. ''that is, Klaipeda is suspended in the air, legally speaking.''
He said one possibility under discussion was to make the port an autonomous zone.
Mr. Gorbachev reportedly also challenged Lithuania's right to Druskininkai, near the Byelorussian border, a spa city famous for its mud baths.

PUB-DATE: March 8, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
In West Germany, Anxiety Over Unity

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMBURG, West Germany, March 2

 BODY:
In the turbulent debate about German unification, West Germany's intellectuals reflect a national mood of confusion - a profoundly troubled mix of anticipation, anxiety and resentment.
What many of them resent is not only that the rest of the world has reservations about the prospect of one Germany again, after 45 years of partition. They are irritated by the undertone: the suggestion that there are still doubts, even after so long, about the depth and permanence of the West German commitment to peace and democracy.
A united German nation, feeling misunderstood and brooding with resentment about the outside world as it did under the Weimar Republic, would indeed be a repetition of history that none of its neighbors want. But there are internal causes for the confusion, as well - divisions between West German generations, and between the intellectual traditions of the two Germanys. 
 
Writings and Comments
The difficulties are evident from the writings and comments of some leading opinion makers in West Germany that follow.
One of the key factors is the distance that West Germans too young to have experienced or borne responsibility for the Nazi crimes feel toward the horrors of Auschwitz, the Holocaust and World War II.
Few of those under 50 still feel the anguish that Gunter Grass, at 62 probably West Germany's best-known writer, felt in 1945 as a youth of 17, when American soldiers showed him photographs of the piles of spectacles, shorn hair and corpses of the victims of Auschwitz. Insult or Equation? His first reaction, he recently recalled in a lecture given to students at Frankfurt University, was that it couldn't have happened, that Germans couldn't have done this. Later, he said, he knew that Auschwitz could never be forgiven, never be overcome - Germans would bear it like a brand until the end of history.
Auschwitz could not have happened then without a united Germany, he argued, and so Auschwitz forbids German unification now.
Mr. Grass's thesis is part of the intellectual debate, though few West German leaders agree that unification led to Auschwitz. Indeed, some younger writers resent this equation, which they believe is an unstated premise of much of the foreign criticism, as a personal insult. Many young Germans refuse to accept that they have been ''branded.''
Dr. Michael Naumann, the 48-year-old head of the Rowohlt Verlag publishing house in Hamburg, for example, said that during a business trip to New York last month, he found, as he put it, that ''they think we're about to reopen the concentration camps.''
Dr. Naumann, who fled Communism with his part-Jewish mother from Kothen in East Germany when he was 12, in 1953, resented this suggestion from American acquaintances. ''What you are saying is that you, Michael, are just like your father's generation,'' he said.
West Germany's intellectual tradition, unlike East Germany's, did not pretend that nobody alive in West Germany after 1945 had had anything to do with the crimes that had taken place before. Many West German journalists and writers, like their politicians and bureaucrats, did not come pure from emigration like Thomas Mann or Willy Brandt, but had tainted pasts as servants of the Nazi regime - something that has been outraging left-wing West German intellectuals for 40 years.
By its very nature, the ambiguity - and the Federal Republic's commitment to democracy and the European Community -kept the question of responsibility in the air in West Germany.
Indeed, attempts to explain how the same people who had been such good citizens of Europe since 1945 spat on all its values before then and nearly wrecked it forever were a central theme of the first West German postwar books about Hitler.
 
Victory of Open Society
The author of one of the first of these, Joachim C. Fest, now 62 and a co-publisher of the daily Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, is one of those who welcome unification now as the victory of an open German society over a closed one.
But even many West German intellectuals are not sure of how to integrate the East German intellectual tradition into their own. For in the German Democratic Republic, as Monika Maron, a 48-year-old writer from that country wrote recently, the official attitude was that the war crimes were the product of German imperialism.
That did not exist on the soil of the first ''socialist'' state in German history, and therefore East Germans were taught to feel no responsibility for it. Communist ideology may have been idealistic in the early postwar days when leftist writers like Bertolt Brecht found their way back from exile to what was to become East Berlin. But by the mid-1950's, it was totalitarian and Stalinist, and until last fall, East German intellectuals who questioned the official line there were either silenced, imprisoned or expelled.
Mrs. Maron, forbidden to publish in East Germany for 10 years, was allowed to leave two years ago for Hamburg with her husband and her 21-year-old son, Jonas. It is natural, perhaps, that she welcomes unification as a kind of liberation. But many others, in East and West, say they would prefer liberalization in an East German state that remained economically and politically separate from West Germany, in a loose confederation that nobody seems quite able to define.
 
Unification, Not Reunification
Unification (most West German intellectuals prefer that word to ''reunification,'' which they say implies a return to the prewar German state) could, indeed, bring a repetition of history, Dr. Naumann and Mr. Fest both said, though not the one the rest of the world fears.
The Communists who ran and repressed East Germany, they said, would have to be decommunized in a process probably just as fallible and ridden with compromises as denazification was after the war.
In many conversations these days, German intellectuals deplore the current political debate in Bonn about whether to recognize the East German border with Poland, as providing ammunition for those who fear that unification will revive German expansionism in the East.
The debate is a typically German preoccupation with an abstraction that has almost nothing to do with reality, most of them felt. Chancellor Helmut Kohl was playing domestic politics with the question of whether, in legal theory, the prewar German Reich somehow still existed, thus preventing anything short of a reunited Germany from finally renouncing Silesia and Pomerania and East Prussia and the Sudetenland, 45 years after they were lost forever along with the war itself.
The real problems of reunification, some thinkers believe, will come from the effects of nearly half a century of division across not just a wall but a world. West Germans have always felt somewhat guilty about the deprivations and sufferings of their brothers and sisters in the east. Now they feel guilty even when they ask how much unification is going to cost them.
Here are some fragments of writings and conversation with a few of these German voices at a crucial moment in German history. One of them is Werner Hofer, a 76-year-old journalist who ran the country's best known Sunday television talk show until 1987, when questions once again surfaced about his work as a journalist during the war. ''We've become a different people,'' he believes today.
The others include Klaus Harpprecht, a 62-year-old author and former speechwriter for Mr. Brandt whose wife, Renate Lasker Harpprecht, is a survivor of the Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen concentration camps, and Mr. Kohl's predecessor as Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, now 71 years old and co-publisher of the weekly journal Die Zeit.
 
Gunter Grass/Writer
 
'We Cannot Get By Auschwitz'
From his lecture ''Writing after Auschwitz,'' delivered Feb. 13 in Frankfurt and Feb. 25 in East Berlin:
When I, like many of my generation, was first confronted with the results of crimes for which Germans were responsible that are summed up by the word Auschwitz, I said: Never.
Even when this 'never' or 'never ever' was destroyed (at the latest, by the Nuremberg trials) . . . it took years until I began to understand: It will never go away; our shame can never be repressed or overcome . . . Auschwitz can never be comprehended, no matter how many explanations surround it.
Auschwitz speaks against even a right of self-determination that is enjoyed by all other peoples, because one of the preconditions for the horror, besides other, older urges, was a strong, united Germany. Not Prussia, not Bavaria, not even Austria, alone, could have developed and carried out the will and the method for organized genocide; it required a united Germany.
We have every reason to be afraid of ourselves as a functioning unity. . . . We cannot get by Auschwitz. We shouldn't even try, as great as the temptation is, because Auschwitz belongs to us, is branded into our history and - to our benefit! - made possible an insight that could be summed up as: Now we finally know ourselves.''
 
Klaus Harpprecht/Writer
 
European Unity: 'The Most Urgent Task'
I was, like everybody else, profoundly moved by what happened in Eastern Europe - I wrote my first book, ''Der Aufstand,'' in 1954 about the workers' uprising on the 17th of June 1953. Our French neighbors in La Croix-Valmer shared the joy, in November and December, but they quickly developed uneasiness when the tempo began to accelerate in December. My barber told me, ''It's beginning to scare me.''
The great problem of a united Germany in the past was that its weight overwhelmed the rest of Europe. Our neighbors wouldn't be quite so upset if the European Community had developed enough authority to counterbalance this fear today. The Warsaw Pact doesn't exist anymore, NATO is weakening as a force capable of providing this kind of order, and the only thing left is the European Community. The most urgent task before us is to accelerate steps toward European unity.
I fear a resurgence of nationalism, and I would rather have had a confederation. It's a tragedy that East German society fell apart like a house of cards so fast. The majority of Germans would have been satisfied with a confederation, but now they've worked themselves into a sort of delirium that disturbs me.
But I don't agree with Gunter Grass that Auschwitz was a consequence of German unity, and have written him to tell him so. Renate, who survived Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen, shares this view.
 
Michael Naumann/Book Publisher
 
'The Right of Self-Determination'
My father died in the battle of Stalingrad, but my mother was one-quarter Jewish, and by 1945 the Nazis were beginning to go after people like her. Most of her family immigrated to England or the United States. We stayed in Kothen, in what became East Germany, and in 1953 there was a big workers' revolt and the Communists went looking for scapegoats. This time they weren't looking for the ''race enemy'' but for the ''class enemy.'' Only the names had changed. We left in the middle of the night, I left some food for my fishes, which hurt me very much at the age of 12 at the time, and I really hold the loss of my childhood against the Communists. I have no nostalgia for East Germany.
In February I finally went back, for the first time, and nothing had changed. I had scratched a ''B'' on the wall, and it was still there. The shutters of our house were still painted green. But it wasn't nostalgic - it was filled with horrible memories. I saw the house where Jutta Wolf, the girl I used to play with, lived, but she wasn't there. In 1961, her husband escaped to West Germany, and she got caught when she tried to follow - her three-month old baby was taken away from her and she spent two years in prison, tried to escape and was caught again and spent three more years in prison. For what - trying to rejoin her husband.
Emotionally I was happy not to be a citizen of the same country as Erich Honecker, Hermann Axen, Gunter Mittag and all those Communists - and I assumed reunification would bring us some of the same problems as we had with denazification after the war, another generation of compromisers, political cowards, killers and collaborators. So I don't get excited about reunification, and I don't want to get any of my property back.
But what worries me in the extreme is that abroad, in England, France and America, people will, willingly or unwillingly, prompt a resurgence of the nationalism that people of my generation fought so hard to get rid of. Denying the right of self-determination to Germans is appalling. What you're saying is that you, Michael, are just like your father's generation. I don't trust you - you're the people who started two world wars.
I agree that the neighbors of Germany have a right to fear unification, but their politicians don't have a right to exploit those fears to win votes, the way the leaders of Italy, France and Britain have been doing. In New York, they think we're reopening the concentration camps.''
 
Joachim C. Fest/Newspaper Publisher
 
'A Victory of an Open Society'
In principle, I've always supported Democrats were wrong to write it off and recognize a regime that never even had human rights. I never thought it would collapse so fast, but I'm happy it did. It is a victory of an open society over a closed society, and I'm just as happy about the similar developments in Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia as I am about East Germany.
If things could develop more slowly and peacefully, I'd prefer it. But I don't think it's possible. I've been in the G.D.R. three times, and people there say they only have one life to live and they just can't wait. I think we'll have to accept it, even though there could be great problems - Communists have a long tradition of undermining democratic institutions from minority positions. Suppose a core of convinced Communists infiltrates our unions, universities and so on?
As far as the border with Poland is concerned, it's a question in two parts - the political question is solved, nobody's going to change the border. But the juridical one can't be solved until there's a government of a united Germany to declare it's not going to change the border. The expellees who were driven out of the former German territories there don't want any of them back. I was in Breslau (Wroclaw) last summer and saw busloads of the expellees visiting ever day, and I asked them, do you want to come back and live here? And they said, ''No, for God's sake, we just want to look around.'' Let them visit, let them buy houses and even factories if they want to. It's the same as if I wanted to buy a house in Alsace. If I have the money, I can do it and there's no problem - even though there's a border between France and Germany. I hope it can eventually be that way in the East.''
 
Werner Hofer/Former TV Journalist
 
'Who Are Our Enemies Going to Be?'
We have to move fast because if things go on the way they are now, the influx of people from East Germany here will be catastrophic. You already see a kind of ''racism'' about it here. At first, people welcomed the East Germans. Now they say they should stay where they belong. Some people are afraid of losing jobs to them. Others look forward to holding an Olympic Games in Berlin in the year 2000 with a single German team that will win all the gold medals!
The people of the G.D.R. have us to help them. We had help from the Americans, who had thought carefully about what should become of Germany and enabled us to make something of ourselves. We owe our good economic performance to the fact that we lost two wars and had to send all our old plants to France, Britain and the Soviet Union after the last one.
What will be more difficult are the political and military questions. Who are our enemies going to be? Both the Warsaw Pact and NATO are already having trouble justifying themselves. A few weeks ago, here in Cologne, there were rumors that the Belgian army was going to pull out, and there was panic here. Not because of any defense function they perform, but because they provide jobs and because people know them.
I told the child of a friend, a few weeks ago, ''Stefanie, what a fortunate child you are -you and your children will never experience a nuclear war in Europe.'' If it were up to Gorbachev, the Soviets wouldn't have 3,000 soldiers in Europe. But it would be a catastrophe for us Germans, who have brought so many to the rest of the world, if Gorbachev failed now.
 
Helmut Schmidt/Former Chancellor
 
'If the French and the Poles Agree to It'
The real beginning of the Eastern European revolution was in Poland, 10 years ago. They were the pioneers. I told Erich Honecker, back in 1981, ''Why don't you open the borders - let people travel wherever they want,'' and he told me, ''I can't. They won't come back.'' And he was right.
I saw the avalanche coming at the end of August, when it began to be clear that the Hungarians would let all those East German vacationers cross the border and go west. But I never thought it would happen so fast. Now economic unity is already coming about, unofficially. Political, formal unity is a completely different thing, and it could take months, or it could take years. It's not impossible it could be accomplished by the end of this year, though it's rather improbable, I would say.
Where I fault our political leaders is that they haven't taken the feelings of our European neighbors into account. German unification can only be legitimate if the French and the Poles agree to it. Both nations have existed for a thousand years - 800 years longer than the Americans. There will always be a negative attitude in New York to German unification, but it doesn't matter. What really matters now is the soul of the Polish nation and the French nation. The Germans have not gone far enough to calm their concerns.
It was a major mistake not to create the European Monetary System years ago, to really persuade the French that Germany was willing to be a real part of the European system. It was a mistake for Helmut Kohl to just go ahead and announce his proposal for a monetary union with the G.D.R. These things have to have the effect, on the Danes, the Dutch and the Belgians, of making them feel the Germans are already behaving the way we were afraid they would once they were reunited.
But there's no European leadership at all at the moment. Maggie Thatcher is the only outstanding personality, but she's on the wrong wavelength. We need a European Marshall Plan for Eastern Europe, and the European Community leaders should be sitting around and talk about it informally, among themselves. But it isn't happening.
 
Monika Maron/Writer
 
'Germans Are Terribly Anxious'
I left the G.D.R. two years ago, for a three-year period in Hamburg, so I knew something would happen there. But that all the dikes would break at once, that I didn't see coming.
But I've been for unification for some time. It's duality I'm afraid of. When there are two German states, the smaller one can only make itself legitimate by building up some kind of separatist ideology, and we know what that led to.
The first trip I took to West Germany was in 1983, and ever since, it's been harder for me to understand why there were two Germanies than to imagine how there could be one. The Rhine did it. I had been to the Frankfurt Book Fair, and had had too much to eat and drink the night before, and the next morning I was on a train to Wuppertal and opened my eyes and looked out the window and said, 'My God, what is that?' And the other passengers in the compartment said it was the Rhine. I looked out the window at this landscape of river and hills and knew right away it was a thoroughly German landscape - kitschy and sentimental as the thought was. It couldn't be anything else.
Germans are terribly anxious. Maybe it comes from the Thirty Years' War, this irrational love of order and security, because Germany was born out of war and insecurity, and periodically insecurity turns to panic and then the Germans go crazy. Maybe once they become a single state, embedded firmly in a united Europe, they will relax.
I come from a Polish-Jewish family, and my grandfather was killed by the Nazis. My son is German. But he didn't kill my grandfather. And I don't need to be afraid of him.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 8, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1309 words

HEADLINE: U.S. PLANS TO MAKE SWEEPING CHANGES IN LABELS ON FOOD

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
The Bush Administration announced plans today for mandatory nutritional labeling on virtually all packaged foods.
In a speech before a food policy conference, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, said: ''The grocery store has become a Tower of Babel, and consumers need to be linguists, scientists and mind readers to understand the many labels they see. Vital information is missing, and frankly some unfounded health claims are being made.''
He outlined what he called ''a comprehensive reform of the nation's food labeling,'' the first substantial change in nutritional labeling in 17 years, when the current requirements went into effect.
 
Period of Public Comment
The plan, which would take effect next year after a period of public comment, would require labels with nutritional information on nearly all foods that are meaningful sources of nutrition and make it mandatory to provide more information, including the amounts of saturated fat, fiber and cholesterol, and the calories that come from fat. 
The Food and Drug Administration regulates about $350 billion worth of food sold each year, and about 30 percent of that has mandatory nutritional labeling, which covers the amounts of protein, fat, vitamins and other components. Another 30 percent has been labeled voluntarily. The remaining 40 percent is not labeled.
The changes would affect virtually all of the 20,000 different labels found in the average grocery store.
 
Fruit and Produce Covered
Dr. Sullivan's plan would also give formal definitions for such phrases as ''low fat'' and ''high fiber.'' At present, manufacturers can decide for themselves what is low or high. Under the Administration's proposal, products may be labeled ''no fat'' if they have none, ''low fat'' if they contain less than a certain number of grams of fat, an amount that is being decided, and ''reduced fat'' if they contain substantially less than the fat in similar products.
The proposal would extend the required nutritional information to fresh fruit and produce. This information would not be on the food but on shelves or in booklets available at the store, said Dr. Frank E. Scarbrough, acting director of the F.D.A.'s office of nutrition.
Government and industry officials said that the agency, which regulates food labeling, has the authority to carry out the proposal without action by Congress. But officials for the Center for Science in the Public Interest, an advocacy group for consumers, said legal challenges were possible. But they said none were foreseen.
The plan came only weeks after Dr. Sullivan proposed changes in the rule governing health claims made on packages. The earlier proposal would limit health claims to the few that were scientifically supported. This proposal has been published in The Federal Register for public comment.
The foods that already have mandatory labels are those that have vitamins or other nutrients added to them, as well as products that make some nutritional claims, like a tomato juice cocktail that claims to be high in vitamin C. Among the products now commonly without any nutritional labeling are desserts, ketchup, steak sauce and other condiments and crackers, candy, cookies, salad dressing, olives and pickles.
The proposal was greeted with a variety of cheers and boos from the industry and consumer groups. The National Food Processors Association said it cannot support the proposal because it would not prevent states from making their own tougher rules. John R. Cady, president of the group, said, ''Why can't this country have a single, uniform food labeling system instead of a hodge-podge of conflicting requirements?''
 
Industry in Basic Accord
He said the association is in basic agreement with most parts of Dr. Sullivan's proposal, including mandatory nutritional labels.
Industry has, in recent years, moved from opposing more labeling rules to supporting them or going along with new rules.
One of the reasons for the switch is the discovery by industry that labeling is widely read and heeded by consumers and can become a marketing tool if the product has some nutritional feature, as with adult breakfast cereals. The companies that now carry nutritional labeling have pressed for mandatory labels. ''We'd love mandatory labeling,'' said David J. McDonald, chief executive officer of the Curtice-Burns Food Company, which is affiliated with Agway Inc. ''It's a level playing field.''
Congressional aides who follow the industry also said the companies now recognize that consumer demands for labeling are strong and more regulation is inevitable.
C. Manly Molpus, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, put his group's position this way: ''Dr. Sullivan's strong and speedy nutrition labeling program is on the right track, but it is wrong to permit 50 food and drug administrations to label food. We agree that today's consumers deserve a modernized nutrition label, and manufacturers are ready to undertake the enormous task of revising the almost 20,000 food labels found in the average grocery store.''
 
Little Extra Cost Seen
Industry officials said that labels are changed frequently and if the the rule is phased in as planned, little cost would be added. Some minor costs would also be incurred in chemical analysis of foods to produce the label information. But ''we do not consider this a major economic item,'' said Jeffrey I. Nedelman, a spokesman for the grocery manufacturers.
Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Health and the Environment, was not in accord with the proposal. ''Congress can do the job better and faster through a change in the law than the Administration can do through a change in regulations,'' he said. ''Congress can make sure the changes are real and not just proposed.''
Mr. Waxman and Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, have proposed bills which would be somewhat tougher in some regards than the Administration's proposal.
Bruce Silverglade, legal director of the Center for Science in the Public Interest, said the proposal is ''an important step forward.'' He saw the situation this way: ''We have been fighting to get information on food labels for years. Now, Secretary Sullivan is staring down the barrels of two bills in Congress, and he would like to act before he is forced to. Unfortunately the Secretary's proposal is years away from being seen on the grocery shelf - it will take longer than he says.''
Mr. Silverglade said he would prefer the somewhat tougher rules in the Congressional bills over the Adminisration's proposal.
Ellen Haas, the executive director of Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, a consumer group, said of the proposal: ''We have been here before. In 1979 we had proposals. But we've not seen them implemented. This proposal will not get us out of the minefield either. We need action much faster than he is suggesting - the process could take three years.''
Dr. Sullivan said the mandatory labeling is especially important because recent studies have shown that the American consumer's chief source of information about nutrition and foods is the food package.
Along with adding saturated fats, cholesterol and fiber to labels, Dr. Sullivan also suggested removing from the label less important items like thiamine, riboflavin and niacin and the percent of the recommended daily allowance of protein. F.D.A. officials said these were listed only because disorders result if not enough of the minerals are in the diet, but the disorders are extremely rare.
Also, the proposal will make some rules to standardize the ''serving size'' on labels. Some companies now reduce serving size to make a product seem to have fewer calories and more nutritional value, Dr. Scarbrough said.

HEADLINE: Cuba Says It Is Ending Military Aid to Nicaragua

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 7

 BODY:
President Fidel Castro of Cuba said today that he is cutting off all military aid to Nicaragua before the new government takes office there next month, according to Cuba's official press agency, Prensa Latina.
Prensa Latina, monitored in Mexico City, quoted Mr. Castro as saying that Cuban assistance in housing construction and health care could continue if the new government desires. 
Mr. Castro had close relations with Nicaragua's leftist Sandinista government, which governed Nicaragua for a decade. Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and her 14-party opposition coalition easily defeated President Daniel Ortega Saavedra in Feb. 25 general elections. Mrs. Chamorro, who was strongly backed by Washington, is to take office as president on April 25.
Mr. Castro blamed the United States and world developments for the Sandinista loss.
Mr. Castro was quoted as calling the elections ''a challenge accepted by the Sandinistas in adverse conditions, amid a dirty war imposed by the United States and an economic crisis generated by the U.S. blockade.
''The elections took place a few weeks after the fall of socialist governments'' in Eastern Europe, he added, ''and the Sandinistas had to make many concessions and made mistakes.''
Exact figures on Cuban military aid have never been announced by the Havana or Managua governments. However, the State Department said in a report last year that Moscow provided about $500 million in military aid to Nicaragua in 1988.
The Soviet Union has since said it would stop military aid to Nicaragua.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Congress, Hoping to Aid New Democracies, Finds Itself Shackled by Budget

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
As democracy blooms in capitals from Managua to Prague, policy makers in Washington are struggling to muster the foreign aid dollars and the political will to bolster a new world order.
But they are faced with three politically unattractive choices: Enlarge the foreign aid budget at the expense of domestic programs; cut aid to current recipients to make room for new ones, or accept a greatly diminished role for the United States in shaping events abroad. Many in Congress fear that the third choice is being made by default.
''I'm embarrassed as an American when I see our inability to address these issues,'' said Representative Dave McCurdy, a Democrat from Oklahoma who serves on the House Intelligence Committee. ''There is a growing sense of powerlessness here because of the incredible bind we are in with the budget.'' 
 
Shortfall Even Before Nicaragua
Foreign aid spending, which will amount to $14.6 billion this year, accounts for only 1 percent of the $1.2 trillion Federal budget. And the Congressional committees that dole it out complained about serious shortfalls long before Nicaragua joined the growing appeals for assistance in moving from Communism to democracy.
But spending abroad has rarely been a high priority in Congress, particularly when pressure to reduce the budget deficit has squeezed many popular domestic programs.
Now some internationally minded lawmakers watch in frustration and even bitterness as prosperous allies like Japan and West Germany plunge ahead with government and private assistance for Eastern Europe while the domestic budget crisis sidelines the United States. ''They lectured us about our deficits while we were paying their defense costs,'' said Representative Mickey Edwards of Oklahoma, the senior Republican on the House subcommittee that oversees foreign aid.
Some in Congress look to anticipated savings in the military budget as the solution to the foreign aid problem, but Mr. Edwards, in a view echoed by Democrats as well as Republicans, is skeptical. He cites the pent-up demand for domestic spending.
 
'You Can't Blame People'
''While the politics may have changed in Central America and Central Europe, they haven't changed in central Oklahoma or central Iowa,'' Mr. Edwards said. ''You can't blame people outside the Washington Beltway who say that if there is going to be a peace dividend, we ought to be using it to rebuild our own highways.''
The House Majority Leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, gave partisan voice to that frustration on Tuesday in a speech blasting President Bush for lacking ''either the vision to know what steps we must take, or the courage to take them.''
Last year, as Poland and Hungary became the first Eastern European countries to break Soviet ties, Congress used creative accounting to scrape together a modest assistance package. But this year, with new demands in Panama, new opportunites to nurture free-market economies throughout Eastern Europe and new promises by the Bush Administration to combat drug production and trafficking in Latin America, the options for money shuffling have been exhausted.
Democrats and Republicans who serve on the foreign-aid committees doubt that the United States can honor existing commitments, let alone undertake new ones. They have pledged a review of current aid allotments, raising the possibility of cutbacks for major recipients like Israel, Egypt, Turkey, the Philippines and Pakistan.
''We are overpromised and underfunded and there are going to be some very red faces,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations. The most glaring example, he said, is the $500 million in immediate aid that the Administration has promised Panama.
 
'$10 Million in Wiggle Room'
''The fact is, aid for Panama is not going to be anywhere near $500 million,'' Mr. Leahy said. ''And if you look at the Administration's request for Eastern Europe, there is all of $10 million in wiggle room to cover Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Romania and Bulgaria. The paperwork alone will eat that up.''
Senator Robert W. Kasten Jr. of Wisconsin, Mr. Leahy's Republican counterpart on the foreign operations panel, pointed to the tempest last month when members outside the foreign-policy committees learned that the first small portion of Panama aid would be financed by taking money allotted for the Sudan and Somalia. The plan was approved only after Congressional leaders promised that they would find a way to replace the money for Africa in the 1991 budget.
''Panama was the end,'' Mr. Kasten said. ''We've gone as far as we can go playing off one region against each other.''
Mr. Kasten favors an increase in the foreign aid budget, a position that puts him at odds with some of his party colleagues. Republicans, heretofore skeptical about the value of foreign aid programs in general, have been increasingly vocal in warning that American influence abroad is threatened unless the foreign aid pie is enlarged.
 
General Tax Increase Ruled Out
In hearings on Capitol Hill last week, a number of Republicans made that clear to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d as he outlined the modest increases the Administration is seeking in the fiscal 1991 foreign aid budget. Mr. Baker said he was open to suggestions, but added that the Administration was not prepared to see a general tax increase to expand foreign aid.
''I know you're not used to having people considered to be on the right of this committee say we should enlarge the foreign aid budget,'' Representative Jerry Lewis, a conservative California Republican, told the Secretary when he appeared before the House Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations.
''If we can't use this opportunity to raise the level of contributions generally, then we are missing an important bet,'' Mr. Lewis said. ''I don't know where we go from here.''
Mr. Baker got precisely the opposite message at another House hearing today when Democrats on a panel that oversees domestic programs complained that the United States was spending too much abroad and neglecting important priorities at home.
Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who heads the Senate Appropriations Committee, said Federal dollars are not the only means of asserting American influence abroad.
''The American entrepreneur needs to get in on the ground floor,'' he said. ''Surely the American businessman is as ingenious as the German or Japanese businessman.''
Representative Silvio O. Conte of Massachusetts, the senior Republican on the House Approriations Committee, urged Mr. Baker and the Administration to go back to the drawing board on foreign aid and find the kind of vision that inspired the authors of the Marshall Plan at the end of World War II. Alluding to Vaclav Havel, the Czechoslovak President and playwright who addressed a joint meeting of Congress last month, Mr. Conte said, ''If you need help, go back and read the speech from that playwright.''

HEADLINE: Bush Says Inadequate Financing Imperils Transportation System

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
President Bush will announce a transportation policy on Thursday declaring that the nation's economy is ''at risk'' because of inadequate investment in public works projects, but seeking to minimize Federal subsidies for transportation.
''The transportation infrastructure is vital to the nation's economy,'' said a final draft of the report. ''There are increasing signs, however, that the system is beginning to break down. We cannot afford inadequate, inefficient transportation.'' 
But, as expected, the Administration's new policy does not promise a blank check to be drawn against the Treasury. It presents a broad outline of transportation programs, without naming individual projects that should be completed or estimating exact costs.
A major element of the policy is a renewal of Federal highway aid programs for the next five years, but the policy seeks to focus Federal spending on highways of national significance while increasing the states' responsibility for other projects.
 
Revenue Sources
To the extent that highway, aviation and rail programs are of national importance and should be controlled by the Federal Government, the document says, they must be financed by fees paid by their users. To the extent that transportation is more local or regional, the burden should be shifted to state and local governments.
The report suggests revenue sources like increased state gasoline taxes, local airport passenger taxes, highway tolls, Federal charges on shipping and boating to help pay for Coast Guard activities, and private investment.
The document makes no estimate of the amount of spending that is needed. Outside experts in recent years have repeatedly called for doubling both state and Federal spending on transportation.
The Administration's policy statement calls for a more flexible approach to Federal transportation aid, allowing states and localities to tailor their use of Federal money to meet the most urgent needs.
Such flexibility, it says, will improve the connections between various forms of transportation, linking railroads and subways to airports and highways in a manner that has not always been accomplished because each form of transportation is supervised by a separate bureaucracy in Washington.
 
Maintenance Needs
In general, it says, the shortage of Federal money for transportation means that priority must be given to maintaining existing transportation arteries rather than building new ones.
But the statement calls for insuring ''that essential new capacity is provided in transportation systems of national significance to meet critical national needs.'' In some cases, it says, the Federal Government should act now to acquire or preserve corridors for future development. It did not give specific examples.
Whether the Administration's approach is eventually adopted depends in large measure on the outcome of legislation extending and renewing aviation and highways programs. Debate on both bills has just begun in Congress and will take months to complete.
The document does not explicitly address a chief issue that is already being debated in Congress: how quickly to spend money from existing transportation taxes and fees and held in special trust funds for aviation and surface transportation. If the money is spent more quickly without increasing the fees, the budget deficit increases.
The policy says simply that the Government should ''spend transportation trust fund balances over time in a fiscally responsible way.''
Many aspects of the Administration's new policy have been revealed in recent weeks in its latest budget request and in speeches by senior officials.
 
Encountering Resistance
Development of the policy has been the top priority of Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, who wanted a single plan that would unify Federal measures governing diverse forms of transportation.
But Mr. Skinner ran into some resistance from other economic policy makers, who insisted that the document not include major conclusions about how much money should be spent.
The policy calls for an increased Federal role in transportation research and development. It cites as examples the need for research into high-speed railroad systems for trips of 100 to 500 miles, and the promise of new computer technologies that in a few decades might permit ''intelligent'' automobile and highway systems.
Groups involved in transportation welcomed parts of the plan, but decried others.
The American Trucking Associations welcomed the efforts to focus Federal highway aid on roads of ''national significance.'' And the group lauded the Administration's insistence on accomplishing its program without raising Federal fuel taxes.
But the trucking lobby objected to the plan's strong support of highway tolls to finance projects.
The American Public Transit Association, which represents state and local mass transit groups, objected to the Administration's insistence that cities and states should bear most of the costs of public transit.

HEADLINE: St. Louis Paper's Staff Bars Use of Bylines

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, March 7

 BODY:
All but three of the reporters, photographers and artists at The St. Louis Post-Dispatch withheld their names from items published today as their union stepped up pressure in a contract dispute.
The byline strike, the first in the Newspaper Guild's 56 years at the flagship paper of the Pultizer Publishing Company, is scheduled to continue until a new contract is signed. The guild, which represents about 620 news, advertising and circulation employees, has been operating under a contract that expired Feb. 28.
Negotiations are focusing mainly on broader management rights and a wage system in which less-experienced employees would be paid at lower rates than others.
The guild also wants a cost-of-living raise that would match inflation; management has offered a onetime 3 percent pay increase. The top basic wage for reporters is $830 a week. Talks are to resume Thursday.
Union leaders say they will begin distributing leaflets in mid-March describing their position to customers and major advertisers. Herbert L. Goodrick, executive secretary of Local 45 of the St. Louis Newspaper Guild, said the next step, asking people not to buy the paper, would start before the end of the month. Last fall, guild members authorized a strike, but they will vote again before walking out.

HEADLINE: Clean Fuels, Clean Air

BYLINE: By Timothy E. Wirth; Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, is a member of the Senate Energy Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As the Senate votes this week on proposals for amending the Clean Air Act, Americans' health and environment are on the line. If they are to be protected, the Senate must make long-overdue choices about fuels to be burned in cars and trucks.
The nation has fought a losing battle against urban smog since 1970. Deadlines for meeting Federal health standards have been missed repeatedly, despite local governments' use of every strategy available to meet them. The casualty list includes more than 100 major urban areas with unhealthy levels of air pollution and tens of billions of dollars of avoidable health costs. 
The single biggest culprit is the gasoline-fueled car. Standards enacted by Congress in 1977 have made new vehicles cleaner, but each year Americans buy more cars and drive more miles. These increases in vehicle miles traveled force polluted cities to run hard simply to stay in place, let alone make progress toward reducing air pollution.
There is just one way to escape this treadmill. We must break our addiction to today's high-polluting gasoline and take advantage of new clean-burning fuels. As President Bush said, we must ''reconcile the automobile to the environment.''
That's what Mr. Bush proposed when he introduced his clean air bill last summer. Its centerpiece was a mandate for the production of a million clean-fuel vehicles yearly by 1997. William Reilly, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, called this program ''the most innovative and far-reaching'' component of the bill.
New, proven technologies are already producing vehicles that run on low-polluting natural gas, ethanol and methanol. By early in the next century, nearly pollution-free vehicles powered by hydrogen, electricity and solar power should be available.
Clean fuels are good for the environment and the economy, and would enhance national security by reducing our dependence on foreign oil. We can reformulate gasoline to make it burn more cleanly, by replacing some imported oil with domestically produced alcohols and ethers, such as ethyl tertiary butyl ether, made from corn, wheat, barley and other crops. This shift would open up major new markets for our farmers, and it could save taxpayers millions of dollars in farm-price supports.
Domestically produced natural gas, a clean-burning fuel, can also be turned into methanol. The use of these fuels not only would displace foreign oils but also give a much-needed shot in the arm to domestic gas producers in Louisiana and the West.
Unfortunately, during recent closed-door negotiations on clean air in the Senate, oil and auto companies made quick work of the President's original proposal.
Aside from a very limited program for certain Federal and commercial fleets, the Senate compromise does not provide for a new generation of vehicles using natural gas, ethanol, methanol or electricity.
I hope the Senate will breathe new life into the President's original vision and put a strong clean-fuels program back in the Clean Air Act amendments.
Building on the Bush initiative, a successful clean-fuels program should have three central elements:
The first is to require that reformulated, clean-burning gasoline be sold in our most polluted cities. (It can be used in any car, no matter how old.) The second is a program calling for large commercial fleets to begin using special super-clean fuels like natural gas and methanol in the mid-1990's. Fleet vehicles - taxis, garbage trucks, delivery vans - travel twice as many miles as private vehicles; thus they offer a cost-effective target for emission reductions. Since they are centrally fueled, they can be more easily converted to new fuels.
The third element is a program calling for these same special super-clean fuels to be used in passenger cars beginning in the late 1990's.
Congress must look beyond the auto and oil industries' preoccupation with the next quarter's profits. The Senate cannot afford to squander this opportunity.

SECTION: Section A; Page 25, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 748 words

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Cheney vs. Webster

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Does the right hand of the Bush Administration know what the left hand is doing? Not, apparently, on the crucial questions of what's happening, and likely to happen, in the Communist world, and therefore on how the U.S. should respond.
William Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, told the House Armed Services Committee last week that the startling political upheavals in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe ''are probably already irreversible in several critical respects.''
Even if reactionary forces within the Soviet Union should overthrow Mikhail Gorbachev, Mr. Webster asserted, the new regime would be preoccupied with the same internal economic and political problems that face Mr. Gorbachev. Thus, it ''would have little incentive to engage in major confrontations'' with the U.S.
These welcome words - unclassified and offered in public testimony - were hardly out of the Director's mouth before Dick Cheney, the self-described ''hard-liner'' who is Secretary of Defense, offered a diametrically opposite view. Testifying on the same day to another committee, he said that the changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union could be quickly reversed, whether or not Mr. Gorbachev survived. 
Mr. Webster's testimony - in the opinion of Les Aspin, chairman of the Armed Services Committee - ''fundamentally altered'' debate on the 1991 defense budget by supporting the view that ''a new day is here requiring new thinking about defense.''
Mr. Cheney, however, holds strongly to the belief stated in his budget proposal that the Soviet military threat could be revived quickly, and therefore the U.S. ''must be prepared to remain in long-term competition.''
The difference, in the largest sense, may be immeasurable. Immediately, and in dollars, it lies between the Administration's proposed $303 billion military budget for 1991, a $293 billion counterproposal that represents the views of Mr. Aspin and Speaker Thomas Foley, and a $289 billion plan backed by liberal members of the Armed Services Committee.
Mr. Cheney's objection appeared to be less to the substance of Mr. Webster's argument than to his open statement of it. Asked in a television interview if the C.I.A. Director was wrong, Mr. Cheney said: ''I think so, but of course you don't know.'' But he added that ''there's no question but what it would be easier for me, in terms of getting Congressional approval of the budget that the President sent up [if] there were a little more restraint in [Mr. Webster's] statements.''
The Defense Secretary is on dubious ground if, as it appears, he wants the Director of Central Intelligence to tailor his views to the political needs of the Bush military budget, or even to keep silent when to speak might be damaging. The Director's writ is to develop accurate and unbiased information to present to the Administration's policy makers - not to shape or suppress intelligence to support policy, much less politics.
That's why it often has been argued in this space and elsewhere that the C.I.A. director ought to have a specific term of office, rather than serving at the pleasure of the President. That's also why covert operations, if any, ought not to be conducted by the intelligence-gathering agency since covert operations are efforts -rarely successful - to carry out a President's policy.
In the Webster-Cheney conflict, what's of more immediate concern is the suggestion that the Bush Administration has no clear attitude on which to base policy about what may be the most important question facing it; or - worse - is unwilling honestly to face the consequences of its judgment.
Mr. Cheney said that ''I accurately reflect the President's views'' on military spending, and surely Mr. Bush did approve his own military budget. Mr. Webster's statement, however, was cleared in advance by James Baker, the Secretary of State, and by the White House. Marlin Fitzwater, the President's press spokesman, contended that the opposing views were ''not mutually exclusive but indeed give us a good picture of the problem.''
That's all right for debate within the Cabinet or the National Security Council but not for two high officials testifying publicly before different Congressional committees. And it raises the question whether Mr. Bush has put up a budget that surrenders to pressures for jobs and defense spending, or one that reflects the international realities accepted by his Secretary of State and his primary intelligence adviser.

HEADLINE: Move Over Ivana And Don, Here's Ed and Felix

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
rrMoney. Power. A love-hate triangle. Angry recriminations over previous agreements on how to divide shared assets. Years of muffled resentment finally exploding into an unseemly public affair.
Felix G. Rohatyn and Edward I. Koch are becoming the Donald and Ivana Trump of municipal government. 
New Yorkers have been treated to a sideshow: seemingly, the chic shot vs. the cheap shot. Ostensibly the exchanges between Mr. Rohatyn, the investment banker and chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, and Mr. Koch, the former mayor, revived a debate over historical footnotes:
How instrumental was Mr. Koch in New York City's recovery from the fiscal crisis he inherited in 1978? Did Mr. Rohatyn, an appointee of the governor, usurp a prerogative of elected officials by denying them billions of dollars until they embraced his vision of how to spend it?
But the vehemence with which the debate has occurred reflects present realities as much as conflicting interpretations of the past.
New York's gloomy fiscal prognosis and the advent of a new administration - one that Mr. Rohatyn voted for and publicly helped into City Hall - herald his potential resurgence as an even more pivotal figure in public finance.
For Mr. Koch, his defeat by David N. Dinkins bestowed a freedom that means nothing left to lose, except his record as mayor. When aspects of that record were questioned again by Mr. Rohatyn in the magazine 7 Days, Mr. Koch became livid. After years of uncharacteristic restraint in responding to a man regarded by many as a sacred cow, an unfettered Mr. Koch finally demanded, where's the beef?
Mr. Koch, no longer cowed, branded Mr. Rohatyn an imperious ''Robert Moses of municipal finance'' who parlayed his reputation at the M.A.C., which was created to borrow in the city's behalf, into hefty fees.
So, who saved the city? Mr. Rohatyn credits former Gov.
Hugh L. Carey, but has always cited Mr. Koch's contribution. Mr. Koch describes himself as ''the orchestra leader while Felix was one of the violin players,'' (prompting Harrison J. Goldin, the former city comptroller to cast Mr. Rohatyn instead as lead baritone because ''one was not second fiddle to the other'').
Who controlled the M.A.C.'s surpluses? Mr. Rohatyn, in concert with the Governor - this time Mario M. Cuomo - and the acquiesence of Mr. Koch.
''It was perfectly obvious that politically we could not make any unilateral decisions,'' Mr. Rohatyn said.
''Felix couldn't do it without my consent,'' Mr. Koch recalled. ''I couldn't get the money without his agreement.''
Mr. Rohatyn's priorities were housing, mass transit and schools. Without denigrating those goals, city officials preferred to spend the money as they saw fit.
''It has the sound of populist rhetoric: 'Who needs these trustees? Let's get our hands on the money,' '' Mr. Rohatyn said. ''The repercussions for New York's credit rating could be disastrous.''
About half of nearly $2 billion disbursed so far was pumped into the city's operating budget and an economic development grab bag; much of the rest was invested in Mr. Rohatyn's agenda.
Did Mr. Koch's expansion of wages and the work force contribute to the latest crunch, as Mr. Rohatyn suggested? Hardly, Mr. Koch says. Meanwhile, he wonders why Mr. Rohatyn has not chided the Dinkins administration for its plan to use $150 million in one-time revenues from the sale of bonds by the Battery Park City Authority to meet current expenses. Mr. Rohatyn said he intends to; so does Edward V. Regan, the State Comptroller.
Did Mr. Rohatyn capitalize on his public position? He was a promiment investment banker before he volunteered to help the city. He declined profits from business his firm did with the city or state. But he bristled at Mr. Koch's suggestion that the firm reveal its municipal finance clients (among the clients Mr. Koch solicited for his new law firm was Mr. Rohatyn).
''The only difference between me and other public officials is that I don't take money and I'm independent,'' Mr. Rohatyn said. If the Governor or editorial writers no longer value his services, he said, ''I'm gone.''
By Tuesday, Mr. Koch invited Mr. Rohatyn to lunch. Mr. Rohatyn declined. Mr. Koch said he will not pursue the debate further.
''I'm a columnist, not a government official,'' he said. ''I raise the problems; I don't have to solve them.''
Nor does he have to stifle feelings about people who, by his standard, he treated gingerly as mayor. Are there others besides Mr. Rohatyn? Yes, Mr. Koch said, two: Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Trump.
