HEADLINE: Tax Cuts for Corporations Burden a School System

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y.

 BODY:
For much of this century, the General Motors factory here has been the bedrock of North Tarrytown's tax base. But now changes in the business world that have driven corporations to cut costs aggressively have come home to this Hudson River village.
Big tax cuts won by General Motors here and by two companies in neighboring Tarrytown are forcing residents to decide whether to make painful cuts in their joint school system, the Union Free School District of the Tarrytowns, or shoulder a sharp tax increase.
Towns and cities across the country have long pursued businesses as a way to expand their property-tax base and ease the burden on residents. But many communities, like Tarrytown and North Tarrytown, are now watching that base erode as corporations increasingly challenge their tax assessments in court. 
''Large companies had for a long time adopted a good-neighbor policy in which they looked the other way, knowing full well they were being overassessed,'' said Joseph T. Pierson, the director of public information for the State Division of Equalization and Assessment.
''Somewhere along the way the competition became so great that the bottom line is now more important than community spirit.''
Here, in successive legal challenges beginning in the early 1980's, G.M., the Technicon Instruments Corporation and, last month, the Consolidated Edison Company, emerged with their local tax burdens greatly reduced. In the largest case, G.M. cut its annual school tax by a third, or by about $1 million.
This year those tax reductions, combined with the loss of an additional $800,000 in state aid and other revenue, have led school officials to present residents with two unsavory prospects for a budget next year.
In one, spending would be frozen at this year's $21.7 million, more than a fifth of the staff would be laid off, many courses, clubs and athletic programs would be canceled, and school taxes would still rise by about 5 percent.
In the second, the district would keep all programs, but the tax increase would be 16 percent.
Last year, before a crisis developed, voters rejected a budget requiring a 5 percent tax increase. The same budget was adopted in a second referendum.
School officials hope to avoid most of the cuts and tax increase by asking G.M. for an advance on taxes that will come due later this decade.
 
Settlement in '85
''We're not asking for a handout or even a loan,'' said the Superintendent of Schools, H. Murray Blueglass. ''If G.M. gives us $2 million a year, we will credit that to their future tax payments. It's negotiable. We just want the opportunity to talk.''
Under a tax settlement reached by local officials and General Motors in 1985, the company is paying $1.9 million a year to the school district in lieu of taxes until 1995. G.M., which has a sprawling assembly plant on the Hudson River here, had been paying about $2.9 million a year in taxes.
When G.M. returns to the tax rolls, school officials estimate, the company will pay somewhere between $6 million and $10 million a year in school taxes. Their prediction is based on the steady rise in taxes and on two large additions to the G.M. plant: an elaborate paint shop and a railroad connection.
Mr. Blueglass has sent a three-page letter to the chairman of G.M., Roger B. Smith, outlining his idea for a tax advance and is asking Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to use his power of persuasion on Mr. Smith.
A spokeswoman for General Motors in Detroit, Paula Powell, said, ''We received the letter, and we are reviewing it.''
G.M., which has contested tax assessments on its plants across the country in recent years, brought its challenge against North Tarrytown in 1981. #4,000 Employees ''We feel it is our fiduciary responsibility to the shareholders to make sure that we're paying no more in taxes than we ought to be,'' Mrs. Powell said. ''We want to remain competitive.'' Local officials say they were pressured by the state to settle a pending tax claim to help keep open the G.M. plant, which employs 4,000 people. After months of negotiations with New York, the company agreed in 1985 to keep the plant in operation; the local tax reductions were an important part of a package of incentives.
''If we had said 'no' to the settlement and chose to go to court instead, we would have had the Governor and everybody else saying that we weren't being a good community member,'' Mr. Blueglass said. The tax reductions - both G.M.'s and more recent ones - have done the most damage to the 1,759-student district.
Other losses have come from a proposed cut of $200,000 in state aid for next year, in line with proposed cuts throughout Westchester County; the loss of about 15 students from outside the district who were paying about $8,500 a year in tuition, and the lack of a surplus. In previous years, surpluses of around $400,000 were used to offset tax increases.
Administrators must decide what to do before a May 9 budget referendum.
Last Wednesday at noon, dozens of students left Sleepy Hollow High School to run a relay to Albany to deliver a written plea for help to Mr. Cuomo the following morning.
 
Letters and Speeches
''A bunch of students are running 140 miles in the winter for their education,'' said Jim Harmon, the Student Council president. ''That should speak strongly.''
Parents have sent hundreds of letters to their legislators, asking for help. And they filled the high school auditorium one night last week for a school board meeting. Some made impassioned speeches about the need to preserve the school system, at whatever cost. Others appealed to the board to control taxes, regardless of the damage.
''With the proposed budget cuts as they now stand, we might as well rename our school district the Union Free Warehouse of the Tarrytowns, because that's what it will be,'' said Dr. Carin Rubenstein, a psychologist and a member of Save Our Schools, a parents group.
Another parent, Michael Arnold, a bank economist, said: ''I, for one, am for paying significantly higher taxes next year. I don't want to see a thing cut from the program, and I know that many of my neighbors feel the same way.''
 
'Sustain the System'
But Dr. Richard C. Sweet, a chemist from North Tarrytown with two grandchildren in the school district, urged the board to spare taxpayers.
''There will be a school system next year even if we take the most severe cuts,'' he said. ''The taxpayers have been hit with tax increases every year, and enough is enough. Let's return to the 3 R's and sustain the system with the resources we have.''
In addition to G.M.'s tax victory, Technicon Instruments went to court challenging its taxes, and last spring the State Court of Appeals ordered the school district to refund about $1.2 million in back taxes to the maker of medical equipment. The court also reduced the company's assessment, and the district's future revenues.
In January a state court approved a settlement between the State of New York and Consolidated Edison that reduces the state's assessment of special ''franchise'' property - mainly gas pipes and wires - in New York City and Westchester County. Con Edison's assessment in Tarrytown is to fall by $872,000; because the assessments in the village represent roughly 10 percent of full market value, that loss is equivalent to the loss of more than 20 $400,000 houses.
The budget crisis here comes after a decade of improvements to the school system, which is 40 percent Hispanic and 12 percent black, and many parents are afraid that the gains will be undermined. The dropout rate has fallen to 4.5 percent from 15 percent. Standardized test scores in math and English are up, along with student and staff morale.
''Here's an example of a district where public education is really working,'' said Julie Anello of North Tarrytown, an artist and mother of three, ''where kids who go to Ivy League schools and kids who go to vocational schools are all being educated together and very well. ''It's absurd that for lack of something as paltry as $2 million, this school system might go down the drain.''

HEADLINE: $445 Million Increase in Phone Rates Is Rejected

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 7

 BODY:
The Public Service Commission today rejected a $445 million request for higher telephone rates that had come under heavy political criticism because it was negotiated between the New York Telephone Company and the commission's staff rather than through the usual process of public hearings.
Although legislators and consumer advocates declared the decision a victory for customers, several commissioners on the panel predicted that the company would ultimately win a rate increase this year, perhaps even larger than the one negotiated.
''I'm far from sure that the outcome will be better for consumers,'' said Peter A. Bradford, the chairman of the commission.
Four of the commission's seven members, including Mr. Bradford, said they had rejected the settlement. Three said they had supported the agreement or a modified version of it. $900 Million Filing Planned A spokesman for New York Telephone, Peter Muller, said the company now planned to file a rate increase request for at least $900 million a year beginning in 1991, when a four-year moratorium on telephone rate increases expires. The increase rejected today also would have taken effect next January. 
The $445 million negotiated increase would have raised New York Telephone revenues by about 6 percent, and the average monthly bill for local telephone service would have increased to $34.56 from $30.90, Mr. Muller said.
A company statement expressed disappointment in today's ruling, saying ''the agreement would have provided economic certainty for the customer and the company, as well as certain other customer benefits, such as modernizing the network.''
The decision had repercussions on Wall Street, where the Nynex Corporation, New York Telephone's parent, saw its stock slip from an opening price of $83.75 a share to $80.50 at closing. The New York Stock Exchange suspended trading of the stock for 2 hours 40 minutes this morning as news of the decision arrived from Albany.
 
Settlement Process Questioned
The commission's ruling, like the heated debate that preceded it, had less to do with the size of the proposed rate increase than with the process by which it was reached.
In rejecting the settlement, which was negotiated in December, the commission followed the recommendations of an administrative law judge, the State Attorney General, the director of the State Consumer Protection Board and Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, who appointed a task force last month to investigate ''secret settlements'' in utility rate cases.
Those officials argued that it was improper for the P.S.C. to grant a large rate increase based on negotiations with a utility rather than on the full series of public hearings and investigations that normally accompany rate cases.
Mr. Bradford stressed that today's decision should not be interpreted as a signal that the commission will no longer approve negotiated settlements. He said the New York Telephone case was unique because of time pressure created by a strike last autumn by Nynex workers and because of questions about Nynex sales practices.
 
Nynex Under Investigation
The company has been investigated by state and Federal regulators for reaping large profits by using an unregulated subsidiary, the Materiel Enterprises Company, to sell a variety of goods and services to New York Telephone. The settlement negotiated between the commission and New York Telephone would have ended the commission's investigation of the sales practices while accounting for the reported overpayments by determining the size of the rate increase.
Attorney General Robert Abrams, who called the sales practices ''incredible financial chicanery,'' asked the commissioners during a hearing on Tuesday to ''send a signal that back-room bargaining will not be tolerated.''
The commissioners clearly chafed at the pressure from elected officials. Mr. Bradford called the lobbying efforts ''perilous and counterproductive'' and said a line should be drawn between the Legislature's right to oversee the commission's conduct and its responsibility to insulate the commission from politics.

HEADLINE: PARENT & CHILD

BYLINE: By Lawrence Kutner

 BODY:
STUDENTS who work a small number of hours during the school year or reasonable hours over the summer may show some academic and social gains, according to surveys of high school seniors conducted by the University of Michigan.
Through his first job last summer, when he was 15 years old, Owen Grover had the opportunity to supervise younger children as a counselor at a day camp run by the recreation department of his hometown, West Orange, N.J.
''It made him feel quite grown up and mature, and maybe a little powerful,'' said his mother, Andrea Grover. ''His older brother had worked for his father when he was 16, but Owen preferred to work for someone else. He didn't want to be dependent on his father to take him to work.''
Finding and getting that first job outside the home can be a landmark for adolescents. It is an event that clearly differentiates them from their younger siblings and schoolmates. It is often the first formal acknowledgement by adults outside their family and school that something they know or can do has value in the adult world. 
''For a child who's having difficulty in school, this may be an opportunity to succeed,'' said Dr. Charles L. Thompson, a professor of educational and counseling psychology at the University of Tennessee at Knoxville. He said his youngest child, who has learning disabilities, felt much happier once she could hold a part-time job.
''It can help them feel good about themselves, perhaps for the first time in a long while,'' he said.
But the symbolic importance of this rite of passage, combined with teen-agers' inexperience with employers and job interviews, means that for many adolescents, finding a first job can be confusing or even frightening.
''It puts your child's self-esteem on the line,'' said Dr. Richard M. Ryan, an associate professor of psychology at the University of Rochester who studies how parents motivate their children. He said he had seen many adolescents who delay applying for jobs because they feel uncomfortable with the process and worry how they will be perceived.
In addition, many teen-agers have misconceptions about what prospective employers expect from them. Dr. Linda Dunlap, an assistant professor of psychology at Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., recently spoke about jobs to a gathering of 15- and 16-year-old high school students.
''Some of them thought they had to show up for a job interview in a three-piece suit and carrying a briefcase for an entry-level job,'' she said. ''Another set of kids thought they could show up like they just walked in off the beach. Most of the kids were at one end of the continuum or the other.''
Although it may feel as if you are doing your child a favor by using your influence to arrange for a job, developmental psychologists caution against it. In many ways, the process of thinking about and searching for a job is at least as important to the child's self-concept as the work itself. The sometimes awkward attempts to figure out where to apply and the daydreaming about how they will spend the money from their paychecks help teen-agers try their new and more adult self-images on for size.
''The child who finds his own job will usually have a much greater sense of accomplishment,'' said Dr. Robert B. Brooks, the director of child psychology training at McLean Hospital in Belmont, Mass., and an assistant professor of psychology at Harvard Medical School. In most cases, he said, parents should take a supporting role in the process.
''If the parent gets the job for the child, that denies the child's need to try out his new sense of independence and competence,'' Dr. Brooks said. One way for teen-agers to express their independence is the way they spend their paychecks. As with allowances, which many child development experts say should continue while children have part-time or summer jobs, a paycheck allows teen-agers to work on money-management skills under the guidance but not the control of their parents. For some teen-agers, the sudden influx of money from a job gives them a distorted sense of personal economics, which can have dire results once they can no longer count on their parents for room and board.
Long before a child begins to work, families should discuss the child's plans for spending and saving earnings. This is also a good time to discuss the family budget and whether a child will be expected to contribute toward living expenses or schooling.
The University of Michigan studies found that fewer than 10 percent contributed more than half their paycheck toward family living expenses. Fewer than 13 percent saved half their earnings toward their education. More than 60 percent spend most of their money on discretionary items like clothing, entertainment and eating out.
The same studies show that high school students who work more than 10 to 15 hours a week during the school year are prone to a variety of problems, including a decrease in their academic performance and an increased likelihood that they will use cigarettes, alcohol and other drugs. There is no single reason for the problems, but they often appear to be related to the increased stress that children feel trying to work many hours and go to school.
 
Helping, Not Hindering, the Hunt
ALTHOUGH it is not a good idea for parents to arrange for a part-time or summer job for their child, there are some things they can do to help in the job hunt that takes their child's emotional and developmental needs into account.
Talk about the idea of looking for a job well in advance.
Many teen-agers will judge a prospective job solely in terms of the hourly wage. ''Set the guidelines about hours, location and type of job ahead of time,'' advised Dr. Robert B. Brooks, the director of child psychology training at McLean Hospital in Belmond, Mass., and an assistant professor of psychology at Harvard Medical School. ''If you try to do it after the child gets a job, you'll have more difficulties setting limits.''
Expect your child to be nervous about the job search and the job interview.
The amount of anxiety that teen-agers show, especially if you have discussed looking for a job well in advance, will often let you know if they are ready.
''A certain amount of nervousness is normal,'' said Dr. Richard M. Ryan, an associate professor of psychology at the University of Rochester. ''If they seem paralyzed by anxiety, they're probably not emotionally ready for the experience.''
Review with your child what to expect during a job interview.
This phase of the job search causes teen-agers a great deal of anxiety. They are often extremely sensitive about how they come across to adults and worry that the slightest flaw will prevent their obtaining a job. But doing a ''pretend'' or mock job interview with your child in preparation for the real thing may do more harm than good.
''The child will be more nervous doing a mock job interview with his parents than doing an interview in the real world,'' Dr. Ryan said.
One alternative is to arrange other teen-agers who are looking for jobs to do mock interviews with other parents in the neighborhood.
Make sure your child considers the possibility that the job may not work out.
Job rejections can be particularly upsetting to teen-agers. Adolescents - especially those who have been very successful at school - sometimes view being rejected for a job as a general statement about their worth. They may show this directly or indirectly, perhaps by describing the prospective employer as stupid or incompetent.
Help them understand that everyone is turned down for jobs and that other employers won't know that they have been rejected.
Suggest volunteer work if your family does not need the extra income from your child's job.
Many jobs for adolescents, like those in fast-food restaurants, often involve unskilled, dead-end work in which they have little responsibility and in some cases ample time to socialize with other teen-agers. The major attraction is the paycheck.
But organizations that use volunteers are more likely to give adolescents work that involves responsibility and training. It also increases the odds that they will be working with adults and, therefore, treated more like adults.

HEADLINE: Liberals Starting a Journal As a Forum for New Ideas

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
Nobody will accuse liberals of having led the political debate during the past decade or so. Indeed, many liberals themselves acknowledge, a bit ruefully, that the ideas that made a difference in the 1970's and 80's came more often than not from conservatives. But a small group of liberal writers and professors, many with national reputations, are starting a new journal, hoping it will become the focal point of a renewal.
The magazine, whose first quarterly issue will be published next month in Princeton, N.J., is called The American Prospect. It was created, its founders say, with the aim of bringing liberal ideas back to the top of the national agenda.
''This magazine will enable us to find out if it's true or false that liberals don't have any new ideas,'' said Hendrick Hertzberg, the editor of The New Republic and a friend of some of the new magazine's founders. ''I think it's false and I think when you get into one church these independent voices that have been singing in different places, they'll make a mighty chorus.'' 
The creation of the new magazine is an occasion for some reflection, by liberals and others, over the recent, rather poor history of a major trend in American life. There have been numerous discussions over the reasons for the relative decline of liberalism in recent years and what liberals must do to adapt to new circumstances.
 
Summoning the Zeitgeist
The writers and analysts who raised $500,000 to start the magazine - many of them concentrated in Ivy League academic centers - argue that The American Prospect is being started at a propitious moment, that is, they say, when there is a national swing in the zeitgeist, a cyclical move back to the bedrock liberalism abandoned and neglected in the Reagan years.
The conservatives have now had their chance, many liberals argue, and their program of reliance on the unrestricted market has failed to solve the nation's most pressing problems. The idea that the public may be ready for a liberal resurgence is not just a hopeful liberal idea. Kevin Phillips, a conservative political analyst, says much the same thing in ''The Politics of Rich and Poor,'' a book about to be published by Random House, and the editors of The American Prospect agree with him.
They believe, in addition, that the end of the cold war has removed a major source of contention among them, one that divided the liberal camp into those who supported conservative demands for more military spending and those who wanted to give priority to domestic programs.
''A lot of the antagonisms that arose in the 1960's have died out,'' said Paul Starr, a Princeton sociologist who will be one of the magazine's two editors. ''Now, with the end of the cold war, a lot of antagonisms on foreign policy are dying out as well.''
Robert Reich, a Harvard economist who is chairman of the magazine's editorial board, said that by this reasoning, ''we're on the cusp of a new era.''
''My simplistic vision,'' he went on, ''is of a great emerging army of liberal people who don't have anything to attach themselves to, no clear policy directions, no distinct public philosophy, certainly no leaders. So it's the perfect time to start the process of redefinition.''
 
Learning From the Opposition
Robert Kuttner, a writer on economic affairs who will edit the magazine with Mr. Starr, said that some of the inspiration for the new magazine had been provided by the model followed by conservatives when they seized the intellectual initiative during the past two decades.
''The long and the short of it is that no existing journal was doing what, say, Commentary or The Public Interest was doing in creating excitement on the conservative side,'' he said. ''Liberals have been defensive and have been trying to figure out what went wrong.''
The magazine's founders are aiming at a circulation of about 15,000 to 20,000; about 2,500 subscriptions have been received so far. Subscriptions can be bought by writing to P.O. Box 7645, Princeton, N.J., 08543-7645. Small sums were raised by sales of advertising, mostly to publishing companies, in the first issue.
Mr. Starr said most of the initial funds came from private donations. The largest single contribution, $50,000, was made by the Joyce Foundation in Chicago, an organization that has given money to a large array of causes, from hospitals and schools to theaters. Another large contributor, he said, is Max Palevsky, a California computer executive who, in years past, contributed heavily to the Presidential campaign of George McGovern and helped finance Rolling Stone magazine.
Any new magazine, but particularly one devoted to scholarly articles, is a financially risky venture, and many of them fail. Tikkun, a liberal Jewish monthly, has experienced financial difficulties throughout its short history. Recently, the American Jewish Committee announced that it was closing its liberal publication, Present Tense.
 
Scholarly, and Not Irreverent
The first issue of The American Prospect is scholarly in tone and devoid of any of the partisan irreverence and sauciness characteristic of such other magazines of opinion as The New Republic on the moderate left or National Review on the right.
The first issue also suggests a certain recourse to names and arguments already familiar to many readers. Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian, outlines what he regards as the emerging new liberal opportunities of the 1990's. John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist, publishes an essay deploring the habit of liberal candidates, as he puts it, ''to desert their constituency and appear as poor imitations of the opposition.''
There are also articles by writers like Mr. Kuttner, Mr. Starr and Mr. Reich, a group of writers in their 40's, each of them already the author of several books on social trends or public policy whose articles have commonly appeared until now in The New Republic.
The three represent a particular strain in American intellectual life -those who came of age in the turbulent 1960's, opposed the Vietnam War, but did not adopt the radical, pro-revolutionary and often anti-American stances of other members of that generation. At the same time, they did not veer toward the neo-conservative right, as did many other one-time opponents of the war.
''The irony,'' Mr. Starr said, ''is that back in the 1960's, I was under assault from the left. Now, the attacks come from the right. Obviously, the world has changed, but we still think that liberalism is the best name for the tradition that we want to carry on.'' What Is Liberalism? Several of the feature articles in the first issue of The American Prospect suggest an answer to what might be the central question about the new magazine: What, in this last decade of the 20th century, is liberalism? How does it differ from conservatism? Do the liberals really have any new ideas or are they merely dusting off the notions of earlier times?
The founders of the new magazine answer those questions in part by exploring what happened to the old liberalism, or, put another way, how the liberal ''malaise'' of the 1970's and 80's came about. A major element, they say, was an overemphasis on the concept of redistribution of wealth. Another element was the common association of classic liberals with the radicals of the 1960's, a group associated in the public mind with a tendency to see the United States, not just as flawed, but as deeply villainous in its international behavior.
''This is not a radical publication,'' Mr. Starr said of The American Prospect.
The leading feature article in the new magazine is ''The Real Welfare Problem,'' by Christopher Jencks and Dathryn Edin. Based on new research and surveys, the article argues that welfare recipients generally work at unreported jobs to make ends meet. The authors' recommendation is for government to supplement low-wage jobs with publicly financed fringe benefits to increase incentives to work.
 
Back to Original Notions
Asked whether recommendations like this one did not amount to a more ''conservative'' form of liberalism, the editors of ''The New Prospect'' defined certain basic liberal notions, which they contrasted with conservatism.
Put most broadly, these principles amount to a distrust of the free market and a belief in enlightened government as the best - indeed, the only - mechanism available to address social problems and gross economic inequities.
Mr. Kuttner said: ''I believe that economies are not self-regulating, that the degree of inequality in our society is too great, and that we need a balance between market and nonmarket institutions to make society work.''
Mr. Starr said: ''We have a very positive view of the possibilities of government. We don't share the pessimism, the sense of futility, of the conservatives.''
